=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Raw, unadulterated engine building in it's finest deck building form. By itself, the game clips right along at 2p, and the probability of deck drawing gives it enough of a risk management that the engine you create doesn't just sit and crank through until late in the game. I like Trains a little more for the deck building mechanic though as it uses an area influence map, but that suffers from a bad theme implementation (while this doesn't have that problem even if it's sort of pasted-on), leaving this as the deck builder of choice. That said, there is basically zero interaction in Dominion, and it's fundamentally about creating a card combo in your engine and running it as hard as possible. The game ultimate seems to flop over once people learn the combos.

Best on the tablet (even the fugly old edition that was free) where it takes almost no time at all to crank out a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have played this game three times now and like it more and more each time I play it. The fact that there are so many different sets of cards and you don't play with all of them each time makes for a very replayable game. Every time we have played we have tried a different combination of cards and each time it feels like it is a new game. 

The game is very easy to learn too. I taught my 13 year old daughter in about five minutes and she beat me the first time she played. Of course I was giving her hints along the way, which helped her a lot. My fifteen year old son has beat me both times we have played. I highly recommend it!

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games. An amazingly simple set of mechanisms makes for an amazingly addictive and enjoyable experience. Just in the base set alone there is a ton of variety in the card types and abilities. One of the best parts of Dominion is the way I can custom tailor my deck to my play style and try to shoot for victory in my own way. Dominion is the ultimate game that fits under the banner of "easy for inexperienced players to understand, but massive depth to explore for experienced players". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

In fact we played it almost every evening in the first week we got - testament to its addictiveness.  Also, it is one of the first games that I have been considering buying add-ons for.

Highly recommended!

RATING: 7

Update 7-24-16: I was unkind in my opinion of this game in lowering the rating to a 6. Even though we gave this game away to my SIL as a game library building present, I've had a chance to play this many times since at various friends' houses, and have never turned down the chance. It's a great gateway game. We don't need to own it ourselves anymore, but it doesn't make it a bad game. Bumping it back up to a 7.

RATING: 3.5
Shuffling: the Game. 
When a game is STRICTLY worse played live as opposed to online you have to ask yourself how and why on earth did it get made into a boardgame in the first place. 
Live it takes 30-40 minutes. Online 5-10. That is 10 minutes of gameplay in 30+ minutes... The rest is shuffling, waiting for your turn, fiddling with cards, counting everything that could and should be done by a computer, not you. 
There are countless opportunities to make an error live. You don't know how many cards are left in each stack, in your deck, your opponents'... which is basic and vital information. 
There's so much downtime. Due to poor design a third of the game is spent just buying victory points. And worst of all, there's no interaction! 
It's okay as an app on your phone. It's miserable as a boardgame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A card game that scales well from 2-4 players, has good variability, and a unique deck-building mechanic which puts a different spin on the current engine building game craze.

Gameplay is simple: always draw 5 cards, then A) play an action card(s), if possible.  These generally do things like get you more cards, allow for more buying opportunies, give extra money to build, etc., B) buy a card(s).  Cards come in 3 general forms: 1) point cards, which do nothing, but are what you need to score points (to win the game), 2) action cards, which give special abilities, and 3) money cards, which allow for purchases in the buy phase. C) clean up your deck, which is to say put all drawn cards into your discard pile.

As the game goes on, you will want to switch from money and powers to points.  The more points, the less flexibility you have.  Game ends when either 3 piles of different cards are emptied, or the 6 point card pile is empty.  There are several different types of action cards that you can substitute into play, which supposedly significantly affects gameplay.  I've only tried to mix things up once, and didn't notice much difference in the general strategy, but with more plays that may change.

This is a good game, a very solid filler, with some light strategy.  A top 10 game though?  Hardly.

Own the [boardgame=40834]Intrigue[/boardgame], [boardgame=51811]Seaside[/boardgame], [boardgame=66690]Prosperity[/boardgame], [boardgame=90850]Cornucopia[/boardgame], [boardgame=104557]Hinterlands[/boardgame], [boardgame=125403]Dark Ages[/boardgame], [boardgame=137166]Guilds[/boardgame], [boardgame=171915]Adventures[/boardgame] and [boardgame=192951]Empires[/boardgame] expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After the played the base set a number of times, I became a bit disappointed in the game. Certainly that it established a wildly popular new genre of board game is noteworthy, but it also quickly feels like a very generic instance of the genre, particular as new games have built on it. Further, I was worried that, once the 10 card spread has been picked, a suitably experienced player would know their strategy immediately and just go through the motions. 

Then some friends asked me over to play the game with all of the expansions (except Alchemy, which we all agree bogs the game down). With the addition of Prosperity, suddenly this game had real depth, and I became hooked. The additions of Colonies (10 pt VP cards) and Platinums ($5), each game has a broad spectrum of decisions to make.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominion is one of my favorite strategy games out there.  It's well-thought out, with great gameplay dynamics, and many possible variations in play.  I love that strategies can significantly change with a few changes in cards from game-to-game. 

Normally, card-oriented games tend to have a significant luck element, but Dominion is close to pure skill.  You really have to think about your actions, what sort of cards you are taking, how the cards work in relation to one another, what cards your opponents are taking, and how you can deal with difficult cards (such as "The Witch" and "The Thief"). 

I'd rank this #1 of the main Spiel des Jahres award winners that I've played. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Without a doubt one of the best games I own, including the sister game and all add-ons. This game has a simple basic rule-set but the cards provide variety. While other games have variety from game to game, Dominion almost seems like a different game every time you play. Critical thinking skills are both demanded and exercised by this game. The wording on the cards is clear and precise and requires players to have similar thinking to play. I generally use this game as a litmus test to see if others can think precisely, cleverly and deviously (as opposed to thinking fuzzy and using language lazily).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have a blast playing this game! Dominion is easy to teach and quick moving, which makes it ideal for casually deciding to play a game. I appreciate the card variety, which can make every game a different experience. That said, at a point you starting learning strategies and which cards are more OP, so the game can become less of a new challenge. I still love this game, but for that reason I'll definitely be looking to the expansions next.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can tell now why Dominion is so popular.  It's a simple enough game to learn, but there's a lot of depth here. I like the delicate balance you have to maintain between treasure/action cards and choosing when to start going after victory points. I'll definitely be playing a lot of this one.

RATING: 9
I like this. Quick action with a deck-building/card buying mechanism. I can see why it's popular.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun, and incredibly addictive! I love this game and everybody I introduce to it asks me where they can purchase it. The game starts out very basic, with only a small selection of options available, but every turn, the amount of things you can do grows even to the point where you have to laugh. I like the fact that this game is about putting combos together on the fly. See what options are available each turn to buy, see what kind of actions you can take, and watch your plan unfold turn by turn. The game is very simple to teach to others, but the strategies that are available give it tons of depth and infinite re-playability. Over all this game is great, one of my absolute favorite games! If I was going to lock myself in a nuclear fallout shelter for 50 years, and could only bring 50 games with me Dominion would be one of them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Deck Builder, Competitive, Medieval

This is a complex game where all players start with the same small deck of cards and purchase new cards with unique effects from a pool of cards determined randomly at the beginning of the game. Complexity level varies but skilled players can construct strategies and combos similar to any TCG, it's a blast. The game ends when 3 different "resource" piles have been depleted, or the highest valued "victory point" card has been depleted. 

This is by far my favorite boardgame and the best one I have ever played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(Please note my updates, modified over time and experience with this title).

INITIAL IMPRESSION: I don't yet fully appreciate the allure of deck-building... I continue to keep trying though, as there is something I must be missing. This will certainly stay on the shelf and I have every confidence the mystery will reveal itself to me.

UPDATE: I have no confidence that the mystery will reveal itself. None. I simply don't get it. To me, this seems as if it's a slot machine played with cards. Dominion obviously needs a home that has more love than I'm capable of giving it... thus it's traded (something I rarely do).

SECOND UPDATE: After taking an even longer break from this game, I repurchased it and I find I'm actually liking it. :) While it won't be my favorite game, it's unlike my past impressions a great deal -- much more favorable. This and the series are keepers for me now, I'm happy to say. I've always WANTED to like it, and now I can say that I do.

THIRD UPDATE: This is awesome. I'll play it whenever anyone wants to do so. The kids even like it. Win all around.

RATING: 8
Played this quite a bit on Goko - this game is quite fun! I think it plays best with 2 players, as more players actually shrink the strategy space (by giving you fewer turns to build a cool engine, thus shifting you toward more boring strategies that load up on VP faster).

The game is quite a bit more fun with all the expansions; I shamelessly just join games on Goko that already have them rather than actually buying it.

RATING: 7
Rating of 7 includes the various expansions that I've played as well.


By far, my favorite card game.  The number of card combinations makes each play slightly different from the last.  The winner tends to be the one that can adapt best to what's currently available.  A nice blend of solitaire and interactivity.

---

After countless games, this one has dropped a little.  It's now in the realm of "fun to play" but never do I look forward to playing.  Still enjoyable though.

RATING: 8
Great game! Very easy to explain and after 10 minutes everybody has the hang of it. 

With the vast number of cards and combinations you can play the game with you really get something for your money. 

Everybody who was introduced to the game liked it immediately.

Goal is to gather the most victory points. To archive thiss everyone buys action cards and other advantages to either annoy your opponents or to give yourself an edge. The cards are themed in the times of the knights and very thematic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
You start with a barebones/crappy deck and slowly improve it by adding better cards & trashing less good cards.  

Basically, you must choose between cards that make your deck better at making your deck better (huh? yes, really) or cards that give you victory points.  At the game's end, the deck with the most VP's wins.  

A very interesting game.

RATING: 4
played 6+ times with 4,5,6 players.

LIKE: non-combat card game, interesting concept

OVERALL: I want to like this game, but I've had multiple bad experiences playing it, and overall did not have much fun.

RATING: 7.5
Very good indeed. I like speed of course and the idea of building a custom deck of cards while playing the game - flat out brilliant. It is simplistic which is (of course) both good - making it easy to teach - and bad - making it somewhat repetitive. Although I must say it isn't repetitive to me just yet. It'll certainly get a ton of plays. And I think will fit the lunch crowd just perfect as this game plays in 20-30 minutes.

EDIT: After many more plays, I disagree with the notion that this game is formulaic - although admittedly, it plays much more like that on-line. I still find it challenging to optimize my purchases - which is very nice indeed.

EDIT: Ok, it *is* formulaic. Once you know the cards well, it is highly mechanical in play. This is why expansions are very much needed to continue interesting play. But I am not attracted to that idea (having bought only one expansion) and instead, am looking for a deck builder replacement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Great for a 30-40 minute filler game.  Plays fast and the base game allows for a fair amount of variation.  A great introduction to deckbuilding.

Unfortunately, while this game was met with initial high praise from me, it really hasn't stood up to repeated plays.  Out of the box, the game allows for a wide range of variability (in terms of different cards being in each game), but over time the game doesn't feel different enough from game to game to really make such variability worth it.  At the end of the day, it always feels like the same basic arc regardless of what cards are in the game.  

I'm willing to admit that this perception may just be due to fatigue with this particular title--it has reached [i]Ticket to Ride[/i] levels of absurdity in terms of additional expansions, and there seems to be a large number of people willing to acquire just about all of them (which I only complain about because these are the same people who always want to play [i]Dominion[/i] because they have a new shiny expansion for it, despite the fact that the underlying game really hasn't changed that much).  It's awesome for a gateway game, I just try to get people to graduate from titles of this depth sooner rather than later due to my preference for heavier games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Easily my favorite deck builder style game. The variance and quick play of this game makes it easy to teach to new players but still falling into that "A Minute to learn a Lifetime to master" style games. I have yet to find myself bored with Dominion and I have been playing for seven years now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't know if this was the first game to introduce the concept of deck building as a mechanic but it is certainly one of the most well known and best designed out there. Dominion is a solid game that will probably stand the test of time. It plays like a ccg but is (allegedly) a closed set of cards. The "last" set, adventures just game out so in theory, if rio grande ever decides they don't like printing money, the game will stop coming out with sets. Dominion has simple, literally as simple as "ABC" core rules that are dressed up with a myriad of different card types. Each time you play you set up a kingdom of a defined number of cards and this is what you draw from to build your deck and attempt to put score your opponent before the game ends. The game is great because while it is simple to learn it is hard to master and the complex interplay of different card mechanics makes the possibilities of combinations and interesting replay endless. My issues with the game are my own and obviously do not diminish the game. These issues include simple logistics, it takes a special insert to organize all the cards in the game now and probably a few rehearsals to set it up and put it away efficiently. This in itself makes me less inclined to play as it takes time to set up and put away AND each new game would require I put away the old configuration and set up the new one. Not the end of the world but not really compatible with what I look for on my regular game store night. Dominion is more a all day multiple plays sort of affair. Also, the theme is generic. This thing is like a stereotypical euro in card form. Bland as butter less toast. These are minor nitpicks. The game is great. I just almost never feel like playing  it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is an interesting deck building game.
However, I never really got hooked.

RATING: 8
The classic DBG and one of the best introductory games ever.  My main criticism is the advantage to the player who goes first, the win ratios of players who go last in a 4 player game can't be much better than 1 in 4. It's also pricey and requires card sleeving (or buying a new set when the cards wear out due to all the shuffling).  Other than that it's the default DBG all others are compared to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After lots of ups and downs, confusion, exasperation, and finally plays with lots of expansions mixed in, I'm finally comfortable bumping this up to an 8.  Not reading about strategy in the forums, I've had to make a bunch of observations and discoveries for myself about how to do well in Dominion.  Now though, I think I better understand how to play in response to what the other players are doing.

Becoming any good at this game has been a struggle.  I'm still not fantastic, but getting the expansions and putting in a bunch of 1v1 lunch games helped a great deal.

Edit: Bumping this up to a 9.  I play it almost every day during lunches, and Dark Ages coming out has upped the fun even more.  It has taken me a really long time to really start to deeply understand this game, but I think I'm getting there.

Edit: With how much this gets played and how much I enjoy it, I can no longer pretend it is anything other than a 10.  It has only reached this level of quality with all the expansions and a great deal of learning, but it has certainly reached it.  This is my second 10 rating.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My gaming group's first deck-builder. When we first started playing, it seemed a bit odd and counter-intuitive. About 10 minutes in, it all clicked, and I saw the brilliance behind the design. You can teach this game to a non-gamer in about 5-10 minutes, and it's a great intro to card-based games.

My wife and I played again with a totally different set of 10 piles to draw from, and the game was even better. The more advanced cards (the ones not recommended as a starting layout in the rulebook) had much more player-to-player interaction and aggression, and we were able to play much more quickly.

I tried to teach my gaming group Netrunner, and it just didn't click. Complaints centered around that game's very steep learning curve and obtuse terminology. Dominion has filled the hole that Netrunner couldn't, and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves. A great game, and a definite buy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I admit, it's a good game that in a way appeals to me. It's fairly quick and easy to learn as well. There's definitely a lot of replayability. With the differing card powers, there's a certain strategy as you decide how to use your money to buy cards.
My biggest gripe is still the lack of theme. When I played, I just looked at the powers and didn't even care about the picture. So, basically, it's pretty clinical and will appeal to those who like figuring out how to do things efficiently. It's more of a filler game to me than a real game where I can immerse myself for hours.

RATING: 6.5
+ Lots of different card interactions to find here; It's fun to build up good combinations and to execute them with a good draw.
- Once you've seen the cards and decided what you're going for, the game pretty much plays itself.


Why it's previously-owned:
Android has put out a pretty slick implementation of this game on their phones. I would much rather play through this game in 4 minutes with zero shuffling than play the real game. 
I traded this away for Colossal Arena and Pergamon.

RATING: 8
This game has turned my opinion of deck-building games completely around.  I agree with others who commented that play lacks interaction (this is not to say the players don't interact - my group had a good time playing this together - only that your strategy focuses less on forcing your opponents' actions than on guiding your own).  However, I like puzzles, and while I am not a fan of puzzle-race games (this breaks the mold on that for me too), the balance of decisions, luck and weight is just right for this game.  Will I like it forever?  Maybe not.  Do I like it for now and see myself playing it at every opportunity?  Most definitely.

RATING: 9
I've played this many times on BSW and finally got a chance to play the real thing. It's a great game with a really interesting mechanic. It plays fast and you can employ a huge variety of strategies. My only problems with the game are that the various money denominations -- copper/silver/gold -- are all uniformly copper in colour, some of the artwork is terrible (the militia card is atrocious), and the back of the cards is a horrible blue colour with an awkwardly placed double logo. I'm sure that this game will see many card expansions, but I wish instead for a second edition with proper artwork and card backs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lowered rating because, after some number of games, the game feels too one-dimensional and monotonous.  The main problem is that, whatever you do, the game is in the end all about money, namely (in most set-ups) raising that $8 needed to buy a Province.  I feel that this game is very surpass-able by later DBGs, just like Magic: the Gathering was very surpass-able (and had been surpassed) by later TCGs down the line.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
CCG deck building without all the CCG ugliness.  25 action cards mean lots of combinations, lots of replay.  One complaint is that an unmitigated Chapel deck destroys.  However, it's still an excellent game and, if the Chapel really bothers you, don't put it in!

We usually draft the majority of the action cards (e.g., draw 2/3, keep 1) and use a veto system for the remainder.  Usually works well.

I love this game!  Plays quick, fair bit of strategy, and the luck factor can be mitigated (to a degree) by your strategy.  Luck still plays a big role, but as with [GAMEID=28143] a skilled player will generally win (or is more likely to win) over a lesser-skilled player.

Rated a 9 instead of a 10 because I've lost interest in it.  I'll gladly play it if someone else suggests it or wants to, but it's nowhere near a "must play" for me anymore, and I feel as though I have a good handle on strategies.  I win around half the time and almost all of my games are 3-4 players.

Give this one a shot and see if it scratches the itch for you.

By the way, for all Dominion I've grown to prefer an even number of turns and phantom Provinces on the last turn (if the Provinces run out then).  It evens everything out and reduces the otherwise significant advantage afforded by turn order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Without the Prosperity expansion, the biggest thing Dominion has going for it is that it plays fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
At first I wasn't too impressed by Dominion. Maybe I set my expectations too high due to the high praise that this game gets. However after multiple plays I've come around to it a little bit.

My biggest problem with Dominion is still its graphic presentation. The artwork and the graphic design are just awful. Why did they even bother hiring an artist if they wanted to publish something like this? Besides that though, Dominion offers quite an interesting game play and constitutes a clever mental exercise.

It's enjoyable to study what's available for you to buy and find the best synergy to exploit. I really like making combos and this game definitively allows you do that. It's very satisfying to get a big turn and cycle through half of your deck.

Yet, maybe because I played other and more refined deck building games before Dominion, I'm not really enhammered with this one. It's a good game, plays quite fast and offers an interesting challenge. However the artwork is really off-putting and the theme makes no sense at all. There's no doubt Dominion is a great innovative title that brought us a whole new genre of boardgames... but it doesn't particularly excite me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
STRATEGY 

A really fast game with a clever mechanic, this is almost like Magic: The Gathering card game. Build your deck during game play to gather copper, silver, and gold coins, which you use to buy land (victory points).

Recommended with 2-4 players (best 3). 30 mins.

RATING: 9.5
I love this game! It has so much versatility and ability to change. There's a lot of strategy, and while there isn't as much chance for sabotage, the fact that you're playing semi-solitaire lets you better use the cards for your own doing. It's a very "in your own head" kind of game, but it's tons of fun, and really gets your brain whirring. Definitely a favourite, and it never overstays its welcome as it plays quickly. It's also much easier to pick up than it would appear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very brilliant and innovative mechanic with the midgame "deckbuilding" as you play.  Between nearly equally skilled players, performing a similar gameplan based on the available cards, it seems heavily dependant on the strength of one's early draws.  That is, if the cards you buy during rounds 1 & 2 are drawn quickly in the second pass through the deck, it tends to be very strong, but if they are in the bottom two cards, and not drawn until the reshuffle, then you get 'screwed' out of one use of them, plus the powerful card they wouldve allowed you to buy doesnt get to be in your deck for the 3rd passthrough.

When playing live (not on BSW), the shuffling can be annoying.  Playing online is extremely efficient and is a superior way to play, imo.  My rating is a '10' for online Dominion due to automated shuffling.  My rating goes down some when you have 3 and especially 4 players, as there is more downtime.  2 player online Dominion is gaming perfection, imo. :)

RATING: 7
Dette må bli årets spill!!! Lærte det i november 2008 i et bursdagselskap for spillnerder. Vi endte opp med å spille dette spillet ca 12 ganger i tillegg til andre spill!!! Siden den gang har vi alltid tatt dette frem ved hver spillsamling. Grunnet til dette er enkel: det er stor variasjon i hvert eneste spill, og det varer i 20 minutter og selfølgelig det viktigste, det er kjempe morsomt. Det er stor interaksjon i spillet. Vi er to stk som samles minst en gang i uka, og da spiller vi dette ca 6 ganger på en kveld. Spillet har noen forslag til spilloppsett, men da kunne man fort bli lei for folk bruker samme strategi. Vi sørger nå derfor for at alle spill er random i forhold til hvilke 10 korttyper vi har med i oppsettet. NB! bruk deckprotector til kortene, da varer spillet lenger!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first deck building game and still could be the king on the hill of these mechanic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I played a couple of rounds of Androminion a while ago and thought it was boring. I felt I didn't give the game a fair shake so I spent some time playing bots on Goko. My opinion has changed from boring to deeply unpleasant.

Basically, Dominion works. It does what it intends to do and it does it well. However it's not what I want and I don't like it. Dominion combines the worst aspects of ccg deck construction with the worst aspects of euro games.

I find the core gameplay to be annoying. It's basically a euro efficiency/engine building game with random access to your resources. I don't find either of those aspects appealing. The cards in the core set are tremendously boring and a lot of the setups lead to even more boring games. Some of them are obnoxious and make the game drag.

The depth comes from deducing the optimal strategy per board and recognizing when the mid and endgames are starting. Many of the boards reward a strong focus on 3-5 cards while the others are ignored. 

Another thing I don't like is that there's no hand management. You deck just vomits cards out and you find the optimal arrangement for them to make it look less like sick. I get that the focus of the game is deck management, not hand management, but I don't like it at all.

All in all I gained an appreciation of the strategy and I honestly got a little pleasure out of the learning experience. I get the same feeling from Dominion that I get from playing time waster games like solitaire Qwixx on my phone. It's fast, repetitive, the decisions are mostly rote, simple, and feel immediately rewarding in an incredibly shallow manner, like grinding in an MMO. I pushed buttons in order and a number goes up. I can see why people get fanatical about it but the decisions it requires are fundamentally uninteresting to me and the act of playing isn't fun and feels ultimately hollow to me.

RATING: 9
Good game to introduce people into gaming. Simple and quick to learn, addictive gameplay, and deep strategy (no big money is not the best play. its ezmode but can be easily beaten). And you can do some crazy things, for example in a 4 player game the other day I was able to build a 19 card deck that bought a province every turn by drawing the entire deck. Easily blew the competition out of the water.

Another time I just bought every witch I could with no moats in the game I just flooded the competition with village+witch. Came out 20 points above the competition.

RATING: 8
Dominion is a fun, fast, light game. The strategy involved can be as deep as you want it to be. With serious gamers, it becomes a race for efficiency and cool combos. With light gamers, it becomes a trial and error process of even cooler combos.

The thing that makes this game great is that it has a face for everyone. I've played quite a bit of this with my gaming group and they loved it. I'm eager to bring it home and try it out with the family. The ease of play and short time span make this a strong contender for purchase by any gamer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I Love Love Love this game.  The more I play it the better it gets the amount of strategy and the way that the game changes each and every time you play makes this one of the best games that I own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Plays fine for a few games and even has some interesting a deep strategy. Once the novelty wears off though, it's just the spammiest game with a really weird tacked-on theme. Can be decent for introducing drafting games to new players, though much better alternatives exist.

Update 2017: Lowered to a 4 for the following serious four problems that prevent this game from ever becoming great:

1. Buying money is the ultimate strategy in 1st Ed. Nothing beats this strategy. Actions cards are just piddling around compared to buying money until you spam VP.
2. Everyone is able to take the exact same strategy. This is the single most damning factor in the entire game. While it may seem to some people to create interesting back-and-forth play, it doesn't. Everything about the Kingdom stock is ruined by this because players can just copy the best player in the game. You can do this tit-for-tat, or just copy their overall strategy. Most strategies die to THEMSELVES which is awful. Worse, many strategies start a counter-your-counter-which-counters-my-counter-that-counters-your-counter chain. When experienced players see this, it just turns off like half the Kingdom stock (boring) and when newbies play, they cause the entire situation to go nuclear and force everyone to start that awful counter chain.
3. Terrible cards in 1st Edition. Mostly it's the attacks and Woodcutter. Jesus christ these make for shitty games where you're taking subpar cards to just be mean. Ultimately, with good players it just means -1 kingdom pile for every one of them you add.
4. The randomness is stronger in this game than Star Realms which seems impossible at first. Except that most stuff in this game is super tight and your opponent can just copy your exact strategy so if they happen to do that and get the correct cards in the correct order before you, or while you don't, you just basically lost to a luckier version of yourself. I cannot reiterate enough how much every player having the same strategy brings Dominion down. This would be fine in a co-op game but utterly broken in a competitive one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like the various combinations of available cards that interact differently in every game. Dominion created this whole deck building formula, and did a great job with it in my opinion. Its strength is in simplicity while the depth is in exploring the variability with weird/interesting combos. But it can come across as a bit dry or lifeless depending upon how you approach it. So you either enjoy the game for what it is or you don't. 

Unfortunately, the base set is what it is. The options are pretty limited and get stale pretty quickly. On its own, the charm fades quickly. Expansions definitely help bring it back to life. But they come in varying quality.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Fine, but later deckbuilders are more interesting and I don't care for the ones which require you set out a bunch of decks. I prefer a rotating market of a wider variety of things.

And in total, personally, I'm finding that I don't love deckbuilding as a mechanism. I like constructing a deck, ala Magic, but none of the deckbuilders which I have played have yet really captured that sense that I'm creating my own personalized deck that's AWESOME, and then test it against my opponent's awesome creations. Instead, and I assume this is the fault of Dominion, it always feels like I'm playing a Euro-style board game with the limited goal of upgrading the things in my hand, rather than building a "thing", and that I'm largely playing a solitaire game for point comparison.

And since Dominion was probably created with the intent of giving people a bit of the sense of constructing Magic decks, that it fails to achieve that is a pretty strong demerit. It, ultimately, failed to accomplish its goal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An easy game for experienced gamers to pick up. Great deck-building fun.

RATING: 6.1
My initial reaction to Dominion was one of sheer excitement and fascination. Being a hard core Magic player, I was intrigued by an idea for a game where the sole purpose was deckbuilding, and for a time it was amazing. Now that enough time has passed, and I have played other deckbuilders, going back to Dominion I have a new perspective. If you have never played  a deck builder and you want to see the bare bones of how the concept works, then this is the game for you, its the original and without the expansion it is streamlined and classic. Otherwise, there are far better deckbuilders out there and this one's crown has been passed.

RATING: 3
2-4(3)

UPDATE:  This literally never hits the table and probably won't.  I'm half keeping it around because I think it'd be great for when non-gamers (sis, cousins, ...) are around.  I've played with them and while they got into it and "got" the game well enough, I didn't feel like they were all that engaged.  And I wasn't all that engaged.

I think the base benefits greatly from Seaside (and perhaps additional expansions), but I can't but think it's similar to Blue Moon in that most of these abstracted / shallowly themed card games just aren't my thing.  I just can't care enough to connect the cards to the mechanic (which to me is only so-so).  Again, except for, oddly, RftG.

I'm not usually one to trade out, but seriously thinking of dealing away my set.

---------------------------------------------------------

It has some interesting mechanics and I can appreciate the play but the theme is so thin I don't get invested in the game.  I don't care about the cards aside from their stats (and some cards seem clearly much better than others), interaction is low and it too often seems to be a race for provinces (after being a race for gold).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Engine building meets Magic-style deck building.  Decisions on timing your switch from building that engine to gathering victory points are familiar from St. Petersburg. 

Player interaction is low to non-existent, depending on the set-up you choose.  Some of the cards like the Militia, Thief and Witch introduce take-thatery.  It would have been nice to see some more imaginative options for interaction, but perhaps those will come with the inevitable expansions.  

Update:  I have recently played several games using random set-ups of cards from the base set and various expansions.  It strikes me as a better game when that great level of variability is accumulated.  However, I am never going to make the huge investment required to reach that point.

RATING: 6
Most of my friends and family love this game and I end up playing it more than I would prefer. So I'm able to isolate the core problem: only some combinations of cards are truly strategic in that they have multiple meaningful strategy branches. In other words, it feels like in 50% of card sets it matters much more that a given player gets lucky early and gets one (or sometimes several) key cards then what happens after that point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played often for a few days when I first bought this game, but its appeal has faded somewhat since. It's fast, and varied thanks to the selection of kingdom cards that make up each game. However, the game seems to be in the strategy one decides to take when looking at the selection of cards in any particular game. There don't then seem to be many decisions to take: one buys according to one's strategy, though there are some decisions to be made there. But actually playing each hand, before the buy, rarely seems to be interesting.

...

After some plays of Intrigue: Intrigue makes playing each hand more interesting, there are a lot more interesting decisions to make in how to play one's hand. So I see a lot more life in this now, and have more enthusiasm for it. Still won't ever be my all-time favourite game, but much improved in my estimation.

...

[July 2010] I played it once the other day, and thought: I don't like this game...

RATING: 8
I love this game immensely, after over 1000 real and online games, it still holds my attention.

So very, very clever, yet so fundamentally simple in implementation.  Infinitely re-playable with so many variations.

Clever.  But when combined with the Expansions, it really becomes special.

I've never encountered a game that so thoroughly dominates a table.  My work colleagues and I play this at lunch, almost every day for over 12 months.  Even though I have tried to introduce other games, they always insist on playing Dominion.  And now I have both Intrigue and Seaside, the possibilities are endless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The mechanic in Dominion is quite unique, the idea of building a deck of cards as the purpose of the game is interesting and offers a lot of space for re-play.

One of my favorite thing about Dominion is that every time I play, I have to come up with a different strategy (even with the same 10 Kingdom cards), because the opponent(s) also have different ways of playing. I also like the fixed start and even though the game is quite scripted in the beginning, I like the fact that you're able to employ any strategy.

The quality of the cards and the amazing box interior offer a great play experience.

The learning curve is very good, in less than 20 minutes, almost all option the game has to offer and all the mechanics are clear.

The only down side I see so far is the master strategy for two player (which I will not disclose). Until someone will prove me wrong (by defeating this strategy, I will not rate this game higher, although it has the potential for 9 or even 10.

RATING: 7.5
the .5 is based on assumed replay value with the expansions... like the game, Don't like waiting for others to cycle their decks.  like the random board (cards).  Like that sometimes it's interactive and sometimes it's solitare, you never know.  Like that even when it's not my turn I watch what others are doing and fret over it, so that I usually feel engaged even with non-interactive cards.  Can see it getting old, but not for a while as the people I play with have big boxs.

Update, played with a few of the big box expansions and while prosperity makes cycling your deck easier and thus turns longer, variablity trumps the offset of waiting...usually.  Still a fun, accessable game.

RATING: 7
Although the cards themselves are nicely illustrated, at first glance it does not look the most playable and exciting of games. The original game comes with 25 kingdom cards, from which 10 are (best randomly) chosen. This makes for some varied and interesting games where tactics change from game to game. Unlike the CCGs where too much is dependent on preconstructed decks, players construct their decks from the same pool of cards and play as the decks become larger.

RATING: 8.5
It might not be as flashy or thematic as deck builders that have come after, but there's just something magical about Dominion that is hard to explain.  I've played nearly every deck builder released in the past few years and have yet to find one that I prefer to Dominion.  Again the fact that I don't think I'll ever play the same game twice is a huge plus.  Also this game is AMAZING as a 2player dual, quick and fun, and my wife and I can blaze through several games in an evening and have an absolute blast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
A card game, with infinite replayability, even without the expansions, none of which I have played.

The mechanics are simple and the game has a very short learning curve.

What makes the game infinitely replayable is that there are two or three dozens different types of cards to choose from, but only ten are used per game, drawn at random.

For me, 7+ is a high rating for a card game.

RATING: 6
May 2012:  This game actually earns a 10 for addiction.  I can think of few games more addictive than Dominion.  

Clearly, the mechanic of always trying to "improve" your hand,  shuffling through cards, then playing them, is a highly addictive pursuit (witness the Magic phenom).  I find it strangely intoxicating as well.  Interesting. 

This game is a definite phenom, a bestseller, and an excellent gateway game.  It deserves major props for helping to introduce a lot of new people to board gaming.  Rating 7 of 10.

February 2013:  Just no desire to play again. Dropped to a 6 of 10.

RATING: 7
My first foray into deck building games, and Dominion has lived up to its name for me. Great game with a massive amount of variation once you start mixing in the expansions. I love how it balances having useful cards in your hand vs critical-to-victory-but-functionally-useless cards. 

Certain combos can be broken, but nothing that some personal black listing won't solve.

Some people also diss the theme or artwork. Personally I find the artwork okay (except Intrigue). And as for theme? I would take a great themeless game over a poor thematic game any day.

RATING: 8
Dominion is an awesome game the began a genre. Vaccarino would seem to be a genius for coming up with deck-building. Though we do feel sorry for him. He created this epic game that has defined an entire genre of game that will not go away. Thus he will be forever judged by that epic creation. And he will never be able to match it much less surpass it. 
That said we just cannot see keeping it. We have so many other deck builders that are better and with theme , something Dominion is sadly lacking in. So while it is an incredible game it isn't for us.

RATING: 6

1/20/13: Got around to updating my rating on this to 6 (from an 8). Dominion has really cooled its jets on me lately. I have no desire anymore to play it as other deckbuilders have passed it up in terms of theme and entertainment. I would much rather play Legendary, Ascension, Epic Thunderstone, etc... Dominion is a great game for someone new to the hobby and deckbuilding in general... but its time has passed IMO.

RATING: 8
There is a whiff of brilliance here, you can just feel it.  Actually this game is VERY popular, who am I kidding.  Many people will testify to the sheer genius of this game, the level of strategy, the decisive choices one faces, mathematical madness and all.  And Dominion is really for the concrete math mind, it isn't very themey or artistic, in fact it is rather numb for a card game.  And that is why I primarily take issue with it.  Although I will not doubt its brilliance, mainly the whole active deck-building play.  And many great spin offs of this mechanic are popping up, if Dominion wasn't your thing.  Still this game is easy to learn, has many ways to play, and has many details and tactics for mastery.  Well done.

RATING: 2
I do like the way your card pile grows, but this CCG-style game introduced me to a second meaning of the term "wristy." Here you'll be shuffling your personal deck every two minutes, playing cards that can "chain" so you keep drawing more and taking more actions (while everyone else just watches), until you are finally left with money cards and "dead" cards and get to buy another card (action/money/VP card). It's very random, and there is almost no interaction or fun factor, let alone excitement level. I played two games and that's enough.

-) Plays quickly - you never wait long for your turn
-) Different decks make for a different game every time
-) Seems to scale well with different numbers of players
-) Small, but interesting decisions
-) Building the deck really gives me a feeling of achievement (it's getting better and better)
-) Neat box

CONS:
-) Bound to become a bit repetitive over time - but I still have MANY games before that will happen
-) Some turns are fairly obvious, and play semi-automatic

RATING: 4
It's a good game with quite a unique system of play. I enjoyed it but I didn't really feel any excitement when playing it also the theme is really thin to the point where you don't care which is a shame as the art is very nice.

After a third game I found I still enjoyed it. It's clever and different. Still not much "joy" when playing.

Fourth game and I'm starting to like it a bit more. With people who have played the game a lot I'm sure it becomes very fast as there would be little downtime due to you being able to draw cards and know exactly what to do with them.

A few more games and ...Nope. Don't like it. It feels that there should be more to it. I'm not good at this sort of game and can't be bothered getting good at it. If only it felt like I was actually doing something rather than shuffling cards and getting more cards to shuffle. Where's the fun?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The standard when it comes to deck builders. Very interesting decisions that are made each turn, trying to find the perfect balance between action cards and currency and knowing when to make the push for victory points. Very good replayability, but only when included with an expansion or two. Really, if you invest in one Dominion box, you need to invest in least one or two more.

One downside is that some cards are clearly better than other cards of the same cost, which creates a mad rush of grabbing as many as you can before your opponents can. Some cards are left untouched because their cost isn't worth their benefit compared to other things you can buy. Also, the game lacks interaction and feels sometimes like everyone is just playing their own game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Thought it was a game of modifiers when I first glanced at it, glad it didn't play like that.  Didn't immediately get the "just one more" crack feeling of Race for the Galaxy either, even though I'm not the biggest RFTG fan.  Good variability.  Printing the helper thing from BGG that sits in your insert makes setup a lot easier.  Many decisions, very playable, also plays great with two.  Really hit its stride for me with repeat plays against fast, experienced players.  Enjoy playing it on BSW as well.  I've come to really dig it as gaming candy, although competitive patterns (especially the chapel) took it down a bit after tons of plays.  I think the base game's shuffling is acceptable, but I'm less interested in expansions because of shuffle-mechanic cards.

RATING: 8
Tried for the first time after playing A few acres of snow and Freitag two deck-builders I have. Now I can understand the hype and why Martin Wallace wanted to adapt Dominion mechanics and make a much thematic version of his own. 

Lots of combinations in the base game (23 Kingdom cards just using 10 of them in every game and depending on the choice games can be significantly different) and though it could get stale if you play it a lot you have loads of expansions that you can add to the mix!

I'm playing a computer homemade version based on MWS and developed by my friend Ordoniez so I can just play two player games ... but it's still great! Keen to explore all the expansions.

I hope there are more strategies awaiting me.

No game has ever garnered such interest.

RATING: 9
LOVE LOVE LOVE!  One of my guilty pleasures is playing card-based games courtesy of my sons.  I used to play Duel Masters with them and Kingdom Hearts because it was a great way to bond.  What I love about Dominion is that all players start on a level playing field so it is not just a competition of who lucked into a rare & powerful card find or who spent the most money buying card packs to fill their deck with the strongest cards.  This games lets everyone start from the same point and how you build your deck is entirely up to you.

RATING: 9
Plays well with 2-4 players, and that's one of the big things going for it.  With 4 players there is surprisingly little downtime.  The downside to this game is the shuffling.  I have seen custom sets with discs used rather than cards and that may be an enhancement.  I'd like to try that.

3/7/09 - Bumped up to a nine.  Still not compelling me as it is with some folks that I play with, but any game that's getting this much play gets bumped up in the rankings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.15
I absolutely love Dominion. I enjoy deck building and engine building, and I think that Dominion does both of those excellently. I have played with a couple expansions, but most of my experience is with the base game. I love finding synergies between sets of cards that can give me an advantage over my opponent. I also love that the game plays so quickly. I used to play a little Magic, and I enjoyed the deck construction aspect of the game but didn't care for the collective nature of the game. Dominion gives me some of the deck design feel that I sometimes miss from Magic. This is easily one of my favorite games to pull out for a quick game with some fun strategy.

Update: Ultimately, I got rid of Dominion because I couldn't find people interested in playing anymore. I still really like the game, but it wasn't worth keeping around since it never got played.

2010-04 I've read more of the strategy/review articles here and stopped buying as many action cards. I also started making use of the trash ability when it was present.
Unsurprisingly I've started scoring better, winning more than my 'share' of games.

RATING: 6
Undeniably well designed for what it is.  This being not more than a 6 is due mostly to taste.  To me this boils down to a puzzle game, where the puzzle is finding the best combos and engines per setup.  Puzzle games are not one of my my 8-10 rating range genres.

Within the puzzle-interactive-card game 'genre' I think I'd prefer Glory to Rome over Dominion on depth and thought, in spite of Glory's higher chaos level.  I also prefer Thunderstone's theme integration better than Dominion's, so if I'm going for some base level immersion in this genre, I'll go Thunderstone.  So while Dominion may be technically the 'better' game design of those three on paper in many respects, I like the other two better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like Dominion.  The deck-building is applealing, where VPs are necessary to win the game but create dead weight in your deck.  You don't really want to get rid of coppers and reduce the cash value of your deck, but replacing them will increase the average cash value of a hand.  Tough choices, and a good game.

With more and more plays, the uber-combos really start to become glaring.  It often becomes a race to get lucky cash draws to buy up all the festivals or gardens or whatever the hot one or two cards are for that game.  Seeing a player play his entire deck of 40+ cards turn after turn is not fun; it's tedious, even if you are the guy doing it.  Rating decrease!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
While Dominion isn't the "first" deck-building game strictly speaking... it did popularize the mechanic and for good reason. This game is incredibly simple to play and manages to deliver something fluid, interesting, and highly replayable. The only issue with the game is that some starting combinations (lots of attacks, lots of curses, etc) can lead to some wonky and slow-playing games. But by being mindful during set-up, Dominion can be a real treat.

RATING: 5
The game had lots of hype and recommendations; got it from a friend that was surprised that i haven't played a "pure" deckbuilder.
It has a few shortcomings:
- 1st player advantage 
- the game is too simple
- doesn't feel fun to pull off combos
- half cards are mean- and even then they are boring
- can be too long for what it is , depending on the kingdom cards chosen
- the base game doesn't stand on its own

My SO didn't want to play it more than once; i played two 2 player games, and several solo. All were meh.

TL;DR the game is overhyped, and the mechanic can't stand on its own.

RATING: 7
Based on 1 BSW play. I rather enjoyed the game, but it seems like the choices you make are rather obvious most of the time. I love games where choices are not a lot, but to take one route makes you agonize as you make your move. This isn't such a game. I liked how it played, but it's just not that "oh, what I'd do" experience I love.

UPDATE: Having played a couple more times, I can see how this game earns it's huge appeal. It's still not amongst my favorites, but I'm now considering buying it, for the sake of having a medium-weight card game I can actually teach easily (as opposed to the great Race for the Galaxy).

UPDATE: Still enjoying it. It shows it's great replayability, which is always a huge plus for me. I'm considering buying it (despite it's rather steep price), and I'm upping the rating to a 9.

UPDATE: It's a good, fun game, but not a spectacular one. Down to a 7.5, and likely to remain there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
I like the deck building mechanic of this game.  It's a fresh take on what is becoming a very common genre of card games.

There is a lot of talk about there being limits to the number of winning strategies and I can't really say if they are true or not.  It does seem that there is one major road to victory (with only subtle variations).

The game plays pretty quickly though, and is still pretty fun so I'm willing to give it a fair amount of tries before giving it up as one-dimensional.

I will say that Race for the Galaxy (which is similar in many ways) does appear to be the more fulfilling experience of the genre.

-------------UPDATE------------------

This game grows on me the more I play it, and the more cards I mix in.  My initial rating (7) was based on games that only used the base set and only used the same "suggested beginners" set of ten action cards.  The game is much more interesting when using different cards each game.  Expansions add even more variety and enjoyment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A simple game, in design and game play. Basically you are trying to optimize your deck and your hand, since you are drawing from the deck you are building.
You are going to be buying from the 10 stacks of cards and adding them to your deck, and then later maybe get rid of cards that become less useful or that clog up your deck, and buying more useful cards.
Plays well with any number of players. I don't like the fact that some cards are rarely picked, so it ends up being the same cards picked up again and again. 
You can always customize the game and leave those cards out but I prefer to have a complete playable game, and not just part of it.
Turns are extremely quick, no AP here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like Magic, but including deck construction as part of the game. Very fancy mechanics that work very well. After playing a few hundert games I prefer Magic again tough...
Found out recntly that I'm not really into it anymore. I will always respect it for having founded a new game genre though.

RATING: 8
I really enjoyed collectible card games for the customizeable decks...but I tend to lose interest as the expense in maintaining them increases (and the variety of cards becomes overwhelming in the deck creation process).  Dominion solves this problem by allowing for variety, but limiting the available mix in any given game to a reasonable number.  However, the constant release of new entries is too much to bear, and too easy to fall behind.  So I won't turn it down, and I enjoy it...but I won't be collecting them all any more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Update: 2-3-2010

It is my choice for as a gateway game and also even play it with veteran gamers as well.  I love the expandability of the game as well and I welcome all expansions.  Very very good game.

RATING: 6
05/12 - Gosh, I wish I had been logging plays earlier. I must have played Dominion at least 60 - 70 times more than listed. There were straight weeks when this got played at least 3 times a day.

07/14 - LeeAnn and I have been playing a ton on playdominion.com. We like the speed at which you can play and we've been trying a house rule to make it actually a game, not a province race. So, now when we play, a certain amount of action cards must be gone before anyone is allowed to buy a province, which actually lets you build a deck and put the deck to work, opposed to getting as much money as possible to win with provinces in 5 minutes.

RATING: 9
The good:
Very fun, rewarding game that everyone I've introduced it to loves. The gameplay is innovative, yet still scratches the same itch of CCG's. But unlike CCGs, buy one set (and any number of expansions) and everyone plays out of it, keeping it fair and even, so you invest in having fun, not being competitive.

The bad:
Theme is detached and feels tacked on, not that this detracts from the gameplay. Lots of shuffling. At least with base set, feels more like you're racing you're opponents than playing them head on.

RATING: 7
LIKES - Easy to teach.  Easy to learn.  Simple game mechanics that provide tons of strategic depth.  It is fun to find combos in cards.  High replay value.  Quick play time.  Innovative take on a deck building card game.

DISLIKES - After a 50+ of plays, the game "feels" repetitive.  Good thing there are expansions.

WHY AN 8.5 BASED ON BGG RATING DEFS? -  This is an "excellent" game, but I don't "always" want to play.  I will recommend it to newbies to games.  It makes for a great gateway game that can provides you with a ton of gaming miles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
Not had this long and already logged in lots of plays.  Introduced it to wife and a friend both really like it.  On the negatives there are puzzles to be solved (or solutions to be learned) in which once they are learned you will have a huge edge on your opponents.    Still really like the game, the engine building and the deck building.  The static buy pool (once game starts) and the limit of one buy and one action (unless cards increase) makes this very skillful and unforgiving if you get the wrong cards or make the wrong choices but makes it particularly satisfying when its all done right. Expansions make the game a lot more fun and varied although can lead to combination fatigue where some players can build up to 20-30 card involving turns which for me is less fun.

RATING: 10
Full Disclosure: I am a playtester for this game. 

Know this: The game takes several plays to really start to shine. I have a fear that the initial glowing reports are going to/may have already created some expectations that will not be fulfilled immediately upon playing the game.

The game, for me, takes some time to get to know. As you play and, and as you try differing strategies and get to know all the cards in the box, that is when the game truly starts to blossom and shine. the first few plays are not likely to make anyone declare it the greatest game ever, but as you play more and the subtle card interactions and tricky plays start to catch hold, well then it really starts to shine.

With experienced players, it can play very fast.

RATING: 5

----------

Definitely a solid title.  After about 25 plays, I have little doubt I will reach 100, but have fears about 'optimal' combos.  For example, the Gardens/Workshop combo seems incredibly strong right now.  I have this sinking feeling certain combos will become the 'best' among particular card sets.  Meaning, once players are familiar with all the cards, every strategy will be a slight variation on a key combo.  Then again, I could be completely full of malarkey.

I'm digging it at the moment, but I already know it will not reach top tier status (in my book) like Race for the Galaxy has.

It goes without saying I'm looking forward to the expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion is a game built on an interesting idea, but which falls short in execution. The variable setup allowing (or even [i]requiring[/i]) different strategies to be pursued increases the replayability of a game that otherwise lacks depth, though some of the cards are markedly inferior (to the point that there is no reason to [i]ever[/i] purchase them). However, the most ingenious feature of Dominion is the inherent opportunity cost of buying victory points -- i.e., buying VPs actually [i]diminishes[/i] the effectiveness of one's deck, as it clutters the deck with cards that do nothing to further your goal of buying more victory points. This is a very clever idea, but unfortunately it is only really offers an interesting choice when considering whether to buy a Duchy: with 8 Gold, buying a Province is a no-brainer, and buying an Estate is (essentially) never a good idea; this leaves the choice of buying a Duchy (for points) or a Silver or kingdom card as the only real decision. The result is that this mechanism helps to (slightly) slow down the leader, but doesn't create interesting or tense decisions for the players. A pity.

Player interaction is present, but often feels somewhat lifeless. [i]Turn N: "Milita." "Moat." "Moat." {Discards.} Turn N+1: "Thief." "Moat." {Turns over two non-Treasure cards.} "Moat." {Repeat.}[/i] The fact that most actions are fairly simple and require limited decision-making during the turn helps keep the game moving, but it does feel somewhat hollow after a little while. [i]Incidental[/i], even, rather than purposeful -- especially when actions are indiscriminate (e.g., Militia). While it is not exactly 'multiplayer solitaire', the game certainly isn't [i]engaging[/i], at least in comparison to other games. 

The critical fault is that the downtime-to-interesting-decision (and even downtime-to-meaningful-thinking-during-opponents'-turns) ratio is quite high. In other words, there is a great deal of waiting for a turn that generally doesn't offer many interesting decisions, and in many cases simply plays itself. The most interesting decision is made at a high level at the outset of the game: which cards to buy, and in what quantities/proportions. The rest of the game is effectively just a test of how effective that single decision is. In essence, the [i]sole[/i] interesting decision is made at the outset (even if it is a conditional decision: buy 2A:1B:1C, but if opponents buy D, buy 2A:1C:2D), meaning most of the actual play time is essentially clerical. 

Other more minor criticisms are the price tag (quite high given the production quality) and the production quality. I don't need the world's best art to enjoy a game, but [i]consistent[/i] design of at least above-average quality is important, and Dominion is a major offender in this area. Not only are many cards at odds with each other in terms of content and style, but some of them are [i]glaringly[/i] bad -- as in [i]impossible to not notice how bad it is[/i] bad. 

Dominion is a decent game with some very good ideas, but with enough flaws to detract from the experience in a fairly significant way. It is still [-]enjoyable[/-] tolerable (after a handful of plays) as a sort of puzzle, but simply does not offer enough to be a [-]great[/-] very enjoyable [i]game[/i]. (2014-03; 2014-06: some further revisions after a couple more plays, with a change in rating of 6 -> 5)

RATING: 5
First play. After all the awards and glowing praise I thought I should try this but had sufficient reservations to prevent me buying it. After one game I am unimpressed. 

Regardless of the manner in which you expand your draw pile, your options are at the mercy of what you draw. You see your opponant take a card, you take another to counter it or exploit a gap. All assuming of course that the cards fall correctly when you need them.

Again I got a sense of hopelessness, wishing that my killer card combo would turn up but finding that they invariably didn't. Its a game of much wishing and chaos and I really don't understand what all the fuss is about.

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game for a number of reasons. The game play is not to long and the gameplay is fast paced. There are multiple strategies to win that regularly work. The variability with the number of cards and expansions is basically limitless. A little advice: you will want to try hundreds of combinations of cards and expansions right off the bat. Play the basic set up for atleast 5-10 games. This will help develope basic strategies and play style. If you jump around to much, you will spend to much time trying to remember what all the cards do, the game slows down and you can never grasp any basic strategies. I understand your strategy will change with the different setups but it will be easier to transition when you need to. Buy and enjoy, you wont be disappointed. Even the very casual gamers in our group enjoy this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
In this game you decide upon a deck construction strategy and that's 90% of the game done in the first minute.

Playing the cards almost always requires no thought. There is usually a "correct" way to play the cards in hand, and the fact that cards don't stay in hand in between rounds means complicated cardplay decisions are thrown out the window.

You find out if your deck construction strategy won after about 20 minutes if you're playing with quick players, but really having a computer sim spit out the results would accomplish the same goal.

So much of who wins or looses depends on the EARLY distribution of cards in the deck. A single clumping of action cards in the beginning can lead to a crucial wasted turn.  In the beginning of the game this loss of tempo is magnified later on.

The win mechanic of buying provinces (first to 8 gold wins) is also not steller. 

Overal: Uggh. A horrible meta card game.
If you want deck construction games then I recommend drafting a game where card play actually matters.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8
As a former MtG + various other CCG games I really enjoy Dominion. It has the fun of building a deck and playing the cards without the collecting factor which in CCG's usually means the person who spends the most money is able to get the best cards. 

Dominion is easy to learn and quick to play.  The generic medieval theme without being supported by an underlying story meant that casual gamers can get into it pretty easily. Even my parents enjoy it!

I have played lots of Dominion, as all my different gaming groups have it, and played most of the expansions as well, at least once. Good game but I'm not enthusiastic about it. I think it is best with totally random cards available, preferrably mixed with expansions so there can be unexpected combos and thougher decisions.  I have also played both english and finnish Dominion and oh boy, is it difficult to change into english when you are used to the finnish wordings on cards.

Owned by friends

RATING: 10
Huippu!. Takana kohta sata peliä, ja silti jaksaa innostaa. Peli tietysti alkaa vähitellen toistaa itseään, vaikka jokainen setuppi periaatteessa vähän erilainen olisikin. Tietyt kortit ja taktiikat ovat kumminkin vahvempia kuin toiset, joten niitä tulee suosittua. Silti korttien sekoittelun tuoma randomius saa aikaan sen, että pelin kulku vaihtelee paljon, vaikka taktiikka saman pysyisikin. Aina ei pysty tekemään mitä haluaa, jolloin pitää jopa järkeillä mitä tekis. Ja juuri tämä saa aikaan positiivisen kierteen: revanssia ja heti nyt.

BSW:ssä vieläkin parempi, koska setuppiin menee vain sekunti aikaa. Livenäkin silti miellyttävä. Jokin parempi "säilytysratkaisu" olisi silti kehitettävä, jolloin setuppiin ei menisi niin paljon aikaa. Korttien pitäisi löytyä aina imiidetli. (17.3.2009)

RATING: 9.65
I love trying to figure out which cards will combine best. I like playing three or four of the same set of cards in a row to try a different way or to tweak if something didn't quite work out right. The game seems to be out of favour with some folks now but it is my favourite deckbuilder and feels more like a whole genre to me than a regular game. I feel it's best to have at least one expanion with it, for the variety. Sure, it may be light in theme, but it is the mechanics I love. It covers so many ideas of deckbuilding in a very clean way that I have serious doubts whether any other deckbuilder will better it for me. We'll see. For now, Dominion is king.

RATING: 9.5
This game can be both great and bad. The kingdom cards you pick can make or break the game. 

So... sometimes the game is a 5, sometimes it's a 10.

The luck factor doesn't bother me the slightest.

I usually dislike when people always use one strategy. I feel as if I were playing against a robot. Personally I usually like to try new stuff instead of simply being a drone (which sometimes ends up costing me the game, but whatever).

To be honest, the base game alone wouldn't deserve a 9.5... maybe an 8.5...  

EDIT: the game is more interesting once you play with all the expansions mixed in... but this leads to a lengthy and cumbersome setup (it takes less time to set up roads and boats), which is the main reason I almost never play this game anymore... such a shame.

RATING: 8
Novel idea for a card game that you're actually building your deck while playing. In this case it works very well and makes for a nice quick cardgame. Great replay value due to all the different card sets included. Many combinations are possible allthough not all would be good for gameplay.

After repeated plays I feel I must retract my earlier statement that not all cards combinations are fit for play. Each combination provides a unique challenge and some are just harder than others. Nowadays I seem to enjoy the impossible sets the most. I also noted that the cards wear rather quickly and are not of the required quality for the heavy usage in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very enjoyable game that has a sliding scale of difficulty as the game grows.  I think that is what makes it work for families and non-gamers.  It is also nice that you only play with 10 kingdom cards so you don't have too much to look at or remember.  There is a level of complexity as the action cards start to build upon one another, but with a few games played it will certainly get easier.

I think my favorite aspect is the slow build over the course of the game.  You start with so little, struggling to afford even the cheapest cards, but then you build up your deck and will play a whole chain of cards that allow you to purchase something much bigger.  It is cool to see new players discover this aspect as they complain about drawing no treasure cards and then play one action card after another and end up with enough to buy a Province.  My biggest complaint is that the game advertises itself as taking only 30 minutes, but usually takes us 3 times that.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A 7 with expansions, but if you're dropping $100 for a game and 3 quality expansions, it should be good.  The game does have a number of things I dislike about it, though.

I do think the game plays much more smoothly online - which is one mark against it.

Another is that the game quality depends on the set of cards available in the pool, so you may want to discard cards from the set which seem useless.  Some sets of cards are better than others, leading to more (or less) interesting games based on selection.  It's not that uncommon for 3 or 4 of the 10 piles in the game to be ignored.  Additionally, some games can become very "degenerate" with certain combos.

I think I like the game best with 2 or 3 players and without cards that slow the game down, such as cards which encourage drawing lots of cards, so you can draw more cards, so you can draw more cards....

Finally, sometimes it feels like the game is just playing itself.  You've made the initial choices, now you just have to see what you're dealt, and depending on what you have in hand, you know what you're going to do.

In some games, each player follows the same strategy and several cards are ignored.  It always feels ridiculous when me and another player are pursuing the exact same strategy! Or maybe the exact same strategy with the only thing to separate the two of us is the purchase of a single card.  While Dominion is a fun game to play and lots of replayability (with expansions), it will never be as great as a carefully designed game.  The set-up is simply too random.

RATING: N/A
