=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Having now played a bunch of the highest rated deckbuilders around, I feel confident in stating that Dominion is the KING of deckbuilders. It is the purest, the most skill based and quite simply the best of the deckbuilders. The randomness in generating a kingdom of 10 cards ensures endless replay value (particularly if you expand the game). The fixed 10 kingdom cards ensures a level of strategy impossible in games like Star Realms and Ascension, which are far more random and luck based due to new cards appearing constantly (I do like those games, but they are not Dominion). 

I feel the urge to deal with some of the criticism often levelled at Dominion:

Criticism #1: Dominion is really played before the game even starts.
Reply: I feel strongly that this criticism is misguided. Yes, you do need to pick a strategy before the game even starts, but in executing that strategy there are a LOT of important tactical decisions like which order you purchase your cards in, when to trigger a shuffle, when to "go green", how to repond to opponents plays, etc. Strategy and tactics are both important in this game.

Criticism #2: The game has no theme.
Reply: This is true. Whether it bothers you or not is a personal decision. Personally, I would hate to ignore an awesome game because of a lack of theme.

Criticism #3: Big money strategies kills the game.
Reply: The strategy known as "big money ultimate" is indeed very boring, but also very bad. Yes, it will often beat the "buy one of every card" strategy, often favoured by newbies, but it will lose to any even halfway decent strategy. Various "Big Money-X" (where you supplement the Big Money strategy with a single type of action card) strategies CAN sometimes be the best strategy. For instance, on some base set boards, "Smithy-Big Money" where you buy a couple of Smithies and no other action cards, is quite strong. Still, an optimal "Engine" that beats Big Money-X can be found on the vast majority of boards - read this for instance: http://dominionstrategy.com/2012/07/30/building-the-first-game-engine/ - learning how to build "engines" is really the heart and soul of this game, IMO - even though sometimes you have to recognize if a BM-X strategy is the best on a given board. Read this: http://dominionstrategy.com/2013/01/21/the-five-fundamental-deck-types-introduction/

Criticism #4: At some point in the game you know that player X will win.
Reply: This is indeed true in some games. Thankfully will usually be over very soon when this becomes apparent.

Criticism #5: The game is multi player solitaire.
Reply: While not completely misguided, you DO have to take notice and respons to what your opponent is doing - not only when playing interactive cards like attack-cards, but also in terms of greening (buying victory point cards).


It has to be said, though, that while this base game is great on its own, it only REALLY gets into its own when you add at least one expansion to it. Basically, you want as many of the expansions as you can justify to buy. I've now bought them all, but you don't necessarily need that. Advice for players looking for expansions: Get Prosperity and Seaside. When you find yourself needing more, get whatever piques your interest, the expansions are all good, although I like Alchemy and Hinterlands the least.

If you're on the fence about this game, go try it out at www.goko.com where you can play the base game for free. Be warned though - it is highly addictive. If you're looking for strategy tips, go to www.dominionstrategy.com. There are a ton of people out there who have played thousands and thousands of games of this - that's how addictive and fascinating a game it is.

I'll track all plays of this as plays with the main game, regardless of how many expansions are added - unless I play only with a certain expansion.

I'm only tracking IRL games of this. I have played a ton of games online of this.

The rating is for the "full" game of Dominion including expansions. I have rated the expansions as well as stand alone supplements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I loved Magic: The Gathering when I was younger, but got out due to the ridiculous financial investment it required.  My favourite part of M:tG was booster drafts - take some random packs of cards, everybody takes turns picking cards out of the deck, in order to try and build the Best Deck Possible.  It didn't matter how many hundreds/thousands you had invested in your collection, everyone was on an equal footing.  It cost me about $15 any time we wanted to have a booster draft, but the gaming enjoyment was something I never thought would be equaled.

I thought I gave up those good times when I got out of magic ten years ago.

And then there was Dominion.

Now I can booster draft as much as I want, for only a one-time investment.  And unlike the ridiculous rules barrier in Magic, I can explain this game to anyone in ten minutes.  Unlike the huge time restrictions in running a booster tournament, this plays in 15-30 minutes.

Every single time I get together with my gaming buddies, the first game I suggest is Dominon.  A year and a half later, that still hasn't changed.  This is the absolute pinnacle of card drafting games.  It's changing the industry and I couldn't be happier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
What I really love about Dominion is the variability that keeps it fresh and begs for experimentation to try new strategies depending on available cards. I love that it is easily accessible for newcomers with a lot of strategic depth, particularly through some of the expansions. The deckbuilding is brilliant as a gameplay mechanic, and it has been endlessly copied due to Dominion's popularity.

Now for negatives. I think the base game is the weakest set I own. I think it's overly bland without enough room for interesting card interaction. The expansions make a world of difference and really allow the game to shine. I particularly like Seaside Dark Ages. Not necessarily a negative, but certainly not a plus is that sometimes an entire card stack might be ignored if nobody thinks it will be strategically valuable. Another negative I have is the lack of player interaction, but each turn plays so lightning fast that isn't too much of an issue. When you do have interaction it is often through an attack card, which can sometimes (admittedly rarely in my experience) be overly harsh and nasty.

At the end of the day, I love to play Dominion without overthinking it and chit chat while doing so. It's more of a social experience for me than a highly strategic and tactical one. It helps that turns are lightning fast, the gameplay is simple but the cards can be strategically deep, and not having to pay too much attention is one slight benefit of the mostly multiplayer solitaire nature of it.

[i]EDIT:  rating assumes use of expansions[/i]

RATING: 7
After 2 plays, I'm not overly impressed.  The game mechanic is interesting, but our 2 plays with the suggested starter set felt unfocused.  By the end of our second game we had a good idea of what kind of deck we should be going for, but didn't see any purpose to it.  You're really completely ignoring the other guy, and your play mostly comes out of what 5 cards you draw for each turn.

We will try a few other deck combos before giving it up.

Update: played a few more times, and once with the expansion deck.  This is a pretty good, if over-hyped, game.  The key is to not over-think it.  The game itself is hardly more than a filler, and if you take it as such, it's pretty enjoyable.  I don't know if dozens of expansions are really necessary.  I might get Seaside and call it a set.

RATING: 7
Interesting game mechanic, quick play time, fun.  It can get repetitive after too many plays, but expansions alleviate that problem.

It is possible to analyze until your eyes bleed to eke out tiny statistical advantages, but that has a very low reward to time spent ratio.  It's best if you try not to take this too seriously (as with most high-variance games) and treat it as just really good filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I must admit I was put off by all the hype but, having finally played it, I can say that this is a really great game. It is not really deck-building in the MtG sense, but more like a classic euro-game in card form (with a little added randomness). You have to be careful to build a balanced deck whilst making the most of any opportunities presented and all the while racking up VPs, needs finesse. Very quick to play as well. Will certainly be looking to get more plays in.

Added: After 8 plays rated down a little because the overall shape of the game doesn't feel right. It all seems to be decided in the first few rounds - say the first third - and luck plays a much greater part in that section than later on. After the first third, it is usually clear who is going to win or lose. A really great game needs to keep you biting your nails to the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Lost a little luster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I’m not a huge fan of the deck-building games as they all play the same: get some new cards, shuffle your deck, draw your hand and play it; repeat these actions endlessly.

Nonetheless, I reckon Dominion has been the first pushing this genre’s latest fashion, which means non-collectable, all-in-one-box card games with lots of expansions, and frankly it also plays like a solid game. Sadly though it’s nothing else than a multiplayer solitaire with no interaction among players at all: the frantic speed it’s usually played at witnesses it’s unimportant to wait and see what the other players are doing, since all you really have to do is to learn every card’s properties by heart in order to optimize the many possible combos, without even really playing the game. 

Anyhow, whenever it’s played with non-hardcore players, Dominion surprisingly turns out as a moderately enjoyable - yet boring - game. (November 2011)

[b]Update[/b] - After further playing the game and finding it more and more boring, in April 2013 I deemed it more suitable to lower my rating from 7 to 6.

RATING: 6
There is a reason why deckbuilders come and go and Dominion is still held in high regard.  It's simplicity is both it's blessing and it's curse.  While it lacks theme, the game cruises along at a lightning pace.  Trying to figure out the best combos among the random decks is always intriguing and everyone tends to have favorite cards.  Knowing when to bail on building your deck and going for VPs and ending the game gives each game a great sense of pacing.  I know people claim other deckbuilders have killed Dominion, but the rumors of it's demise have been greatly exaggerated.

RATING: 9.25
I liked it better as the game went on. Learning new cards each time, while keeping the game fresh, will annoy me until I know them all. Not sure I'll ever play it that many times to learn them, though. It was definitely interesting. The game ended sooner that we'd expected, because someone told us as we were playing that the -1 cards count as a pile that can run out for the end condition. We didn't know that--thought it was just the action cards--and so we were suddenly in the end game instead of the mid-game.

UPDATE: Played two more time. I really, really like it now. Each game is so different because of the combo of cards, and I'm much faster to figure out what they all are now. Can't wait to play again.

RATING: 6.5
This game is an instant classic. The first time you play it you are so excited by the mechanic, which is so neatly executed. The base game has such solidly designed cards and a lot of replayability.

I am unsure of whether to give this an 8 or a 9. I'm a little Dominioned-out at this point, which is why the rating is a little lower than it once was.

RATING: 10
A very cool building game.  It was better than I expected.  It also gets tense if you watch what and when people are buying the point cards.  Looking forward to playing this one again.  Upped rating by one as I have now played with two and played three games in an evening.  You can play it at a breakneck speed to crank through games, you can play it leisurly and chat while you play.  Still lots of fun and still very interesting.

Update-March 09 - Raised to a 9.  Have recently been doing random decks and found I prefer that.  It makes you think about how the combo's will work and how each game will play out differently.  Really a good game.

Update-Feb 10 - It's now a 10.  I haven't tired of it in the least.  It's a game you can bust out 3-4 different games in one sitting with all feeling different from each other.  It's also a game you can play fast, or leisurly without it becoming a drag.  It has reached the ranks of classic for me and has earned it's 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After playing a few times I am slowly coming to the conclusion that Dominion is perhaps playing itself too much. Each player's strategy will be fairly obvious and easy to copy without much penalty at that. Particularly two-player games tend to be very even in score regardless of who is doing all the 'work'. With a few unfortunate rounds it is easy to be overtaken in the strategy you developed yourself.

Most of the time, though, the game is intriguing and rewarding. Deckbuilding is simply fun!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dominion wore out it's welcome fairly quickly for this type of game.  I think the main thing is that the tactics of playing a hand are so rote that the only interesting thing is creating a strategy.

This would not be dealbreaker, except that the vaunted variability of the setups is far less than it appears.  A number of cards are pretty terrible or of very limited use.  On the other spectrum, certain cards/combinations dominate any setup in which they come out.  Stuff like Witches and Workshop/Garden.  Assuming relatively experienced players, their analysis will likely be similar and it would seem that card draws might be the deciding factor.

I only wish there were more pressure to adapt your deck to your opponent's.  As it is, there aren't many attack cards or strategies that require an overt response from a player.

Expansion cards could shore up these weaknesses, but I haven't heard them spoken about with too much fondeness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A very versatile game that's easy to teach non-gamers.  Each game can play drastically differently depending on the cards laid out in the supply pile.  One aspect of this game that I don't like (that some people love) is the opportunity to string together long combos that that essentially allow a player to play his/her entire deck.  Turn length increase dramatically and I find that the game generally overstays its welcome after that.  This can be completely avoided by limiting the number of "+action" cards at the setup of the game.

RATING: 7
I get that this one is a classic. The pioneer deckbuilding game. I appreciate that and I understand it should be and was very popular in its time. I don't get why it still is. The deckbuilding evolved and there are so many twists to it. So many interesting games with this mechanic. And this one is just boring to me. Most time is spent waiting or shuffling. The concept is great and there is a lot of strategy involved for sure. The interaction between players is indirect and it feels more like solitaire to me. Maybe expansions change it but with so many good deckbuilders I don’t think I want to waste time to see.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The base mechanism has some promise, for a light-hearted, laughter-filled game. However, there isn't much game to go with it in here. You just look at the available kingdom cards, decide what combination you're going for and the rest is just a matter of timing.

Like mentioned in a review, the game can be summed up in 3 steps:

a) if you have 8 coins or more, buy Province
b) if less then 8 but more then 6, buy Gold
c) if less then 6, buy silver or a card that is better then silver, most commonly one that will net more cards in your hand.

There are some variations to it (garden decks, chapel decks), but it's just not interesting enough to hold my interest.

It's not enjoyable (I don't have fun) and not interesting (It doesn't make me think in new ways)

After a third match, I'm not playing this again. Maybe with future expansions they'll twist the game enough to become interesting, but I doubt it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This would have been a 9.5 or 10 if it had more direct player interaction in the base set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My first re-entry into board gaming along with Heroscape.  Really fun game the first several plays.  Not fun enough for me to play it anymore or invest in the expansions.  Appreciate that it created a genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very clever card game of VP collection, using cash cards to buy cards to give you more cash and actions and then finally using the cash cards to buy VP cards, all based around a deck which you have to build and manage. More VP cards dilutes your deck, so timing is critical.

There are quite a lot of different types of cards which are mix-and-matched to form the cards in a particular game, hence giving Dominion oodles of replayability. You can build up some pretty good combo's but you have to get them in to your hand at the same time and that's the hard part!

Much more appealing to me than Race for the Galaxy, so I reckon that it should do pretty well!

RATING: 6
It's been said that this game is an original, engaging mechanic in search of a theme and that seems fair. For players who obsess over reaching constantly for the mathematical ideal of optimal play, Dominion is the near perfect game with a clever, elegant system. I'm just not that player. I'm not convinced either that the game has been created yet which is the best vehicle for this game engine (Thunderstone is still not it for me). I can respect the game that Dominion is and understand its deserved popularity, but I play games to enjoy the elements (theme, immersion, narrative) that Dominion just doesn't seek to offer.

RATING: 10
I know that is a bold rating, but here's why I don't think any other game will rival my affection for this game. Not only is the game well balanced, has a great sense of variety, and easy to teach new players while maintaining a great depth of strategy, the value of the game not rivaled by many others is its speed.

If I can play a game 6 times in a night vs. one three hour session of Battlestar Galactica, I'm going to take the game I can play fast. If you're bored or losing, it's not long before you can try a different strategy or a different activity altogether.

Rocket power pacing, gentlemen, is the key to a superlative gaming experience.

RATING: 9

I use everything from the base set to all the expansions, depending on who I play with.  I don't think the expansions make things better or worse; the cards all start to blur into each other after a while and I'm not sure that's a good thing, but variety is always nice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A nice easy game to learn, but with a lot of depth and replayability due to the interaction between the kingdom cards.  I generally don't want to play it more than twice in a single sitting, but I'm willing to pull it out to start or end off an evening of gaming if nothing better is available.

After 20 plays the shine has really worn off of Dominion.  Yes, the large number of kingdom cards appears to give an almost limitless amount of variety... except for the fact that the game really boils down to the same few things.  Pick a strategy based on the cards in the pool.  Execute it.  Oh, and shuffle until your hands cramp and the skin wears off your fingers.  I understand that there are a few viable strategies available, but it really boils down to being lucky and getting your strategy going before your opponent does (assuming equally skilled players).  I really, really enjoyed this at first, but now I find the game to be tedious and I'd prefer to play many, many other games over this one.  Dropping to a 6.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
15 plays:

A solid and accessible game that feels bland and limited. I love the fundamental game mechanic of deck drafting and altering that draft. But the ways of altering the drafting and gameplay feel dry and administrative rather than inspiring and fun. 

Partly this is due to the theme adding nothing. The art is so lackluster I feel reluctant to recommend the game, because I wonder if other families will take one look at the cards and put the box back on the shelf.

Partly it's due to the minimal player interaction; there are even enough of each type of card for everyone, which means you can't screw each other over. 

But most fundamentally, it's because there is so little anticipation in the gameplay experience. 

There's no "I have this amazing card coming up, can I use it on him in time to cancel his powers and snatch victory?" There's only "I've run my hand responsibly with such and such strategy, let's see how it did." 

That's not an impossible mechanic to pull off -- 7 Wonders, a very similar game in some ways, manages to provide a sense of milestones and increased stakes and at least defensive interaction via taking a card another player wants.

The expansions open the game up somewhat, but not as much as I'd like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2pl 3pl
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First play - December 2008.  Bought January or February 2009, bought second copy around June or July 2009.

My favorite game, and it has been pretty much since I was introduced to it back in 2008.  The only thing significant that I would change is my opportunities to play; they must be increased!

I love the high modularity of Dominion and its expansions.  I love the basic deck building concept of fighting against the inherent randomness of a shuffled deck of cards by controlling what the contents of the deck are and the immediate feedback of what is working and what isn't by way of the repeated shuffles and draws.  I appreciate the relatively light rule set with the relatively deep tactical opportunities.  I appreciate that the game gives me a sense of creativity through competition.

Ideal at three players, terrific with only two, still pretty good at four.  I recommend not playing with five nor six.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Dominion.  Played it more than any other game (because of playing online).  The game is well balanced and requires rethinking of strategy with each game based on the deck given.  There is always a strategy, you just have to figure it out and stick to it.
Negatives:  The game has luck with how your cards are shuffled, but that luck will rarely ever negate one strong player versus another player that does not understand how to find a strategy.  It is hard to get the game to the table with players who are not interested in breaking down the cards to find a strategy.
Someone who has figured out some strategies can truly dominate the game.  I always take 1-3 curses in place of starting coppers when playing against people in person.

Rating has dropped due to monotony over time, but this was played more than any other game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Drawn into game again. Surprised to find I enjoyed the game more than I expected (which wasn't much). I think, in my case, the card mix has a lot to do with how I enjoy the game that results. The game length is very sensitive to this. This game plays best when it doesn't overstay its welcome - it just doesn't have the depth to sustain a lengthy session (and don't ever play with more than four - maybe even three). Maybe the thing is to only play it once in a while to bring back some of the freshness it originally presented, and find a drafting mechanism that works well. I have stuck with the base game (although I would happily trade it) - and I'm super glad I didn't get any of the expansions while my enthusiasm was still fairly high (at least I trusted my instincts that far)...
______
Argghh! I knew it! I wish I would give more weight to my first instincts. I have lost much of the interest I had in this game. It turns out that the most interesting part of this game is the initial "stack draft," after which the game devolves into a dull, repetitive chore. Thing is, I knew that it would. Oh well...
______
Despite what I'm reading, I'm seeing that games are lasting considerably longer than I would expect given the essentially simple repetitive nature of the actual play. Shuffle, deal, play and buy cards, shuffle, re-deal, play then buy cards again, rinse and repeat - many, many times. I'm having serious doubts that this will continue to keep my attention for the length of time it takes to play. I had hoped this would be among the arsenal of "filler games" I like to have on hand, but it is far too long for a filler and lacks the "heft" of a main game. So, still with the reservations (preliminary rating trending downwards)...
______
Despite some reservations and skepticism about this highly hyped game, I finally got to play it and experienced the enthusiasm first time players seem to exhibit (I was surprised to find the deck building exercise could be as engrossing as it was). There is an addictive aspect to the game that simply has to be experienced to understand. What I'm not so sure of is whether the replayability and staying power is going to be there over the long haul. The durability of the cards is a concern and I'm going to try and sleeve the most commonly used ones - if the tray will still hold them!? This could well be a game that will wear out its welcome eventually. But so far, it has my attention!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Provisional rating - might alter if/when I play more. I was expecting something much more 'wow' given all the hype and the way others were raving about it.

Mechanic of build your deck by drafting is really novel and has potential [Game gets an extra point for this alone] - but I feel it is a bit of a lost opportunity. 

Game play was dull and repetitious, and the decisions not all that agonising, and the shuffling - ugh, expect to shuffle your cards a lot in this game. Play some cards, ditch the rest, draw, then shuffle, repeat ...

Much prefer race for the galaxy as a super fast filler, and I really didn't get the "must play again now ..." feeling, certainly wouldn't want to spend an evening playing this over and over and over. 

Need to try with less players, maybe with less the game shines? Wasn't enthused enough to want to get my own copy (even in trade), many other games I'd rather play. Could have been the combination of cards used, it might be better with all of them in but less - so then there is pressure to grab the bits you need for your engine and you have freedom to try whatever you like, rather than be limited to a subset.

Thinking about it, I'm sure a computer implementation would be 100% better - faster to play & no physical shuffling required.

*** Update
Played more (as everyone else seems to think it is the best game ever ...) and rating has dropped. I find the game dull - there is an initial bit of thought when you see the card pool at the start, but after that it is all fairly obvious - draw, buy, shuffle, repeat. Trick is deciding at what point to stop developing your deck and switch to vp gathering.

Clever mechanics, but paper thin theme and very little interaction (even with the 'nasty' cards that some players refuse to use!) leaves me uninspired. Just hope the cult of the new will kick in and people will want to play something else.

**** Update
Continues to be flavour of the month with most (and an expansion to add more 'must play') and my rating has dropped further, now at the point I'll actively look for something else to play, or even just drop out and go home rather than play this again (and again and again) ... 

Maybe I'm missing something, but I've managed to do so in all the games I've played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The aim of the game is to build a good deck so that in the final rounds you can buy as much victory points as possible.  Therefore, you need to keep a strategy in mind along the game.  However there is a bit of luck involved since the cards in hand are picked up at random from the pile you bought during the game.  well...this description might sound confusing but the game really isn't :) it is straight forward,you have various options to change the decks  so it won t get boring, and the element of luck involved is still structured around the deck of cards that you built so no big surprises there.  It should be fast paced but my first game took at least 1.5hrs (we played it as a 2 player game so  maybe that s why) 
Score: 5/5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An innovative deck-building game.
Play one or more cards form your hand, buy one or more open cards (shuffle) draw 5 cards. That’s the whole game. There are 3 type of cards: Actions cards which give you new actions, VP cards or money. Money is the second type of cards, as with the money in your hand you will pay. The last type is vp cards, which are useless during the game and block your hand but in the end only this cards will be counted. Dominion has an easy and addictive concept, which works very smooth. With 24 action cards, from which 10 will only be used, there will be a lot of variation. A game can be as short as 15 min but can also take until 45 to rare 60 min.

With just the base game and Intrigue I get the feeling we'll have enough to hold us for a long time to come.

RATING: 8.8
Ton of fun.   But thing to note, there is no theme to the game.   In fact, the pictures on the cards are not even necessary. 

But if you want a straight forward game, that you can spit out in 30 mins.   This is a great choice.

This is the original deck builder.   For me it is still one of the better ones.   And I love that designers have used this platform to make deck building a mechanic that you find in more complex games, and not just that game itself.  

But if you like a more simple deckbuilder with a tremendous amount of variance (because of how many different decks), Dominion and its expansions are excellent.

RATING: 6
This game is a blast!!  However, playing with the right group of people makes a big difference.  My first five plays were about 30 minutes each.   Then I played with my brother-in-law and nephew and that play took over an hour.  It was still fun but it moved alot slower (almost too slow).  I'm hoping that as they start playing it more, it will move quicker but we'll see.  To me one of the biggest pluses of this game is the fact that it is quick.  That said, it is a greta dynamic, never gets repetitive (since the different card mix keeps driving different tactics), has luck and skill.  It even has a bit of long-term strategy as you may try to plan what your deck will look like before you start.

RATING: 8.5
The gold standard for deckbuilding games. The base game alone offers a lot of variety and complex interactions, and defines the mechanics you need for the rest of the expansions.
A great card game overall, but as you add more and more expansions, the game gets to be quite a chore to drag out and setup to play. My group has a house rule that if we bust out Dominion, we are playing at least three games, because setting up the required cards can be time consuming.
That said, nobody ever complains when we want to play three games of this...

RATING: 5
I just don't really find Dominion fun. Part of the issue might be that most cards in the base set are rather bland; I'm sure it's a much livelier and richer game with expansions thrown in. 

My core problem with Dominion, though, is that it feels like a solitaire game. The amount of interaction with your opponents is just not high enough for me. I get bored.

The deck-building mechanics in this game are really clever. I can see how why the design has won so much praise. But while I can intellectually appreciate what the designers accomplished, when I actually play Dominion, I just don't find any joy in it.

RATING: 5
This is definitely a good game, but I'm not all that sure it's quite as deserving of its high praise here on the Geek.  I'm not massively keen on the overly tactical, rather than strategic play, demanded by having a new hand of cards every round -- and all the deck shuffling upsets my over-protective sensibilities; I just worry about the cards getting too worn too quickly.  However, once past those concerns, the game does shine, and there's a real joy from getting that perfect hand come up, the one you'd slavishly drafted for.

RATING: 5
2-4 | (3) | 30 | 8+ | Donald X. Vaccarino
Supposedly, the best thing about Dominion is that after finishing a game, you want to play again immediately. In my case, however, Dominion falls flat. I feel like the whole game lasts 30 seconds, the time required to see the available kingdom cards and decide how you plan to win the game. After that, it is just a matter of going through the motions. While I appreciate its innovative design, I'd rather play Race for the Galaxy or Magic the Gatering instead, two card games before which Dominion simply pales. 
--------------------------------------
Update: playing Dominion online is way more enjoyable than face to face, since shuffling is automated. I think Dominion is a 6 or even a 7 when played online.

RATING: 6
Full Disclosure - I am not one of the engineers that pre-determined this game to be in the Top Ten.

Yes, it's got some originality. But a whole lot of card shuffling. Stack your deck full of money cards and load up on veep cards. Multi-player solitary card shuffling. This is not the second coming. And this is certainly over-hyped. 

Its virtue? Its vacuousness only lasts 30 minutes.

#6 highest rated game of all time? Puh-leeze.

Update March 2012: this really is a meh game. No matter what expansion or decks you mix in - it's the same strategy. Build up a small deck or get actions that let you get draw cards. Put lots of money into your deck. Then start buying VPs.

RATING: 7
46 plays.  Closing in on 50 plays.  I still like Dominion and have never seen the need to get any of the expansions.  It helps that a lot of people I know also know how to play this, so it's easy to pull out.  I think 7 Wonders is a better game with similar features, but I think Dominion will continue to be played semi-regularly for years to come.  Looking forward to teaching it to my kids. 

This is quick and easy, and most everyone who's tried it likes it, and for that reason it gets played a lot.  I tend to enjoy it while I'm playing, but don't find myself relishing the idea much beforehand.  Not sure why that is; I think it's that I'd rather play some meatier games but I do enjoy this once I get into it.  I have no doubt it'll be a staple of game nights for years to come.

After playing Intrigue, I don't see the need to get it.  I don't like the length it adds to the game while you're trying to figure out how best to use your multi-ability card.  Ditto with Seaside.  I will definitely look into any small-format expansions that get released, but I don't think I'll (over)play Dominion enough to warrant any of the expensive, big box expansions.

RATING: 10
I love deckbuilding, and Dominion is still the best deckbuilding game that I've played so far (e.g. it's deeper, more elegant and less luck-based than, for example, Thunderstone or Ascension.)

It's really fun to think about all the Kingdom cards and to try different strategies with them. It's true that the game feels a bit multiplayer solitaire, and can be played almost in autopilot. But it actually isn't multiplayer solitaire, if you want to play well. You have to pay attention to what the other players buy, and how far the game has progresses, and you need to adjust your buys accordingly.

The base set is a bit low on interaction, otherwise solid.

RATING: 4
It's not absolutely awful. I'll give it that.

What it *IS*, though, is a maze with one possible entrance and one possible exit. Many might argue that the variety in cards and the potential combos give Dominion incredible replay value, but a conscientious gamer will simply sit in front of any given card selection for about 5 minutes, figure out the optimal combination and stick to it until the game ends.

Perhaps this is the game for you if you plan to play with a somewhat disinterested friend, or with a happy-go-lucky gamer who is not so concerned with winning. That is not the case for me -and within my gaming circles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion was my very first deck builder experience so it has that nostalgia factor that keeps me from rating it lower. I really enjoy it every time that I play it, but I find that over time it has come out to play less and less frequently. This is due mainly to its static nature. Even with a ton of expansions it still gets stale after awhile and begins to feel kind of pointless. It's fun, but it's not as fun as it once was.

RATING: 5

sleeved

Dominion was my first true and "nothing but deckbuilding" game. I owned MageKnight before but I had to try a game that doesn't do anything but deckbuilding, so I bought a used copy of Dominion.
I didn't regret it. It is a nice filler game that flows very well. Lots of choices, lots of strategies.

But at some point it might reach a state where it becomes boring.
Therefore I like Arctic Scavengers (which came out at the same time) or other deckbuilders much more but I understand why Dominion is such a success.

RATING: 10
I do think this is a solid game though, and quite enjoyable.  However, everyone seems gaga over this one and I don't really understand it.  It's a little too solitaire for me I think.

Update June 2011:  I sort of got burned out on this game after the original, and didnt really revisit it until now.   I've got to say, it's far more interesting with all these new expansions and in the fun ways that they all interact with one another in random setups.   This sort of replayability is something the original Dominion was missing, and I have found a new appreciation for the game.

Rating up to a 9.

Update Aug 2011:

Rating upped to a 10.  This is the first game that I had initially rated poorly (6 in this case) that turned into a 10.   

Having played a hundred or so games online now, I'm struck with how even after a ton of plays new strategies and considerations can come into play depending on the random card selection.

Now it's important to note that without the expansions, I'd rate Dominion a 7.   But with all the expansions and random setups, this becomes a 10.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I first heard about [b]Dominion[/b] and the description of how it was played I was a little confused on the mechanics.  It's a game that is a bit hard to explain without actually sitting down to play.  But once you play it it is easy to understand.  

It is a card game where you build custom decks out of a common pool of cards.  It's not a collectible card game, and the actual building of the decks is a key mechanic of the game itself.  It is a very clever design that has already inspired many new games with their own similar deck building mechanics.

The one thing I don't like about the game is that there a very little interaction between the players.  Most of the cards don't affect your opponents at all.  It's the limited numbers of each card where the most interaction occurs.  Most games have a "multi-player solitaire" feel to them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another mechanism that is new to me- this time, deck building. Very fast to play and learn. Needs lots of shuffling - card protectors seem like a very good idea.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ahh, Dominion.  Another game that took me a long time to get worked up over - or, if not worked up, at least convince myself I needed to have.  Why?  Well, there is my longstanding dissatisfaction with most card games, coupled with the incredibly over-the-top amount of fanboy love showered during the initial months it was out.  Plus all that damn shuffling!  As someone who hates riffle-shuffles ('cause I suck at the technique, and hate the wear on the cards) the amount of shuffling was definitely a turn-off.  But with so much hype, there was no way to avoid getting it, right?  So we got it.

It is a very good game.  In fact, it definitely deserves all the accolades it has received.  All the cards are useful, given the right combination, even if some don't seem so at first.  What I like most about the game is the post-mortem aspect of it - at the end of the game, you can spread your deck out, and SEE the whole game at a glance.  It helps analysis and building strategy immensely.  The design is fresh, and really deserves the SdJ.  Plus, it does justify expansions.  Not millions of them, but I can already see how Intrigue could add a lot, as some cards are a bit boring for my taste.  Overall, though, it still lacks just a little spark for me - it is a game I admire more than desire.  I love playing it, but rarely suggest it, and can't bring myself to play more than twice in a row.  And all that shuffling?  I actually like it, in a Zen sort of way.  I don't do a riffle shuffle, but usually a pile-shuffle, and the down time actually helps the game to flow better for me, as I am no fan of games where everyone is playing fast and furious, to the point where I can't tell or care what anyone else is doing.  The shuffling makes our games more like 30 min rather than 20, but that's fine by me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is a great, and quite possibly the first deckbuilder. It's an interesting mechanic, and the game itself has tonnes of variety. Excellent game, have thoroughly enjoyed playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent game, especially for former CCGers who want that feel again without having to invest a bajillion dollars in cards, just to lose to the guy who invested 2 bajillion dollars.

This has quickly become a new favorite of the group, especially because of its speed, and its ability to work well for only 2 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I really hated this game the first time I played: everyone at the table was just silently taking their turns, and I felt that I would rather just play alone (or not play at all). When the game abruptly ended, it seemed totally arbitrary and I felt as though it didn't matter that there were other players there.

After a few more plays, I like it more, but still feel that the game is too short and desperately needs more player interaction. I'm considering buying Intrigue just to add more "take that" elements to the game. 

Oh yeah: set-up and clean-up are also a pain, and man oh man, all that shuffling...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The second coming.. this ain't.  Lots of shuffling and low on interaction.. really low.  I think you could all be in separate rooms, play the game on your own, and come back to see what the best score was.

I'm looking forward to trying the published edition.  I'm hoping I'll see something in it that I didn't before.. as I'm sure it will see some play in my local group.

Update: I've tried the published edition.. it's exactly what I remembered.. multi-player solitaire.  Ah well.  It's fun to build up your deck and mess around, but it's not really a game.. because there's so little interaction.  Still, I do find myself wanting to play with it and optimize... but it still feels like it's more a puzzle than anything.

Second Update:  I think I've figured out what it is.  I love the deck building mechanic, but the game that you play with this mechanic is rather lackluster.  It's plays so quickly that I'm willing to play it whenever right now, I'm just hoping something else will "click", though my hopes aren't high.

Third update: I've raised it to an 8.  I don't think it's climbing any higher.. and I suspect it will actually fall eventually.  It's fun, and I want to play it a lot right now, but I think the depth only goes as far as the expansions do.. and I'm not sure I'm willing to spend that much on a game if they keep churning out expansions.  I was already burned by the RftG expansion being 18 cards and retailing for $25, I'm not sure I want more of the same with this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't have many games that I rate a "10".  I also have yet to rate a game a "10" right out of the box.  I want to play it several times before I decide to rate it "perfect".  I will say that Dominion probably had the shortest path to a "10" out of any game I own.  The more I play it, the more I see the subtlety of the game.  I love how changeable it is (by switching Kingdom cards) and how it affects your strategy from game to game.  This deserves a "10".

RATING: 7
My wife actually ENJOYS this game! That fact alone puts it in the top tier of my collection.

EDIT: I unleashed this on the game group last night and they ate it up! Four games in a row, and they wanted a fifth game but it was 2am and I had to go home. This game gets bumped to a 10.

EDIT 2: I've introduced this game to several more non-gamers and they've all loved it. This game would get an 11, if I could do so.

05/07/09: The game is getting knocked down to a 9 for now. I still love the game, but it's getting less table time nowadays, and a new 10 has emerged for me (CoH). Perhaps the upcoming Dominion expansion will put it back at the top.

09/06/11: Knocking this down to an 8. Even with some expansions, this game has largely played itself out with my group. 

01/25/12: Lowering to a 7, and it'll probably stay there. We're just not really playing this game anymore. It's still a good game, so I'll not move it down below 7, regardless of how little we play it in the future. The BGG description of a 7 ("Good Game. Usually willing to play") sums up my feelings pretty accurately.

Great design ideas, but there isn't even a spark of story or life in this game.  I'd rather not play a game at all than play this.  And the cards and shuffling are, sorry, a pain in the ass.

RATING: 9
The more I play this game, the more I like it. Getting a good hand is a great, great feeling. The only problem is that I don't have a regular playing partner. My fiancee hates the game (I have no idea why), and my brother visits infrequently and is at best lukewarm toward it.

UPDATE: I am enjoying this a bit less now. Gameplay is quite abstract, and feeling a bit too similar from play to play (though I have yet to try the expansions). Plus my fiancee still dislikes the game, is quite bad at it, and absolutely despises any of the interactive cards (e.g., the ones that force you to take Curses).

UPDATE: BSW has significantly upgraded my opinion. Even my wife (the former fiancee) likes this game quite a bit online. Playing online makes you realize how much or your FTF time is spent setting up, shuffling, etc.; BSW lets you just focus on building your deck. What's quite unusual is that I've won all but one game on BSW, but my wife still likes to play it! 

UPDATE: Ye of little faith. The expansions have really improved my opinion of this game, especially in BSW. I will play this any time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I came back to Dominion again recently after a long, Thunderstone-enforced break, and you know what really pissed me off? Why the hell did they use such a tiny f#!king font for the card powers?! They are impossible to read from any distance. There is tons of space on the card, and the geniuses who did the graphic layout went with like a 6-point font for everything. They should be fired. Rating reduced because the physical design so badly inhibits play, and because of RGG's stubborn refusal to fix multiple egregious, glaring problems of this kind despite several opportunities in the expansions.

With that out of the way, my biggest complaint about Dominion has loomed larger - too many combinations of cards yield entirely uninteresting games. Many sets simply devolve to buying as much cash as you can. Some devolve into pointlessness as cash is too easily destroyed and not enough money is generated and things take forever. In many, half the cards you should never, ever buy. There is an admittedly fairly large sweet spot where the card mix generates an interesting game, but like Agricola, the  diversity appears much greater than it actually is. The designer needed to spend more time on mechanisms to ensure reasonable card mixes and less on throwing every card idea he had at us. One non-Seaside Dominion set seems to work, but combine two, and it seems to go unstable too often.

A friend of mine commented that Thunderstone takes Dominion and makes a game out of it. I think that's strikingly true. I like Dominion; I just wish it were more stable and reliably produced better games and the physical design wasn't such a god-awful train wreck. I like Thunderstone (and Race for the Galaxy) much more.

FWIW, my favorite Dominion configuration is Intrigue stand-alone. I think the cards in Intrigue are more interesting and it usually produces a good game. The core set is probably the most reliably good game, but the cards are somewhat less interesting to me.
---
I still like Dominion, but it feels just a touch  undercooked to me. The Thief and Gardens seem to be game-changers in ways that don't quite feel satisfactory to me, and it seems like there aren't enough defensive cards. Some stuff feels slightly mispriced. I like the game quite a bit, but it doesn't have the same draw as Race for the Galaxy and is in very much the same space. Also, the completely AWOL theme is a bummer, as is the terrible graphic and communication design, both of which lend an air of amateurism to the whole thing, which isn't good.
---
I can't comment on Dominion without going into a slight usability rant. I think  they did a great job with the illustrations, but why, oh why, are gold cards not gold, silver silver, and copper copper? They are too hard to tell apart during play. Same comment goes for estates, etc. Also, they took a page out of the Magic book that they probably shouldn't have: one of the card's most important features, its cost, is a tiny icon. This should have been larger.

This is only a minor gripe, but it's unfortunate to compare the tremendous communication design of Race for the Galaxy's with the thoroughly mediocre design on Dominion, especially considering that Dominion has to convey vastly less information, and yet still can't reliably do it.
---
As I've played Dominion more I've come to enjoy it more. Still not convinced it's going to be a big long-term winner, but we'll see. I think a lot of the variety is somewhat illusory; not all combinations of cards is going to produce an interesting game, and there are certain "baseline" cards that'll have to be in almost any game, so like Agricola, what you see is more than what you actually get.

Still, it's been fun, the game has been more robust than I had expected and somewhat more flexible, and I look forward to logging a few plays on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A multiplayer race to solve and build the best probability engine. The attack cards make the race a bit more interactive. Update 1/6/12: Dominion has gotten a bit stale at this point, I think because I've played Magic again and remembered how much more diverse its game play is than Dominion's.

RATING: 8.4
Classic Deckbuilding. Many variations, strategy usually must adapt to the cards available. Reliance on ratios, card stacking and some luck. Rated down from 9 to 8 because there can sometimes be a 'clear path to victory' in some card combinations. This can be a very math-based, ratios game. Sometimes you will get very great, tense games, with 2 or more people employing completely different strategies.

RATING: 8
I was told that I probably wouldn't enjoy this game if I didn't really like CCGs.  Boy, was that person ever wrong!  This is an engine building game, a genre that I really love, and is certainly among the best of it's type that I've ever played.  The variety created by using a different set of 10 cards every game is really the icing on the cake, as the game completely changes based on the 10 available action cards.  A very innovative and great game!

However, after several plays of the base set I started to get stale on the original 25 cards.  However, that all changed with the expansions which is why I pushed my rating of Dominion down a tick, and raised ratings on the expansions.

RATING: 7.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Following the Seaside expansion, this has surpassed Race for the Galaxy in my eyes.  The added level of planning and added game length that many of the cards require (especially Embargo and Native Village) have turned this game from a race for money to buy Provinces into something approximating a light board game.

The variability of kingdom cards provides impressive replay value without sacrificing player control over the outcome.

I hate that the theme is pasted on (a deck is nothing like a functioning empire), but the game is blatant about the centrality of the mechanics, so it seems more forgivable here than in Race for the Galaxy. 

All-in-all, a fun, light, tactical game that I enjoy playing between longer board games.

RATING: 6
Dominion is a game that popularize a revolutionary mechanics of non-CCG deck building. Many fine games today would not exist if not for Dominion. However, it must be noted that the game itself is very theme light - its first of all a card manipulation game, that never really gives you a feeling that you are a ruler managing his realm. Artwork and card names seem forced onto card effect that rarely make logical connection in my mind. Interaction with other players can be severely limited, and there is sometimes too much shuffling, and too little actual playing - it gets a bit tedious after a while. The game also takes a while to play with 4 or more players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
There are an abundance of comments here that illustrate clearly why people like actual game play.  Here is why I rated Dominion a 9.5:

I bought Dominion Big Box over a year ago and finally got around to playing it this month.  I took it to a large family camping trip last week and ended up teaching 9 different people how to play it, ages 12-57.  The oldest people were women who feel most comfortable playing games like Yahtzee and Scrabble, and several others were primarily video gamers who are into games like Munchkin and Risk.  

They all absolutely loved Dominion.  In fact, they were fighting to play it. Even my mother-in-law was reluctant to give up her spot!  

These are my in-laws, and I've been camping with them for 15 years now.  This is the first year I have ever seen them all come together and truly enjoy a game across gender and age groups.  They have brought many games in the past, and I've brought things like Shadows over Camelot and Settlers.  

Admittedly, several of the non-gamers were nervous about playing when they saw the cards; they were overwhelmed at first.  However, I convinced them that it would be easy for them once they got started, and I was right.  

I highly recommend this game to just about anyone.  It definitely filled every niche in my family.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only 71 plays?
We must at least have played this one 100+ times.

When deckbuilding was something completely different and our daughter had learned to read in school this was practically the only game that hit the table for quite a while...

... and then came along Legendary - A Marvel Deck Building Game...

RATING: 8

RATING: 7
If played with gardens and witches it becomes a more interesting and dynamic game. I wish there were more attack cards in the basic game.  

It's super easy to learn so if you want to introduce friends to board game it could be a good start. Still, with the most exciting card being a witch that gives a curse there are so  many other games that have more humor on the cards. The cards look nice and are easy to handle which is necessary with all the shuffling going on in this game. 

There is quite a lot of luck in this game, but not as much as you would think. It's all about balancing your deck and buying the right cards at the right moment. If you think a bit about the statistics when buying cards you will have a deck that is a bit more useful.

RATING: 9.3
Innovative card game that plays quickly with so many paths to victory.  As soon as you pick up your first hand, the paths to success between you and the other players immediately diverge.  There are some nits to pick, like WTF is the Chancellor good for? and the certain card combinations that seem to break and/or delay the game (i.e. workshop/garden or village/smithy).  However, the game is amazing 95% of the time.  One of those games you can play back-to-back for hours without getting bored.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As a disclaimer, I generally hate games where you have to find the best card combos. They wind up serving people who want to play the same game endlessly. Great for them, but for me, this game just doesn't merit that kind of attention. 

Add this to my dislike for deckbuilding and naked solatairish engine building and this is just not a game for me. 

And I know a lot of people accuse games with subtle or low amounts of player interaction for having none at all, but this game truly borders on zero player interaction. Even the attack and defense cards seem to get played more for the additional coin/card/action bonuses attached to them. Otherwise you play your hand. No piggbacking ala RftG, no fight for cards/actions ala Goa/PoF. NOTHING.

The game lasts too long (I would say 45 minutes for people who have played less than 10 games) to stomach that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Dominion + all expansions we own: The cards have hit the table very often and already show signs of tear and wear!

We are moderately annoyed that the new german version (which uses, I think, the same cards as the english version) is incompatible with the old version! New expansions are only available for the new version!

Either way, we condensed the game into one box, but we are also not very likely to pull this game out again, as we have played it "to death" already! More likely, we are going to grab Guildhall, which is faster to setup and offers some interesting interactions between the players. Still, Dominion is one of the best (and least convoluted) deckbuilders out there!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[u]October 09:[/u] Laurène's newest craze, she just keeps wanting to play this one... Although I agree the gme is really fun and begs to be played over and over again, I'm already finding the first touches of lassitude after 20 games... I still have fun and it is so short that we can just get it out anytime so it will likely continue to get played for a long time, but I'm afraid replayability isn't as great as I thought...

[u]January 10:[/u] Got the expansion as Laurène wanted to play more and I was already tiring. We introduced several of my friends to the game, including some that had never played recent boardgames before, and it was a hot with everyone. However, the game is already not coming out much anymore. However, I think this is a game that you'll want to play over and over. Once the game comes out again, it will probably be played to death once more, then it will disappear for some more time then reappear and get played a lot, etc... For the moment, it's not getting played... [b]Downgraded the rating from 7.5 to 7.[/b]


[u]May 2014[/u]: I just realized why this game, despite being brilliantly executed does not work so well for us. We did liek the game while exploring the game space but now I realize that I never quite managed to get into a game of Dominion as I have been able to get into a game of RFTG for example. There are two reasons for this, the major one is that there is no immediate feedback on your actions. Every action you take won't really affect the state space until several rounds later. This could be great except that the state space never changes dramatically. Everything is continuous, there is no real sense of progression. The second reason is the fact that once you have made your choice of strategy early game, the implementation of it is rather straightforward. Sure, sometimes you'll have to adapt but I feel like this is rather rare. Overall, it almost seems like the players take one decision at the beginning of the game (which cards will I focus on) and then the game kind of plays itself until we know who the winner is...
Overall, I recognize that the design is great and very innovative and I have had great enjoyment of discovering the state space but it has always been more a polite liking than a passionate liking... whatever that means...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy, fun, replayable, excellent for 2 / 4 players. 

One of the best games that I have played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My first couple of plays were with 2 players, and I think it's more fun with more players as the attack cards start to shine, and I think one should always include a couple of attack cards so it doesn't feel too solitarish. 
I do, however, appreciate a game of Dominion with only 2 players and no attack cards now, but that certainly wasn't the case first time I played it. 

The downtime is minimal unless somebody reveals a killer combo of Villages combined with +X cards, but compared to many other games you don't have to think a lot during your turn as you can often only do a few different things.

There is luck involved (it's a card game after all), but it doesn't bother me at all as a superior strategy will win most/all of the times. And that's exactly one of Dominion's strengths: there are hundreds of strategies to pursue (with no broken strategy) and the games will never be the same because of the card shuffling and the 10 different kingdom cards you choose!

Also, my girlfriend and frankly everybody I play games with like it quite a lot, more than me, and if they suggest it I will gladly play it with them.

My personal recommended number of players: 2, 3, 4
Best with: 3

RATING: 9
*9* (100+ plays)
I have played this game over 100 times. lots of replay value and the game holds up its interest. Not to me mention there  are a ton of expansions and I think the game doesn't necessarily need all that's out there, but the expansions are there for vast amounts of variety. I'll only play this with 2 or 3 players, anymore and it suffers from lots of downtime. I still would like more player interaction because it feels more like solitaire. Even with all that said this is a great deck builder that won't go away. The combos and planning are amazing in this, probably some of the best card combos out there. I own the big box and that's enough to keep me entertained.

RATING: 7.5
Rec'd 2008 BGG Secret Santa

One of the better games of 2008 in my opinion.  The options are varied, and the replayability is unlike anything else because your usable cards are constantly evolving.  There is nothing here that needs fixed or adjusted to play - everyone plays with exactly what is there - no more and no less.

An excellent game, and one that my daughter likes, so I am sure it will get played frequently.

RATING: 8.86
(~50 plays)
This is one of the most innovative games I've seen in a long time.  It's deceptively simple once you play it once or twice.  It's not terribly interactive, but that's probably it's only fault.  Try to grab silver and gold when you can, especially gold.  Most winning decks are designed to get to 8 coins as fast as possible to start buying provinces.  It's possible to win in other ways, but not recommended for beginners.  Dominion Intrigue is a must expansion once you've played enough of the basic game.

RATING: 6.5
The original deckbuilder!  Dominion gets a lot of points for the great mechanic of using your deck to buy a card and then shuffle that card into your deck to draw later on.

When I first played this was a blast - lots of strategies and experimentation and close games.

However, some of the cards and strategies became clearly more powerful.  The chapel/big money strategy seems impossible to counter.  Also as the game has aged I would go to Thunderstone over this any-day because of the theme and deeper strategy.

**Had many plays before logging.

RATING: 10
Disclaimer: My comments are only based on BSW play of Dominion. Might be completely different when played with actual humans in the same room. BSW does take the shuffle and "housekeeping" out of the equation. For some players who have difficulty shuffling cards this might be a "deal breaker."

I like the fast paced nature of this game. With most sets and experienced players a game will last only about 30 min. Very simple to learn. I still hate the Witch.

Update: Played for "real" with game night friends. Everyone seemed to enjoy this card only game. Shuffling can get a bit tiresome but all-in-all a great game.

With the new expansions I LOVE this game family! I think it's my favorite 2 player game of all time!

Update to the Update: Total obsession! I LOVE all the expansions to this game...I think I will be collecting them for years to come.

RATING: 6
I have played this 3 times.  I like it, but the game is very dependent on the group and the array of cards in the market.  I can't shake the weak theme and the intensely solitaire nature of the game.  Look at the market, pick a strategy, execute, and cross your fingers that its better than what the other person is doing. At the end of the game, look up from your cards, compare strategies, and declare the victor.  

I think I need to play it more to get into the right mindset for this albeit very clever game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]Includes upgrade pack[/b]

The original deck-building game has proven to be possibly the ultimate "spouse game" that I play with my wife. And the funny thing is that I was resistant to Dominion at the start. Due to some sort of resistance to the Cult of the New and hype, I put off trying this game for quite some time until the thought struck me that my wife might like it.

Boy am I glad--I got the base game on the cheap, and my wife and I swiftly racked up 20+ plays, which of course led to the expansions. Dominion is swift, fun, and addictive. It definitely has that slot machine satisfaction of seeing your hand reload with the cards that you've picked up along the way. There's all sorts of combo goodness in a game of Dominion.

Are there any flaws? Sure... the game has virtually no theme. I recognize cards by what they do and not by what theme they convey, and I never even try to connect the dots between the two. That's about it though. The shuffling doesn't bother me. I've never tried playing the game with 5 players, and I imagine that might be a drag. But for 4 players and less, looking for something quick with a heck of a lot of replayability, this game has it in spades.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As smooth a deckbuilder as you can have with plenty of cards not just in the base but with the almost the dozen expansions out now give you plenty of opportunities to try out new and different cards each time. The attack cards bring some interaction to the game, but in some ways slow the game down a bit as you may have to wait for your opponent to finish shuffling before completing the action. If I didn't have Legendary I'd consider this, but now with the second edition maybe it's worth it still.

RATING: 7
A game based around deck building is a nice idea. It's a shame the gameplay itself is so repetitive and boring. The lack of interaction and the way the cards are just laid out in front of you makes me think that, like in CCG deckbuilding, there will be optimal picks. If there are known paths through, then replayability may not be so good. On the other hand, I can see it could be quite addictive. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One I think everyone that likes the idea of deck building games needs to play at some point.  No real theme, but this game can really teach you how to play that type of mechanic.

RATING: 8
Love this game. My brother in law introduced it to me and I liked it enough to buy my own copy. Now the whole family is addicted. I like the variety stemming from the use of 10 out of 25 possible Kingdom cards for each play. The rules and play turns are simple enough to make things flow quickly, yet the strategy is deceptively deep. 5-2016: Revised down a bit. Still really enjoy this game, but looking for deeper ones these days. It will remain in the collection though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Put this into a category of game I am more and more unenthusiastic about - efficiency engine card games with minimal player interaction. See: Race for the Galaxy, St. Petersburg, etc. While I appreciate the deck-tuning aspect of Dominion, I find the player interaction - both social and gameplay - to be minimal. While there is an element of pacing control, it is subtle at best. Meanwhile, the more 'aggressive' action cards are really just a simple min/max decision - and a relatively simple one at that - without having any really tactical or strategic importance. So, really, the enjoyment of the game comes down to getting your machine humming faster than the other guy's. And I do understand that enjoyment. I think of it as time trial compared to a road race. It is just not for me.

I should note that I still love San Juan for sentimental reasons if not for real gameplay. It may be the only efficiency card game I like. But even SJ requires you to play the other players in role selection and the building of buildings complementary to your opponents role needs.

RATING: 7
I started playing this game much later than I perhaps should have done. It's a better competetive deckbuilder than Thunderstone, but suffers (as some other deckbuilders do) from the relative lack of choices. Your first few turns are generally crucial, and can determine who will win there and then. After that, your choices get less and less important until you're practically playing on autopilot. Thanksfully though, games are generally quite short (20-30 minutes) and some excellent kingdom cards in the later expansions give you tough choices to make.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:indigo: :( :D :) :what: Played this for the first time after an almost one-year hiatus (!) from F2F play (many of my regular playing partners are lukewarm on the game and I got a little burned out on it after playing it [i]a lot[/i]) and I was pleasantly surprised to discover that I found Dominion totally delightful all over again. This is just a brilliant, brilliant design. Games are super-quick (almost filler-length for a two-handed match between experienced players) and every game is very different. Dominion is tilted heavily to the strategy vs. tactics side of the continuum -- there are some luck-of-the-draw elements but matches are only truly a tossup if both/all players pursue the same strategy, and [i]that[/i] is likely as not to be groupthink at work. (There's one best way to do win a given hand, but the odds that both players have instantly hit on the exact same plan are ... remote.)

The theme is less a "theme" than an "excuse" and there isn't much direct interaction -- there are attack cards but they don't pop up in every game and even in games where they're on the board, their efficacy depends on the context. I guess this is why people on BGG are slagging Dominion a bit -- with an assist from the Cult of the New. For my part, I have yet to see a deckbuilder that comes close to being the game that Dominion is. If A Few Acres Of Snow didn't have its *cough* issues, it'd be in the running. Everything else I've played is somewhere between meh and and gawdawful.

I strongly prefer this as a 2-player game; I rate this as a 6 or 7 for three, and a 5 or 6 for four. Never tried with more than four but I strongly recommend breaking into two groups if possible for any group larger than three, as the downtime is considerable.

I haven't tried the more recent expansions: my set of base, Intrigue, Prosperity, Seaside and Cornucopia is more than enough game for my purposes.

RATING: 9
Dominion simply has everything I want it to.  Variety in the cards gives it replayability.  Much more than I would ever expect from a single box game.  

It has several hallmarks of a great game
1) makes you feel progressively more powerful over time
2) has a pretty balanced sense of fairness, in players are mostly open to the same opportunities.  
3) The core rules are easy enough to understand.   All the pieces of the game are simple cards, which further reduces complexity.

RATING: 9
+The optimal strategy for most kingdoms is quite difficult to find, requiring some real intelligence and insight
+Near limitless kingdom combinations, especially with expansions means you can't just reuse the same strategy as last game
+Easy to teach to new players
+Easily the most strategic game I've seen popular with non-strategy gamers

-Way too much shuffling; some games I'm shuffling my deck every turn
-The board is the same for everyone, which means you can mindlessly copy another player's strategy without knowing why it works
-Some kingdoms have an extremely simple/obvious optimal strategy, so it comes down to luck who wins (don't be fooled though, luck isn't THAT big of a factor in general)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion, whether played on BSW or with cards, is essentially video poker as played in casinos: the two games are enjoyable, addictive, rewarding, and ultimately hollow in almost exactly the same ways. The decisions involved in Dominion--broadly, what to buy and when to 'switch' from income to points--map almost perfectly to Jacks or Better's decisions of what to draw and when to cash out. This analogy is so good I can't believe nobody else is using it.

Player interaction is technically present, but every decision in the game is best characterized as a [i]response[/i]. This is common in many efficiency games, but Dominion takes the concept to an extreme that will make some players feel that their presence is only required because [i]someone[/i] has to shuffle the cards. This is difficult to phrase well, but in Puerto Rico each decision is a response to each player's individual board position, including the stock of buildings. In Dominion, the decisions and cardplay of other players are interesting only as inputs into the state of the seventeen stacks of cards on the table (the video poker machine).

Dominion's legs will almost certainly come from subtlety and not depth: it may take hundreds of games to become an expert, but after the first [some low number], players are improving their work on the same set of ideas, not continuing to have new ones.

The amount of shuffling in Dominion is astonishing. Early enthusiasts claim the shuffling is not so bad, but they are wrong. It is absolutely as bad as you fear it is. To play Dominion 2-handed is to accept that you will be shuffling under time pressure for the next fifteen minutes. Multiplayer games aren't as bad because the other players buy you some extra shuffling time.

I like Dominion about as much as I like Jacks or Better, which is a fair amount. Ultimately video poker gets a slight edge because unlike when I play Dominion, after a few minutes of video poker, waitresses start bringing me free drinks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7.7
One of the predecessors of all deck builders. When it came out it was a super hit. If you have never played this game: it is great! If you have played it a few times: it is great! If you have played it more than 20 times, it's boring.

To say a game gets boring after 20 plays is quite the compliment mind: to be able to so easily pick it up, draft cards and start playing is a rarity in games but once you have played it so much - every game starts looking the same. Head for silver, then gold, then VP, the win.

But I believe that is the only bad point, it is a fun game that is not too stressful yet quite meaty. 

I found this game sometimes infuriated non gamers "How come you won and we basically chose the SAME CARDS!?" and if they have never played, it's tricky telling them that order of purchase, limitation of dross, and ability to "spike" 6-8 gold is important. No doubt they will come to the same conclusions after a good few goes.

Definitely a staple game in my collection now and forever more!

RATING: 9
Pros:

Still the best of all the deck builders. The delta between the best & worst players is enormous and the depth of the game with expansions is seemingly endless. Even when you play someone far better than you, you come away learning something and will be better for it your next play.

It plays quickly and is great as a 2 or 3 player game. 

Cons:

with 4 players i find it starts to bog down and one of its best qualities fades away. there are rules to play with 5 or 6 in one of the expansions but I'd only play 5 or 6 at gun point.

Without multiple expansions, the game lacks all the depth and lack of luck factor that I just raved about.

The theme is non-existent; Dominion is sort of the chess of deckbuilders; it requires the most skill but it's really an abstract game.
