=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Received Christmas 2009.  Instantly addictive.  Short learning curve to understand the game...although it does take some time to start to remember what each of the 25 decks do during play (ten are used in each game).  Once everyone gets on to the card abilities game time drops.  Until then, it has been a 60+ minute game.

The suggested "first game" set up is okay to get you oriented...but once is enough and you want to move on quickly.  A random drawing of ten decks is the way to go with this game.  The balance between the card powers and the way they enhance each other when used in a combo is evidence of a well thought out and playtested game.  It gets top marks for that.

It is no surprise that this rocketed into the (BGG) top ten and has stayed there.  This appeals to the masses and delivers a fantastic gaming experience.  The simplicity of the design and ease of learning coupled with the depth of strategic choices make this well deserving of its' status.  This is the first game in a while that keeps calling me back to play just "one more time".

It is easy to see why there is a demand for expansions.  It is not that this game doesn't deliver or needs to be enhanced.  But there is a curious draw to experience what new cards would bring to the game.  I already want to get Intrigue or Seaside...and I have not even begun to exhaust this one.

Top notch game that I am compelled to give a 10; always want to play and expect this will never change.

I suppose it is best to place comments in their respective game entry for the three card expansions: Stash, Black Market and Envoy (in order of preference).  They each seem to have their place.  And, like other cards, they may or may not get purchased because of other options and players' strategies.

Update: as of Jun '10 I own Seaside...and would not play without it.

RATING: 6
The first few plays of Dominion were sheer joy, but as the expansions kept piling up and piling up, the game lost its lustre and appeal for me. Not that I am obliged to pick up new expansions, but because I realized that the game sorely needs them to create the combinatorial explosion of variability and to alleviate the buying gold strategy. A great gateway game, but not one which I need to play again or own. I am much happier with a meatier deck builder like A Few Acres of Snow or even Concordia.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dominion brings the pleasure of CCG deckbuilding into the middle of a conventional card game.  The mechanic of constantly changing your deck through play combines with game-to-game differences in available cards to produce a wonderfully strategic experience without sacrificing flow.

The fact that the game is short means that you can easily play several times in one sitting, which allows players to change up the available cards and have different environments to analyze within a compact time period.  The occasional swing due to bad luck is also easily shrugged off due to the short length of any one game.

After a short game or two of learning curve, Dominion boils down to analyzing the card combos that are available - and the number of potential combos grows exponentially with the number of card types.  Expansions will doubtless exploit this phenomenon with practically no end in sight.  I could easily imagine buying expansions for this game for a decade, and loving every one.

Basically, Dominion is my favorite light game - and I don't expect that to ever change.

[edit in 2013: Dominion is still good, but I don't really play it any more due to a shift towards longer multiplayer games and especially the local takeover of Android: Netrunner.]

RATING: 7
This is not a genre that I usually expect to like a lot (card games). The comparisons to Race for the Galaxy delayed my interest, since I don't care particularly for RftG. But I think the similarities are pretty thin. Dominion is its own game.

I only dabbled lightly in CCG, but this one feels like a simplified version of CCG play. There is little direct confrontation, and not a terrible lot of player interaction, but the game was a pleasant surprise for me for one reason alone: my 8 year old son is great at it!

I was surprised at how easily he understood the game, and how good he is at it. He wins about 75% of our match-ups, including 2p or 4p games. I even woke up to find him solo-ing one Saturday morning. For a game that encourages him to read and has some decision-making, this is a great choice. 

The constant need to reshuffle can be irritating. I wish the game could have used draw bags and chits instead, but its tolerable. I doubt the game will have longevity with the regular game group, but he'll definitely be wanting to play this one for a long time.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dominion is a deck-building based filler that created its own niche when it was originally released. The game is simple: you have a starting deck of coins and VPs. You draw a hand of 5. You can use the coins to buy more coins, VP cards, or actions. Actions break the rules in some way. VPs are useless when you draw them, but you need them to win the game. Purchased cards are put in the discard stack, and you have access to them next time through the deck. The cards are the big variable, before the game 10 action cards are chosen or randomly chosen to be available. These interact in various ways and let players break the rules (i.e.: buying more cards, handing out negative VP cards, allowing players to draw more cards, &c.).

The replayability of this game results from the various potential setups. Players need to evaluate how the various cards chosen for the game will interact and create a deck of cards that can negotiate the terrain most effectively, and this is fairly interesting, though it does tend to fade after a moderate amount of play because many of the cards have effects that are similar and others are situationally dependent on other cards being present, or cards that are better or worse depending on the number of players in the game. Sometimes, decks are best made very thin: so you can churn through the deck and fire off chains of effects quickly. At others, the game can become more reactive, and careful defensive play will carry the day. There are quite a few ways to successfully approach the game, which is one of the things that has made it hold my interest.

The play is very fast, easily in the Race category, easy to crank out in 20-30 minutes for experienced players. What you get in the base box, for me, isn't enough to hold up to endless play, but it's harmless fun and I enjoy sitting down and rolling through a game or two in the present. 

I do find the design pretty impressive though, and I've been playing it on and off as my main filler since it was released. It provides a good degree of variability and fun in a very compact time frame. It's not my very favourite game in its class anymore, but it was an innovator and it has held up pretty well for me. Also, my gf loves it and it is extremely portable once the cards are taken out of the base box and thrown into a standard long box, so some bonus points there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Scratches that itch for a former Magic: The Gathering player for the combinations in the game.  And it plays really quick too (once the players are familiar with the rules).  Looking forward to the expansions that are obviously coming for the game.  

The "Market" card is perhaps slightly underpriced for what you get for it.  

The only complaints I have are that the text on many of the cards could have been printed larger, the color on the back of the placeholder/randomizer cards should have been more distinct from the normal backs, and some of the artwork is too dark.  (Having said this, none of these minor problems inherently detract much from the game play, but would have been more "user friendly".)

Edit:  Having played with five players (after getting Intrigue), I *never* want to play with five players ever again (and definitely not with six).  Turned a fun game into a miserable experience.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Damn clever game that feels like a CCG in that you build your deck as you play. Since you only play with 10 types of cards at once you can get a lot of interesting game combinations. Also, this thing has a virtually limitless pool of potential expansion and add on cards. I suspect we will see tons and tons of expansions and promotional cards for this puppy.

Scratch the limitless pool of potential expansion opportunities idea. The makes don't want expansions to this. They want to make whole new games to milk this for all it is worth. Lame!

I originally gave it an 8, but after repeated plays it is really starting to bore me. It is still a very good game, but it has grown stale with me. I will play it occasionally, but that is about it. I am downgrading it to a 7 for this. It should get a 6, but it is still a pretty clever and original idea, so I will give it the extra point.

My wife still digs it a lot and teaching it.

Do not touch this game with a 10' pole if you hate shuffling!

RATING: 8
Another favorite of ours.  As a newbie to "real" board gaming, I had no idea there were games out there not based entirely on dice rolls and luck.  This game puts everyone at equal footing at the beginning of the game and allows each individual strategy to determine your fate.  The practically innumerable variants in card choices keep on your toes and allow you to constantly discover and develop new strategies.  It revolutionized board games in our lives and opened our eyes to what's out there, and it will always be a centerpiece in our growing collection.

RATING: N/A
Strategy game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Easy to learn and addictive. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cons:
- Setup before, during, and after can be painful. Have to hunt for 10 specific kingdoms. Have to shuffle a lot during the game.
- Can be lots of downtime if opponent is playing a big combo.

Best Aspect:
The best aspect of Dominion is how elegant it feels. Once you understand the base mechanics it feels very cleanly designed. Victory cards are how you win but they also make your deck worse. This one simple aspect of the game immediately opens up Dominion strategically. The cards in your deck serve a purpose and you get to sculpt and shape that purpose simply by playing the game. 

Of course when playing strategically or competitively, you add or remove cards from your deck that will help you execute your strategy. But the same principle allows you to play with newer players, who don't quite understand any strategy yet, and still have fun. Of course you could blow them out of the water with Big money or chapel, but maybe this time you'll see how fat you can make your garden based deck. Newer players still get to execute their own (bad) strategy and still have fun (witch may ruin this).

Decisions are limited and feedback is incremental. You only have so many cards every turn and so many actions/gold. There are only so many kingdoms you can actually buy this turn. These factors all encourage thinking strategically but at a manageable scope. At the start of the game you pick one strategy based on a couple of kingdoms. Each turn you make small incremental decisions and each turn you get to evaluate your past decisions. RNG helps here as you cannot plan out every following turn just from seeing the starting kingdoms.

Other Pros:
- lots of expansions can help keep the game fresh and the variability of kingdoms large.
- Cards can be quite thematic. Witch curses you by adding worse than useless cards to your deck. The chapel is how you can cleanse yourself of such curses. Of course not all cards are like this and the theme usually falls apart in the context of the entire deck/game.
- As mentioned above can be as competitive or casual as you like it to be. Can be a con if the veteran decides to mercilessly destroy the newcomer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is strictly a 2 players game. With more it gets tiresome and imbalanced.
You will like if you played Magic and your life is devoted to the endeavour of finding the combo.

I doubt of its replayability because, event though there are thousands of possible card combinations, the strategies are only participated by a tiny "elite" fraction of the cards. So, there are hundred times less strategies that what may be apparent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game looks great and seems like it has lots of replay value and possibilities. However, after playing it a lot, it seems to me to be very one-dimensional. Although it has lots of cards which could change each game, if you want to win you have to avoid collecting too many different kinds of cards. Why? Because they'll slow down your deck and not get you what you need--money to be able to buy Province cards. That's the problem with the game--if you want to win, you have only one basic strategy: collect money fast and buy Provinces. If you buy too many Action cards, you lose. Not much fun after awhile. I've donated my copy of the game to the local University Game Club as they want a copy of the game. Hopefully, they'll have more fun with it than I did! (NOTE: With the release of Thunderstone, I found that it did what I felt Dominion tried to do--and did it better, too! It also has a great theme that works perfectly with the game!) (Donated to the University of Utah Great Move Game Club.)

RATING: 7
The hype was right. This is by no means a tour de force, which might be expected of a game that cracks the top ten, but what it does, it does well, and it does fast. I am VERY appreciative of a game that can be engaging, and play within its documented time of 30 minutes. That, and the enormous variability allowed by the random setup. This could be my new gateway game of choice, if only because it's short enough that you can play multiple times in one sitting, allowing new gamers a chance to "reset" once they get it, rather than suffering through the 2nd half of something, knowing that they didn't really get it during the first half, and wishing they could start over. But the constant shuffling kills me. As does the excessive number of expansions. I haven't bought any flavors and don't plan to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I am not one for growth games, let that be known before you read my comment. I dislike the way in which they move the game forwards (by simply causing growth and thus advancement to happen in a positive feedback loop); I dislike the way in which small differences in the early beginnings grow and enlarge, making catching up very difficult; and I dislike the insane amount of attention such games get as a general rule. Dominion is a growth game, so it will not ever score high with me. Now, in Dominion's defense, I will say a few things which I sort-of liked based on the single time I played. First, it is quick. Second, the growth mechanism is easy enough for me to understand it, which is a prerequisite if I am to play these games more often. Third, there are very little differences to enlarge as players do not draw from a common pool which runs out easily—it's all their own creativity. Fourth, the idea is very original to say the least. All in all, things which  help me appreciate the game more than its other growth brethren.

But.

But for one issue. The game causes an [i]insane[/i] amount of card manipulation. My girlfriend and I were playing at such a high speed at some time that we felt that all we did was shuffling cards. Yes, the decks grow, and the shuffling becomes less. But the basic play-draw mechanism is so quick that shuffling still provides the big break in this routine. We were very glad we were done with this game, and neither of us felt the need to try again. Perhaps in computer form, where all you need to do is click on cards, the game is better. But when played F2F, I cannot derive enjoyment from this game, and will actively avoid it to the point of refusing to participate in a game and doing something else, like reading a book, instead. Dominion is not broken as far as I could tell (although experienced players will undoubtedly hit on killer strategies), so it won't get the lowest possible rating.

[b]Update[/b] Retry, this time with 3. You know what it is that I don't like about Dominion? It's that it obliterates a somewhat interesting strategical problem of how to best 'grow' a deck of cards by excessive tactical micromanagement interleaved with that infernal cycle of shuffling, redrawing, discarding, and shuffling again. Really, humans have creative brains: let them program a strategy into a computer Core War-style (see [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Core_War]here[/url]), and pit various strategies against each other, with the computer doing the boring rest of testing the strategies several million times. I'm still planning to avoid the mechanism as much as I can.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

the first dominion i've ever played; you get bored without expansions soon

RATING: 9.25
Purchased December 2008.

Hype.  Hype.  Hype.

Played a prototype around Origins time frame and really enjoyed it.  Played 3 games straight.  Bought instantly once it was released.

So far this one is winning on the wife front.  She said this game is very easy and that she enjoyed it.  Only problem is that she would rather not play with me.

See lots of parallels with Saint Petersburg and Magic.  Both games I thoroughly enjoy.  This time next year, I for-see this game being the game I've most played. 

January 2009 - Took less than a year (only two months).  This is my most played game.

RATING: 8
I should probably rate this an 8, but it gets an extra 0.5 for getting so many dang plays, and for getting my wife interested in something other than Rummikub.

I've not tried the other deckbuilders, nor do I see any need to. I've got Prosperity and Seaside, and would love to pick up Intrigue and Hinterlands at some point.

Sure there's some sameness, but that just means you've played one-too-many games that evening. There's no other game my wife will play five or six times back-to-back. This is partly because she'll win four of them, but even Lost Cities stops at three.

I'd say this is in my top-5 all time.

RATING: 9
My favorite thing about Dominion is that it is hoards of fun even when you're losing.  I love the mechanic of looking at the set of cards, deciding what you think the optimum path (or in some cases, most fun path) to victory is, and then trying to execute it.  That much fun packed into 30 minutes is a treat.  I do think it can suffer from the "everyone playing alone" syndrome because it plays so quickly -- it can be hard to watch what other people are doing and still be ready for your turn.  Depending on the players, this can make for poor table feel.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Back in 2009, before really diving into boardgames again, I stumbled upon this when searching a birthday gift for my brother. Quick to play, great mechanics, an instant classic. Also, if you're into semi-autistic deck-shuffling, this one is for you. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Play this all the time with my coworkers. This game is excellent.  I love all the tons of combos and trying to figure out what the best combos are on any given board. Game is best with players of similar skill level since having some knowledge on how to balance cards in your deck and knowing what the stronger cards are gives you a huge edge over new players.

Downside of this game is that the random setups can vary wildly in how fun they are, how much strategy there is, how much luck there is, how interactive/mean they are, and how long they take.  If a great set of cards comes out, this game is AMAZING.  If a terrible set of cards come out, the game can be just way less fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

-How encouraged I feel to try new combos (and there are a LOT of things to try with all these expansions out).
-How well the game scales from 2-more players.

Don't Like:

-Some of the inconsistent card art.
-The lack of a tidy way to store all the cards.

RATING: 6
This is a great 2 (or 3) person game. The best part is that I am always anxious to play again - even after just finishing a game. I suspect that we'll play this game a lot in the coming years. The downside is that the game can take a while to set up and it takes a while to understand the rules of certain cards. When we are using new cards or haven't played in a while, we'll spend too much time reading and re-reading the rules for a given card. This can be a drag on the player experience. 

8/8/2012 2:34 PM - setup time has turned out to be a big deal. We tend to play games w/ less set up time. 

9/2015 - I've been convinced I don't play this game enough. I'm going to push to play more this fall.

RATING: 8
Dominion has a surprising amount of strategy involved, which isn't immediately apparent on your first few plays. How you play and plan has to adapt to the cards that are in play - a different combination each time, which meant every game I played felt different even though they were always against the same people. The only downside to Dominion, and the reason I no longer own it, is that the set up can sometimes be longer than the game itself leaving it often sat on the sidelines at game night. That and the fact that the urge to spend money on the expansion packs is overwhelming.

RATING: 9
Dominion was the game that got me back into board games. Now, I just like Dominion. I am really burnt out on this game and deck building games in general. Everyone seems to be putting out deck building games now and they are all pretty much the same. I like how quick this games plays--even though it takes forever to set up. I wish the theme was stronger as well. It has medieval looking pictures, but they really don't have anything to do with the game. Its just a card game. The strategy is easy to get as well and some cards I never play because they don't fit into the strategy that wins. I will still play this game, but I have found other games that hold my interest for longer.

RATING: 8
This is one of the only purchases I have made based on (largely-justified) hype. I appreciate the innovative deck-building mechanism but I am not entirely convinced that this game has more depth than breadth.

While the variety of kingdom cards certainly provides players with many different options, I really don't know if having all these options makes this a great game. San Juan, for example, seems to have much more depth with fewer cards and a brilliant role-selection mechanic.

With Dominion, the jury is still out, but I do have fun playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Already a modern classic! :)
It excels at the innovative introduction of two mechanisms:
1. Very variable game setup due to the choice of 10 different kingdom cards that the game consists of in every game. 10 out of 25 in the base game and out of a whopping 234 when playing with all expansions (through Adventures) and promo kingdom cards (through Prince). Every game is different, thus very high appeal to play over and over again!
2. The deck construction that happened prior to the game in other games so far *is* the game in Dominion!

It is great that the designer is very active and readily answer questions on the [url=http://forum.dominionstrategy.com/]Dominionstrategy forums[/url] and here at BGG! :)

What I don't like about the official Dominion is the hidden trackable information (HTI) and thus the incentive to tediously memorize cards. Which is why I am an avid proponent of deck counters in online Dominion. Read more about my general stance on HTI in my profile.

This is my most played game of all time with close to 7.000 games (most of them online and with expansions). But I am still eager to play more, it hasn't lost its appeal (except for the loss of appeal due to the abysmal Goko online implementation, of course).
Dominion is that good and provides that kind of long-term versatility with all expansions! :)

So my rating of 9 is for the base game only, together with all expansions it is a 10 for me (reflected in ratings of 9.5 and 10 for most of them) - even in spite of the HTI! :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
My first few plays of this were... modestly entertaining. Fun enough, nicely balanced, but nothing to write home about. Then I played with a cardset which which turned the intro-set play dynamics [i]completely[/i] on their ear, and was intrigued.

Having now played enough to understand some of the subtleties, I appreciate the game even more - although I understand the complaints about how "select a strategy" is the lion's share of the game, with actual play being secondary, I do feel like there's enough course correction / reaction to other decks to make it more than just an extremely long scoring round. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.3
The process is too dull. The game is too variable and loose and this results in bad rounds.

The framework underpinning it chokes the more interesting spice that you sometimes discover. 

I don't want more buys, more cards, more actions or a richer more weeded deck anymore. Too easy. Too dull. 

I would sell all of Dominion. I would never ask to play it again. The problem was not just my knowledge level or the strategies I employed during the game. The problem is that there is too much basic framework in the game and it makes it dull. And playable. 

I have better games.

I find Dominion challenging to play yet simultaneously dull. At this time, with the competing games I have on my shelf, that just isn't good enough. I need more fun out of a game than Dominion offers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion's deck-building mechanic is brilliant in its conception and simplicity, and it intuitively appeals. But the actual game turns out to be pretty bland and disappointing, primarily because its narrative structure is completely in opposition to the ideal for a game. The most important and interesting decisions occur at the very beginning; by design, later choices have an ever-shrinking impact as your deck grows in size. By the midpoint, gameplay devolves into playing out your hand mechanically, and purchase choices are completely defined.

It doesn't help that setup for this game is quite fiddly and can take a third or half as long as the actual game, and that the constant shuffling is an irritant. The theme is also so innocuous as to be absent, and the card designs suffer from a number of usability issues. And the game has a strong starting player bias and offers little compensation for this. I foresee another game coming along soon that refines the core mechanics of Dominion into a much more textured and tense game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Components: Nice artwork and clear iconography. The shear number of cards is a bit of overkill (the game could come with far fewer copper cards, for instance), but most of my plays are with two players, so I might just not have a grasp of how many cards come into circulation with more players. The compartmental insert is greatly appreciated; yes, it's still difficult to find a particular card type (even with the handy divider label), but I much prefer this to just a stack of cards, or bagging them all separately.

Experience: Very fast-paced, to the point of it being my turn again before I've even refreshed my hand. An exciting, frantic race.

It is a lot of fun to draw a hand of five cards and play it out. I like a lot of luck in my games, to give me something to blame when I lose, and to present me with fresh choices at every turn. For any given hand, this game delivers on the luck, but that luck, in the long run, is tightly controlled by the buying choices I make. I'm hardly ever forced to add a card to my deck, nor is a card often forcibly removed from my deck, so most of the cards in my deck are there by my choosing, and so I'm usually thrilled with all the cards I draw each turn.

Playing action cards is mostly straight-forward; I don't mind that; it is the payoff from having bought them, i.e. I only bought them so that I could play them, and now I'm getting to play them. Buying cards is more thought-provoking. In many cases I can still do it on auto-pilot, but even the simplest of such decisions are balanced by the fact that the decisions happen quickly and frequently, and thus aren't individually burdened with carrying the weight of whether I enjoy the game or not. The sum of those 20+ decisions over the course of the game is definitely enjoyable. 

There are only a few action cards that allow for direct player interaction, which is fine with me. In most games I like to build my own sandcastles and not have them knocked down by others. And of course I must watch what my opponent is doing and adjust accordingly, just as in Race for the Galaxy.

I've read a few comments recently that suggested some players might not always buy a Province if able. So far I've never passed up this chance, even early in the game, or even if the card is the penultimate Province card. Gardens aside, with 8 copper and any number of buys it is the best bang-for-my-buck, and only pollutes my deck with one non-actionable card. Thus far, having 5+ Provinces in a 2 player game has always been a trait of the winning player (5 Provinces to my opponent's 3 being a 12-point swing), so it seems advantageous to grab these as aggressively as possible.

Recently started playing a variant whereby each player has five random types of kingdom cards uniquely available to them, and am really liking this variant. It prevents any sort of mirroring strategy, and with fewer choices I often employ kingdom cards that would not have looked as attractive among twice as many of its peers. If I had to pick the single thing I most enjoyed about all games, I'd probably say it's the “work with what you've got” challenge of card games, and this variant delivers on this even more than does the initial constraint of 10 kingdom cards, but still leaves enough options available to me for interesting decisions.

Update: Despite Dominion being a great game, I don't think I'll play it anymore, as Thunderstone scratches the same mechanism itch, but with so much more that I enjoy. But I'll probably always have a soft spot in my heart for Dominion.

First Played: 2009-02-15
Last Played: 2011-11-27
Eagerness to Play Again: No Desire

Plays (29):
2 players: 28
3 players: 1

At £30 rather than £3000 though, I am happy with Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent gateway game.

Will feel familiar to anyone who has ever done deck-building, and vaguely familiar to anyone who has played simple card games like Uno or Go Fish.

Excellent replayabililty; as not all cards will be used each game, each game will feel different for a good number of games. 

Expansions
Although there are many wonderful expansions available, start out with just the base game, there is plenty of entertainment to be had! If you really enjoy it, buy one (or if you must, two) expansions at a time to freshen the game up if it begins to feel stale. Many people will be very happy to own only the base game or maybe one expansion. You do not need them all to have a great time playing.

Notes
Highly recommend sleeving your cards as you will be shuffling a LOT. Even if you shuffle gently, you will avoid stress watching friends shuffle while playing your game.

RATING: 6
Many years ago, I got very crazy about Dominion. My completionist syndrome acting up as well, so I hunted expansion after expansion and promo after promo. The turning point came with the Alchemists. I simply couldn't justify to myself to shelf out more money. And, to be honest, I did have enough expansions to make setup a chore, even with the app.

But then I realised that we were essentially playing multiplayer solitaire. True, there are a few cards that make you do stuff to your opponent, but most of the times it's a simple race for VPs and turning cards on your own. Now, my copies are sitting in my shelf, collecting dust and waiting to be sold.

Perhaps I simply over-indulged.

RATING: 10
Absolutely LOVE this game.  This is the funnest game I have played.  First play rank was 7/10 but after about the 3rd play (knowing what I was doing) 10/10.  I was playing 3-6 times per day.  Come home from lunch and play.  I have since purchased intrigue, seaside, hinterlands, prosperity.  Replay value is almost infinite.  Just with base set there are 3 million different combinations.  Prosperity is a must.  This is the most addictive game I have played.  I have well over 300+ plays and it's still fun.  There is an app for smart phones call Androminion which is where about 1/2 of my play time has come from.  Everyone we've introduced this game to loves it and half buy there own set.  I am not a card game fan but this game is very very fun.  Even haters like this game.  10/10 still after hundreds of plays.

RATING: 5.5
I think I would find Dominion a lot more fun if it weren't for that one guy. Oh, you don't know that one guy? I'm talking about that one guy who sits down at the table and immediately identifies the best combination of cards to play and then flawlessly executes it, absolutely decimating everyone else at the table. I've played a lot of games of Dominion and they've never lacked that one guy. Maybe I could put more effort into avoiding that one guy but I think the fact that he's kind of ubiquitous says something problematic about the game: there is a right answer. And if you don't immediately know what it is, you're probably not going to have much fun.

Yesterday we played with the kids who also loved it first time and when I went to work my daughter and Lisa played 3 games back to back using some of the different Kingdom cards. This has never happened before. I am convinced we will get value out of this as my daughter was also asking if there were any expansions! 

Update - We had a lot of plays of Dominion but it does not now feature as one of our 'go to' games as it used to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Plays: 1
Finally got a chance to play this big BGG-hit.
The thing I like is the deck-building mechanism. At first it feels weird to discard and reuse all you cards, but after a while you realize it's all about deckbuilding. Another interesting aspect is when to stop buying "money-maker" and start buying victory points.

However, the game lasted a pretty long and felt too repetetive after a couple of turns. Furthermore, interaction is very limited. I've been told interaction improves with the uses of more advanced cards, but not too much. The fun I had playing the game resulted from funny remarks of fellow players critizing the game - not from gameplay itself.

The final verdict: novel and interesting deck-building mechanism, but not I game I'd like to play on a regular basis.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Next to Marvel Legendary, and maybe Thunderstone, this is my favorite deck builder. Yes, you can fall into more of a solitaire type of game where you basically buy what you want and try for the most points without a lot of player interaction. If that's a problem, add some attack cards to mess with other players.

The theme is really enjoyable and well put together. Some combinations (especially when you add in expansions) seem a bit OP and broken. The mechanics are pretty simple to pick up and play with even for younger kids. They may not be great at it, but it's something they can understand and have fun with.

Biggest drawback to me is that when someone hits on the best strategy for a given layout, there's not much you can do to stop them. They get their engine rolling and it's just a matter of time before they buy out the Provinces.

Still a game I love playing, but I find it best in groups who can just casually enjoy a game with some dessert, a warm drink, and some conversation. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
La "revolución" para los (ex)jugadores de Magic, engancha como pocos y el precio es más que correcto, especialmente si tenemos en cuenta la cantidad de partidas distintas que se pueden hacer sólo con la caja básica.

RATING: 7
This game plays well with two to five players. Although sometimes maligned as group solitare, I enjoy assessing the card tableaux and finding a way to make it work. There are so many different combinations of cards, it makes for a puzzle to be solved. Liked it so much, got Intrigue and then Seaside.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is a cold, calculating euro at heart but somehow manages to appear like something else. What I really love about it though is setting the game up, looking at the available kingdom cards and figuring out what I'm going to do this time. Dominion is both a strategic game (which cards will you buy) and a tactical one (how you play your hand). Experimenting with card combos is a lot of fun, especially with the expansions where some really crazy things can happen. I can see why Dominion has won all possible board game awards, as it really does deserve them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can see why so many people love Dominion but I have never found it fun personally. I don't like to shuffle a small deck of cards again and again. I find the theme to be non-existent. The game boils down to a pure math game: buy these cards that'll let me play these other cards that'll let me buy these point cards. I wouldn't mind an abstract game if the mechanics are either simple or innovative, but Dominion seems to be both dry and needlessly complicated. There are so many different types of cards, each of which does some variation of a few functions. Experienced players have seen all the card sets and memorized the optimal combos, so they steamroll newbies because a small improvement in card-play efficiency gradually builds up to an insurmountable lead. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A simple, fun card game that has a ton of underlying strategy.  I enjoy it over CCG like M:tG because every player starts with the same hand and access to the same cards.  Also, a one time purchase gives me all the cards I need for a lot of variation and strategy.

RATING: N/A
JS 2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game plays just like collectible card games, except there is nothing to collect.  That is a victory for the gamer since the biggest downside of collectible card games is the cost and the inevitable "arms race" that occurs between friends, and neither of those situations occurs in Dominion.

In a nutshell, you all build decks while actually playing the game, using community provided cards.  Awesome!

The problem with this game is the usual problem with all card games; card counting.  Yes, you get to break out those Rainman like memorization brain cells and attempt to maximize your deck.  You do not have to card count, but if your opponents can and do (like mine), you basically have no choice if you want to keep up.  While not game breaking, it is a problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Amazon box w/ Alchemy & Prosperity included
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played 5+ x
No theme, lots of shuffling, boring samey games. Somehow even with changing out the kingdom cards, it never really feels any different. It's just draw cards, play cards, buy cards, rinse repeat. There's no engine you can build that you can count on, unless you do some drastic card trashing. And even then, everyone is probably doing the same thing you are so it turns into a race of who can trash fastest. Just not fun for me.

RATING: 7.5
This is my wife's favorite game.  We play on isotropic quite a bit (though we have the cards too, the logged plays are with the physical cards).  There is a lot of replay value in this game; with random kingdom cards, there's always different strategies to try out.

We include the expansions when we play.  I would rank them:
1) Prosperity
2) Seaside
3) Alchemy
4) Intrigue
Take this with a grain of salt; there are cards from Intrigue that I like more than cards from Prosperity (Bridge >> Loan), but this is the general feeling.

RATING: 9.5
A wonderful, wonderful game.

Prominently features the card-evaluation that makes me love drafting Magic. Witnessing your deck mutate whilst playing appeals to my 'nurturing' side. Running through the deck so many times, ensuring all cards are played roughly equally, minimises luck. 

I firmly blame my loss on the fact that we thought there were more of a certain card, so I was planning for a longer game. (Near the end, it turned out they'd been wrongly laid out.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game that apparently started the whole deck-building genre? Well, thanks for that, I guess; now you can go away.

This game has no theme. The only attempt at a theme just amounts to a light hand-wave. The art is very bland and elementary. And with every expansion, the art not only gets worse, but it feels like they purposefully ask the artists to make art as bad and different as possible from any of the previous art, so none of it matches either.

There's rarely anything to do while you wait for other players to take their turns. Nor a great deal of interest in what they are doing.

The cards themselves, regardless of how you choose the ones for your session, are mostly useless. There always seems to be one clear dominant strategy. And in general the basic money cards are the best buy. Which sort of makes it absurd and repetitive not just during each play, but from play to play. The variety by changing card sets is somewhat an illusion.

The base game is just very dull. It's made decent by one or two of the better expansions. But then they went and made that a mockery too with the endless stream of expansions that are mostly filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really, its much too lucky. Beginners can pick up the rules quickly. A good filler game.

RATING: 7
I normally don't care for themeless, storyless games, but Dominion is an exception. Every combination of cards that make up a game is a puzzle to be solved, and a race to see who can solve it first. The simplicity of the basic structure hides what builds over the short playing time into sometimes very elaborate game play. I thought the original game was interesting but rather bland, but the addition of cards in the expansions made it much more interesting to me. 

I have the second edition.

RATING: 3
I just played this game again recently after a few years of avoiding it. This recent game just reminded me how much I hate this game. In the future, I'll find something else to do while the rest of my friends play this. So little decisions for all the effort of constant shuffling. Barf. 

For the most part, I enjoy the games in the top spots here on BGG, so I value the rating system. However, in this case, I strongly feel that this game does not belong in the top 10 here on BGG (I'm disappointed in my fellow BGGers ;) ). I guess my interest in deckbuilding died when I stopped playing Magic the Gathering and Jyhad (1995). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Intro to Deckbuilding

Own the Dominion Big Box set due to the value.

Pros: Good card stock, pioneered the deckbuilding-as-a-game mechanism. Engine building and hand management blend into a fun game of deciding when and how to buy victory point cards to end the game. Lots of replayability here with the variable setup of cards.

Cons: Dry theme. Card sorting and storage can be a challenge. The Big Box version has dedicated slots but the box is huge and you would never want to store it sideways.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Catan has the title of my "gateway" game, but Dominion is responsible for lighting the flame of obsession in my life.  The deck-building mechanic was completely new to my gaming friends and myself, and once we caught on we really enjoyed it.  It was amazing back when I first tried it, and with the expansions, it never seems to get old.  I love that endless variety, and that each new game is a chance at trying something new.  Another plus for me is that is plays very well as a 2 player game.  I prefer 3-4 players (have played with 5-6 and that makes for much too long a game IMO), but 2 player games work well for me.  One common complaint from friends is that "experience" with the cards gives too great an advantage, and I do agree to a point.  There are a few "can't pass up" cards that an experienced player will know about, but I usually share that information before each game in an attempt to even the playing field.  At the moment, this still holds the place of "favorite game".  I love it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The base game is just a little bit stale on its own though, as most of the cards are fairly straightforward and it's difficult to really be creative in your card selection.

Prosperity
Intrigue
Seaside

RATING: 7.5
(2010)
(Barely play the boardgame, but play a lot on the phone: androminion)

For 2 - 4 players. Nonetheless we have played 5 people without much of a problem.

Dec 2011: Very good game. We randomly pick 10 (out of 25) Kingdom cards and play with them, having always different games.
We usually tend to build Action Decks.

Jan 2014: Now I tend to buy just 4-5 action cards, the rest is money. Usually I never buy Duchys (maybe in late game) but Provinces. If possible (chapel, steward, trading port) I try to clean my deck. If "curses" are present, I always try to send them to other players at the beggining (Witch, Torturer...). Market, Laboratory and Militia are always good.

RATING: 4
I'm still willing to be persuaded on this one and keep coming back to it.

However, having got into gaming about 2 years after Dominion's explosion, I'm not sure that I'll ever be sold. 

Essentially, it's a puzzle game: experienced players will look at the available cards and instantly know the best combinations to aim for. Non-experienced players will make what seem like perfectly reasonable plays and find that the game is over just as they're getting to grips with it - and that they've lost.

It just doesn't feel rewarding enough for me to want to become an experienced player.

Quick game (usually) with a high replay value

I've heard a lot of people compare this game to Magic.  I have to search to find loose similarities.  Everyone starts with the same deck and has the same options to expand his deck during the game.  Something I like even more: no one is guaranteed victory because he spent all his money on cards.

RATING: 5
The first deck building game I played (and the first for most people), but I feel gameplay tends to get too repetitive as you get more plays into it. Game turn into "engine-based combo vs mono econ midrange" pretty quickly and the winner often ends up as the one who's better at keeping track of the deck's of both players. Having memory be the most important mechanic of a game leads to pretty unexciting grindfests, but game is probably significantly better when taken less seriously.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dominion is a filler game extraordinaire.  It plays very quickly, yet is fun.  The assortment of cards guarantees quite a bit of variability (a must for short games), though not as much as you'd think (you'll definitely find yourself playing favorites).  I love the deckbuilding, which takes me back to my MtG days.  However, there isn't as much depth to this as appears at first blush.  Ultimately, you're trying to build a deck that will get you $8 to spend each turn.  Action cards are important, but not as important as they seem at first.  Economy is more important, though you can not totally ignore the action cards unless you want your deck to be too slow.

So my rating is a guardedly optimistic 9.  I'm worried that I will eventually tire of the game as I've already noticed my decks tend to be about the same each time.  I've played Intrigue once, and it promises to inject some much needed new energy to this game.

Update:  I tend to avoid this one now.  I still like it, but it drags on longer than it used to.  The expansions are the biggest culprits for the slowdown.  Anyway, this game is just a bit too long to be a filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Amazingly fun game with infinite replayability and deep strategy.

150+ plays later: Still my favorite game, especially with all the expansions. If I could play one game for the rest of my life, it'd be this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A simple but effective deck building game that is a lot of fun to play.

What I liked:
* Fast paced
* Works well with varying number of players
* different cards every game
* Different cards certain strategies work better in some games than in others.
* Game feels fresher longer

What I didn't like:
* Big money strategy is fairly effective and this strategy is virtually the same every game.
* Theme isn't worked in that well
* Can be a bit fiddly setting up particularly with expansions.
* Insert is ok for just base game but could have been a lot better.

RATING: 7
Probably not fair to judge against Race for the Galaxy as it's a VERY different game, but that's the same niche it lands in.  Much lighter and even less interaction (even though you have cards that let you "attack" your opponents), but it's sure addictive.  I'm not sure how much staying power it will have even with the different decks, but we'll see.

[June 2014 - 9.5]

While we've moved on to many others, this one (even just the base set) is so much fun to pull out and speed through a game or two. There's plenty of strategy, but once you're familiar with all the cards, you really play through it with a nice rhythm. It really shines as a two-player game, but also plays well with 3-4 if everyone has that rhythm down. Amazing that it's still one of my top-rated games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[2008-10-26]
Bought it at the Spiel 2008 for ~23€.

[2008-11-14 Rating: n.a. -> 10]
There it is, my first 10. I always thought, it would be a "heavy" strategic game that would win the race for the perfect ten, but now it is a light-to-medium card game. Well, who cares if it's such a great and addictive one. After playing about 60 games, I just have to admit that I really love this game and I don't expect this to change in the near future. Maybe it's shine will wear of after another 150 plays, but that's not really a problem. Dominion would be the most played game in my collection then, by far.

What I really like about Dominion is that it takes some time to see how to play this game well. In the beginning you are struggling with all the action-cards only to discover later, that a coin-heavy deck is better in many situations. Then you discover how to streamline your deck and suddenly you notice that some action-cards thrown in the mix boost your deck more than you ever thought they would. And guess what, even the action-cards you initially thought were more or less worthless start to shine at some point. It is this learning-process that I deeply enjoy.

What makes Dominion even better in my book is the fact, that everyone I introduced to the game loved it and wanted to play it again and again. This observation had a great impact on my decision to rate this one a 10. Of course there are meatier games with more strategic and tactical potential, but most of them are just collecting dust on my shelf. Not this one, even my girlfriend, a non-gamer at heart, likes to play this gem from time to time.

Did I already mention that Dominion is also great with just two players? Well, it is. And so my decision is settled: Dominion gets the 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
ドミニオン
２～４人
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion is an interesting case of a game that started out strong for me, but then rapidly went downhill from there. When I first tried it I was pretty impressed. Unfortunately, as time went on I liked it less and less. I think the biggest thing that kills it for me is the down time.

With many heavier games that require a lot of thought, there is plenty to think about between turns. Either individual's actions are directly effecting you in a significant way or you need to think between turns in order to not spend an especially great amount of time ON your turn figuring out what you are going to do.

In lighter/faster games like Race For the Galaxy and Zing! things are constantly quickly moving. You are able to take your turn and immediately do something else. There is very little down time because things are constantly happening.

With Dominion, there is only rarely something going on between turns, and when something does happen it is only rarely something you can influence. Usually, what will happen is someone will play a bunch of cards and do something. Then the next turn will play their cards and do something, and it will go around the table until it is your turn to do your next move which you decided to do when you redrew a little while ago. 

Occasionally someone will play a card that influences you. This tend to has a low impact however, as it is mostly them making a decision rather than you. In addition once you have played the game a handful of times the number of difficult decisions, and thus tension, goes down quite a bit. Whereas in a game like Race I still feel like I am making tough decisions even after having played it over 200 times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great as a filler game. Seemed fantastic on 1st plays but replay value questionable, even w/ expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players are medieval lords, growing their landholdings.  Large box card game.  Players take turns playing an "action" card, which grants the card's ability, possibly triggering more actions, card draws, discounts, etc.  The player may then purchase a card from the common supply, adding it to their deck.  Cards purchased may be money cards (allowing purchases), action cards (allowing more abilities) or land cards (victory points for winning).  The weird things is your entire hand is junked at the end of your turn, and you draw an entire new hand for your next turn.  So you essentially are playing lots of mini-hands.  The card burn rate means lots and lots of shuffling.  Game ends when three decks dry up.  Very light and fast game play, with basically no theme at all - essentially a big-box filler.  Fun to play - the equivalent of gaming popcorn, you just want to keep nibbling at it.  Only problems are the enormous box (why?), and I wish the cards had clearer text and costs.  Dropped a bit a couple of years later - it's got a bit bloated and there are better deck building games out there for me now (lean and mean Puzzle Strike, and the deep Thunderstone).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun card game with a very definite progression. Players must be very skillful about managing the ratio of cards in their ever-growing hand in order to win. Learning card combinations is key. Game offers lots of variety and has a high replayability value. Appeal to a wide variety of gamers.

RATING: 6.5

I know I will never play this game as much as I did when I first played the hell out of the base set.

RATING: 8
Idea:
Buy cards from 10 randomly chosen stacks + point/cash stacks to combine deck that sweeps through opposition. Base game has somewhat 40 different cards and expansions give more.

Mechanism:
Draw cards, play card(s), refine your deck or hit other players decks, choose right moment to start buying point cards (because they dont give other functions) and get most points when game ends due score cards are bought out or three stacks are bought out.

to Whom:
Good to play 2-4 players, easy to teach hard to master, to some extent repeats itself without enough cards. Requires loads of card suffling.

Special: Playable online through BSW (Not all cards included though)

RATING: 6
really intriguing game (no pun intended) -- it's really awesome trying a new card set and discovering all the different combos. my first game was a perfect example: we played the starter 10, and I had 1 villager/smithy/market and played them all in one turn, then realized how awesome it was to cycle through my deck like that, so i bought up all the villages and markets and smithys and had a blast drawing through my deck every turn and being able to buy multiple provinces once everything was said and done.

however, everyone needs to be on the same skill level/knowledge base for the game to be enjoyable, otherwise the better player will destroy the table. this makes it hard to teach newer players, although you can always experiment with an alternate strategy.

also, it seems almost necessary to get expansions, since your card set options will grow factorially as you get more and more different expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dominion is a fairly simple engine-building game, conceptually. Your engine is your deck, which you move through at a semi-fixed rate, picking up five cards per turn and reshuffling when you run out. Certain cards move you through your deck faster, or cause your opponents to move through their deck slower. At a certain point, you switch to acquiring victory points. Whoopie.

The interesting bit is the variable setup. You pick 10 cards from an ever-increasing number, then stare at them for a bit. But that stare hides a lot.

Some setups are obvious and less interesting; get money +one or two action cards. But ~70% of the time, wheels start turning and you're faced with some options. Usually, you pick up trashing first; get rid of the crap  cards from your deck, move through it faster. But sometimes there isn't trashing, or there are attacks that you have a priority to get. Sometimes games are long and drawn out with lots of crap and lots of micro-decisions about how to manage it. Sometimes you'll completely wreck an opponent's deck, and he'll concede.

"But wouldn't you rather have a game that does that, but in a more focused way?" Sometimes. But sometimes you and your opponent disagree on the paths, and you get interesting stuff, tweaking your way through the forest. Sometimes you need to grab his power cards, or take a sharp turn into ending the game before the behemoth he's attempting to assemble takes off. And that's interesting, and that's something you don't get without variable setups. Playing a fluctuating herbalist-philosopher's stone against an ambassadoring opponent with an engine was a really interesting game.

So why do I only rate it a 6? Well, I've played mostly on isotropic (I've played >20 games in person, but >300 games online.) Without the online interface, players move slowly, and the game overstays its welcome. A dominion game that lasts 15 minutes is a lot of fun; one that lasts an hour and a half verges on torture.

There's also the problematic bit with variable setups: sometimes they're not all that interesting. And while Cosmic Encounter and the like have player interaction to steer the game in interesting directions, Dominion really doesn't have anything to fall back on.

Luck? That's an issue too, although not an extreme one. In interesting setups, skill probably makes up %60 of the outcome, and the better player wins ~80% of the time (good players get lucky, too). In less interesting setups? The good player can eke out percentagewise advantages, but that's really not that interesting.

An interesting variant I sometimes enjoy is Progminion; find an interesting set and build a robot to play it. This is a lot more interesting than it sounds.

All in all, it's a 6; I'll play it sporadically. I'd play more if it were on a good online implementation. It was an important part of getting me interested in designer games (I was pointed to it from an MTG site). It's fun. But it's not the greatest game around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
USUCEU

What I will note (having just played with 4 for the first time in ages) is that I think this game is by far a better 2 player game than 3 or 4.  The down time is just too high, especially late game, with more than 2 players and the game simply becomes tedious.

RATING: 6
Certainly this is over-hyped to some degree.  The core mechanic is very much the same as To Court The King, but with coins on cards replacing the pips on dice.   But the gameplay is awfully repetitive and there is a crapload of shuffling and drawing cards.  Almost to the point of annoyance.  Playing your hand is practically automatic also.  The graphics aren't very good (compared to Race For The Galaxy or Magic) and all the coins are the same color.  Interaction level is very low, no matter what cards are in play.  Another concern is that the dominant strategy of "Buy Gold + Buy Province = WIN" seems to make all the interesting card combos irrelevant.  On the plus side, there are a lot of variations in the setup, which might give this some shelf life.   Gameplay is casual and surprisingly light, which means it has a lot of tougher competition for a game in this range.   I appreciate the addictive quality but overall this is much shallower than I expected.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Of all my games, this one hits the table more than any other.  It’s not because its my favourite game, but it just works so well in so many circumstances.  It scales well with any number of players and is also a good two-player game.  It works well with entry gamers, non-gamers and even seasoned gamers (although you may need to add in a few expansions for them).  With about a half hour playtime, it can act as a starter game for a game day, or if played multiple times in a row, be an event all by itself.  Every game can be different or many of the recommend sets/configurations can be re-played multiple times.  
I think what makes Dominion so enjoyable is it appeals to the primal human desire to accumulate wealth, buy things and build something bigger and unique.  The mechanic is so simple but (especially when expansions are thrown in) understanding how some cards may or may not interact with each other is a study unto itself.  Every time we sit down to play a new card arrangement in Dominion we feel like we are about to engage in a science experiment to see how cards will play off each other.  Even when some random sets are created and players may struggle, its not that the set is broken, its just Dominion challenging you past your usual comfort level and making you quickly devise a new strategy and think outside the box to win the game.   
I often hear, "oh so and so is a better deck builder than Dominion because it adds this and that, etc.", but when even just a few of the many expansions are added, none have the breadth and depth that exists in the world that has been created through Dominion.  With so many expansions and countless possible combinations, Dominion has almost become a hobby within a hobby.  Such care has been taken to make sure cards can work with various other cards, no other deck builder can hold a candle to the well-balanced and streamlined play of Dominion.  In the study of deck builders, all games start with Dominion and then circle back to Dominion; it is the grand-daddy of them all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good deck building game. Works for beginners, but may not be great to mix beginners with developed strategies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.38
card drafting & deck building  78,423   4.1x
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the progenitors of the deckbuilding genre, Dominion is no longer the flashiest, or the fastest, or the most exciting, but it may still be the best.   I knew this game was great when I first playtested it, and it's still getting played years later.  

Dominion's design has some serious strikes against it.  As what is essentially an economic engine snowball VP grab, there can definitely be a runaway leader effect.  That is, when someone starts buying gold & provinces, they're probably not going to stop.  
The way that other players buy cards can have more of an impact than your own decisions.  This sort of multiplayer chaos is in lots of games, but pronounced here because of the limited numbers of each card available.  If you're going for a particular deck, and you have that build to yourself, it'll be powerful (maybe).  But for every player who decides to move in on that archetype, or hate-pick cards from it, your chances of winning drop dramatically.  
The attacks, depending on the current setup and the cards themselves, tend to be either too weak to hold back the leader (iow, a mere nuisance) or so potent that they become a component of one of the best strategies.  In the latter case, the person who's winning is usually using them, and making everyone else's day miserable.  The stronger (and more grief-y) the attack, the more it demands that you buy it yourself (or at least try and mitigate it), and such games can be long and painful.
Oh, and then there's another potential problem, which is the perceived dominance of 'big money'.  I don't think this is such an issue as some make it out to be,  but there's no doubting that there are some setups where you can largely ignore the idea of buying any significant number of kingdom cards.  You can't fault people for seeking out a winning strategy, but it's pretty boring to set up a display of cards, then only use the ones that are in every game.
Lastly, as a card game, there's a lot of randomness.  This means that while things will usually even out, sometimes you can make all the right choices but have them swamped by the effects of the shuffle.  2 players can go for the same build, buying the exact same cards in the same order, but one of them will get to $5 or $6 regularly, while the other will never get a hand above $4.  Without the capability to buy the cards they need, the 2nd player will quickly fall behind.  Other things that can happen are having critical cards be at the bottom of your deck after the first shuffle, so they not only show up late but miss your next deck cycle entirely, and the 5-2 split at the beginning.  Depending on the card offerings, getting a $5 and $2 opening hand can be terrible, or it can give you a huge boost.  It's no guarantee, but I'll be betting on the player who gets mine/cellar, or laboratory/chapel, or even market/moat over someone who has to go 2x silver since all the mid-value cards available stink.  I often advocate a fixed-opening variant where you skip the initial shuffle in order to patch this, but it's yet to catch on.

[i]However[/i], I have to say that Dominion isn't done in by these issues.  Most of the games that have come after it have inherited them, or even made them worse.  For a while there, I felt like the other deckbuilders, with their more freeform style, had almost replaced stodgy old dominion and its 1 action 1 buy limitations.  But as time's gone by, I've come to appreciate what those restrictions do for the game.  Dominion isn't a case of just buying the most awesome/expensive card every turn.  You have to make a careful consideration of what should really be in your deck.  Too many terminal actions is bad.  Too much time spent building up your engine before switching over to green will doom your efforts.  Buying points too early can have the same effect.  A statistician with a spreadsheet could calculate out the expectation values of money in your average hand, but you have to do this on the fly and simply have a feel for what the right ratio of money/actions is.  
Rather than an ever-changing parade of cards, Dominion asks you to look at a static 10 and figure out which decks are going to be dominant in this mini-metagame.  Despite the things I listed above, and despite the times when it feels like pulling the lever on your own personal slot machine, I think it's a good test of skill, and a solid design.

RATING: 7
Dominion is that weird, wonderful grandpappy of deckbuilders and nothing can ever take that away from the game.  However, most of the popular complaints about the game are valid - multiplayer solitaire at its finest.  It's good fun, especially if you've never played a deckbuilder before, but the mechanic has been improved upon multiple times and you'll find that the more you play Dominion, the older it gets - if that makes any sense.

While I have put countless amount of hours into this game, I have moved on, but it will always hold a special place for being the deckbuilder that started all deckbuilders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
REVISED REVIEW:

I admit, at first, I hated this game a lot, if you want to know why, you can see my OLD REVIEW below.  However, after playing about 50 games, using a mix of cards from the original, and the expansions Intrigue, Seaside, and Prosperity, I have found a great appreciation for the Dominion SERIES, however, the original is still lacking in strategy and player interaction, when compared to the expansions.  I think one of the reasons I was so hard on the game was it was my first deck-building game, and although it seemed like a great mechanic, the game didn't see fun to me.  I laid out 3 reasons this game was bad (see below), but I will now admit that there is really only one flaw in this game, and thats with player interaction.  There is more strategy to Dominion than I originally thought, but it takes playing with other players that are knowledgable about the game to see it.  Now that I have played several decked building games over the years like Thunderstone, Ascension, and Legendary, and the shuffling doesn't bother me at all anymore.

I have revised the overall score to 3 stars, but I give Intrigue and Prosperity 5 stars, that is a great combination, making a very strategic and interactive game.  I hope this helps anyone buying this game, if given the choice, I would buy Intrigue over the orginal as a stand alone game, and then consider expanding it once you have the hang of it.  Although, there are a few cards in the orinigal that are really good cards, but I'm not sure if buying the whole game just for a few cards is worth it, considering you have the choice (when I bought Dominion, there were no expansions yet, for the record).  

OLD BLISTERING REVIEW (revised due to many of the comments below, playing the games more, and the expansions)

I feel like I'm the only gamer that hates this game on general principle.  When I first bought this game I really wanted to like it; in fact I HAD to like it because EVERYONE likes it.  I don't like ANY aspect of this game, but instead of going through them all, I will stick to the 3 things that KILL this game.  ONE: its 4 player solitaire.  There is so little interaction between players its boring.  I have heard that some of the expansions fix this problem, but I hated this game and I'm not spending $50 more dollars on the off chance I might like it.  TWO: It looks like a strategy game, but there's really only one strategy, BUY GOLD.  Nothing beats this strategy, and even thought you are given a plethora of action cards, most of them just add useless cards to your deck, whereas more money always puts you in the best place for every situation.  Of course, some would say, doesn't that just mimic real life, if you have more money, you can do more.  Of course it does, but who ever thought a game was good because it mimics real life?  Quite in the opposite in my opinion.  THREE:  Shuffling, MY GOD the shuffling.  I really don't mind shuffling cards, but after the 300th time, I get sick of it.  Yes, you could go out and buy an automatic card shuffler, but, and I'll ask it again, WHY OH WHY, would I want to spend MORE MONEY on this train wreck.  Any game that makes you spend more, or buy expansions, just to make the game good isn't a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Fair.  Fast play, short games.  Having the right card mix is pretty essential, but on the other hand randomly selecting them is fun too. There's no real theme to the game, and at the end there's nothing to really talk about -- no narrative, story, or anything.  It feels a little overdeveloped, like all the rough (and interesting) edges were streamlined out of existence.

Looks to be a huge money pit with all the expansions on the horizon.  I'm not really feeling the need to be a completist these days so I'll probably wait and see.

RATING: 8

This is my most played game but my rating has dropped over time as I've lost interest.

RATING: 6

RATING: 6
UPDATE: So many deck builders are so much better than the first one now. Sold.

UPDATE: Dominion is wearing thin on me -- I think the deckbuilding mechanic is great, but it just ends up feeling like a one-trick pony in terms of the actual gameplay. Also, the graphic design of the cards varies widely but unlike Magic: the Gathering or Blue Moon, the general quality of the artwork is pretty mediocre. It also seems like the franchise is moving into Carcasonne-like levels of expansionitis. I need to leave this one alone for a while.

-----------
First impressions are very positive: easy to teach, lots of variety. I like the "CCG-like" aspect of it combined with the ease of getting into the whole thing, especially with new players.

I have a few minor annoyances with card design, but what are you going to do?

RATING: 5
Rio Grande have been doing very well with their strategy card games lately.  The rules are so easy that I literally explained all of the rules to a friend in less than 5 mins.  I don't see it being difficult for anyone to understand how to play this.  Being played well is another matter because deck construction is definitely a refined talent involving consistency, synergy and creativity.  Dominion is the grandfather of all deck building games and yet it's still probably the most popular.  That's certainly a testament to the games quality.  Unfortunately in the base game, there is not a lot of variety in the cards and not a lot of decisions in the order in which to play your hand.

Digital Alert:

The biggest downside for me is that there is a lot of shuffling during the game as well organization of the stacks of cards before and after the game.  This makes the physical copy about a 4 rating for me.  If I was rating this just based solely on BSW online play, I would probably rate this a 6.  I would be even more keen to be able to play it on iOS if it has both AI and online options.  I hear it's in the works and will update this entry if it does come to pass and I try it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

Az első pár kör még érdekes, amíg beindul a szekér, de utána átmegy egyfajta automatizmussá, kicsit gyerekkorom pirosozása jutott eszembe, ha valaki tudja miről beszélek. Igazából nem nagyon figyelve a másikra, a felhúzott lapok alapján már automatikusan teszem a dolgomat, és várom, mikor jönnek a várva várt értékek.
Maradok a San Juannál, ahol sokkal nagyobb a játékosok közötti interakció, ahol végig feszített az izgalom, s nem csap át holmi passziánszá.

RATING: 5
Gifted to me!!!!!!!!! Yay me!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
12-11-10:  1st game 3 players...until my daughter fell asleep at the table.  She was buying tons of silver and gold.  All of sudden, a 2-player game.  Mystery Bob starting doing tons of multi-action and multi-card draw combos and getting more and more cards, and more and more money.  I started getting more money and slowly buying duchys and provinces.  After several multi-action card and multi-buys turns by Mystery Bob, I quietly bought more VPs and quietly ended the game.  He was...surprised!!!!!

2nd play - Village Square set up.  I won by 2 points.  Played 3-player and my daughter finally started seeing how to utilize her action cards to maximize her buying power.  Pretty fun!!

3rd play - Big Money set up.  Mystery Bob finally won...by 1 point!  Played 2-player; I ended by buying the last Province Card, but I had trashed 2 of my Estate cards early in the game via the Chapel.

Once you get past the novelty of the card combos, there is nothing left.  I can win easily as my husband becomes distracted by making longer and longer card combos.  I focus on points and usually squeeze a win right by him.  Only game I lost was because I trashed an Estate card--if I hadn't I would have won. 

Have not played in a long time.  TRADED!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My feelings on Dominion ebb-and-flow much more than with other titles. I love the puzzle of 'solving the market'. Which cards interact best with the other cards? Which cards will my opponents target, and how can I counter them? Is this game going to play quickly or slowly, and how can I tailor my strategy around that? This puzzle solving keeps me in love with Dominion. However, once the game actually starts, it feel like it drags on. I run through the motions and hope the Provinces dry up quickly, so I can try to solve the market again. But the constant expansions keep drawing me back in, and my first games playing Seaside were some of my favorite ever.

RATING: 8.93
deck building in a pure form. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Limiting actions and buys per turn adds a lot of strategic depth and makes the game generally more punishing than other deckbuilders I have played. Looks like there is more of a barrier for newer players and more to be explored and replayed due to this limitation in play. Keeping the same cards available all game reduces chance of a plan being ruined by the wrong cards coming out. While the deckbuilding mechanic itself has been done to death, these differences make Dominion very distinct from games like Legendary, Ascension, and Star Realms
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Enjoyable, but a little dull.

I like the basic deck-building idea (although I still prefer something like Magic where you can do the deckbuilding on your own time), and pulling off combos is fun.  The basic set of cards, which is what I have mostly played with, is well balanced, and gives a surprising number of different possibilities.  

The downfall of the game, however, is that there is virtually no interaction.  You are just racing to see who can build the best deck fastest; you are not playing against the opponent, but instead both of you are playing against the game.  The upshot of this is that the game gets old quickly.  It was fun at first, but as soon as I had figured out the combos, there wasn't anything left.  

So, in summary: pleasant and at first interesting, but not very interactive and so lacking in replay value.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
