RATING: 9
I really enjoy Dominion.  It has the deck building that reminds me of MtG, and the play is fairly quick; allowing for multiple games fairly painlessly.  I can see this as becoming one of my top 10 games.  To make set up / take down easier, I have converted all the cards into a trading card box, with index cards separating and naming each card.  (using colored cards for each set, but ABC order for all.)  Makes carrying and storing the game a breeze.  Many others in my group have now abandoned the provided box from Rio for the CCG generic box.

RATING: 7
"You are a monarch, like your parents before you, a ruler of a small pleasant kingdom of rivers and evergreens. Unlike your parents, however, you have hopes and dreams! You want a bigger and more pleasant kingdom, with more rivers and a wider variety of trees. You want a Dominion! In all directions lie fiefs, freeholds, and feodums. All are small bits of land, controlled by petty lords and verging on anarchy. You will bring civilization to these people, uniting them under your banner.

But wait! It must be something in the air; several other monarchs have had the exact same idea. You must race to get as much of the unclaimed land as possible, fending them off along the way. To do this you will hire minions, construct buildings, spruce up your castle, and fill the coffers of your treasury. Your parents wouldn't be proud, but your grandparents, on your mother's side, would be delighted."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b][thread=507774]The PLAYMOBIL® Legion reviews "Dominion"[/thread][/b]

(As of [b]127[/b] plays) The genre-defining deck-building game. I find that winning efficiently is not necessarily as satisfying as discovering new and unlikely card combinations. Not the Greatest Game Ever, but easily my Most Played Game Ever and, contrary to my early predictions, I am still not tired of it. Replayability is vastly improved by the expansions, especially [GAMEID=40834], which manages to revitalize the gameplay without introducing too many new mechanics.

[b]Why this is in my Top Ten:[/b] Dominion is all about the joy of discovery - discovering what cards work well together, discovering new strategies, etc. Every time I have played Dominion, I have experienced the joy of discovery. Occasionally the discovery in question is "Wow, that was a [i]terrible[/i] idea"... but I still get joy from it. Plus, the relatively simple gameplay makes it possible to introduce this joy to new gamers. 

[b]2 year verdict:[/b] I don't see any sign of my interest in this game diminishing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3, 2-4

RATING: N/A
Lisa
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
In my opinion, the endless shuffling is part of the appeal.  This, like knitting, is an activity for slightly hyperactive people who need to be doing something with their hands all the time.  I like to sit quiet and nearly motionless, save for scratching my beard in deep thought, so this game is not for me.

The game seems to work well enough, but once you've worked out the strategies for each set of cards, it becomes a matter of luck between experienced players.  A new set offers interesting new strategic inquiry, but I don't get the sense it takes that long to work out the best options, so buying new decks will be required to give the game longevity.

I always take the cards that nobody else takes, because I feel sorry for them.  My anthropomorphizing tendencies make me finish last again.

RATING: 6
Played a number of times now. A good and innovative game. I just simply do not understand it. Luck seems too important in this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is just a temporary rating, since I haven't gotten to play with all of the cards yet. Dominion has been immensely enjoyable so far, but I wish there were more opportunities to screw your opponents. If we don't play with the Witch or the Thief (or, to a lesser extent, the Spy or the Bureaucrat), the only interference will be racing to grab the Chapel/Laboratory/Market cards first. 

Still, so far it's been scratching my CCG itch. Some combos are glaringly obvious, but there have been a few fun ones to discover. And as a longtime CCG player, I feel right at home tweaking my strategy between games to find the best optimization for my deck.

That above statement is my only potential caviat: Dominion, at its core, is an efficiency game. Find the optimal turn-based buys for whatever mix of cards you're using, rinse and repeat. And if there were only the ten basic kingdom cards included, Dominion would be a puzzle to solve instead of a game to play. However, there's a lot of customizing and variety included here, so I'm not worried about it losing its spark anytime soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A CCG-style game and a less confrontational version of MtG where you build your deck on the fly.

- pros: scales well, interesting decisions, synergistic combos/cards, quick play-time, good replayability, unique mechanics and gameplay
- cons: luck element, lots of shuffling, weak theme, minimal player interaction.

The unique mechanics, interesting decisions, potential for synergy and interesting gameplay, combined with quick gameplay and remarkable replayability/variety really makes the game.

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/354034]The starting player has an advantage[/url] if he triggers the game end, [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2974072#2974072]even the designer admits this[/url].  Solution: Perhaps the other players should received the opportunity to finish the round? Or get one more turn?  See [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/356437]my proposed variant[/url]: [i]When the end game is triggered, players complete the round.  No additional Victory cards are made available for purchase, aside from the ones already remaining available.[/i]. For more discussion, see the thread about the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/368753]equal number of turns[/url] variant.  This is probably the best solution (although people earlier in turn order are slightly disadvantaged by this variant because maybe they would have bought victory points had they known the game would end; but people late in turn have disadvantage that Province cards are all used up).  Either way there seems to be a slight advantage, either to starting players (with official rules), or later players (with 'finish the round' variant) - which is lesser of the two evils?  Probably the "equal turns" variant is best.  Note that the number of Provinces is always divisible by the number of players.

Good resources on why the [thread=784021]Big Money[/thread] strategy isn't auto winning.

Which expansion next?  See: [geeklist=141264][/geeklist]  Seaside, Prosperity, and Dark Ages (35 new cards) are best.

See my pictorial review here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/356227

Expansions also owned: 
[gameid=51811]
[gameid=66690]

Also: [gameid=110831] and [gameid=66682]

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
At first I was very impressed with the design of Dominion and played several games in a row. I still think it's clever though not for me. It is what it is, and for some people it's gaming crack while for others it's much ado about nothing. You're basically playing against yourself to see if you can make longer and longer card chains based on a different starting point each turn. 

I get that that is absolutely fascinating to some people. It's too akin to chewing gum for me; even in my card games I need something more substantial than that. The cycle of expansions is necessary because you get bored with solving the same puzzle over and over, so I don't see how they can ever stop cranking them out. 

I've subsequently come to appreciate deckbuilding when it's part of a larger construct, but let's thank Dominion for getting us there. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I should like Dominion since I usually prefer playing card-based games, but the game is far from being my favourites. You mostly have the feeling that everyone is building a deck of his/her own (and that you're playing alone), and most of my playing time passes while I wait more skillful players to end their turns.

RATING: 7
After several plays, this is becoming the pick-up game of request. so easy to learn and fast. the variability keeps each round fresh and the card combos are great fun to trigger.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I discovered deck builder mechanic from Trains, the descendant of Dominion. My favorite part of Trains is the card play and deck building so it was natural give a try for Dominion. So far I haven't yet bothered playing Trains again. The deck building and card combos in Dominion are pure brilliance.

I have to admit that I just could not hold myself and immediately bought a pile of expansions although I could easily continue playing on with base set only. The learning curve that I have witnessed for base set is brilliant. First you just start messing around and trying different ideas with cards. Slowly you start discovering synergy between the cards until you reach the point where you are able to properly formulate (at least seemingly) sensible strategy for the whole game. After that you will improve in the evaluation of efficiency and quality of strategies. I hope that the same process is started all over again for the each expansion.

The rating for this is the overall rating for Dominion and its expansions. The reason why it deserves rating this high is the combination of the brilliant game system and excellent content (cards) for the system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Another minor complaint: the base game does not feel complete by itself.  Do yourself a favor and buy an expansion too (just not Alchemy).  I recommend Prosperity.

RATING: 8
Based on 25 plays, some of which online (BSW).
+ Variability
+ Fast pace
+ Easy to learn the basics
+ Multiple viable stategies of winning
> Storage solution is a challenge, especially with expansions.
- Card shuffling is annoying and slows the game down. In this regard the online version is superior.
- Some cards slow the game down, such as Witch, but are often too good to be left to other players.

Since 2009, updated Dec 2011.

RATING: 9.5
Rating is not for just how "good" I think this game is, but for how simple it is to play, how simple it is to teach, how much fun other people have with the game when they play it and how much fun I ALWAYS have when I play it.

I also enjoy that it plays on the shorter side, the random setup possibilities, the gazillion different card combos you can play with, the spiffy shuffling of cards, the whacky combos that can be built and the player interaction that may or may not be there depending on the cards.

I think I have babbled long enough...

RATING: 5
Don't get me wrong, I used to love this game, and I would play the crap out of it. But, that was when I was all about winning games, and not about playing them. I constantly lost, and I feel like the fact that there is a decent amount of skill in this deck builder means I felt I should be able to win more. Suffice to say, I am sick of the game. Eventually, the games feel like competitive solitaire, and they get similar. I appreciate the game for being the first of its kind, and helping me get into gaming, but I have moved on to games that don't make me so focused on winning, and not about the experience. The game is the focus when you play dominion, not the people playing. That's what I think is missing for me

RATING: 7.5

I would never buy this.  If I have the urge again, I will go back to playing on BSW.

RATING: N/A
8+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played 50+ times with 2-4 players, including 1p and 2p games on Goko etc.

2011: When I first tried this out (in 2008 when it first came out), it felt too mathy and mechanical and I decried the lack of theme. I gave it a 6. Then I traded for a copy a year ago just to get rid of a game I didn't want, knowing that Dominion was a fairly sought after game. I didn't play it the first year I owned it. Then I lugged it out one day when most of the rest of my games were packed up, and suddenly I saw the variation in tactics the game offered. "Hm. Well at least that part is fun." I gave it a 7. It intrigued me, so I taught it to a different friend and her and I both had a blast. I gave it an 8. I traded for the Intrigue expansion so I wouldn't burn out on the base game early. Intrigue was awesome, and it made me realize how "boring" the base game is. A week later I forgot to bring down Intrigue so it was back to base set only. And it was awesome. I gave it a 9. Today I taught my friend's boyfriend to play, having also taught it to another friend last night, and realized that even the base game is something that (right now) I can't get enough of. I give it a 10.

AUG/13: As a GAME SYSTEM, Dominion rates as a 10 for me, no question. The base game though is not as interesting to me as some of the subsequent expansions, and using BGG's rating system, I have to give the base game an 8. The expansions range from 8 to 10 for me. Dark Ages is the one I enjoy the most. Then Seaside. Then Hinterlands.

SEP/13: Taught this to a new friend, then taught it to my brother and his girlfriend, both instantly wanted to buy copies. This game is just that good. You can complain about the solitaire nature of the game, but people seem to enjoy the puzzle aspect of the game in a social setting.

Rating history: 6|7|8...|9...|10...|9...|8...
GAME SYSTEM RATING: 10. Awesome gameplay, and combining plays from the game system, I'm over 100.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fun game that anybody anywhere likes to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast, easy, strategy in card management.  Thousands of possible card combinations, so very replayable.  Can't wait for expansions on this one.

Since I have alphabitized the cards in the box, in order to truely choose cards randomly, printed the names on paper and draw 10 face down.  Then people complain about the combinations or lack of combinations--I say, play it how we draw it.  It demands creativity and leads to new discoveries in play.  To play a game without extra buys or actions can be very difficult, and adds new dimension to the game.

I think I am going to fall over and feint...My husband, with whom I have logged over 7,000 plays of Lost Cities, but besides that will play only 10 Days in Asia, and Crokinole, announced he will replace Lost Cities with DOMINION!  How did this miracle happen?  Our daughter was visiting and wanted to play and her father did not want to be left out!  He slogged through 3 games whining, cursing, and complaining...so knock me over and revive 3 days later when he announced he liked it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
12/8/09  Since I'm on the very cutting edge of board games, I think I'm finally going to try Dominion tomorrow.

12/9/09  Played first 3 games of Dominion, all 2-player. Liked it alot, but wish we had more players. It just became a race for a couple key cards.

12/10/09  Been thinking about Dominion quite a bit (sign of a good game). I want more theme and less focus on one card or two. Maybe Thunderstone?

1/27/10  I played Thunderstone last night. I think I liked it more than Dominion in almost every way.

4/13/10  Played Dominionx2. I'm kind of indifferent to it still and I think it's kind of souring me on Thunderstone, too. Genre might not be for me.

9/21/10  Ascension was fun. I liked it better than Thunderstone and much better than Dominion. Maybe this whole deck-building thing will have legs.

10/12/10  Game night started with Dominion. I liked it more than normal. Alchemy cards, better randomized cards, or the fact that I won?

11/2/10  Played Dominion (with Seaside for the first time). I'm probably disliking Dominion less, thankfully since it's kind of unavoidable.

6/21/11  Dominion - I'll never be a fan, but I'm at the point where I don't actively hate it. I'll play, but won't suggest it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
IMO, best card game ever with the highest replay-ability you'll ever get in a game - IF you get several of the expansions - and there's a lot, with no word on when they'll stop coming.

This was the first popular deck building game and is still far and away the best.

If you've never tried it, the core game is available online for free to play as much as you want - you'll have to pay for expansions, though. And if you like it enough to get expansions, I recommend buying the physical game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's not that Dominion is a bad game; indeed, when I first got it I really loved it. It's just that there are games that take its basic mechanic set, improve what's bad, and eliminate what's terrible. Effectively, this game has been iterated upon and improved beyond all recognition.

That said, it's unlikely to leave my collection because it is, frankly, the grandfather of the genre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Easy to understand and teach.  I enjoy the elegant design of this game.  It doesn't have the heavier feel that causes me to give games a higher rating, but that doesn't mean I don't really like this game.  I really do enjoy playing Dominion.  My wife enjoys this game too.  She brings it out every evening for the two of us to play on the kitchen table.  We do the random Kingdom Cards setup each time and it's always an interesting game.

No doubt about it, my wife really likes this game.  I heard her teliing friends about it on the telephone.

BTW, my wife and I both enjoy playing this game against each other on BSW.  Removing all that card shuffling is good.  However I do not include these plays in my recorded game play counts at BGG.

RATING: 9
Stepped down from 10 due to mild burnout. Still a great game, but the urge to play has waned a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The granddaddy of all deck-building games still the best. My rating for the Dominion system is a 10: this rating of 9 is specifically for the first edition core set. Like most, I greatly prefer the cards in later expansions. If you're starting a collection or just want to play casually, you're going to want the [thing=209418]second edition core set[/thing].

Even knowing how many official Kingdom cards there are between all the expansions and promos, it's still amazing how different the game is every time. The other great thing about Dominion is that it literally has four or five rules, and everything else you need to know is on the cards, all of which are pretty self-explanatory. Every time I've played, I've offered to go over all of the Action cards with my opponents, but they've always declined and we've managed just fine.

We're working our way through the recommended sets included with each expansion as we get them. Lately, that's been the easiest way for us to get going with a game, as opposed to randomizing a set. Most of my plays are recorded under the base game, including games using randomly generated sets of 10 cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Plays include all owned expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Speedy, casual game with a fantastic mechanic that allows massive replayability with a decent depth of strategy. The theme is rather irrelevant to the gameplay. It's possible to burn out on this game if you play it too much.

Duration: Fast, especially when there are fewer players.
Design: The rules are very simple and elegant, making this a great gateway game. The deck drafting is fantastic; you get a lot of control over your approach. The Kingdom card selection and the interactions between them keeps things fresh. There is a first player advantage, and limited interaction in some setups, especially with fewer players.
Strategy: You have many options, but there tend to be optimal approaches and suboptimal Kingdom cards. I play for fun and ignore them.
Components: The art style is all over the place, and some cards are sub par.
Theme: Generally there is little integration with the bland theme, but it happens on occasion (eg Bureaucrat, Thief).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Collectible Card Game minus the Collectable = game I'm very intrested in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cards are sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
Boy did I fall in love with this one right away. I still really like it. For the length of time you devote to any single game, I believe Dominion offers greater depth and variability (& re-playability) than any game I've ever played. Even without direct player interaction, this game forces you to balance what you want to do with what you see your opponents trying to do. I love the aspect of figuring out how to use the cards in combination, how to build a good deck. 

Two things happened that knocked the game down in my eyes. One (and this happens with games I play), I started playing it on BSW. I played hundreds and hundreds of games. I got really good at it. And I became obsessed with not only the game, but with my win percentage. So I overplayed, and stopped enjoying myself as I became obsessed with keeping my ranking up. So I quit playing all together. The other thing was, I realized that buying money is, for the most part, more important than buying action cards. The cards are what makes the game fun. When I began focusing on my money supply more than my action cards, I became a much better player. And I enjoyed the game a little bit less.

I came back to the game face to face after about 6 weeks of not playing, and realized I still really love it. It will never hold quite as much allure it once held. My gaming group absolutely loves this game, it is played often and well there.

EDIT: As of this writing. expansions up to Prosperity are published. I have again fallen heavily in like with this game. There are so many card set combinations, so many strategies, so many cool ways to play. I just love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A great, and now legendary, deck building game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is fun but it sure is fiddly.  I'm talking about all the card stacks, the shuffling and the post game sorting to straighten it all up.  For a card game it isn't very portable and hogs table space.  It seems like the kind of game where if your opponents have read strategy guides on the geek they will crush you every time.  The interactions of the cards are fun but really money is more important.  Going for the gold and buying provinces works well but takes some of the fun out of all the card combos.  Just when the decks get interesting the game is over.  Running out of provinces is a harsh game timer.  I can't get too excited about a game where my aim is to get a playing card with gold coin printed on it.  Not too much theme or interest there.  I suppose it scratches the Magic itch, like people say, but Magic the Gathering wasn't ever really boardgaming either.  

It feels like only part of a game to me, and I'd rather play regular board game for a more satisfying experience.  Still if you want a fast, fun filler and don't mind a lot of setup and shuffling, it's good.


Update:  Played a bunch, good solid game. Enjoy it when I play, but don't pine away for it. The shuffling feels like Fred Flintstone when he's running in place in the cartoons.  Doesn't go anywhere.

RATING: 9
Rules Complexity: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Player Interaction: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Depends on the cards used in any given game)
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Depends on the cards)
Theme Integration: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:

"The shuffling game".  This is a very intriguing game that I think is worth owning not just because it's so different from everything else, but because it's an engaging puzzle about building an economic machine that will help you rake in the victory points, while being a race game at the same time.  It presents the classic problem of "when do I stop focusing on getting money so that I can start grabbing victory points?".  While many of the tactical decisions are obvious, it's important to chart out the strategic course from the beginning of the game, and there can be a variety of paths to victory.

- Shuffle, shuffle, shuffle...
- Very little interaction between the players

RATING: 2
I am really finding it hard not to give this game a "1".  I guess there's SOMETHING to it, but I can't figure out what. It's simply an exercise in boredom and frustration.  You have this great "deck-building" mechanic, and then can't actually us it to any extend because you throw all your cards away every turn.  Besides the fact that you have your own deck, this has no similarity to a collectible card game AT ALL.

I was playing with folks that play Dominion often and like the game, and they would just quickly take their turn with even saying a word.  It was sort of like 6 people playing solitaire at the same table.  It didn't even allow for SOCIAL interaction, let only interaction related to the game. 

And I don't mind a decent luck factor in a game, but this game seems just rigged to be annoyingly UNlucky, no matter how much strategy you employ.

How is it at all possible that this is ranked so high?  One of the worst games I have ever played (and I have a fairly decent collection and games played). 

I guess if you want to sit around a table with a bunch of folks and shuffle cards quietly for an hour, this "game" is for you.

RATING: 9
Played today for the first time. We were able to get 3.5 basic games in (I had to leave). Good time was had by all.

It took about 45 minutes/game. Fast playing and different every time with many avenues to build one's deck. Once the first Province (6 VPs and $8) is purchased usually triggers a VP chase. We played with  the basic 10 card-types although I believe there are 25 total card-types.

Lots of replayability and a relatively short playing time should allow it to fit in with most gamers' schedules.

RATING: 6
I enjoy playing this but it hasn't been getting a lot of love since newer, shiner deck builders have been coming out.

The building of your card engine and the comboing of cards is really a cool feeling. It plays quickly and is very smooth. People can pick this up very easily and enjoy seeing the deck that they have constructed churn out benefits. It's the fine tuning that takes casual players a bit longer to get - don't buy all of the shiny cards with nice actions all of the time.

The lack of interaction is fine. If you want more then play something else. Sometimes it's nice, especially for such a quick game, to sit back and build.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is probably one of the best engine/deck building games out there. It plays significantly different with 2,3, or 4 players and the strategies will change all the time. There is a uniqueness to the gameplay as the options for building your decks change every game. Throw in some expansions and you'll never play the same game twice. There is a significant difference between skill levels of new and experienced players. 

Plus: Deck building is fun and allows you to customize your play style.
Minus: Lots and lots of shuffling, get deck sleeves if you can find ones that fit nicely.

Is this a game to have in your collection:Yes
Is this a game children can play:Maybe
Is this a good game for new gamers:Yes

RATING: 4
I don't get it. Even after the first game the mechanics already seemed rather obvious, repetitive, and uninteresting to me. While I applaud the idea of a card game that has all the advantages of a CCG without its disadvantages, this isn't it. I can't believe anyone who has seriously played M:TG finds this interesting.

Dominion is the perfect showcase that seemingly limitless permutations of possible card combinations do not equal limitless replayability. If all the big decisions have been made a couple of turns in and all the rest is played on autopilot what's the point?

RATING: 8.5
I was worried that it's popularity meant we wouldn't like it. On the contrary, we love it and have been able to get a friend playing it who absolutely refused to play our "types" of games before he played this. I love that you can play several games in one sitting and not get sick of it because of the variety. I also love how we still talk about our hands hours after we finished playing. That means we had fun, and isn't that the point?
Unfortunately, now that I've played Race for the Galaxy, I prefer it over Dominion, and Dominion has had less plays as a result.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game. Variable setup, satisfying engine-building, amusingly rickety theme (but who cares about that?). Surprisingly simple to teach and once people get the hang of it it almost always hooks them. Downtime is a bit of a problem with 4 but that's why you play it with 2 or 3.

RATING: 8.5
Plays very much like a CCG, without the need for buying thousands of dollars worth of packs. The balance can vary wildly depending on the cards selected for any particular round. So any given game could be near-perfect, or be cluttered by scores of useless card choices.

Overall this game works, and provides a huge variety of possibilities even with just the base set.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think this is one of the best games to teach new gamers. All the kingdom cards are right out there for you to explain at the beginning, or as they are able to afford them, and it's real easy to play as you go and correct them as you go. Further, just doing the basic strategy of buying silver until you can use it to buy gold is something a new player can do. I've done it while teaching others so they could see how their attack cards disrupted me.

Beware of trying to go nuts with combo cards. Oftentimes you only need to get a couple of cards in your deck.

I'm tired of shuffling. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2-4 players
Card game
Deck building game - Winner is the player with the most VP cards in their deck when the game ends.
Buy cards from the community supply that are either VPs, money (to help buy more expensive cards) or support cards.
30 min

RATING: 8
So yes I rated Dominion the same as Agricola. They are both equally fun in there genre.

I am not much of a 'deck builder' kind of guy but this game is quite fun. First you have all the cards you need. So, no need to spend more money on more powerful cards (like some other game).

The only issue I had with it was the price of the game. Over 50$ for 500 cards, a rulebook, a plastic cardholder and an oversized box. I don't care what people say about the art. This is quite expensive.

I love the game but I would recommend people to try it before they buy. This is the kind of game you want to be sure about otherwise I will sit on a shelf.

RATING: 10
Second edition fixes all problems the original game had. I have no qualms with recommending this game.

Making the construction of the deck the primary mechanic of the game was a stroke of genius. The shared supply of cards makes this title incredibly strategic. Its modular structure makes it easy to play over and over again.
The simplicity makes this easy to teach, but perhaps too plain for experienced gamers when another set with the base cards is available.

(164 plays, underestimate)
First Impressions: 9

I have been working on this fan expansion since the release of Guilds.

RATING: 6
EDIT:  Obsoleted for me by several of its children.

---------------

A genuinely great little card game, deceptively deep.

Eurogamers have "claimed" this as one of their own, but this isn't a Eurogame.  It is truly the offspring of the CCG realm, ported to a single-box form.

Yeah, the theme is not there, but I can easily demonstrate how badly themed most CCGs ultimately are, how surprisingly abstract all but a few of them can be.  

Unlike Race for the Galaxy or Agricola, this one's probably truly worth the "hype."


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Custom PnP on Poker Chips : Dominion + Intrigue set.

Dominion is a game that I loved initially, played it dozens of times face-to-face and tons upon tons of times on BSW.  I was completely enamored with it.

Now, I rarely play it, because several of the children it has spawned have eclipsed it, with more interaction, more confrontational gameplay, more theme, etc.  So while I still fire up the AI version for a quick fix, I haven't played the actual game in several, several months.

I'm bumping down my rating, but only a bit.  I rarely want to play this anymore, but I have a huge amount of respect for the game for generating a whole new genre.

But the common criticisms about the game are true.  The theme is thin, the interaction very low.  Also, the game peaked with Prosperity; Alchemy was pretty bad, but the expansions since Prosperity have all been worse than Alchemy on almost every level.  So the game too is getting worse with each expansion now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love this game!  Have all the expansions up to but not including the adventurers.

RATING: 8.173
One of those rare games that lives up to the buzz.  A wonderfully unique method of play, which turns your hand & deck into an efficiency engine.  Different card sets produce different feel of game.  Just a great card game, if possibly a little tad too long (25/10/10). UPDATE : Well, the spark never really turned into a flame - I will play it, it just does not bite me - rating reduced from 8 to 6 - but I am still willing to be convinced otherwise (24/12/11) UPDATE: I could possible be in the process of being convinced; rating raised to 7 (17/11/12). UPDATE: More plays and I'm convinced! Rating back to 8 (Dec 2013). UPDATE: Updated using v2 upgrade kit (Rating 8.173, Jan 17)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Me and my wife used to love this game. It was probably a favorite for both of us. For me it has been fading a little bit over the past years, but I still enjoy it a lot. I still wish it had more theme, but the gameplay still works great for me. Always challenging with the infinite amount of combinations you can make. Great with 2, but also with more players.

Also own:
-Intrigue: Brings more cards and the option to play with 5 or 6 players. It still works alright with 5 or 6, but is better with less.
-Seaside: We love Seaside and the cards that have more ongoing effects.
-Alchemy: An interesting concept with the potion cards, but it can be hard to get a good balanced set of 10 cards when you pull at random.
-Prosperity: The bigger money and VP values are great additions and make the game even more interesting.
-4 Promo Cards (Black Market, Envoy, Governor, Walled Village)

RATING: 9
Dominion is a great way to get that CCG feel, without having to sink all your money into it.  It has a real neat Deck building mechanic. Trying to balance your need for Treasure, Actions, and Victory Points is the best part of the game! Dominion is the classic deck builder and still does it best when you need a simple card game with lots of choice and engaging game play.  One of my favourites.

RATING: 7
[b]Why I got rid of it:[/b]

The first deck builder I ever played and definitely more strategic than any I've played since but I just didn't get it to the table much anymore. For a card game it's extremely un-portable and cumbersome and I don't think I really want to play games that have deck building as their sole mechanic.

At the end of the day, it's not a bad game, but tough decisions had to be made because I'm trying to thin my collection.

RATING: 4
An interesting little game.  After my first half-dozen plays this seems largely dependent on who can get their economic engine up and running faster.  The fact that early card draws can slant this favor to a player early on is a point of concern.  There is a fair sized variety in the cards, but I am not sure how this promotes replayability other than superficially.  I have enjoyed my plays more than those of RftG, but I am leaning to the side that this game is not deserving of it's hype (although still solid).  There are things here that remind me a lot of St Petersburg, but it doesn't quite feel as complete.

RATING: 6
Playing Dominion gave me a new term to describe games:

A "bubble gum" game - lots of activity, big flavor at start but just a tastless chewy mass after a while.

My rating dropped to a "6" and I sold it off.

--------

We've played 6 more times now and yes, this is rather addictive.  We are still playing with the basic 10 Action cards.  The last three games we have been experimenting with combinations: which means concentrating on buying several of only a few of the Action cards.  In the last two games I've won with a Workshop/Remodel deck (4 of each) and then with a  Village/Woodcutter deck (4 of each).  I was giggling the whole time.  It really is fun to imagine that a combination will work and then to "try it" - the games are so short and painless that you can experiment till your hearts content.

-----

I'm bumping it to an 8.  

After 3 play I'll start Dominion at a "6".  This game has added a new term to my Vocabulary: a "bubble gum game" - one that is process heavy, is not too taxing.  It seems interesting enough to keep you playing it.  

There are a number of others like this in our collection, and we tend to play them fairly frequently, so I suspect that this will be a keeper.

RATING: 5
The rules are extremely simple and it is very easy to learn HOW to play the game.  How to play WELL, however, is another matter.  There is an amazing amount of replayability, with 25 different cards from which you choose 10 for each game.  It's clear, also, that no matter the cards, there are different paths to victory.  After our slow first game during which we learned the rules, our second game went very, very fast.  Be warned, though - I think this is a very geeky game and although I consider it to be very light, it is definitely not something to break out unless you have fairly seasonsed board game players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've mixed in all my Dominion cards, so I have trouble ranking the base game by itself. The base game, as I recall, was kind of bare. With a good number of expansions, though, became a glorious game. Dominion is what got me into modern board games (even though there's no "board," per se). The setup is a little tedious and time consuming (if you are picking through all the cards from all the expansions like I'm doing), but it's a great game to introduce to non-gaming friends and everyone always has a good time (provided there are not too many attack cards in the kingdom). I've since moved on to other games and hardly break Dominion out these days, but I still think of it fondly. As far as playing a game these days, I have trouble getting it to the table because of the following:

- Setup takes forever. Dominion is only fun with expansions, and with all the expansions, the card selection takes a long time, if you want to have a balanced game. Just pulling out the cards to make the kingdom and putting them back is too much time spent for how much game you get.

- Having played hundreds or thousands of games of Dominion on my phone, I'm kind of worn out on the game, and the tabletop version just feels sooo slooow (even though the human interaction is unmatched).

- The shuffling does get tiring, especially since there are cards in the game seemingly designed for apps and not physical card play (Philosopher's Stone, Scavenger, etc.).

- I didn't think the game was dry at first, back when I first got into the hobby, but after playing more thematic games that are just as strategic or more so, I simply crave more engaging / interesting games. 

- The giant box of Dominion cards is too much of a pain in the ass to pull out for a 30-minute game. 

Update: Just became too unwieldy (physically and gameplay-wise), and the setup-time/playing-time ratio was too burdensome, and our interest in other games too strong, to hold on to it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ok I must admit that I was very very leary about this game. All I kept thinking was it was going to be similar to MTG and  Munchkin. Both of which I can't stand. Once the rules were explained to me. I was like ughhh. I am gonna hate this, but I must say I had a very fun time playing it. It was nothing like the two forementioned games that I despise. After my first play I had decided it was fun and I would surely play again, but didn't think it was something I would buy. So on the way home I was thinking about it more and more. Wondering what other cards there were and how they would come into play. Then I started thinking about all the endless combinations of games that could be played. Especially with the expansion and another expansion to be due out soon. So, after many hours of thinking about it. I wound up purchasing both the game and expansion and I am very glad I did so.

This game is just plain fun. It has endless numbers of possible setups for each game, which keeps things fresh. It plays quick and there is hardly any down time between turns what-so-ever. There's the possibility to pull off some incredible card combos, screw the other players and lots of strategies and tactics that can be used.

In fact I was told at the begining of my first play that I was going to suck at the game, because I wasn't familiar with the cards and how they worked. Well, I wound up tieing for first place, but can see this statement being very true. It takes a few plays to learn the cards and different ways to use them, but I picked up on things pretty quickly and did pretty well and had fun doing so.

So for anyone out there who still has doubts about this game. I say give it a try. I am not very fond of most card games, but am very glad that I took the time to try this game. It has a lot to offer.

Thanks to my friends Josh, Dave and Chris who introduced this great game to me. I am already excited about picking up the new expansion.

**UPDATE** This is becoming one of my favorite all time games. I just can't stop playing it. At first I thought they were coming out with expansion way to quick, but they both add so much more to an already terrific game.

RATING: 6.5
Played this at Origins 2007 before Rio Grande picked it up, and again in 2008.  Interesting deck building non-collectible card game.  Lots of combinations, but the luck of the draw definitely matters.  You can buy a bunch of cards to counter your opponent's attacks for example, and draw them all when your opponents haven't drawn the attack card.  If you can live with that kind of luck (as one would expect with any card game), then this is an excellent game.  Also, the design is innovative, and deserves recognition for that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is a card game but very strategic. Unlike many card games, the random element in Dominion is much smaller (or more manageable).

Yes, luck is still a critical factor because it affects what cards you ultimately draw from your deck, which determines your available actions. But you have absolute control over the probability because you decide which cards to buy and how to build your deck. Basically, you make your own luck.

As a result, the "buy" phase is the most important portion of the game. (Of course, the use of Chapel can be very strategic too, but that is a different topic).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought Saturday Nov 22, 2008 and tried for the first time only in May 2009.
After twenty plays or so, I would say that this game is at the same time :
- a pretty clever and very addictive game.
- a too mechanical and not so interesting game
To me, Dominion is really a gamig paradox :
- you feel like playing it and you don't mind doing a second or third game.
- you realize at the end how the quickness of it is due to the lack of real decisions to be made each turn.
If you buy it, no doubt you will enjoy playing it.
If you don't, you will not have missed the masterpiece of gaming.

RATING: 8
It's all been said - deck building, points collecting etc. Dominion has that something. Something that makes a great, everlasting and addictive game. It's not the graphics (very mediocre by the way), it's not the theme (rather abstract) - it's the mechanics.

There are games now that try to recreate and reimplement the same idea - pointless and dull so far. Dominion is a game worth buying to every collection. Casual and hardcore gamer's alike.

RATING: 7
You just have to respect the originality and elegance of Dominion. The game is simple to learn, very varied and has a reasonable amount of depth. However, I'm often not having quite as much fun as I'd hope when playing Dominion. The basic structure of deciding your strategy when you see the cards and then just playing it out does not appeal to me. Also, far too often the gameplay degenerates to me staring blankly at the opposite wall for three minutes at the time when one of my opponents does his draw-draw-draw-shuffle-draw-draw-draw-discard-draw-buy routine, only to complete my own turn in five seconds.

RATING: 8
Coming back to this after Thunderstone blew it out of the water. This isn't as bad as I remembered after playing it to death when it came out. What really killed it for me was playing it on BSW, which was a big mistake. If a game like Dominion has no theme, then BSW is going to wring every drop of life out of it, since you play so quickly with no human interaction. 

The game itself can be pretty good with the right people. It's quick and has a lot of strategy, but is not overwhelming. 

The graphic design and theme is, of course, horrendous. But so be it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the two main games I use to introduce people to gaming. It's so easy to play. You make choices that affect you in the long run...even if "the long run" only lasts 30 minutes.

The theme isn't as bad as people say. I like MOST of the artwork, but the game could play just as well without ANY artwork.

It's fun to analyze the cards you've set up on the table, and figure out a plan of what you're going to buy to get that currency/vp engine going.

The only bad part is that it is difficult to affect other players (without curse cards). Unless you are counting and keeping track of every players points as they buy them you are not going to really feel any tension. (It's not hard to do...but annoying that you have to. Maybe if someone invented a points track that was visible as you played?)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
11/17/15: Probably the only bad thing about this game, at least in this version, is that I'm not much of a fan of the player interaction. Witch = spam curses. Militia = reduce cards. If your opponents are using those cards, you have to take them into account, but with Militia that usually means very little unless you're running a lean deck via Chapel, and with Witch, your only real options are to Chapel or to Witch right back. I actually hate the Witch because its existence in a kingdom means that you are forced to deal with it. I hear later expansions do player interaction better.

But that's really the only con, because otherwise this game is amazing. So many options to choose from. So many possible strategies: big money and its variants, draw-engines, combos -- I love it all. Would always be very happy to play this game.

RATING: 7
I traded for a copy. Looked in the box, saw all those endless rows of sorted cards and quietly put it away. Got the rules out a while later, didn't really gel on what the game was about, put it away again.

Finally I discovered an online verion at goko.com, and after watching the bots cream me a few times it finally clicked. What a neat game it is. I had never encountered 'deck building' before, and now that I know what it is, it is very well executed. Of course familiarity with the cards would help tremendously with long term strategies, and I haven't played it enough to know if any of those strategies are pretty much 'givens' or not.

Also, there are a *lot* of cards. *Lots* and *lots* and *lots* of cards. And the endless recycling of the decks, the ever longer chains of action cards...I honestly can't see myself wanting to do it with real cards. :) So I'll be sticking with online play for this one.

RATING: 7.5
[b]Dominion[/b] [i]Donald X Vacarinno 2008[/i]
A fantastic deck card building game that is one of the best and more fresh ideas created in the last years in the boardgaming industry. I dont think that its deepth is comparable to other games like the classic euro games but it is still a very fast and enjoyable card game, which offers a lot of decissions and options for its short playing time. Dominion base game has been expanded with several aditions that offer new paths to victory and improves the game a bit. I would rate Dominion core game with an eight, but combined with some other expansions it reaches a better qualification and its top 10 status is fair enough to me, although is not one of my favourite games ever it works very well with many kind of players and it is a worthy addition to almost any collection.

RATING: 3
First Play Dec 08 - Interesting mechanics and nice box.  I worry about replayabiltiy despite the 25 "different" decks.  Plays quite solitaire, and even with the interactive cards, there is little you can do to "protect" yourself, either you draw a moat or you don't. Addendum: It's also soulless with a paste-on theme (might as well just have cards saying +1 action etc, I don't really care what they are). 4.2/10 after 5 plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A deckbuilding game beyond compare. Each player starts with game with a simple deck of a few resource cards and victory point cards, then has a chance to add to that deck every turn by buying cards or (sometimes) via action cards. Each newly acquired card becomes part of your deck, cycling through with the rest of your discards when your draw pile is empty. A randomizer mechanic allows for interesting variety in the available cards to purchase.

RATING: 8
The immense depth of strategy makes this game as addicting as nicotine. As soon as you've played, you want to go back and try again - which is something you can actually do with this game because of the manageable play time.

It reminds me of heavily strategic games like Starcraft. Managing a balance between early and late game, different play styles and strategies that are so variable and yet mesh so well. This game is a classic.

I'm looking forward to trying this with the expansions, but I feel like even after enough plays to wear down the edges of the cards, I can still squeeze plenty of worth out of the base game. Great value for the amount of times you'll play.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After quite a few plays on BSW my opinion has changed from mildly enthusiastic to boredom.  Most players on BSW are like me and have an average win % around 50% and since most people play 2-player games that means we are just winning our share.  Then there are the rare players that have a very high win %...these are the "card counters" who can keep track of what's in the hand, draw deck and discard piles (or come pretty close to it).  So for most of us players, it is just kind of a random outcome; for a few there is a great deal of skill.  I've never been good at tracking cards and don't really want to expend that kind of effort.  This is one of those games that fools you into thinking you are actually doing something when in reality, unless you are one of the rare talented card counting players, you are just fooling around.  Won't play this much anymore.

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game, and because of what it has meant in my progression of games, it probably always will be.

I think it is flawless in terms of mechanics, and it meshes so well with the expansions that came after it.

I understand that some people don't like the lack of theme (doesn't bother me one bit), and some people just don't like deckbuilding games, and there's a big chunk of people that don't want to like something that is this popular.

Either way, I think you have to admire and marvel at how intricate and developed the strategies for this are, given the cloak of simplicity it is with it's rules of "draw, play, buy, repeat."  

I can't say enough about this game.

RATING: 6.5
This game is good, and I can see why it's considered one of the greatest games ever made.  But it's not my personal favorite.  That's due more to personal tastes than anything else.  There is a very good amount of strategy in choosing which cards to get, but there's also luck of the draw, though you're pretty much digging your own grave if you buy too many good cards that prove useless if they dilute your deck each game.  On the other hand, there are some cards that are good no matter how many of them you buy, and that puts me off a little.  It may be good strategy, but I can't help but see it as a cheap strategy.

Personally, I prefer Ascension over this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I'm not sure I understand the hype surrounding this one.

The mechanics (ie. deck building) are really not that innovative, since that's been around for close to 20 years now. So, why this seems like a novel concept is beyond me, except that you get the entire card set in a single box. The only thing really novel here, is that building your deck is actually part of the game...but it feels that's all there is to it, and there's nothing else inside the box, really. It's too bad too, since I was looking forward to this one, as I was really into MtG long ago, and was looking forward to something similar like this (all the cards needed to play in one box). 

The mechanics are rather dry, bland, and well, mechanical. The theme is so tissue paper flimsy, you could stick anything on the cards and it wouldn't matter. This is MtG for Eurogamers; no player interaction with a single simple mechanic; shuffle until you develop carpal tunnel... 

As a designer, I also find the font to be ugly, and hard to read, and again, has little to do with the theme, except that the wordmark kind of looks like it's trying to be related to Old English or something similar. The card backs...erk...turquoise, navy and khaki...'nuff said. 

So much could have been done with this games' theme (another dry, medeival euro-game *yawn*), and art, but it has neither. The theme is tacked on to attract the euro crowd, and I can see no other reason for it.

Seriously, there's just some cool mechanics here, with very little actual 'game' inside. Believe me, I looked really hard inside that box, and there's just some interesting mechanics, and little else to keep me interested. Just not my type of game I guess.

It's a game I've tried to finish on several occasions, but the Lady and I get too bored, and move onto other games we find more interesting and fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion is a 2 to 4 player game in which the main mechanic is deck building.

You read that right, this game is more about the deck of cards you end up with than the cards you play in the game. I find it a very original approach which will no doubt be copied in the future by other games.

It’s a medium/light game that takes about 30 minutes of play, very simple to grasp and with a good amount of choices. It’s one of my favorite "filler" games already and I’m always ready to play it.

The objective of this game is to end up with the most victory points in your deck, seeing as those victory serve no purpose on the deck while actually playing, there is a balance to be maintained between cards you can play and cards that will ultimately make you win.

From 2 to 4 players.
Ages 8 and up.
Playing time: 30 to 45 minutes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
We've given this game a dozen or so tries and it's just not for us.  I think we don't like it because the theme isn't really there and we like to get lost in the stories of our games.  Also, we've learned that we don't really care for deck builders.  But the real deal breaker for my wife and I is that we played a couple games without even speaking.... even when we played the "interaction" deck, there was very little interplay between players.  It felt like we were both racing each other in a game of solitaire.

I did some more research online and discovered one of the reasons why people rate this game so highly - the statistical weight of cards and the strategy that can be employed once you know all of the cards, but in the end, it's a card game, and we were looking for a board game.  

Not for us, good to know, as this info will help inform our future game purchases.

UPDATE (several months after the sale)... I've been thinking more about this, as I was recently looking into Android Netrunner LCG.  It never occurred to me to think of Dominion as an evolution of the Magic: The Gathering format.  I think this is where my dissatisfaction came from... I was approaching Dominion from a mindset that wanted to play a board game, and I found a card game.  Had I approached it from the mindset of wanting to play a game like MtG but not deal with the CCG or LCG aspects of it, that would have positioned it better in my mind.  I might give this another try someday.  Just wanted to share my thoughts.

UPDATE:  Nah, forget it.  There's plenty of games out there. No repeats!

RATING: 7

+ Many game starting set up combinations possible, 3'268'760 combinations to be precise,
+ Very high replay value,
+ Good mechanics, fast and easy game play - good playing time,
+ Simple rules, easy to get to play for beginners,
+ Aesthetics are good, cards are nice looking.


Cons:
- Shuffling could be done differently, depending on player, some don't like to shuffle cards at all,
- Not easy to follow how other players are handling their cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I liked Dominion quite a bit at first, then went through a period where I lost my desire to play the game. It suffered in comparison to Race for the Galaxy, which I can play endlessly without feeling like I've exhausted its depth. In comparison, Dominion was much less challenging and much less interactive. In Race for the Galaxy, I feel like I'm playing against the other players. In Dominion, I feel like I'm playing against the 10-card tableau for the round.

But I'm now playing Dominion again and enjoying it. The key for me has been to play it less often and with more realistic, mature expectations. Dominion is what it is. It doesn't have the depth of Race for the Galaxy, but it does have good depth in comparison to its ease of play. There's just enough depth there to keep me engaged rather than playing on autopilot. It has found its niche as a very light game that can and should be played very quickly. If it were easier to set up and tear down, I would play it more often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game runs like a Rolex, and can become an addiction for the right group.
Warning: Aside from the addiction properties, the theme is simply window dressing. You're supposed to be building a kingdom by investing in new properties and ventures that allow you to buy bigger, nicer, huge tracts of land. 
Yes, that was a Monty Python reference. 
But behind the window dressing is a card game you can't put down, which scales perfectly from two to four players, 5 or more if you buy the Intrigue expansion, and there are expansions galore. 
You'll want all of them.

Simplicity itself, the game can be explained in an A, B, C, fashion.
You and your opponents start with the same hand of ten cards: seven Treasure cards that represent money you can spend on more cards, and three Estate cards that represent victory points at the end of the game. 
Each turn you draw five cards from your deck. You can play action cards you've purchased which enable you to take additional actions and/or buy additional cards. As you progress, you can chain these action cards together like a hipster on a five-minute smoke break. After your actions you spend Treasure cards in your hand to purchase new action cards, or cards that represent new lands and add to your victory point total at the end of the game. After you've taken your Actions,(A)and completed your Buying(B), then you Clean up(C)by placing unused cards from your hand into your discard pile, draw 5 cards from your growing supply deck, and the turn moves to the next player. Play continues till someone buys up the last, most-expensive land card, then each player removes only the land cards from their decks, totals the points, and whoever has the most points wins.
That's it. I've just covered the rules for you. There are a few more, but they hardly matter or even factor into the game. It's brilliant I tell you!
And so efficient!
Sometimes things happen so quickly, that it's already your turn before you can shuffle and draw your next five cards. Dominion is easy to teach, develops critical thinking, is constantly evolving with expansions, and is never the same twice.
This is the card game you use to show people that there is something else out there besides UNO and spades.
Slap some Dominion on them and you'll have a new minion in your board and card game empire. They will allow you to teach them other board games because you will have gained their trust. 
Yes, wide-eyed trust. Such a valuable commodity, trust.
Trust is where you start. Once you have gained their trust, the rest is easy.
You may now invite them over for tea and cake. 
They will come willingly. 
Oh, yes. 
Willingly.
They will come...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love Dominion. Lots of fun deck building.

An evergreen favorite, and one that a lot of people already know how to play.

Build up your kingdom from penny-ante to pound-for-pound awesome by buying cards and taking actions to improve your starting deck. At the end of the game, the player with the highest value in (otherwise useless) victory cards wins the day.

RATING: 8.5
Not since Carcassonne have I been blown away by a game like I was the first time I played Dominion. I tried the other top games, Agricola, Puerto Rico, Power Grid, all good games. But none gave me the impression that this game has given me. 

12-30-09: Beginning to lose some steam for me. Just got my gf Seaside and we don't find ourselves itching to play. I do love trying to put together great combos and love the new options available with the expansions, but even with the different action cards the game still feels the same from game to game. And I sure am getting tired of shuffling.

Now days, I mostly play on BSW. So much easier and quicker. Will play F2F if I want to use cards from the expansions not available on BSW.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This was an instant attraction for me and my game group and this was the most played game in 2008, which is a feat considering that I got the game in November. One reason behind this is of course the play time or what game it packs in that time. My general thoughts about most short games are that they are too similar when played many times. With this game the change of the kingdom cards changes the game every time making it feel fresh every time I’ve played it. There isn’t a really deep game in this, but the strategies are subtle enough to make it worthwhile to play again and again making it the perfect filler.

At first I played only the preset decks and I think they are fun as there are generally a few strategies to play with them, but I have slowly abandoned that for mixed sets not because they are bad, but more that it feels fairer. I have also tried it with drafting and it works fine that way too. Generally I prefer faster sets to slower as the game can seem to drag a little. That was especially true in the beginning where most games ended with Province exhaustion.

Expansions make this game shine even more. Once you get the strategies try to get an expansion. This will shake the strategies and make things different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Gamers who like TCGs or CCGs for their mecanism of deck building should be interested in this one as deck building is kind of the core of this game. So it's still kind of innovative as a new game in 2008 but not too strong on interaction. I own the german edition and I must say that they failed in supervising the print process. Comparing it to the Rio Grande version, colors have slightly changed from realistic to colorful and most of all they're darker, much too dark! I feel with the illustrators that must now see their work devaluated by a suboptimal print run. Shame on this evitable publisher mistake. This was just a remark on color trueness. The print quality or ergonomy is no problem.
Otherwise a really good game even if I sometimes get stressed by the constant "shuffle your deck". As the general reception is good I bet there will be some expansions for Dominion.

PS: Any literal similarity from the "Moneylender" to me is pure hazard :devil:

Update: I didn't even log 10 games and it already feels worn out. Lowered my rating from initial 7.5 to 6. Creating chains with +1 Action / +1 Card is just too uninteresting and repetitive.

RATING: 9
This is the game that convinced me that I was right to get back into playing board games. The mechanics are fresh, the game is fairly easy to teach to others, and the game can move very quickly. The only thing that stops this from being a perfect game is that, despite all of the randomness, there isn't much there to keep the game balanced. If one player understands the kingdom setup better than the others, then that player is going to win without much opposition. This makes it difficult for new players to play with more experienced ones - and thus keep them interested in playing the game.

RATING: 9
It's not often a genuinely new mechanic comes along. This has it. More importantly, it's lovely to play, and reasonably deep, to boot. 

The new mechanic has been recycled (pilfered wholesale) by many games now, but I think Dominion gets the complexity level about right - i.e. not very.

And to those who criticise it for "lack of theme", I say "pah!". It's got just the right amount of theme - enough to help you mentally navigate the game, but not get in the way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really don't know why anyone compares this game to Magic: The Gathering, aside from the fact that it's a card game with art on the cards.  Perhaps it's because this is a deck building game and the process of building your deck to play Magic is often the most fun part?  The main difference here of course is that deck building IS the game of Dominion and not something you do alone surrounded by stacks of cards.
Easy to teach, learn, and play, this game still has complex strategy as the best built deck will almost always be the winner.  Also, the variety of starting set ups gives this game tremendous re-playability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominion is just a genius game. No dice, no board. Just you, your cards and your wits. The exponential variety to this game is my favorite aspect of it. The original Dominion has simple cards, but they are still strong and I often mix in the original Kingdoms with other sets. 

An easy Ten from me. Even after playing for a few years.

RATING: 7
This is a themeless game that everyone in my play group loves and it is slowly growing on me. My enjoyment of the game depends very much, however, on what cards are available that game. The basic goal of using cards to get money to buy VP is boring, and I prefer cards that encourage player interaction or require planning to pull off big combos. In other words, the game doesn't come to life for me until you add in the various expansions, particularly the intrigue expansion. But it is a fine game that I usually enjoy, mostly because I'm playing with friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love this particular idea of deck building, and I loved the first plays. My BIG issue with this game is that many cards don't work at all or are mispriced. There are many good cards that cost as little as 3, and quite a few powerful cards that cost only 4. And then there's all of those cards that are priced at 5 and even 6, which are just not that good. 

This game should thrive on the diversity of its cards and the different ways to build a more and more powerful deck fast. Unfortunately, the game doesn't accomplish what it sets out to do. You can focus on just buying money cards, completely disregarding all the other cards, and do quite well. This fact means that the game is broken, it doesn't live up to its potential.

It is said that this "big money" problem is remedied by its expansions. To me that means that in order to unbreak the basic game you need to buy its expansions...? Then the original game just isn't as good as all that. It is also said that problem is remedied by playing the game even more often once you run into it. Unfortunately, the problem sucks enjoyment out of the game, so why play it more often? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favourite game, period.

It is good for use with friends who are infrequent and/or light game players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very well made deck building game. The idea being to build your deck to acquire more victory points then your opponents.

Victory cards have no function until the end of the game (at least in base set) so you don't want to buy them too early, but if you leave it too late the game might end before you have enough points to win. So you have to pick the right time to start buying victory cards.

The attack cards give interaction between players, and if play continues while you do cleanup phase it plays every quickly and there isn't much downtime between turns and you will spend the time between turns thinking of what to buy.

RATING: 9
Heard about this game for a couple of years now, and finally picked it up because none of my other gaming friend had.

Totally addicting gameplay, wow. I have only played it a few times, but the incredibly simple mechanics and HUGE array of setup and play options are really amazing. Every game feels different, and requires different strategies.

The combos available here rival MtG for their breadth, even if the base game has limited options. Unlike MtG though, I don't have to keep spending $800/yr to keep up with this game.

I'm usually not much for expansions, but Dominion cries out for them. Will be keeping an eye out for more.

RATING: 10
Yup, I'm hooked.  It's fiendishly brilliant in its simplicity, and actually includes a little interaction and vaguely theme-connected mechanics (i.e. you buy a moat, but it's not ready to defend you until it's built... when you draw it again) for an otherwise standard engine-building Euro.  After about 20 plays it lost a bit of luster, but I can still see enjoying this for quite a while, especially when more cards become available to mix things up further. 

Update: I've been playing this more on BSW using the "setup" option, where everyone choosed what action cards to use before the game, and that has really reinvigorated my love for this game.  Some very interesting combinations of cards and strategies...  This has legs, after all. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game rocks!  It fast, its exciting, it offers lots of different tactics and it has a brand new game concept which is simple and elegant.  A lot of people have compared Dominion to Magic the Gathering but even though both games are about building a deck of cards they play very differently.  

In Magic you have to build your deck *before* the game starts which means that you have to take a lot of strategical decisions beforehand.  Once the game runs, you cannot undo any of these.  In Dominion you make up your deck as you play which means that you have the opportunity to correct mistakes while you're playing.  As a result, Dominion is a game that can be easily learned on-the-fly.  It's so fast that you can just try one tactic, correct it while you're playing and when you fail just try the next one.  This makes it so unique and exiting: It's fast, deep and flexible.  

My initial rating was a 9.  Raised it to 10 after >10 plays.  Maybe if a killer strategy is developed I may have to lower it again but for the time being this is the game that has impressed me most since the Settlers of Catan was published.

Edit: Rating lowered to 7 after numerous plays.  

Edit: Rating raised to 8 after trying some new card combinations.

RATING: 8
I've been an avid CCG fan for a while, and one of the important parts of most CCGs is deck-building. Dominion, in an interesting twist, makes deck-building the *game*, not the preparation. I've really enjoyed this one when it hits the table, even though my group would only play the most basic setup (without most of the interactive cards) and then killed it for lack of interactivity :( Really hated that move, among others.

It's a very fun game, that can be quick or long depending on players' actions/strategies. At one point I'll have to pick it up again (once I find a group that will play it again >< )

RATING: 10
I love this game. My wife and I play together at least once a week. She is not a typical gamer, nor am I, but we both really enjoy this game. Playing this game has made me feel the need to purchase more strategy games, as my wife and I both have enjoyed our interactive time together. I highly recommend this game to all casual, and non-casual gamers. It is just good solid fun, with lots of strategic depth based on all the combinations of action/kingdom cards available. Losing at this game makes me want to play even more. I think about all the things I should have done, and just want to get better. Very addicting!

UPDATE (6OCT2013): Just broke this back out and taught it to my 7 year old son. It still gives me those feelings of wanting to play again and again. I think it had the same affect on my son, as he immediately asked to play again, even before the first game was over. So much fun!

RATING: 6
The idea of using deck construction as an actual gameplay mechanic is very original, but that does not mean it is very good or engaging. And the amount of reshuffling is a bit annoying. Besides, most cards are very similar, unimaginative and/or uninteresting, and the whole game is basically another efficiency engine. Even the medieval theme, which I usually like, feels dull and generic. The game does have some qualities, being simple, quick, well-balanced and quite strategic, with no big flaws. But it lacks tension, depth, and a sense of achievement. It is mildly fun and I will certainly play again, but I'm in no urge to do so.

RATING: 5
Fun and simple.  Easy to introduce non-gamers to.  Gets repetitive pretty quickly.  Probably needs some expansions to have any staying power.  And even then it might get old fast.

Update 4/7/12: 6 -> 7 Much improved with an expansion.

Update 12/16/12: 7 -> 5 I just don't play it anymore.  With three and four players, Dominion doesn't offer any of the types of player interaction that are why I play multiplayer games (conflict, alliances, manipulation, trading, whatever).  It's much better heads up, but if I'm going to play a two-player game there are so many better options.  Plus the overhead of dealing with and storing all the cards, and remembering to play the combos correctly as Throne Rooms and Schemes are played with duration cards just got to be a pain.  isotropic spoiled me in that regard.  

Dominion is a fairly deep game (or at least a fairly [i]wide[/i] game), and as such is something of a lifestyle game.  But it doesn't interest me enough to commit the time to be a truly excellent player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After our first 3 plays I was ready to sell this game. I found it rather boring. I did some research and realized that we were not trying to build an "engine". Once we discovered this technique, the game quickly became one of my favorites. Now I see the endless possibilities of building an engine, completely changing the cards, then doing it all over again. In our group, we come to a consensus on the deck. We do not do it random, but rather only pick cards that people want to use. Once an engine has been built with certain cards we remove them for a while to keep it from getting to samey. We talk strategy with each other as well before the game starts, and we always discuss our plays as we are making them. All of this helps us avoid a "multi-player solitaire" experience and makes the game better. I would recommend this game to anyone and my rating may increase even further over time.

Update: The more I play the more I am hooked on this game. It is still not quite my favorite game overall, but engine building is my favorite mechanic from any game that I am playing right now. I find myself continuously thinking of ways to improve my stack and make it work more effectively. Brilliant.

Update: After 10 plays I still find the game very good. No sign of tiring at all with all of the possible starting combinations, which each may require a different strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

While this game may have had it's heyday I have to believe that much of the basis of it's high rating is nostalgic. I have found greater enjoyment with virtually every other deckbuilding game I have played--although , of course I am selective.

RATING: 8
Well, I stand corrected. This game is not bad at all. Everything I read about Dominion made me think it would be a terrible bore. When someone finally pulled the game out, I didn't complain simply because I thought it would be rude to refuse to play something everyone else wanted to play. And frankly, I'm the type that has to try most things at least once.

During the rules explanation I alternately dozed off and considered stabbing myself in the eye. Ifrst third of the game I was honestly lost. But you know, by the time the first game ended, I had to admit that the game did not suck anywhere close to as much as I had imagined. In fact, it was really quite decent.

We played two more times and by the last time I could even say that I had a half-decent idea of how to play. Lost that one by only one point.

What I liked the most was trying to balance the need for lots of money, with getting a decent mix of action cards.

And now after several more plays, I've upgraded the game to an 8 since I have found myslef wanting to play the game more. Simple and addictive. Yet has some depth.
