=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Really quick and really fun. On those two qualities alone, I see why it's compared to Race for the Galaxy, even if the gameplay is almost entirely dissimilar. This is an economic engine building game where you eventually start cranking out points instead of money, so timing is a big issue. It's novel, unique, and did I mention quick and fun? Not the revelation some people have made it out to be, but awfully good.
This game might have a serious start-player advantage, though, almost on a par with T&E; but it's not as good as T&E.
[EDIT] I think I've burned out on this one a bit. Too much shuffling, too much reliance on one or two action cards (what's the point of so much variety if it's often best to ignore 80% of the board?), and too many interminable +draw +action turns. I prefer Thunderstone. There, I said it!

RATING: 6

Great ideas, but a bad realization, could by WAY better.

RATING: 6
Finally had a change to play this game. All the stores here carry Dominion and pretty much everyone has played it so I expected great things. I should've have known better. All the games that gain mainstream popularity are simple - due to the fact of general public being simple - but I prefer games with complexity and challenge. The title suggested that this game has something to do with dominating other players but it's just a boring eurogame without any interaction. You collect points. That's the only goal here. To collect bloody points! Also, the cards at play always have a couple that are clearly the most beneficial for collecting those boring points which means everyone collects the same few cards and no one pays any attention to the other ones. All in all a very boring game experience. I'd suggest Mage Knight over this any day. A superior gaming experience but with quite a similar use of cards as this one.

RATING: 7.5
Traded in the Michiana September 2010 Math Trade
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
FINAL COMMENTS:  I have a love hate relationship with this game, which I have probably played close to 1000 times now.  As a 15 minute computer game, with all the expansions, I rate it an 8.  As a 45 minute board game, I rate it a 5.  So, I'll give a 6.5 as a compromise.  The game is great because of the multiple paths to victory, extreme variability, and long term planning required to win.  However, for many setups, just buying all the treasure cards you can (or sprinking a couple actions) is better than an action based strategy, which is a little frustrating.  Additionally, you spend FAR more time shuffling and waiting than you do thinking.  How to play your hand is mindless and decision-free usually.  The only choices are the strategic buying choices, which as severely constrained by is this better than a similarly costed treasure card?  The answer is almost always no. 

A great game, but not something I will ever play in person unless asked to.

What follows are my older comments about the game that I will leave here for historical value:

Hugely overrated.  The "popcorn" of gaming.  A fun game desperately in need of more theme and more ways to interact with the other players so it doesn't feel like an optimization exercise with a couple interactive cards as speed bumps.  For the playtime, its great.  The downtime is minimal and the decisions can be engaging regarding how you build your deck and create your VP engine. 

As a face to face game, this is a 6, because as a half hour game its vapid and interaction-free.  On BSW, its a solid 8, because its 10 minutes of efficiency engine where I can check my email on the other player's turns. 

Although the overall strategy is almost interesting, the tactical decisions are all very very simple.  Do I concentrate on drawing, or actions, buying, etc, or what?  Thats the interesting part of the game, and its really interesting.  How you build your deck/engine is a lot of fun and strategically pretty deep.  However, the actual turn to turn play is boring, repetitive, and often is just an optimization exercise.  What do I do this turn?  A monkey can do this part of the game.  Too easy, no brainpower needed.  The overall strategy has some neat choices but your hand plays itself.

I can see why people are so crazy about it, but there are some warts and I don't think its worth an higher ranking, much less the gaming-jesus status it currently has on the geek.  A functioning theme would have added a lot and not been difficult to implement.  Plus, with the ability to swap cards in and out there should have been some variants with more interaction.  Hopefully in the future this is taken care of by expansions.  

Anyone who thinks the game is original hasn't done enough CCG drafts.  Basically the same thing here. Still, for a game with no difficult decisions whatsoever and no interaction, Dominion is pretty good.

I have played it on BSW about 300 times now, and unless the expansions really ratchet up the interaction, I can only see this rating holding steady or going down.  I don't see myself buying it either.

Update:  This is catching on in person at the local game store now.  I've played a few games there.  This is a thoroughly "solvable" game where players of equal skill value will mostly win or lose based on the draw of the cards.  I think a rating of 6 is pretty generous.  Online, it is great, but in person the only reason I really play it anymore is if it is with a group of people who I like and with whom I can have fun no matter what we play.  That isn't exactly a ringing endorsement of the game.  Dominion: the Shuffling!  Probably in the top 5 of my most played games if you count BSW but also something I will never, ever buy.

Game almost plays itself once you know what you are doing...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

I was worried it would be a ton of shuffling, but this was rarely a factor as most shuffling happens in downtime between turns, and small deck sizes means it doesn't take long anyway. Main drawback is the limit of 4 players. I really can't see why you couldn't have more.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After just one play, I immediately liked this game (other than puzzling through the confusing rules).  Just ignore the phrase "but the player must do as much as he can" during the playing of an Action card.  Things like +1 Card or "trash this card" are mandatory, but +1 Action and +1 Buy don't mean that those actions have to be taken immediately -- it means that they get added to the allowed limit of Actions and Buys, which a player is never forced to take.  (You don't have to play any Actions or Buy any cards at all, even if you have the cards in hand to do so.)

This game has so much replayability because even if you follow the same strategy, you are drawing different cards out of your deck.  It's also much more enjoyable than a CCG because you don't need to buy more decks of cards.  But then again, each new expansion costs like $30, so this game has a certain collectible/novelty cost...

The key decisions in the game are about what mixture of cards to acquire -- early on, you probably need to get some actions that let you draw more cards (like the Smithy), then you need to buy silver and gold Treasure cards (to allow you to buy bigger point cards).  Buying multiple Market cards to chain together is a good strategy, as is the Cellar for the later game when you have many point cards you want to discard.  The Village (+1 card, +2 actions) is a great action multiplier card.

Building an efficient deck is an important key to Dominion, and nothing emphasizes that like the Chapel strategy -- trash cards that slow you down (like your entire original deck of Estates and Copper), and replace them with bigger money or Action cards that you can use every turn.

One simple strategy is to buy only Silver and Gold cards (no Actions) until you can afford Provinces, then buy Provinces (and near the end of the game, maybe Duchies).  This is a good baseline strategy to try to beat -- just because you think you have a strategy that works, it may be too slow to beat the simple Big Money strategy (perhaps augmented by a card or two like Smithy).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very good game; you should definately have one

RATING: 7
A pretty fun game.  Multiple ways to play.  Thank God for the online version because shuffling decks would get tired and painful after a while.  I always feel engaged when playing, waiting for that next hand to come off the deck.  There's no shortage of strategy and ways to achieve winning here.  

Tread carefully when it comes to expansions.  Some of them can really flip the way you play and require somewhat re-learning the entire game over again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have to admit that when I read everywhere how this game has deck building mechanics, I expected a bit more in the actual deck building departement. I'd rather call it "engine building with a fixed set of cards", since deck building proper would imply more than a choice of ten cards to build your deck from - but that's just my interpretation.

Of course, only having to choose from, read and learn 10 cards per game makes this game easier to grasp, and the cards easier to balance.

The game is very neat. Quite simple mechanics overall, maybe lots of shuffling, but the clear distinction between the action and the buying phase (while not that easy to grasp for newbies) makes things very clear, rules-wise, and interpretative errors of card's powers rare.

A notable mention to the inlay. It's great.

Nevertheless, this is for trade. It just doesn't see enough table time, and I'd rather play other games, too.

RATING: 8.5
The Dominion series is definitely a favorite of my family and I.  We currently own 5 expansions in addition to the base game.  If I include the expansions with the base game when considering a rating, it would definitely be a “10”, but since I am rating the base game itself, I am being a little more reserved with the rating.  Hence, this is why it is one of our favorites (with the expansions), yet “only” receives an 8.5 rating.

For those of you new to Dominion, the game consists of a plethora of cards and *only* cards.  I mention this, as I remember being slightly disappointed when I opened the box and saw no other components (other than the cards).  This was my first introduction to a game like this, and I wondered how fun a card-only game would be.  Well, I discovered it can be a blast!

The cards are unique and divided into three main categories (action, treasure, and victory).  It is quite fun building up your “dominion” and trying to decide if you should use an attack card to punish your opponents, or if you should use a card to aid in the purchasing of other cards to aid in the building process (whether it be through larger treasure cards and/or through action cards that provide larger bonuses, and/or victory cards themselves).

And although there are attacks, my family and I find the attacks to be fun in nature (sure, there are those, “Oh, rats!” moments when you have to take a card you do not want or need to give up a card you were hoping to play, but we find it all fun).  And while most of the cards affect the person playing the card only, there are certainly a few that affect others (i.e. Bureaucrat, Spy, etc.) and therefore offer player interaction.

And one of the best things about Dominion is that no 2 games are the same.  There are approximately 25 action card sets (in the base game), but only 10 of these are used in any one game.  And if you use a random method of selecting which 10 to use, your games are almost guaranteed to have a different combination of 10 each time.  This could (and does) affect what strategies a player uses when playing (so you are not always doing the same thing / playing the same cards each game).

Overall, Dominion is an excellent game to play with family and friends.  We play with 3 players 95% of the time and 4 players the other 5%, and find both to be very enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
6-8-10
After trying this with other people and each combination of 2P, 3P, and 4P, this game is excellent.  It has the elegant Euro feel but with very little downtime and a quick pace.  There is a good amount of thinking to be done in regards to card selection and deck balancing but at the same time, it's very easy to understand how you get points and put together strategies.

It's pretty easy to teach - once the player understands the basics of how a turn works, how the game ends, and how to win, it's a matter of figuring out what the 10 Kingdom cards do and going from there.  Each game can be quite different with a multitude of strategies to try out which should keep the longevity high.  With multiple expansions to add, I see this one coming to my game group pretty much every time.

There really aren't any downsides here.  Quick play means even a bad game will end sooner than most other Euros of this depth - if you're behind and you know it, your suffering will be over soon!  It's fast to setup and put away.  Definitely glad I bought this one.

RATING: 7
After much (deliberate) avoidance, I was finally acquainted with this game, and I now know better why this fairly quick and somewhat addictive game is rated so highly by so many.

I had two plays last night with a good friend, which we actually split 1:1.  The game is a different kind of card management game than RftG, requiring some ability to organize and utilize one's cards in any order- it reminds me far more of MtG in that sense.

But one still builds engines, and accumulates VP in hand, and the deck with (3) Laboratories, (1) Library, (1) Cellar and (1) Spy I had 2nd game was able to cycle through all but one or two cards in almost any shuffle, and I obtained all of the last 4 Provinces, after being down 4 to 2.

An interesting, and potentially addictive game- I will start this at a 7, based on my (2) plays.

NOTE: I have good reason to believe that Santa has selected this for my stocking this year, IF I am a good geek.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple mechanics, fast play, furious competition, many different strategies, seemingly infinite replayability. The fun of assembling a deck a la Magic, with the slugfest feel of Colossus: Arena, and the multiple paths to victory like Puerto Rico. It's definitely a winner! Initial rating: '8'.

Now, if only it could accommodate 5 or 6 players, this would be outstanding...  but I see there is a variant! After 20+ plays, I can see where one could start to burn out or start to play on autopilot...

Update: Game takes 45-60 minutes for newbies, especially if one of them has AP. Could ruin the experience for everyone else if not corrected immediately.

Update: it is possible to teach a 10-yr old, who has some CCG experience, but there may be a bit too much downtime and not enough player interaction that they lose attention quickly.

Update: After 50+ plays, I am bumping this up to a '10'. I'm addicted. So are my gaming buddies.

Update: tried to teach this to non-gamers on New Year's Eve, with a crowd of people talking around us, and with kids running around. Thought I was going to lose them, since they were confused and thought the game was ultra complex, and it took longer than an hour to finish (they had played and liked Settlers the previous year). We ended up playing 10 times through the next day! I'm not sure if this is a good 'gateway' game since if they have never heard of Magic, or any modern boardgame, then there is no context, other than "It's a really convoluted game of Uno!"

Update: after 80+ F2F plays, this is still a favorite in my gaming circles. As some of us are familiar with all the cards, we get the newbies into the 'random' mode after only one or two 'basic' card setup games, and don't bother with the other setups. This keeps everything fresh for the veterans. Strategies are quickly discovered, and just as quickly circumvented by another subtle strategy. I am really beginning to appreciate the subtle sophistication of this seemingly simple little game.  

Update (2/3/09): 120 F2F plays. Have consistently played this on every game night, save one. Our group now plays 'rounds' of 3 or 4 games, depending on the number of players, which equals 2 hours where we could have been playing something else. This game continues to rock. Although I've seen comments on the thin, pasted on, generic theme, and the lack of interaction, it still works. Each of us have become enamored with certain cards. We 'bitch' and 'curse' when the Witch comes out, moan when the Thief steals our gold or shout with glee when someone else has theirs stolen, and feel a smug sort of satisfaction when we trash 3 estates and a copper with the Chapel. There's plenty of cursing and trash-talking, which makes for humorous and memorable gameplay. We still talk about the most memorable one as the time the Thief stole everybody's money, and we experienced first-hand what a deflationary economy feels like.

Update (03/08/09): 149 F2F Plays. I've lost the last ten or so straight games... what is going on here? It seems everyones' playing skill has bumped up a notch? The game again is becoming a puzzle/challenge to decode, now that everyone is caught up.

Update (03/19/09): 154 F2F Plays. I'm still on a losing streak. Somehow, the standard plays don't work as well as they used to. I'm waiting eagerly on the promo cards and the expansion.

Update (04/10/09): After a hiatus of three weeks, the promo cards showed up! Played three games with both, where they added interesting dynamics. Black Market is like a drug, which is useful early in the game to get 'special' cards, but can be a distraction. Envoy is not as powerful as Council Room, because the opponent will choose your single gold or action card, and make your draw worthless. However, with Throne Room, could get you eight juicy cards to get you that Province.

Update (04/26/09): 161 F2F plays. Okay, I admit it--the game is starting to get boring--the novelty is wearing off. It doesn't hit the table as much as used to. If we have 30-45 minutes to kill, then this fits the bill. The consensus is that the Envoy is generally useless. The Black Market is a pain-in-the-ass for me to setup and take down. Now, I just outlaw the card altogether, because I don't want to deal with another 10 minutes putting the cards away.

Update (05/23/09): 169 F2F plays. Envoy is now considered useful if coupled with Throne Room and/or Village, otherwise, it is useless. We now use the leftover "blue-back" template cards for the Black Market. This speeds up setup immensely, although we now know when a "special" card is popping up. No matter. Also, Dominion is not as portable as once thought. 500 cards in sleeves is pretty bulky and heavy. They will fit in 5x sleeve tuck boxes, but still it is of considerable density.

Update (05/25/09): 170 F2F plays. Envoy coupled with Festival/Village is devastating in the later game. Early on, it seems trivial to dismiss a silver or gold treasure card, but later on it becomes a nightmare if Envoy is played off of a Village or Festival, and another Village or Festival (or Council Room for that matter) pops up along with a Gold or two.

Update (06/14/09): 172 F2F plays. Have played with the heavy-duty Ultra Pros card sleeves since the beginning, which were slightly oversized. Today, played with penny-sleeves that were the new "Euro" size. Don't bother with cheap penny-sleeves. Get the thicker, more durable plastic. It is worth it in terms of durability, but more so in the feel of the cards, as well as shuffle-ability.

Update (08/15/09): 177 F2F plays. Hadn't played it in nearly two months because the Euro-sleeves took that long to arrive in the mail from Mayday Games. Still hasn't lost that 'touch' in terms of speed, fun, and interaction. Now, need to sleeve Intrigue and get Dominion back in circulation.

Update (06/18/10): Haven't played it in awhile. With the original box holding both the base and Intrigue cards sleeved, makes for a heavy weight to carry around. It takes too much time to set up and put away for a filler 30-minute game, which is what this game has devolved to. No one wants to play this as the "main course" like we used to back in the beginning. With Seafarer, I am done with this game crack. Downing to "7".

Update (02/10/13) 186 F2F plays: Haven't played this in nearly two years. We brought it out briefly back then, and it still had that "magic" that only deck-building can bring. That said, Dominion is a significant milestone in board gaming evolution. As important as Settlers of Catan, it has its place in history. No other game has brought so much gaming pleasure (186+ plays), for so little money. If there were an equivalent "life time achievement award" for board gaming, this design deserves it a thousand-fold.

Update (01/02/2015) 189 F2F plays of base, 232 F2F plays if including expansions. Another two-year hiatus, broke it out for a late night romp, and it is still fun and amusing every now and then.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A mechanical kick in the pants.  Draft cards to build an efficiency engine to hit the magical 8+ coins per hand and then start buying the big victory points... the rub being that once you start buying VPs they will clog up your machine and make it run all choppy.

Other than committing to a strategy the game really comes down to timing the switch from deck building to buying VPs.  Come in too soon and you bloat the machine with crap.  Come in too late and you're behind the curve and will lose, maddeningly, by something as stupid as a single card-buy.

It's fascinating to watch the different solutions grind away at the problem and to see who had the most efficient engine—and best timing—at the end.

The only knock is for the flaccid theme, which is, perhaps, thankfully thin, given how mechanical the game is and how fast it plays with experienced players.  (It's not unusual for your turn to come back around before you're done shuffling from the last one.)  A narrative layer would probably just slow everything down.

That said, I like to think of it as scratch-building a Ferrari and then seeing how much cocaine I can hide in the gas tank while still getting it across the border.  And then maybe something about fire-breathing pimps.

Or this:

[b][blogpost=5983][/blogpost][/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
毎回ランダムに決定する10種類のカードを組み合わせて、対戦相手よりも効率の良い組み合わせを発見するゲーム。
サプライの組み合わせの多様さがゲームの求めてくるアドリブ性につながるため、ある程度拡張セットを購入する必要がある。基本セットのみの評価は5点。
適正人数は二人。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I finally got a chance to play this with 3 friends.  It was our first encounter with a deck building game.  We all liked it.  I will say that this game is easy to learn and I will certainly introduce it to my 11 and 13 yr old.  they may struggle with the underlying strategy but that is always a learning curve.    The concept and rules are very simple and the base game is nicely accompanied by several optional deck sets.  You play with 10 'sets' of cards, each set has different actions.  Each turn you can buy a card from the set, buy more money, or buy territory.  you start with very few cards (money, territory) in your hand and every turn you can buy more.  Eventually, you have good sized deck to play so it becomes a balance of buying the correct type of card(s).  The player with the most territory wins.  Very good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The one that got me again into the hobby. We played and played and played, got some expansions and played some more. Absolutely love this game. Explaining it to new players is a piece of cake and almost everyone i played with, really liked it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not my favorite game, because often it feels like it plays itself. There is little to playing your hand, so most of the game revolves around the cards you purchase. Once you get some experience, some of the purchase decisions become automatic too. It might be surprising, but short as it is, I find Dominion too long for the number of important decisions you make. Usually it comes down to a subtle choice of the timing of starting to collect victory point cards. 

The game is almost entirely strategy and no tactics, and I prefer games with a more even balance between the two. I periodically rediscover it by playing online on goko, which largely takes care of the length issue. 

A good engine building game, just not something I enjoy putting on the table or spending lots of time playing.

RATING: 7
빠른 게임 전개, 그리고 리플레이성, 다양한 왕국카드가 게임의 재미요소를 높여주지만, 
어느 정도 플레이에 익숙해지면, 빠른 덱 회전, 액션 횟수의 증가와 드로우 중시의 전략으로 고정되게 됩니다. 결국 모두가 비슷한 덱을 구성하게 되고, 그걸 가장 먼저 구성하여 돌아가게 되는 사람이 이기게 되지요. 익숙한 플레이어끼리 플레이를 하게 되면 전략이 비슷해지게 됨에 따라서 게임이 한 쪽으로 편중되는 현상이 발생합니다. 다양한 카드나 혹은 룰의 변화가 요구되지 않는 한 이 게임은 여기서 더 이상 진보할 수 없을 것이라고 생각됩니다. 물론 모든 게임이 진보할 필요는 없고, 꼭 확장이나 추가판이 있어야만 재미있는 게임이 되는 것은 아닙니다만, 다양한 카드를 사용하게 해놓은 게임이 종국에는 한 쪽 전략으로만 쏠리게 되는 현상은 결코 좋은 게임이라고 생각되지 않는군요. 

하지만 빠른 게임 전개와 쉬운 룰, 그리고 2-4 인 이내에서는 인원 수에 관계없이 즐길 수 있다는 점은 훌륭합니다. 10 점 만점이라면 7 점 정도입니다.

RATING: 7
One of the best games ever made when it first came out, but there are much better games out n.w! Excellent as 2-player or multiplayer. Fast games (20-30 minutes on average) with little downtime between turns. Deck building genre has run its course.  Game requires constant reshuffling of your deck which takes up most of the downtime. A decent amount of player-player interaction that can thwart your plans at any given moment. Random card selection ensures that no two games are exactly alike.

No voy a descubrirle a estas alturas el Dominion a nadie, así que pasaré de hablar de sus bondades e iré directamente a los puntos débiles:

estrenar.

- El que sale tiene ventaja. Entre jugadores experimentados, esta pequeña diferencia en el orden de los turnos puede resultar decisiva. No es definitiva, pero salir da un plus.

Por demás, mucha tensión y diversión.

RATING: 6.5
Solid deck builder, albeit quite basic in relation to many other deck-builders such as Legendary Aliens, Xenoshyft, Shadowrun Crossfire etc. But because of that it is very easy to teach, and makes a great gateway for the more complex deck-building games out there, since they all share similarities from Dominion.

For me, I feel the base is just too "basic" and grabbing a set of dominion base cards with Seaside and Prosperity. They seem to be the most well received of the many expansions for Dominion and don't look like they add unnecessary complexity. Overall a great game that is now 8 years old and still can be fun by its own merit. For me, I'd love to expand on it and see it truly shine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A deck building game where players acquire new cards from a common shop. There are 10 "kingdom cards" in the shop that are randomized each game.

The only things worth victory points are the cards with a victory point symbol--most which do absolutely nothing during the game. Usually the game's rhythm is building an engine and then at a certain point, switch to buying as many victory point cards as you can.

There are many expansions, each themed around something (ie: Prosperity adds various treasure cards, Dark Ages cards encouraging trashing your own cards, etc). The vanilla set is fairly bland; I would recommend adding either Prosperity, Sea Side, or Empires to your collection when you are ready for more variety/options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Received as Dice Tower Secret Santa gift from Joe Steadman.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A card game about getting cards. The mechanisms are refreshingly original (in the context of Eurogames at any rate) if a little repetitive. The skill lies in knowing the good combos and timing the game such that you can make the switch from buying coins and actions to buying VPs. I have some concerns that recursive drawing is so powerful that once cards like Laboratory are on the table other strategies don't have enough time to be competitive. Card designs are much less attractive then those in Race for the Galaxy, but sets are more expensive, bad news for regular players as the constant shuffling creates a lot of wear on the cards. These days I'll only play the base set to teach the game to newcomers, Chapel, Gardens, Laboratory, Thief & Witch are the most interesting cards and lead to divergent strategies, but the expansions (especially Dark Ages, Hinterlands, Prosperity) are much better overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]EASILY ONE OF THE BEST GAMES OUT THERE, INCREIDIBLY VERSATILE AND FAST, EASY TO LEARN, IMPOSSIBLE TO MASTER[/b]

Dominion strucks everyone at first as a reinvention of the Magic: The Gathering phenomenon: A collectible card game (CCG) that is not actually a CCG. But still, it appears as if the most MTG-hating geeks (Most of them former players of Richard Garfield’s opus maxima, by the way) think the idea behind Dominion is the very same of MTG and its marketing strategies. Granted, Dominion has a lot of expansions, all of them released in a very short time span (Maybe 2 or 3 years), but not having the expansions does not mean Dominion is not an amazing game all by itself.

As I mentioned on my profile, I’m a huge fan of empire building games, and at first I was too sceptic about the claims of some about Dominion being a game that “allows you to build your own kingdom”. Unless it was played on a cardboard piece with lost of miniatures or finely illustrated bits, I was neither buying that claim nor game. But after getting the game (Mostly because it had just won the Spiel des Jahres award and because I’m a consumer wh*re) and actually playing it, I came completely around and discovered an awesome game, elegant, simple and profoundly strategic and tactical.

It would be now worth mentioning that the author of Dominion (Mr. Donald X. Vaccarino) is a retired Magic: The Gathering player, so the similarities between these tow games are obvious, but Dominion takes the whole card game ethos one step further, by allowing the possibility of not being a huge stupid bully against your opponents and actually allowing everyone to play as they want, without even deeming important whatever the other players do on their turn. Kudos for all that, Donald, old chap.

Also, it’s not-worthy the fact that because it is a board game, once opened and started, both players are pretty much on the same level of chances of winning the game, and experience playing Dominion, though useful, may not be all that matters when playing this game.

[b][i]I. Criteria[/b][/i]

Mechanics: :d10-1::d10-0:
Design & Art: :d10-1::d10-0:
Packaging & Presentation: :d10-9:
Theme: :d10-1::d10-0:
BGG Factor:  :d10-8:

[b][i]II. Sliders[/i][/b]

Abstract [b]____[COLOR=#FF0000][5][/COLOR]_____[/b] Themed: One thing about Dominion is to consider that actions are not always related to the name of the card that grants said actions, but only on the more “story-ish” side of the game. Another fact to consider is that there are at least two other home-made versions of the game, both keeping the core mechanics intact but dramatically changing the setting and theme of the game. However, if it had been a sci-fi themed game, I’m pretty sure I wouldn’t have even tried it in the first place, so it’s safe to deduce that the them Dominion sports is most relevant to me.

Simple [b]__[COLOR=#FF0000][3][/COLOR]_______[/b] Complex: Learning the game is easy, especially because most of the rules and effects of each different action are explained in the cards themselves. The level of complexity is always established at the card selection phase of the setup, so It’s just a matter of taste of the players.

Strategic [b]_____[COLOR=#FF0000][5][/COLOR]_____[/b] Tactical: Dominion is one of those games where strategic and tactical thinking are one in the same. Will you go with the most expensive cards, the most cheap ones? Will you play the card which gives you more actions, money or buys? 
 
Luck [b]_______[COLOR=#FF0000][8][/COLOR]__[/b] Skill: Considering the fact that the decks built in each game comprise the cards each and every individual players want, the luck factor would only be present when drawing a new card, which, if drawn from a deck carefully built and protected, could very well work just as good in every situation. “The luck of the draw” expression could be used here, but for one reason or the other, luck is what one makes it In Dominion.

Fiddly [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Elegant: There are of course certain things in the game that must be consulted with the game rulebook, but usually, they’re just nuisance and do very little to either solve the problem in question (because it is not that important) or usually, the answer just pops in front of you after reading for a minute or two.
 
Indirect interaction [b]____[COLOR=#FF0000][5][/COLOR]_____[/b] Direct interaction: It’s up to the players, but the interaction idea of Dominion not always involves blocking or crippling your opponents. If desired, a completely peaceful, individualistic efficiency-driven deck can be built, or maybe the players will prefer a bit of interaction.

Cutthroat [b]____[COLOR=#FF0000][5][/COLOR]_____[/b] Friendly: STUPID MILITIA CARD! OH YEAH, AND NOW YOU PLAY COUNCIL ROOM? DAMN YOOOOOOUUU and thanks for the extra card!

Heavy use of language [b]_______[COLOR=#FF0000][7][/COLOR]___[/b] No language needed: Dominion has around 5 to 6 key concepts needed to understand and play it. Once these concepts are understood, things should flow smoothly, but of course, sometimes asking those that understand those concepts or the language they’re written in is necessary.

[b][i]III. Number of players recommended[/i][/b]: 4.

[b]CHEERS![/b]

RATING: 7
Love the idea of building your own deck as part of a game but it doesn't work that well as the sole focus of a game. It was quite addictive at first but I don't think it holds up well to repeat plays because each turn is actually pretty boring. It doesn't have close to the same depth or variety as RftG.

Still, easy enough to be a good family game and I'm happy to play once in a while.

Best played with equal turns and "phantom" provinces.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The quickness, addictiveness and variability of this game are really its selling points. My thoughts:

I'm pretty positively inclined toward this one.  I was a light CCGer for a while there and this is one psuedo-CCG that actually captures the deck-building part of such games as well as the gameplay.  Plus, it's just really fun to see the engine work. And I've always gotten a lot of enjoyment out of a nice combo play.

I wouldn't argue that it is in any way a deep game, however. It's kind of a junk food gaming experience. Why yes, I would like to eat that stick of cotton candy, but I can't really expect to derive any nourishment from it.

UPDATE:  It's a little embarrassing to raise the rating of a game whose entire point is that you can play quickly to an 8, but this is pretty addictive.  I don't understand why everyone else likes it so much, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ever since I got into gaming, I've heard people talk about this game. This game, they say, was revolutionary to the hobby. This game introduces a new mechanic that every other game wanted to copy. And when I first looked it up to validate all this hype, I thought, "...blah." It just didn't look that good. The artwork seemed so boring at first. So, I passed it up. Until....

When I finally played it...I now understand the hype. This game is wonderful! It is so simple, yet with enough depth and replayability I had to have it! This is the KING of deck-builders. You need to efficiently manage the building of a deck in a frantic race to get the most victory points. The base game comes with different sample game set ups that are really fun. From decks that produce a lot of money, to others that attack other players, these set ups help learn all the different aspects of the game.
Though the theme is definitely pasted on, because I never really felt that I was building a 'dominion.' And the artwork, though at first glance I didn't care for it, has actually grown on me. I like it even. This game is a slam dunk.

RATING: 9
Initially an 8 for base Dominion alone. Adding in Intrigue bumped it up to a 9 for me. This game system is just so addicting, and there's so much depth to it. It took me 4 or 5 games before I really began to appreciate just how good Dominion is, but now I can't get enough of it.  

It's like giving a bunch of mechanics a pile of odds and ends car parts and challenging them each to build the best functioning car they can with the same pieces available. It's like giving a bunch of chefs the same random ingredients and having them compete to prepare a better dish than the others. Everyone uses the same cards, but tries different strategies and combos with them, which makes the game endlessly fun and interesting. It's different every time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
En síntesis, Dominion es un juego en el que hay dispuestas 10 cartas en una zona común y cada jugador, en un solitario paralelo al de los demás, debe desentrañar cuál es modo más rápido de lograr la victoria a base de adquirir y jugar cartas de acciones, tesoro y victoria. Cada jugador forma su propio mazo del que robará y descartará cartas, a base de comprar cartas de entre las 10 del "mercado" común.

Las cartas de tesoro sirven para comprar cualquiera de las tres clases de cartas y hay de tres valores distintos (1,2,y 3 monedas).

Las cartas de Victoria no sirven más que para conseguir PV´s al acabar la partida. Tres valores distintos con tres precios distintos que "estorban" en la mano, pero que son necesarias para ganar.

Las cartas de acción (color gris) permiten mejorar el mazo, hacer más acciones, compras o conseguir más dinero de lo habitual.

Parece juego de cartas para jugadores de Magic con síndrome de abstinencia. Depende de la suerte. Ejemplo: si te tocan 8-8-8 monedas puedes conseguir 18 PV's; si te tocan 10-7-7 sólo 12... un 33% menos. Los usuarios de BGG o bien por estar hartos de gestión de recursos o bien por ser ex magiqueros, lo han sobrevalorado excesivamente. Aún así le seguiré dando oportunidades.Buenísima la idea de "haz tu propio mazo y ponlo a funcionar".PROS: partidas cortas que dejan ganas de más. Más matemático de lo que pudiera parecer. CONS: Mínima interacción entre jugadores, sin tensión, sin decisiones (nada más que las evidentes). Si tienes 8 monedas, compra una provincia. Si tienes 6 compra oro. Fijo que ganas. "¿Qué ha pasado mientras barajaba? Bueno, da igual. No importa." 

+120 partidas online en http://kingdom.servegame.org/kingdom/showGameRooms.do

Ahora juego en http://www.goko.com/games/Dominion

EDITO: en https://www.playdominion.com/Dominion/gameClient.html

Con tantas expansiones, parece útil jugar con 3 ataques + 1 carta de victoria + 6 cartas de acción. Tantos ataques, dificultan mucho la estrategia big money. La carta de  victoria extra añade más profundidad y hace obligatorio pensar estrategias distintas. Las 6 acciones, de distintas ampliaciones, mucha rejugabilidad.

NOTA:En febrero de 2012 le subo a un cinco tras instalar Androminion en mi móvil.

En Marzo de 2014 lo subo a un 6.5 tras probarlo con mi hijo mayor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The reigning deck-builder, Dominion is probably past its prime in terms of hype but not in terms of ubiquity. Recognized immediately in most gaming circles, it is a good go-to game with a new group. Play is fast, easy to understand, and quite full of fresh experiences - if enough of the expansions have been gathered.

RATING: 9
Dominion is a very light game, very easy to get into. What I really like about dominion is not the dept of every match, which are obviously shallow, but the opportunity the game offers to play multiple matches in a row so the players get to figure out the best way to build their deck for each set of cards on the spot. 

If you play Dominion occasionally, you won't like/appreciate it. It's a game that requires multiple matches for each 10 card draw so players can build and evolve from one match to another.

RATING: 6
Decent deckbuilder, but I hold the (admittedly minority opinion) that it's not the best. Fourth at the outside, by my reckoning;

- Valley of Kings is all-round better, simpler and seats more in a game.
- Star Realms is faster
- Paperback is more versatile, and hits word-game fans as well as general game fans (which makes it a marginally better gateway deckbuilder).
- Shadowrift is much deeper (if you're into cooperative games)

Given that I own all of the above, Dominion isn't likely to hit the table very often. Don't worry though; I found it a good home.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A terrific game.  There's little to say that hasn't been said.  It's simple to learn, challenging to master, and all the expansions provide near-countless permutations of possible game setups, dozens of successful strategies, and all-around lots of fun.  It's family-friendly (my inlaws love it, and older children can play too), and has lots of subtleties.  It's a game that I'm constantly learning.

On the other hand, there is pretty much no theme to the game (perhaps aside from the Alchemy expansion), and sometimes the game can feel automatic/mechanical.  Most kingdom cards invoke very little interaction with other players, so my biggest criticism is that the game often tends toward several people playing solitaire at the same table.

Still... it's a modern-day classic that inspired a new breed of board game.

Purchased from Troll and Toad, spring 2011.  "BIG BOX" EDITION!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played Feb 26th, 2009. Taught in 15min, played in 45min with 4 players. Quick game with good strategy/luck mix. Each players is given 3VPs and 7copper to start (10 cards). There are various stacks of cards which you use to accumulate more cards or VPs. It's a race to gather VPs. On your turn you draw five cards from your draw deck and are given one action and one buy per turn. Special cards allow you to have do things like draw cards from your draw deck, take extra actions, double a card, upgrade gold, discard a card(s) from the game, make people place a VP card from their hand to the top of their deck etc. You buy other cards with your gold in your hand (along with special cards). Easy to learn and a quick play. I'd recommend giving this a try and purchase consideration.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I ♥ Dominion!!  I have a blast playing it.  I like that it has a shorter play time than most games, so once it's set up, it's easy to select new kingdom cards and play again and again.  In this way, you can enjoy two or three games in the time many games take to play once.  The game is interesting because there are so many kingdom cards, of which ten are selected for each game.  The fun is trying to be creative to combine the effects of the different action cards.  The player that is best able to build their deck into just the right balance of treasure cards and action cards and trash less useful cards will probably win.  Other merits:  A good level of player interaction so that your actions may affect the other players.  Short turn time-- In most games there is small down time between turns.  In games when players build wicked engines in which they play many action cards in one turn, if you didn't build your deck well, you will be waiting a long time between turns and waiting for your opponent to crush you and end the game already.  But, if you're hip to the jive and you both have big engines, the game is still extremely interesting.  I like it that even though so many cards have been released in all the expansions, many of the base game cards are among the best.  It was suggested to me to not add Alchemy to my set and I do not own Alchemy.  I would say the same thing about Dark Ages.  I agree with Tom Vasel, that Dominion plays exceptionally well with three players, but I also enjoy playing with two or four as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Oct08: I say WOW!  That was awesome.  I need more time with it.  For now, every purchase decisions was interesting, difficult, and had long term consequences.  (Except for buying the 6vps, but that's so satisfying I don't mind.)  I still struggled with how to balance my deck with just the base 10 cards.  I can't even imagine the variability with 25 cards to choose from!

The shuffling was annoying, and the actual card play was pretty obvious, but those got out of the way quickly and just let you get purchasing.  Besides, you did need to pay attention to your card play and "listen to your deck" to see what purchase is needed.

Just awesome.

Nov08: Alright, 10 plays in, I can declare it a 10.  I still might like RftG a tad bit more, but that doesn't make this a bad game by any means.

May09: And 40 plays in it has dropped from a 10.  It does many things right, but some just aren't there.  My biggest complaint is the rough edges I see.  Instant end on provinces.  Chapel power.  Very sharp income/VP splits.

Jun09: And back to a 10 with the first expansion.  No rules changes, just new cards.  But they blur the vp/income split nicely.  They also add even more interesting decisions during the play of your hand.  Yes, it slows it down a little, but that extra time is full of additional decisions so it works out nicely.  I also have switched over to the wooden chip version.  *Much* nicer.  Shuffle?  Just swap bags.

Aug16:  Haven't played in years.  Still awesome.  Expansions have gotten out of hand, and I have a pile of ~deck builders, but gotta respect this first one.  It did so much right.

RATING: 10
While I may get burnt out on it, Dominion is still THE deck-builder. A total classic and a milestone in modern designer games. It got everything right and every game after almost always took away good design when Dominion's formula was tweaked. Criticize the dry theme all you want, but I've only seen one deck-builder, Arctic Scavengers, actually feel representative of its theme rather than feel like grabbing piles of cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Players | 2-4  With Dominion Intrigue | 2-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The original deck building game. As of this writing, I still prefer it over the alternatives like Nightfall, Thunderstone, etc., if only by a narrow margin, because I think it just flows faster.

There are a few caveats, though. The art is...okay. Certainly nothing to write home about. It also completely lacks a theme. There's a story about players attempting to acquire lands in order to get a dominion of their own, but it's slapped on at best. Really all you're doing is crunching numbers. Thankfully, I feel the fun factor is enough to ignore this problem.

The biggest issue I take with this game, however, is near-zero player interactivity. You hardly ever affect the actions of other players. I hear Prosperity alleviates this somewhat, but alas, I don't own it, so I couldn't say.

Having said that, it's easy to learn and even people who aren't into board games seem to enjoy this, at least from my experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Received in trade Oct 25, 2010. Looking forward to playing and commenting.

Am now in the midst of my 4th play with my primary gaming partners--my children. We are all enjoying it very much. The simplicity of the system suits the bottom of the age group, but each time through players like taking a turn because they have something useful and interesting that they can do. The younger ones enjoy the art and having a name to associate with most of the plays, and I enjoy exploring various card combinations. I imagine the game will hold up nicely for us because we can rarely get in more than a game or two a week with the kids' activities now.

12/01/12 Update
Actually stopped keeping track of plays after first six months. My guess is somewhere in the 200s face to face plays as played many nights with family on vacation where games start in the afternoon and go through til midnight, usually with multiple tables for some portion of that. Easily have 1000 plays on Droid (before I retired the ap this fall so I could get something done in my spare moments)

RATING: 7
A fun abstract deck-building game. Visually, the game leaves much to be desired. Mechanically, the game is very satisfying.

The game is simple to teach and *can* be fairly short once players get a feel for what they're doing.

The real downsides are the games that devolve into deck-drawing (slowly drawing your entire deck into your hand every turn).

The game isn't perfect, but it's very good. I consider it one of my favorites.

RATING: 10
When we got this game, as a wedding gift, I was worried, because I don't like card games. When me and my wife tried it, I learned that I was wrong and that I love this game. Both of us enjoy it, although neither of us have any previous experience in deck building games (or card collection games). There are some nice twists from expected game mechanics (for example, cards that you buy are, contrary to expected behaviour, placed in discard pile) that make difference between good and great game.
There is also game theme which perfectly blends with card names and design. I know that it is eight year old game, but if somebody didn't try it, I highly recommend it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
So, I was having a great time at a friend's game night. We had just played a fun party game with everyone, when most people left, leaving only a few behind. "I want to play Dominion!" Says my friend. "Man, when you were playing it earlier, it looked really, really boring" I say to myself. I think perhaps I should leave, or just watch them play. But he convinces me to play, preying upon my curiosity given how highly rated the game is by a lot of people. 

Two (maybe three?) hours later, my friend "wins", and I'm not sure exactly what it was that any of us did right, or wrong, to win, or lose. Theories fly around about what we should and should not have done, and comments of "that was so fun" make it around the table.

I am left feeling confused, with a sickening, empty feeling coursing through my veins. And my night was effectively ruined. Why was I feeling this way? The game is certainly not terrible, but there was something about it, and now I know what that is: the game presents itself as a strategic card game while being nothing more than luck of the draw. 

Can one influence how the hand plays out to a certain degree? Yes. But it's smoke and mirrors. I had never played the game in my life, and I was just picking random cards, then playing them in combinations, to which other people said "ooh!" and "ahh!", then suddenly they were copying my "strategy." Only I never felt in control. I only felt I was being given the illusion of control to satisfy the drive to build towards something better. The majority of the "game" was looking back through card combos and deciphering exactly what it meant we could do next. "Two, five, six, one, two, three, ok. Ten, with enough buys to do what I have to do" *contemplates "I'll take a market, a silver, and a moat, with two coppers." Ad nauseum. What was fun about this? Watching other people lay cards down, and then count numbers? 

I mean, it really wasn't tooooo bad, but I honestly have no desire to play again. Maybe if there's free food involved. Or something.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Good game.  I think that there isn't always just one optimal strategy, like most people complain about, but randomizing the layout can definitely make cards overpowered or worthless.  I would be interested in coming up with my own layouts and trying to find the most balanced ways to play. 

if you have mtg experience, and were good at it, you will have an advantage over players who haven't had any experience deckbuilding.  Dominion is an exercise in efficiency.

This game is not a multiplayer solitaire game, if you think it is, you are doing it wrong.  You need to constantly pay attention to what your opponents are doing, and adjust your strategy accordingly.

Seeing as I only have a couple of friends who I would potentially find this challenging with, I probably won't rush out to get expansions, maybe 1 or 2 depending on how often it hits the table.  If I didn't feel so limited by who I can and can't play this with, I would rate it higher.

RATING: 8
After playing this I was reminded on the time spent playing CCGs for years.  This will cover that itch and does not require the extensive time beforehand perfecting the deck.  On the downside, you cannot spend the time perfecting and designing the deck beforehand.  This game plays roughly the same each time (Buy silver/1-2 cheap actions, buy gold/expensive actions, buy victory points) despite the variety of the cards in play.

It is an addicting game however and one of the few recently I just want to play again right away.  I still have not a game session where I only played it once.  Wisely, the designers made preset action card combos as well as the ability to randomize the deck selection to allow the most replayability.  Certain cards always seem to go faster than others (Village, Market, Festival) while others I have seen purchased once or twice a game total (Adventurer, Library).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the classic games. I do not know if this game is the one that created the "deck building" mechanic but, if not, it is the one that popularized it and it was the first game with that system that I ever played, and I simply loved it. The concept is so simple, so neat, but it works amazingly and, on top of that, it is funny to play. You begin the game with a starting set of cards, I thing that you start with 12 and your hand is always 6, then you play those 6 cards, you do one action and one buy, all the played cards plus the bought card go to the discard pile, the you draw the other 6 cards, repeat the sequence of the turn and after that just shuffle the discard pile and those cards that you have bought are now on your active pile of cards: easy and amazing.
Having said that, the problem is that Dominion may have created of popularized the system, but is feels as an incomplete game. Ok, the system is cool, now what? Just buy states and money? What for? When after Dominion I played Thunderstone, it all made sense. That is Dominion but with a purpose. Having said that, it has been a long time since I last played Dominion because the game is no longer within my group of friends, but I would not say no to a round of the game. I may think about buying it to play at home with non-games.
Positive:
1. Deck building
2. Deck building
3. Deck building
4. Easy to explain and play
5. The box is well prepared for fitting all the cards
6 A good option for non-gamers
Negative:
1. Amazing system, but without an interesting purpose. Later games have taken the system to another level: Thunderstone, Mage Knight...
2. The slow player can kill the game. This game can be fun when played quickly
3. Excessive expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great Deck building game.  Good for whole family..

RATING: 6

EDIT: Some action cards are clearly better than others and are bought much more often than others (or always).  Bad.

RATING: 7.5
Dominion is a great card drafting game with a theme that most fantasy-adventure gamers will enjoy. The game requires you to create a balanced deck while recognizing and executing on combinations of cards that will help you to be efficient in racking up points. With so many possible variations there is a lot of replay value in this game. RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is pretty much what I expected after reading about it, another good fast card game, which I am a sucker for. Essentially a hand management engine game where you build nice combos by actually building your hand WHILE playing, not before, which is a very neat change and this is the core game. Not sure what the theme is and well, it doesn't matter really. 

The nice thing about deck-building is you choose which cards you are taking into your hand rather than being subjected to the luck of the draw, also in this game you have the exact same choices to choose from for cards as everyone else so this obviously limits the amount of luck. Luck does play a part here however as after buying cards to put in your hand you are now forming a draw pile, this means cards are still coming to you randomly BUT you get to skew to the odds of which cards come to you and how often. 

Another big bonus here, there are 500 cards in the game, the way the intitial action piles are laid out there are many many combinations of different actions you can group together to start a game (25 action piles in total but typically only using 10 at a time, number crunchers how many is that?), this means even by changing say 1 or 2 piles the new combos that become available will change adding new dynamics, this means of course BIG replay value, in those terms. 

Its a fast and easy game to learn (very unlike RFTG in that way) that plays fast with very little downtime, no AP and just a smidgen of interaction thrown in with the screwage and defense cards. It did seem to me the one basic strategy of how and when to shift you focuses seemed obvious for the most part. Gernerally speaking, first start building money so you start see more money and bigger numbers, then start really focusing on the actions which is your engine, finally shift to VP's, going VP's too early gives you dead weight in your hand. I'm not expert after one game and won't claim to be, this is just how I saw it and it did seem obvious, you might disagree. 

Well this game is not without negatives IMO as so far I touched on mostly positives, constant card shuffling being the obvious one (read buy sleeves) and the other being limited depth. Now I did not say no depth and remember the game is fast so I'm not knocking it too much, at least not yet and discovering all the best working combos is fun. I think the games 'width' makes up for the depth, in other words there are so many different combos to discover with all the cards that you won't notice the lacking depth so much at first but to me the overall scope in a game is truly limited. The price in this case is another along with box size, 2 things I normally don't ever complain about. 40 or 45 bucks seems pretty steep even if there are 500 cards and tons of replay value, 30 was fair for sure and I think 35 most people could fathom (it was 30 Euro afterall in Europe)

Summary - If you like games like San Juan, RFTG or want a nice 30 minute meaty card game that scales 2 to 4 this is a pretty safe purchase. I think the price is too high and I have too many games already so I'll play friends copies and try to get it in a trade maybe later. 

UPDATE: 7.5 => 7  That was fast (2 plays). So much for the replay value if you don't really want to play it, I might not turn down a game but I would rather play something else given a choice. I really don't find enough interesting decisions here, add a card to your hand, add a card to your hand etc, its a decent filler but I would choose to play RFTG over this or any number of actual full course games...  OVERHYPED IMHO and better suited for online play to avoid shuffling. 

Edit - played a few more times on my phone with a free program I have and the game just leaves me cold. Pure "deckbuilding only" makes a decent filler, just not one I particularily enjoy (tried a few others too) yet its hard to fault the game since it at least gets the playtime versus what you get right. Maybe "A few acres of snow" will make a game out of deckbuilding...  

The HYPE MACHINE really went out of control here on this one I mean top 10?  The ratings on BGG have 'jumped the shark' on this and proved what many already knew, they are a popularity contest for the 'cult of the new' and not really useful anymore sadly.

RATING: 8
oh boy... this one is fun and *very* addictive...

After our first play, my wife and I could both see strategies we wanted to try "next game" as it's pretty easy to see what cards did/didn't work with your strategy.  I find myself thinking about strategies and card combinations a lot...  There seems to be a strong metagame here.

The random nature of choosing which ten kingdoms cards to play with is so, so, so awesome and really changes the feel of one game to the next.

So extemely happy they are expanding the game constantly: I can see this game getting played by my wife and I (and taught to our friends) for years to come.  

This game, more than any other, has caused our non-game-playing friends to suddenly become *very* interested in our hobby.

RATING: 9
Excellent game. With expansions it has a lot of re-playability. After many plays, I still enjoy it but it's very solitairy and can be quite slow in games where there are lots of +cards/+actions combos.

Best as a 3player to keep the pace up when players do have long turns.

Only difficulty is how you choose the setups; some setups can be so bad that it's just best to ignore and go big money, or they may cause an incredibly slow game (eg lots of curses and no trashing). In such cases you need to recognise this at the start and choose another setup, or make a small change.

RATING: 7


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is a good, fast game when I'm not looking to think too much past the next hand but is sufficiently challenging that it keeps me engaged.  There is a set of ten cards you can buy to add to your deck and as the game goes along you add to your deck according to your strategy, using your coin cards.  The goal is to increase the coin count of your hand enough to start being able to afford the victory point cards.  The cards are either coins for buying, victory points for winning, or action cards for having interesting and useful effects.  The composition of the deck you build determines the hands you draw, so you form a strategy on what cards you want to buy at the very start of the game and then each hand do what you can with the hand you draw.  Theme is sort of generically medieval.  The variety of possible action cards and they way they can interact, with only ten being in play in a given game, provide it with significant replay potential.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Trying to decide how much I love this.  It's either "I love this game", or "this is the greatest thing since sliced bread."  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not exactly sure why this didn't hit it off for me.  I think it was because it seemed flat.  By that I mean, it was just deck building, and I think there was a way to brake the game.  Admittedly, it's been a year or so since I gave this a play.  I should revisit and modify this review.

Just played first game after, wait for it, three years.  My son is my gaming partner, given his age, vast gaming experience, we had a much better experience with Dominion than we had previously.   Really enjoyed the variety of options.  Again, it's purely deck building, and maybe I need something extra, but this was a fun game after all. Glad we came back to it.  

Got in 3 more games tonight with my older son, a non-gamer.  Because Dominion is very much limited to a single mechanic, he was willing to play. He won one and lost another by only a point.  Conclusion: good game for your non- gamer friends. 

Okay, 2017. We all got hooked. We started to see strategies and combos, got familiar with the cards, tried a couple of expansions and even the online version.  We love the game. It really took on a different feeling this time around.  Picked up Guilds and Cornocopua.  Had a blast.  One of our oldest games, and now one of our best. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is the standard to which I hold all other deckbuilding games. I've yet to find another game that surpasses it. It's one of the few where all the cards are out on the table (literally) - almost every other attempt at deckbuilding has injected some sort of randomness that takes away from the strategic nature of the gameplay.

I do understand some of the complaints about it lacking direct interaction, but this doesn't bother me that much.

DISCLAIMER: My rating here is for the series. The base game, after many, many plays has lost its luster. I still enjoy it and recommend it to newcomers, but I prefer to add in some expansions. If I had to rate the base set by itself, it would only be a six for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
== Initial comments after a few plays

Snowball engine card game.  I like the idea of building your deck as you go, but I miss having a tableau like with Magic or Race.

Since I got tired of waiting for it, I proxied the entire game and played it ~10 times with that set.  I've since played about 15 times on BSW, and it's much better on the computer.  No setup/teardown (which is fairly annoying in this game), no shuffling every 45 seconds, and no worries about trying to find sleeves for non-standard card sizes.

Early indications are that the Chapel card may be broken beyond repair.  Certain cards hose it, without themselves being broken, but if those aren't in the mix the game devolves into trashing your start cards for some silver and gold, buying a card drawer or two, and then buying a Province every turn.

==

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It can play very differently depending on which cards are in the setup, but even with the same setup, there's usually some room for variety.  With the expansions, there are now lots and lots of cards, but that can be deceptive.  Some cards play very similarly, so that a strategy for one card will work pretty much the same for a similar card.  Example: Village and Mining Village.  But some cards that look very similar end up playing very differently, so it's good to approach each new card with an open mind.  Example: Mine, Remodel, and Upgrade.

It took me a few plays to warm up to this game.  I never disliked it, but it didn't become one of my favorite games immediately.  But it didn't take that long to get there.

I think the best way to learn is the "First Game" setup, especially for those who aren't "gamers".  Most gamers should do all right going with a different setup, but I don't recommend it.  Once you've learned the game, usually it's best to use a random selection of cards, because then everyone has to adapt to whatever cards come up instead of playing their favorite strategy over and over again.  As more expansions come out, it becomes harder to just do Random 10 from everything, but you can mix and match sets and then go random from that.

I generally don't like lots of Attack cards, but I will play them if the situation calls for it.

Full disclosure: I am a lead playtester.  I became a lead playtester after Seaside came out, but Dominion was my top-rated game long before that.

Note: Aborted game on 2013/02/10 not logged.

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2014-09-30

Dominion is THE deckbuilding game. I have tried many deckbuilding games but no one comes close to touching the king. Most have failed to grasp what makes Dominion great, namely: limited buys, limited actions, static market offering that allows for real strategic plays and fairness to all players. Without these, the strategy is to buy the most expensive card you can afford. In Dominion many times you want to buy cheaper cards because they complement your overall strategy. In fact the most powerful card in the base game is the Chapel which is very cheap.

I always want to play Dominion one more time, it is very addictive, easy to explain and quick to play. I also really like the expansions, they add a lot of replayability and endless combinations to try. Even the base game has a lot of combinations to try. It is a bit thin on the thematic side (it doesn’t bother me), but I do feel the theme through the cards (the player with the most lands wins the game). Amazing art.
 
Dominion is one my most played games (not counting MtG which I played for most than a decade).

I don’t have anything bad to say. If pressed I would say setting up the game can be tedious with all the expansions, also transporting and storing it can be a chore. About the gameplay, the shuffling can bother some people, but not me. I love the game. It can be hard to catch the runaway leader, but as the game is (generally) short I don’t really care about this.

I think they won´t release anymore expansions, but if they do I will happily buy them. I have all things Dominion (even Alchemy, the worst expansion). I expect I will continue to play it ten years from now.

Contrary to what the BGG poll says, I prefer to play Dominion with only two players. I won’t refuse three or four players games but they add a lot of uncontrollable luck and downtime. Both negative things for me.

It is a shame they closed down Isotropic and the game isn’t available on iOS yet. I know Goko has a website but last time I was there it wasn’t very good and it was very expensive, basically I would have to repurchase every expansion. Things could have changed now though, I have to review this again.

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2015-09-15

After careful consideration, there are almost no game I  would play instead of Dominion (there are only 2). Even if we play only the base game I always have fun with it, so the rating of 9.5 applies to the base game as well.

I LOVE it, the best deck builder game ever made.

One of 2008´s Favorites. 
Top Ten game.

Current Rating: 9.5

I have at least 30 plays before 2010 thus I have not logged them.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Acquired via Math trade
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As other commenters have noticed Dominion tends to keep one thinking about combinations and tweaks long after leaving the table, a sign of a potentially great game.

Dominion is less prone to the Race for the Galaxy criticism of "lack of player interaction" because of its customizable starting configuration.  Lack of targeted "screw you" cards keep the focus on your own deck, though; all interactive effects are global and affect all other players, though potentially some worse than others.

I prefer to play with 3, 2, and 4 in that order.  With 4 the game feels like it has too much downtime, which sounds ridiculous since there's about 30 seconds between turns but there it is.  2 is excellent but a tad too zero-sum and easy to track for my taste.  3-player Dominion strikes a great balance between the two.

I've pretty well burned myself out on Dominion, and I'm not likely to suggest it again in the near future.  For all the good qualities - and there are many - I find the attacks a little too passive-aggressive and take-that, and the system a little stale without them.  I've lost too many frustrating games in which I get hosed by the draw order that I'm not sure I trust my wins either.  Still a good game, but if I'm looking for a filler-length game I'll suggest RFTG.

I play Dominion less than I might otherwise because of the deck-destruction attacks:  Thief in the basic set and Saboteur/Swindler in the Intrigue expansion.  Frequently people want to play with 10 random cards, and since I'm not willing to play a game with any of those three I'll usually play something else.  Oddly I don't mind the Witch as much since she only adds Curses, not taking away a card I've already bought.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I think it's clever and I enjoyed it. 

It's very smooth and fast, but I wasn't really gobsmacked; I think I need more plays to have it bloom--it is quite quick to play, but I have handicapped friends who it's dead for simply due to the shuffling.

During this first blush rating, it seems to be lacking something to draw me in and engage my imagination. I wonder about it's long term playability, but I'll need more plays to judge this.

I did enjoy the game--I just didn't feel like I was making any real decisions. Right now, I put this down to being a rookie with the system.

[b]I'll gladly play it again or anytime it hits the table[/b], but I haven't been thinking about it while I've been away from it.

RATING: 9
This game is brilliant.  It is such a fast playing game, each game is different, and the depth of strategic change from game to game is truly amazing.  I always liked the game, but I don't think I fully appreciated its brilliance until around the 100th play or so.  It starts good and gets better.

The only thing that keeps this game and its expansions from being a 10 is that, once I discovered it online, I don't want to play it in person any more.  A game can be played so quickly online and there is no shuffling.  It's hard to justify getting it out with the family.

RATING: 6
Four plays only, which I very much enjoyed. Basic premise is simple, fun and refreshingly different. 

Not sure how deep into the plethora of alternative action cards I'd want to go - clutter/payoff ratio might lean a little towards the clutter end of things.

While I enjoy it, my suspicion is that there's not really a massive amount in here, so I prefer playing it as a quickfire game. My main beef with the game is downtime - call me impatient but I find myself getting frustrated by some of the longer turns that can be strung together with use of the village etc. 'OK, so I've taken two actions so far but I've still got 3 actions remaining, and a credit of two extra treasure, and I can still draw two extra cards .. or was it 4 actions remaining??' JUST GET THE F*****G CARDS DOWN, IT'S NOT CHESS, YOU CAN ONLY BUY ONE CARD!!

RATING: 8
Well I get the hype...a fast almost filler type game that has enough meat to keep a core gamer happy but also simple enough to please the casual gamer.  Given the intial design and the number of expansions that have come out I doubt this game will quickly go to the wayside for the mass of people.  I've actually not played this live yet (10+ plays on BSW) but I've honestly had a great time with it.  I'm excited to get it to the table!  As of right now I would rank this card game right up there with Race for the Galaxy.  At some point in time it might actually exceed it just given that there will be infinitely more oppertunites for me to get this game to the table as opposed to RFTG.  

This game has turned out to be a big hit with pretty much everyone I've played it with...going to bump this rating up a bit.

***For awhile there it was getting over played but gotta say this gamed appealed to everyone...even the female gamers of the group enjoyed it.  In terms of card games while very different in feel from RFTG and San Juan it should be mentioned with those in so much as they are some of the best card games out there.

RATING: 10
Just played 13 times in two days.  And I can't wait to do it again tomorrow.  

This game is addictive, and ever changing.  I highly recommend using a pre-set for your first couple of games (I like Big Money and Interaction better than the "First Game" set-up), and then switch to a random set from then on.

A non-existent learning curve.  With the best part of MtG being deck construction, I can't believe it took this long for this idea to arrive.  Excellent!

Update:  After 30 plays or so, the time has come to say that this is a 10 game for me.  I'm sure I won't _always_ want to play 30 games in a week of this game, but it has real legs.  And the possibility for expansion presages a renewal every so often that will be exciting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A decent puzzle game that left me completely flat.  I am NOT a big CCG fan, and I guess I just don't like the 'deck building' feel of Dominion.

Sure, there's lots to do and every game will be different... but it still feels too much like multi-player solitaire for my liking.  I've only played a few times now and it seems like the first person to buy gets a slight advantage, and the first person to be 'cursed'  (especially if it's early in the game) is at a disadvantage.

The good thing is that it is very quick playing, otherwise my rating would have probably been lower.

RATING: 5
Had a chance to break this one out to new non-board game friends. After the first game, everyone got what the game was about, and second play went a lot more smoothly.

For such an amazingly easy to teach game, this game is packed with so many strategies which is a huge plus. But theme is just bone dry... It just felt like shuffle shuffle draw do stuff written on cards. And I could see that people were not really getting into the game at all although they got the mechanic down perfectly after 1st play through. 

With more plays, it just feels like exercise to me. Only having 10 kingdom cards in each individual game seems to be main problem. I think that I much prefer Thunderstone with its epic variant.

And after trying out so many different games, I decided that deck building games are not really for me. I would still play only if someone strongly wanted to try out what the Dominion-love was all about. I like the deck building mechanism; but if whole game is dedicated to just that, I think that it loses the charm. For example, I love the deck building aspect in MK, or any other CCG where I get to build the deck beforehand.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The first deckbuilding game. It sets up a new genre of boardgames that have quickly multiplied. The first 25 kingdom card are fun to play. Having 10 of the 25 sets to choose from leads to many many unique games. Adding all the sets in is mathmetically mind boggoling.

The ability to choose what cards go into your deck can range from the obivious to combo cards for later in the game. A well thought out game.

Copy what your opponent is doing (not recommended) to just gathering money to buy Victory Point cards. (Big Money).

This game has set a high standard for all deckbuidling games that come in the future.

A relative quick set up time. Not much down time unless your opponent likes to draw a lot of cards and not do much else. Takes a little bit of time to put away since the cards will be needed to be sorted out. But that gives you time to brag or lament about the previous game.

Easy to learn. Easy to teach. Can be quite addictive.

-------original review-------
Yes it lives up to the hype for it. Deckbuilding fun. Curses, now I will have to save up and buy all the rest of the expansions.
