RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2009 Spiel des Jahres Winner[/url][/b]

[thing=142131]Dominion Big Box Edition[/thing]

In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.

Players: 2, 3, 4 (5, 6 with Dominion: Intrigue)
Time: 30 min
Mechanics:  [property=2041][/property], [property=2664][/property], [property=2040][/property]

[u]Integrations/Expansions[/u]
[center][floatleft][thing=40834]Intrigue[/thing][ImageID=460011 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=51811]Seaside[/thing][ImageID=543471 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=66098]Alchemy[/thing][ImageID=698779 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=66690]Prosperity[/thing][ImageID=1747320 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=90850]Cornucopia[/thing][ImageID=950200 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=104557]Hinterlands[/thing][ImageID=1077695 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=125403]Dark Ages[/thing][ImageID=1321190 micro][/floatleft][floatleft][thing=137166]Guilds[/thing][ImageID=1646917 micro][/floatleft][/center]

RATING: 7
Dominion is an innovate game that deserves due credit for inventing the "deckbuilding" genre. It is easy to teach/learn, plays quickly, and provides a tremendous number of combinations. The hidden scoring system provides a great element of suspense. Weaknesses include shuffling ad nauseum, lack of meaningful player interaction, and the feeling that you're not really "doing" anything. While it isn't a favorite, I'll still play and will always respect its contribution to the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Caveat: I'm a sub-contracted playtester.

The game that got me to stop playing Race for the Galaxy.  I think I've played Race three times since I first played Dominion, and I don't even have ready access to a copy of Dominion!  This is only the third game I've rated a 10, and my first new 10 since the day I joined BGG.  I think it's that good, folks.

The replayability is high, player interaction can be very high (depends on the card sets in use), group-think can be a factor, human psychology can be a factor.  Play with the same set of 10 cards and refine your strategy; switch out just one card for another and it's like a completely different game.

There are 3268760 combinations of decks (25 things, 10 at a time or 25!/(10!*15!)).  If only one tenth of one percent of those possible deck combinations are "good" (for some definition of "good"), that's 3268 different sets.  If every one of them is "solvable" in a single sitting, that's still 3268 playings of a game with no repeats in strategies!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do like Dominion, but it's kind of lost its shine for me as of late.

RATING: 6
Yet another arbitrarily medieval-themed game, but I thought it was decent. Any complaints about "too much shuffling" are clearly overblown--it really isn't that bad, and everyone should be so lucky to play any game enough times that the components show some wear. 

I'm curious about the attack cards. The two players who employed them most heavily finished well behind the front two...I finished in 2nd place with scores: 42, 33, 14, 11. Is the negative effect you give to others damaging enough to warrant passing up a chance to buy cards that give you additive benefits (Throne Rooms, Markets, Festivals, etc)?

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the very best. Tight; engaging; perfectly weighted, plenty of variety; excellent tactical and strategic balance.

A sugaring of luck from card shuffling, but the player who assesses the synergy of the available cards and follows the most efficient strategy will prevail. The game gears beautifully, with the starting game engine building (and culling), while the late games becomes a dash for the victory point finishing line. 

Players have to read the game and judge when their engine will be efficient enough to make a break for the finish; jump too early or too late and you'll likely lose. Several times I've messed up and all players have dashed too soon only to find us all have to return to improving the engine to close out the game.

Pros: 
- almost perfect in every way. 
- great game length.
- easy to teach, hard to master.
- an excellent amount of repeated game play.
- numerous interesting decisions.

Cons:
- Honestly can't think of anything wrong with this game; perhaps some of the card abilities aren't perfectly aligned with the card's theme; but the overall theme/flavour of the game is enough to overcome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game has been wearing on me lately. Less and less excited to play it.

RATING: 9
Very nice game. It has an innovative way of drafting and cycling through cards that's very entertaining. You can take different strategic approaches, but their success will have a lot to do with how the cards come up. In the tradition of board games that masquerade as card games, this is a very good one.

UPDATE: Despite this game's popularity on this site, everyone who I have introduced it to has had the response of "meh". Gamers and non-gamers both. Sadly, I may not have opponents for this game. I should stop buying expansions now....

UPDATE #2: Discovered that my girlfriend loves this game so I've gotten to play it a lot more, AND I have gotten all of the expansions. Ah, what love will do. I have upped my rating to a 9. Not just because I'm really enjoying the game play, but I have more appreciation for the invention of the deck-building mechanic. There hasn't been a new mechanic of this quality and usability in a while (I write this in June 2013). Seeing how this has been implemented creatively in so many other games is impressive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played only twice, but my rating stands. Mainly because it is "revolutionary" in its own way and because of the multitude of options you have in-game as well as pre-game.

artur
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
El creador de la mecánica de Construcción de mazos.

Muy fácil de explicar, muy fácil de jugar.. Los jugadores empiezan exáctamente con el mismo mazo y tendrán que desarrollar y mejorar su propio mazo. Para hacer esto, los jugadores deben de comprar las cartas que se encuentran en la zona central. Esas cartas están repartidas en pilas distintas dependiendo del tipo de carta.

Cuando juegas ó compras una carta, ésta va diréctamente a tu pila de descartes. al final del turno tendrás que descartar tus cartas restantes y coger 5 de tu mazo para el turno siguiente. Cada vez que tu mazo se acabe, barajas tu pila de descartes y coges 5 cartas. Las cartas pueden proporcionar más cartas, más acciones, más compras, dinero, puntos de victoria...

Un juego muy divertido pero a veces un poco solitario, dependiendo de los mazos iniciales escogidos. Con más de 500 cartas tienes juego para rato.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2013
[/color][color=blue]
The creator of the Deck Building mechanic.

Very easy to explain, very easy to play. Players start with exactly the same deck and they will have to develop and upgrade their own deck. To do so, players need to buy the cards laying on the pool. Those cards are spread in different stacks depending of the type of the card.

When you play a card or when you buy a card, you put them on your own discard pile. At the end of a turn you have to discard your remaining cards and get 5 new cards from your deck for the next turn. Every time your deck runs out you shuffle your discard pile and get 5 cards. Cards can provide more actions, more cards, more purchases, money, victory points...

Very fun game but sometimes a kind of solitaire game, depending on the starting decks chosen. With 500 cards you have game for a while.[/color]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Bought Essen 2008. While I'll play it if asked, I don't feel the need to own it so ended up selling my copy.

RATING: 5
The Good: Dominion plays fast, is mechanically smooth, easy to teach and learn, and the variance in decks should be enough to keep the game feeling fresh for a while. 

The Bad: Dominion is ALL deck building with very little interaction. Not bad if you like those sort of games, and in fact I think its a great gateway and good for ex-Magic fans.

The Ugly: Dominion is nothing more than its core mechanic. I spend all my time spending cards to buy cards, so I can spend better cards to buy better cards. Rinse and repeat. I feel no real sense of accomplishment, strategy, tactics, or drama. I simply build up a deck of cards and play whatever I randomly draw. 

WIFE RATING - 3

My wife was extremely bored and felt like she was on "auto-pilot" after the first couple of hands. She'd play it again but not without protest.

I imagine it will eventually fulfill a role similar to San Juan, which I wound up rating a 6 after some initial excitement.  When the excitement wears off, perhaps this game will settle in there too, but for right now I give the extra bump for originality.  But is it a top 10 or even a top 20 game?  No way, IMHO.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating with 80+ plays. (Rating increased to an 8 after 15 plays and to a 9 after 30 plays). 

A heartwarming concept and a slick design. The game gets a lot better once you're familiar with the cards and ready to deal ten random for the set-up. For new players I recommend twice with the basic set-up, twice with "big money," and then ten random. 

Make no mistake, Dominion is a build-income / buy victory points game. I'd love to see the deck-building harnessed to a different objective, but it's still a compelling, fast, and abundantly replayable game. Two players can sit down and blow through 6-8 games without breaking stride. In fact, that's how I prefer to play this game. Don't be deceived by the 15-20 minute playing time (with two players). An evolving series of 6+ games is the way to sink your teeth into this one. Better in 2 1/2 hour doses once a week than a quick fix every day. 

After 80 plays, I've noticed that experienced players wear out a bit on a few cards: Chapel, Gardens, and Thief. Each alters the game significantly, and after you've played as many games as I have, you're usually looking for a flexible set-up that allows you to tinker. 

[b] Thanks Secret Santa 2008!![/b]

UPDATE (5/09): I just played for the first time in three or so months. Now that I've fully sated myself on the originality of the concept, I'm finding it more comforting than thrilling or engaging. The forum comments about it being "advanced slot machines" or an "iteratively biased random number generator" ring true. I've downgraded my rating to an 8, where I think it will sit. I whole-heartedly recommend playing this game at least a half-dozen times for the innovation though (see what you think).  

Update (6/09): The truth is, I have no desire to play this until an expansion comes out. I feel like I've seen 99% of what there is to see. I realize now how much the initial experience was about novelty - much more so than with many other games. I like the speed of play and the deck-building-on-the-fly. But at the end of the day, it remains disheartening to see this level of innovation welded to such pedestrian "VP race" gear-shifting. I'd like to see much more now that the basic concept has been established. My 8 rating was an afterglow. I'll give Intrigue a shot but I don't have high expectations.

RATING: 5
UPDATE: Deck building has become a much overused mechanic since Dominion put it center stage. I don't really like the deck-building genre much it seems that they all feel pretty similar. They just don't inspire me.

This is a good deck-builder but not something that I'm interested in playing anymore. I like Thunderstone Advanced more based on the theme.

================================

This is a great card game! The mechanics are very unique and you are faced with deep strategic decisions which are unlike those in any other game (at least they feel different). 

The main reason being because you buy cards from a general supply that, when purchased, go directly into your discard pile. Each of your turns ends with discarding all cards you played, along with your hand, you then draw a new hand of 5 cards. So there is a strong element of deck building and the construction of the deck takes place each turn when you try to buy something to add to it, but what you buy only helps in the future since it goes into your discard pile. You also buy money this way, a gold treasure has value 3 and costs 6 to buy, but then it's in your deck for the rest of the game and you can use it multiple times to buy other cards.

It's a novel game that demands analysis and forward thinking to do well, and one where the novice player has absolutely no chance of beating an expert player. This will appeal to some people and not to others, but the game design is unquestionably brilliant. I only wish the price point reflected the contents of the over-sized box...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I got to play the final prototype (I think) at Gulf Games with Valerie and Dale.

All I can say is that I went to GG to play Agricola but after I tried this once, I was hooked and never played Agricola.  I think I played around 12 to 14 times over the weekend.

The game is truly amazing and I would be suprised if it was not a total hit at Essen.  From talking to Dale and Valerie, it sounds like there are a ton of new cards planned for future expansions which is only going to make the game that much more enjoyabled (I did play with some of the expansion cards which seems to add some complexity to the game).

I have seen comments about how people say this is a solitare type game/not enough interaction but they obviously have not played some of the cards since Dale and Valerie set a game up and played with me where where the whole game was about interaction (tons of cards swapping and stealing).  

Throw a thief (potential to steal money), spy (able to check the top card of all decks and either discard or keep on top), another card (can't remember card name) where you pass a card to the left (and the person who played the card the ability to trash a card) and a witch card (not sure of all the powers but one is everyone but you gets a curse card (-1 VPs) and you will have a ton of interaction.  

The beauty of this game is that you tailor it to what you want with the 10 cards you decide to use in your game!

I usually don't rate games a 10 but this game really grabbed me and is a must preorder!!!

RATING: 8

[b]Star ranking[/b]
Fun: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Satisfaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
Esthetics: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star: Expansions are essential.
[b]Verdict: KEEPER[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As testament to the replayability, we've had over a dozen plays, and I still don't think we've made it through all the different decks in the box. Games are fast, and the mechanics are simple, leading to repeated plays. With the prospect of a plethora of expansions to explore as well, Dominion will likely remain a favourite within our collection for some time to come. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
100+ plays.

+ Incredible replay value.  Games can be a race or a slog, aggressive or peaceful, simple or complex.  In some games straightforward strategies can be the best, but in many others intricate combinations can be even better.
+ Solid metagame.  Worthy of quantitative analysis.  Can be played at a very high level.
+ Satisfying mega-turns.

- Forgettable theme
- Randomness (card drawing)
- Nothing to do on opponent's turn.  Can feel solitare-esqe.

Have app version.

Dominon's a blast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ok, finally 6/10. It's just not enjoyable with too big experience differences. Some of the cards just stress me out and I don't want to use them (throne room, witch). To quote another BGG member: "If I have to sit through another turn where my opponent spends five minutes chaining together a dozen actions only to buy another action which will let him chain even more actions on his next turn, I will probably shoot myself."
---
What a forth and back! It's 8/10 again after having discovered that my girlfriend enjoys it and getting in more plays within a short timeframe. 
---
After playing this FTF once with a guy having played this a lot on Brettspielwelt, I downgraded my rating again. Different experience levels matter too much. My girlfriend didn't enjoy the game on her single play for the very same reason. I wouldn't turn down a game of Dominion with equally skilled players but I probably will turn down playing with BSW guys.
---
It is growing on me and I upgraded my rating to 8/10 after 6 plays. I enjoy this more than last year's hype game RFTG. While it shares the engine building principle, this one's far more accessible, plays quicker and player interaction is more tangible. It doesn't bother me as much here if other players play their cards right. It's easier to follow their moves and understand what they are doing. I could imagine playing this with gaming newbies what I couldn't imagine for RFTG.
---
Very innovative game. I was out of the running after one third of my first game and this will happen to some players in each round if they are not really experienced. Strategy dominates tactics. While the mechanism sounds confusing first the gameplay is very straight forward. This needs a few plays to grow on me... or not.

RATING: 10
Awesome and fun game, even for me (I've avoided CCG's). I think it makes the CCG format accessible to everyone. However, the game is deceptively tedious to teach. I told my buddies it would take an hour for their first game, and it ended up taking four hours. Sooo many questions. Advice: for your first game, don't worry about being competitive, just explore the effects of the cards.

RATING: 7
Another gateway game. I was hooked on this game (like many other people) for some time and basically mastered it, to the point where I was winning 10+ games in a row in every group I played with. In a way, it was one of my first exposures to the world of board and card gaming. But after that, it got a bit stale. I am happy to play it when the rest of the group wants to, but it is quite far down the list in terms of personal preference.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The fun of CCG deck-tuning without buying all the cards. Player interaction can be light, but it really depends on the selection of cards and how players approach the game. Unfortunately, the more I play this one, the less I enjoy it. The card selection creates combos that are predictable and oftentimes the best strategy is to ignore all the cards and focus on money. A good concept, but a flawed design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Game is very simple and easy to learn. I watched a 3 minute YouTube video then read the directions. Total time spent was around 10 minutes and then it was off to play. The game is very simple and turns are very fast keeping everyone involved. Although the game is simple it actually has an incredible amount of strategy and depth. I can see plenty of value in the base set alone and with the expansions I can see almost infinite possibilities and almost unlimited play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rating with about 25 plays:  

The 6.5 rating is going to make people think I don't like this game much when I actually do.  I bought it on release day and don't regret it for a minute.  I really love the deckbuilding mechanic it's certainly a game I've never played the like of before. 

So why the lowish rating?  

I'm concerned that this game is such a one-trick pony that the variety of cards isn't going to be enough to make it something I want to play a year from now.  I'm also concerned that despite the card variability, the number of viable strategies is actually going to be pretty limited once I've had time to explore the game.  In the first 25 plays attempts to focus strategy rather than building a diverse deck have usually ended disastrously.  This may be due to inexperience...  or not.  

Ultimately, despite the fact that I haven't had the game long, I can already think of a handful of games in my collection that I'd rather play because of the interesting gameplay variety they provide, and that's not really a good sign regarding Dominion's longevity.

Update:  7-2009

I've now played the game once since December 2008.  Every time I walk in my game room to choose a game for play my eyes linger on Dominion for a moment, then I move on.  That alone speaks volumes.  Dropping rating to a 5.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

All of my gamer buddies enjoy this as well, its so simple to learn, and tricky to master well. Plus, we are usually all in the running until the scores are counted at the end.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My personal gateway into the world of board games: the first, and still the best, deck building game. The theme is totally detached from the mechanics, but the game plays so smoothly and variety between games is so immense that it is an easy flaw to overlook.

Dominion is commonly cited as being a "multiplayer solitaire" game. While I would not argue that Dominion is lighter on player interaction than many other games, there are definite subtleties in how to respond to an opponents buying patterns that expert players will take advantage of.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The unbelievable amount of hype/buzz for this game prepared me to be disappointed, but so far I really enjoy this game.  The quick play time and large amount of replayability are huge assets.  There is just the right amount of luck, but skill seems to play a big enough role that the better player should win most of the time.  The theme is, like many releases, ridiculously pasted on, but when the mechanisms are so compelling, who cares?

Update, July 2013: Now that the initial wave of expansions has concluded, there is no denying that Dominion is one of the greatest games created, nearly always full of delicious decisions and endless variety. Up to a 10. This 10 is for the game system/family, not necessarily for just the base set alone.

RATING: 3
There are many deck builder games out there, Dominion is arguably the first to do it well, but there have been many other deck builders to come out since Dominion's debut.  Some are complete knock offs, but still good.  Some have found their own niche.  Some are just superior in every way.

For me, Dominion is clunky and slow.  And since there are several other deck builders that I like a while lot more, so I'll never play Dominion again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[Update] Subsequent playings have improved my view of the game. I think I was originally underwhelmed because of my high expectations (due to the hype on BGG).

This game uses a somewhat unique idea of building a deck of cards on the fly. Its a bit long to be a filler, but because the turns are quick, there is little downtime. My main complaint is that the strategy aspect is pretty low. Players cannot really have a grand plan for a deck theme (which is typical of deck-building), because of the various random elements and because card choices are limited and shared by all players.

And I hate that most Kingdom decks (which are supposed to provide replayability) only add Actions or Buys or Cards in varying degrees. No special rule cards that can really be combo-ed to make powerful decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Which superlatives haven't been used for this game?

Well I'm not sure but I'm certain it deserves a large number of those that have been attributed to it. I find it to be deep given the length of play, novel given recent publications and hugely replayable if you're the right type of gamer. I'm loving it and can see it improving with more expansions.

The detractions. Box size, shuffling, non-standard card size and setup time. These certainly don't detract enough from the game to make this a bad purchase.

RATING: 9
This game goes pretty quickly, if every player knows what he is doing and if everyone pays attention. The aim is to collect victory points, however these cards are totally useless until the end of the game and simply clog your hand. So having too much of them too early is certainly a drawback. Moreover, while building the deck you must keep the right balance between Treasure and Action cards.

Šis žaidimas yra pakankamai greitas, jei visi žaidėjai žino, ką jie daro, ir jei visų dėmesys į jį sukauptas. Žaidimo tikslas - surinkti kuo daugiau pergalės taškų, tačiau iki žaidimo pabaigos šios kortelės yra visiškai bevertės ir tik užima vietą rankoje. Taigi, prisipirkti jų per daug ir per anksti nepatartina. Be to, renkant savo kortų kaladę reikia išlaikyti tinkamą Treasure ir Action kortelių santykį.

RATING: 7
Only played base game... some random card choices make the game extremely weird and low scoring, while others allow you to almost bypass the action cards entirely.  Fair amount of luck involved in your deck shuffles if opponents get their golds and silvers to come together and you never can to buy the best VP cards, or if their action chaining cards come together and yours don't, you can lose making the same moves because of the shuffle... is ok when you're in the mood for card randomness + strategy of deckbuilding.

RATING: 10
A game for retired Magic-players. Almost too easy to learn, but offers a lot of differing setups and therefore a lot of possibilities for gaming without becoming dull. Game length isn't luckily that long as during a play it might become boring, as it may happen, that you can quite early see who's winning in the end. This offers a nice and compact package for some nice drafting, but a main problem with having just the vanilla Dominion is that it's a mere tutorial for the actual Dominion experience. Without expansions my rating would probably be 8-9.

RATING: 4
Playing this game is nothing like playing, collecting or building decks for Magic: the Gathering, and people who say it is are assuredly not Magic players. This is a sort of economic engine game that may play out as multiplayer solitaire depending on the random selection of featured cards (apparently it has a theme of expansionism and even conflict but in any given game this may be complete bullshit). Gameplay is well-oiled but repetitive and seemingly heavily influenced by luck, although knowing when to switch from engine building to VP gathering obviously plays a large part.

After playing again with different cards (but still little meaningful interaction), and doing much better, I can see the attraction clearer, although this still leaves me with no great urge to return.

RATING: 4
Initial rating 6 - 1st play: It's very simple - so simple I had a hard time at first wrapping my head around it thinking "that's it?" The game was called many times "brainless" you do your move which is fast and move on. If you like your turn to come around quickly then you should like this - 30sec to 1:30 and it will be your turn again. 

It's very much and engine building VP game. I don't mid the game - it's not my particular must have either. Though I must say this could be a great "gateway" game.

Oct 27/16 - Rerated to a 4. This game has seen it's heyday. Time to put it out to pasture. Boring... I would much rather teach a new player Vegas Showdown, Ticket to Ride, or Catan.

RATING: 8
I like this game. It's not so dependent on luck as RFtG, but it's harder to adapt if things hit the fan. The variety in the Kingdom-card-combos give a long lifetime to this piece of art. The playtime can be really short, when there are only seasoned veterans involved. And I don't mind the shuffling. My only real complaint is the cardsize. Hard to find proper sleeves for this sucker. I wonder though, after how many plays will this game hit the auto-pilot-mode? Experienced players will make the same decisions as they get to know the cards, so the only way to have a winner is purely determined by the amount of luck involved. Good game anyways. Feels fresh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There's the Dominion "system" (domain?) or whatever you want to call it, and the Dominion base game.  This rating is for the system, i.e. the Dominion base set mixed with cards from other expansions.  I would give JUST the base set cards a rating of 7 or 8.  They are great for learning the game, and I am definitely glad I started out with it, as it was one of my first modern boardgames, and my wife and I had never played a deckbuilding game before.  But ultimately, the base game cards are just not as interesting and fun to play compared with the expansions, there are more "dud" cards that almost never get bought, and if you are only playing with the base set, even with all the possible permutations of kingdoms, you start to see card combos more frequently that dominate any given board (e.g. workshop and gardens).  

Update:  I have not played the 2nd edition, but it seems like some of the cards were tweaked/changed in response to some of the criticisms like the ones I made above.

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  50+

RATING: 5
Based on 70+ plays on BSW and 4 face-to-face.  I think the deck-building mechanism is brilliant, although the decisions aren't all that exciting (usually the only trying one is what to buy). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The start of deckbuilders (at least the mainstream ones) is this one and it is for a reason. The game is pure, your goal is to get estates and provinces but the appeal of it is you can decide when you will do that. Do you get a lot of actions and try to combo them to get big stuff or do you go money route? When do you start buying point cards? What combos can you pull off this game. I understand why people like this game so much but I just don't see myself getting excited to play this one. The art is horrible and I like it when deckbuilding is not the main focus of the game but just a mechanic. I recommend people trying the game but there have been better deckbuilders that came and Dominion is not the only one in town.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cardgame with ingenious mechanics - you build your deck while you play.
The cards that are available are different for every game which adds a lot to the replayability and makes different combinations possible in every new
game.
While the mechanis are very innovative I would like gold to be less powerful. Most of the time your best buy is simply more gold. Having more interactions with other players as well as interaction among the action cards would be nice.
However this game has a lot of potential so that I am looking forward to more expansions.
Besides this is finally a game that plays well with geeks but also with my parents!

RATING: 7
2014-02-13 - I rated it 9 at first but changed to 8. It's very addictive at first, but after a while you realize that it is a game about buying cards and nothing more. With too many sets of cards the best strategy is to get 8 gold in single hand every turn and that's it.
It's good, but there are better deckbuilders.

2014-09-03 - I lowered the rating to 7. I think that I'm not as big fan of deck builders as I used to be. And Dominion has its flaws mentioned above.

2016-04-04 - 7->6 - Deckbuilders are not my genre and I prefer them sometimes as the mechanism, not the game itself, although I can play it from time to time.

2016-04-24 - 6->7 - After playing quite few of them I finally consider Dominion to be the best of the genre. I don't think I will own it anytime, but I can play it if someone would like to.

2016-10-11 - I bought Dominion! If I want to own a deckbuilder this is one to get.

2016-12-29 - I'm getting rid of Dominion! I like this game but I found that I really don't like to own it (and I guess it's the first such case), because of need of carrying a lot of heavy boxes with cards, then selecting right decks for the game. I prefer just sit at the table with Dominion ready and play it. I don't feel that way to any other game I own.

RATING: 8.8
Stopped playing this for a couple of years for no reason and set up a game just last week. We've now played 4 or 5 games since then. The only disadvantage of the game is the setup time compared to the play time. When I'd stopped playing for a while, I assumed that the reason we played multiple games in a row like that was to offset the long setup time. But now I remember what I knew then — it's just fun and satisfying. Dominion is one of those games where it's hard/you have limited options in the beginning, and then through your work and planning you are able to accomplish more as time goes on. That's a psychologically pleasing sequence of events. (Feels to me like the opposite of how I feel when I play Agricola.) [thing=37380][/thing] and [thing=8217][/thing] follow that same satisfying path.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Only played on BSW so far, but I have about 30 games under my belt with a variety of different kingdom card configurations.

I like it!  It does have a lot of MTG elements I can enjoy without the time and money problems.

There does seem to be some imbalance with villages, as having a large number of villages often corresponds to winning, but this isn't true every time.

My other observation is that the victory point system feels a little clunky.  I didn't design or playtest the game, so this concept might be completely unreasonable, but I think it would be interesting if each card had it's own VP value in addition to it's action.  This would solve two problems.  First, it's very easy to keep track of how many victory points everyone has.  In some games you know about halfway through that you're going to lose, and in many of them it's just a race for the provinces.  Second, it would add more tension to each decision, as your deck's final value is constantly changing (you could even have powerful actions with negative VP points).  I still think there would be room for VP only cards that net you a large amount of points similar to the "big buildings" in Puerto Rico.

On the other hand, this would generally mean larger decks are always better, while in the current rules you can end up with efficiently Chapeled decks that win with something like 15 cards.

In any case, I think this is a solid addition to my collection as it has a lot of replay value (much like Ra).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I can easily see why it's so popular. Very interesting game with lots of possibilities due to randomization of the available cards. I currently want to keep playing it constantly!

Edit: Back to a 8.5. Very fun, still love it but it is losing my interest in ways that Race, Tigris, and Ra don't.

Edit: And down to 7, too many others in the space now

Update based on play with my 9 year old son.  He picked up the rules pretty quickly and wants to play again with different cards. He's already understanding the way some cards work together and the need to balance between action, treasure and vp cards.

Initial rating based on solo play to learn rules.  This looks like it would be a lot of fun with 3 or 4 players, as there are many different strategies to pursue.  This is my type of game, building an economic engine that you turn into victory points.

Quizás le falte algo de "alma", es decir que te involucre un poco en el juego, pero al ser tan entretenido y rápido de jugar no se echa de menos ese defecto. RATING: 9
A Dominiontól egészen egyszerűen leesett az állam. Mindenféleképpen be akartam szerezni a játékot, de valami miatt óvakodtam attól, hogy rögtön kipróbáljuk. Azt hiszem, hogy az ilyen jellegű kártyajátékoknál megszoktam, hogy hosszabb játékidejűek, és bizony a szabályok elsajátítása is általában nem pár perc. Aztán amikor végigolvastam a szabálykönyvet, azonnal kikészítettem a paklikat, pár mondatban összefoglaltam a szabályokat Anettnek, és már el is kezdtük a játékot. ANNYIRA jó volt az első játék, hogy RÖGTÖN, ahogyan befejeztük, kezdtük is a következőt. Azért ilyen nem sokszor szokott előfordulni és nem csak a kevés idő, meg a fáradtság miatt, hanem általában egy-egy parti után nem érzem én sem, meg Anett sem, hogy abban a pillanatban ugyanazt újra szeretnénk játszani. Szerintem ez sokat elárul a Dominionról. Kártyajáték, de mégis kevés szerepe van a szerencsének, nagyon kiegyenlített. Mindenki ugyanazokkal a lapokkal indul, mindenki ugyanazokból a lapokból vásárolhat, és mindenki eldöntheti, hogy pár körön belül milyen lesz a paklijának az összetétele. Zseniális. 
A dobozban pedig eléggé szép mennyiségű lap található, ami nagyon magas újrajátszhatóságot biztosít. Ez a második játék Donald X. Vaccarino szerzeményei közül, amivel játszottam (a másik a Kingdom Builder volt), de mind a kettő megalkotásánál fontos szempont lehetett, hogy nagyon sokszor lehessen velük játszani úgy, hogy mindig hozzá lehessen tenni valami újat (és most nem a kiegészítőkről beszélek, mert maga az alapjáték ilyen).

RATING: 5
Basic game is fine but with minimal player interaction, and the additional cards add the kind of passive/aggressive elements of competition that I don't like.

A fine game with much variability and easy to see why it could get so many replays, it still can't hold a candle to so many other multi-player options...I just have a strong preference for games that have a narrative.    It is pretty fast, though.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Imagine you're on a game show where every player is given ten random ingredients and challenged to cook up the best dish. You choose your ingredients and their proportions carefully and season to taste, and if it tastes like barf -- oh well, you only spent 20 minutes on it, so just have another go at it!

Dominion is just like that. I love the feeling of building the perfect little recipe for any situation.

It's easy to learn and easy to play (contrast: Race), but the more you might feel like studying the cards and how they work together, the deeper your experience becomes.

It really is that good!  In fact, it kinda ruined my enjoyment of every other game I own for a long year.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played this game, literally, hundreds of times, and I still am not sated. Is it that great? Well, objectively, maybe not, but it really suits me. The deck-building takes me back to the joys of Magic: The Gathering before I had so many cards that constructing and deconstructing decks became a massive chore. The build-the-most-efficient engine aspect appeals to the perfectionist in me. The quick play time really appeals to, and the sheer variety that you can get out of, really, not that many different cards is surprising. Almost loses half a point for the endless shuffling, but since that doesn't deter me, I'm keeping this a 10.

RATING: 8
Bought Swedish edition on 110104.

Ang. den svenska utgåvan:

Den svenska kortet Spion (Spy) nämner inte att det är spelaren av kortet som bestämmer om de andra spelarna skall lägga tillbaka eller kasta kortet de visar upp. Tyvärr står det heller inte i reglerna. 

Valet av översättningen "ta upp ett kort" för "gain a card" är kanske inte den bästa heller... men det klargörs tydligt i reglerna att det nya kortet inte får tas upp på handen om det inte explicit sägs så. 

Dessutom är samtliga Hertigdöme-kort feltryckta, det står "Hertigöme" på dem, trist. 

Annars en solid utgåva som funkar bra att kombinera med utländska expansioner. Tack för det!

/kgm

---

For me, the thing with Dominion is identifying -- as well as actually managing to follow through with -- a strategy that will make use of the available cards to gain victory points quicker or more efficiently than my opponents. 

The fun thing is that we all start out with the same resources (the cards), but choose to utilise them in different ways to achieve that goal. Also, you may get to mess with your opponents' strategies sometimes.

Dominion also scratches the CCG "deckbuilding" & hand optimising itch inside a manageable and closed card set environment. That's a plus for me.

RATING: 10
Definitely my favourite board game. I love the variety and the simplicity of the mechanics, and I enjoy shuffling cards, which helps because this game has a ton of card shuffling. This is an easy game to teach how to play, which is a huge boon. I'm always looking for more games that play well with non-gaming enthusiasts.

I think you really need at least one expansion to get the most out of Dominion as it massively improves the variety. Having said that, I've played hundreds of base-game only games against AI on the free Android app and I'm not bored of it yet, although I much prefer playing against real people with the physical cards.

RATING: 8
Great mechanic. I think I'd like best Thunderstone, because Dominion lacks the thematic appeal of the other game, but my wife simply loves this. The expansions would probably enhance the replayability.

EDIT 24/10/2011: I'm very tired of the base game. Intrigue improves, and Thunderstone is funnier. Rating down to 7.

EDIT 27/07/2012: After playing against expert and dedicated players I begin to realize how deep this game really is. Rating up to 7.5.

EDIT 03/10/2012: Rating up to 8. I like this best with expansions, but with every game I like it more and more. There's a depth here I'm just now realizing.

RATING: 6
I read the forums on this one before I played it and I'd have to agree that the game probably is designed for the Ralph Wiggum crowd.  Er um, sorry; the "marketing and sales crowd".  It seems a bit limited in value to me ... but then I've only played twice.  Here's my take; if the goal of the game is to acquire Duchies and Provinces, and those are purchased via Gold, and you can upgrade Coppers to Silvers and Gold; then why not focus on just those?  Concentrate on getting more cards drawn so that you have a greater change of getting coin cards.  And then purchase Silver and Gold if you can't afford a Province.  Seems simple enough and it worked for me.  But again ... I've only played twice.

RATING: 9
Dominion introduces a clever twist on card games that is really unique: each player starts with an identical very small deck of cards and they can each customize their deck on the fly while playing (during the course of the game they can 'buy' additional cards for their deck). 

This game is very easy to learn, pretty quick, enjoyable for almost anyone and incredibly addictive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There was a time when deck building was restricted to CCGs. A time when very few games integrated deck building as a core mechanic of the gaming session itself. Then Dominion made its appearance, making deck building mainstream. 

At its core, the game is simple: on your first turn you study the cards, picture what combination you think will be effective, and then designing a master plan revolving around it. You will spend the first half of the game building your killer combo, following your strategy as best as you can. Once you reach the latter half all players plans will unravel, so you'll figure out if whatever you came up with was a good idea after all.

The base game has two main flaws. First, card variety: the number of possible tactics and strategies are quite limited if you restrict yourself to the cards included in it. This is fixed with expansions, though your wallet may not be pleased.

Secondly, it is the definition of "multiplayer solitaire". There are cards labelled "attacks", which actually offer direct interaction in between players, yet most of these are as uninteresting as they are unnecessary. The only cards which truly affects other players plans are those which add "curse" cards. Whenever a "curse" card enters the pool, viable tactics and strategies are reduced tremendously, as curses are stupidly powerful. Considering what makes the game interesting is goofing around with the potential combinations, curses hamper the overall experience badly.

Dominion is best played with two or three players, as the game is virtually the same with any number. More players simply increases downtime. Add a fourth player and the game borderlines the unplayable. Expansions allow more players, but playing more than four simply makes the game drag forever.

Funny enough, the base set is more balanced when played in combination with other expansions rather than on its own. At least it's easier to teach and learn than other expansions, so it still makes for a good starting point.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:2~3
:thumbsdown:4

[i]For more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
At first view a nice gameplay idea. But it's a bit to abstract - the cards could refer to any other historical background, it's really a pasted theme. 

And there are really many, many action cards that don´t work well, but others are real game breaker cards. The combination of two or three out of the 25 action cards, and then mainly focussing on Gold-cards and Province-cards makes the game. It´s a real simple math. In other words: There is only little possibility to change winning strategies, which makes the game only "5" in our gaming group's opinion - after some plays you know, what cards to combine (that are very few) and which ones aren´t worth anything. 

And beside this: Nearly no player interaction - there are some action cards that steal cards from other players or give them negative points - but in general there is nearly no interaction. And because of this the downtime with four players is a pain in the...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

The actual theme of the game is almost non-existent, but if you play with the right people, that doesn't matter. 

I recommend picking one up.

RATING: 9
I find my self drawn to its simplicity over time.

Easy to teach, very inclusive, fast to setup and fast to play.  Allows for great tactics, and multiple kingdom card combos allow for replayability.

Love the mechanic where everyone has the same actions as another player until the very end. No one is left behind in the gameplay.

EDIT: I still play this game to check if it should be a 10 and I still go back to playing vanilla Dominion.  I have yet to say no to a game. 

15Jan2010 : Yup still a "10"
08May2010 : Still a 10 in my collection. 
02Jan2011 : Still a 10, one of the few things fighting off my WoW addiction.
13Nov2011 : said no to my first game of Dominion.  SO reduced it to a 9.5.  I didn't want to rummage through 4 boxes to find cards we wanted to use.

RATING: 9
A quick cardgame.  That is ever changing and with modest amounts of strategy.  Each strategy changes and depends on what others select as you aquire your attack, point, purchase, and defense deck... which is randomly shuffled out each time. Has some random element depending on the shuffle.  But everything gets played in the end.  
Lots of attack and defense play.  Very interactive.  No specific targeting of one player, everyone gets it if it gets played, so low arguments.  
A staple at the gaming party to even out game ending times to shuffle players around for longer games, or over lunch (sticky card deck).

RATING: 8
A deck-building card game where you compete to get the most Victory Point cards in your deck.  You build your deck using any of the 16 (maybe 17) available Kingdom Cards which you purchase using Treasure cards in your deck.  Each game can be a unique experience since you can pick and choose 10 of the Kingdom Cards that will be used.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game is pretty light and easy to play, but it may take a couple of games to play well.  There's a good variety of card configurations, but competitive strategies for a given configuration are more constrained than it may seem.

It actually reminds me of To Court the King, where you're using a random element (die rolls vs. a five-card hand) to acquire abilities that manipulate the random element, improving the chances of unlikely or impossible events.  Of course, Dominion seems to have a much broader palette from which to choose, which (for better or worse) is ripe for expansions, but it has a similar feeling of building an engine on top of random events.

The game can take longer than suggested, particularly if cards get distributed suboptimally, but that should definitely improve quickly with experience.  Unfortunately, that same experience may lead to more sameness of play than the variety of cards would imply.

With the shuffling and setup involved, the game lends itself well to online play at BSW.  Games can be quite quick, which can throw slow players into sharp relief.  Quasi-degenerate setups (e.g., workshop/gardens) seem more obvious as well when playing through more games in succession.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I have at least another 100 plays that aren't logged. My rating of the base game encompasses all cards and expansions since we always pull from the total card pool.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
► Best deck-building game.

The game that started the whole deckbuilding craze in the board game community. Many designers and games since then copied or implemented in some way the concept of [b]Dominion[/b]'s deckbuilding mechanism. In terms of a pure deckbuilding game, [b]Dominion[/b] is still the best.

What makes this game so great is the fact that it can be played in various different ways with very different strategies, depending on the stacks of cards you bring to the table during setup and which of these cards you then "buy" and add to your own deck. You will be building your very own personalised engine that you keep expanding and refining.

The game plays [b][i]very[/i][/b] fast once players are familiar with the game's flow and cards. It also works very well with just 2 players - many players even say that the game plays best with just 2.

Fans of [b]Dominion[/b] have almost limitless options, thanks to the countless expansions, each offering more and more cards, resulting in a sheer plethora of options and combinations. Each expansion has a very different focus and they become increasingly complex, so beginners will want to get one of the first-released boxes for their first expansion(s).

The cons: if you don't like shuffling cards, you might dislike [b]Dominion[/b] for that, as you will be shuffling [b][i]a lot[/i][/b] while playing.

The game is also often criticised for having no theme, which never bothered me personally, as the rest of the game is good enough that it does not matter -- and I'm saying this as a player who generally likes thematic games.

Because of this, many players prefer playing [b]Thunderstone[/b], which indeed adds theme and a bit more complexity, but at the same time takes away the very fast-flowing gameplay by doing so - which absolutely killed the fun in [b]Thunderstone[/b] for me personally. In the end, it - again - comes down to personal preference.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I play this one a lot with my kids and wife and we love it. Easy to learn and easy to master.

We keep doing the same thing in two player, and it's resulting in roughly the same scores every time.  Even when we force ourselves to buy action cards instead of gold or victory points, we do that for a while until the money is strong enough to get victory points, and that's all we do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fast-paced, easy to learn, and somewhat luck-based card game that rewards forward thinking and a modicum of card-counting.

The theme of the cards is integrated nicely into the gameplay and the art is well-done.

Light on player interaction, the game plays like competitive deck-drafting. I lowered the score I gave this game because the replay value of the core set of cards is limited and only a few combinations of cards work well together. Choosing randomly often leads to imbalanced play or useless card choices.

[update 2017] oldie but a goodie, but at this point feels dated. I also prefer Tanto Cuore, Barbarossa or Heart of Crowns for the same gameplay but superior art.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.

Dominion is not a CCG, but the play of the game is similar to the construction and play of a CCG deck. The game comes with 500 cards. You select 10 of the 25 Kingdom card types to include in any given play—leading to immense variety.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fast playing game. A kind of reverse Magic the Gathering. You lay out 10 kingdom cards, each gives you a bonus (extra action, buy, coin, card, or something). You draw 5 cards and play them; you have one action, one buy (unless your played action card(s) says differently). Build the perfect deck (buying action cards, victory point and more money) and the winner is the one with the most victory points at the end. I love the game because it is fast paced and because, with the expansions, no two games are alike. Try it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First deck building game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Essentially a masterpiece. Introduce the relativelly new concept of "Create your own deck. Then play with it", only present in CCG until Dominion release. The variety of kingdom cards provided in the base set is large enough to enable lots of different strategies, which guarantee that the game will last "fresh" during an indecent amount of plays. 

Moreover, altough the average game length (20-30 minuts) could imply that we are talking about a light game, this is definitelly not the case. Being able to both choose a correct deck building strategy and adapting that to other players manouvers is not generally a piece of cake. 


The main drawback of this game is that some strategies (essentially those involving drawing tons of cards each turn) can end up dramatically arising the general downtime, which kill one of the strenghs of Dominion: its fastness. However, these kind of situations are not common due to the fact that the random kingdom cards setup and the ending conditions usually prevent this kind of "eternal turns" from happening too often.


All in all, Dominion is a meaty game (with more meat that other games with playtimes 5 times higher) with a very small playtime, suitable for almost everyone. Completelly recomendable.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I am yet to introduce this to anyone who didn't enjoy it... expansions keep the game interesting and fun. Much more strategy in this than may be initially apparent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very interesting mechanic, but I don't like the victory conditions. I have to agree with the comment somebody else said on the internet:" It's a mechanic in search of a game". I would have prefered more something like attack your opponent, or capture some resource on the table. I think what is missing is something that stays on the table.

It's also hard to know what is your current balance of your deck in order to determine what are it's weakness to patch. Most people argues that the box was really not convenient to store the cards, either thay would have put more space to plan for expansion or either there should have use a linear storage box with separators.

Finally, I don't like the idea of having gold card which in fact works like land in magic. It's like a regression in the CCG concepts. Now most CCG trys to avoid the land bug by making sure all cards have multiple usages (use as land or ability). I would have loved dominion to have multiple use to each cards. Maybe each action can either be played as an action or as gold. Anyways, it's just and idea.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An interesting deck-building or deck-accumulation game, where you are trying to acquire card(s) with each hand, to build a growing personal deck.  The number of cards for each one you attain increases the probabilities of drawing them with each hand when you cycle thru your whole deck.  Getting too many weak cards or minor cards could dilute your strong cards that you covet with each hand.  It can be addictive when you find certain cards sets integrated for certain games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Early rating, this one has the potential to get to a 10.  Rating bumped from an 8 to a 9 as I have gotten more plays.  So far, I only played 2 players but it is a game my wife and I are both enjoying.  Quick playing with good variety due to the different cards, I expect to get 100+ plays before I tire of this one.  Currently my wife and I are both winning about 50% of the time.

Edit:  I have bumped to a 10.  I have also played 4 player now. I enjoy the concept of building an efficient deck and the variety of cards keeps the game fresh. I don't see myself tiring of this game and the expansion will only add more variety.

RATING: 6
LIKE:

* Variability of each game due to 10 different cards being played each game.  
* Interesting concept of making a game out of deck-building.
* Expansion possibilities (which is obviously reality!)
* Tension of building a deck versus purchasing VP cards which clog your deck but give you points.
* Generally plays very quickly and often can be played a couple times in a row.

DISLIKE:

* If it drags, this game gets extremely painful to play.  This is too light a game to take time to think about what you need to do.
* More interaction would be interesting.  Some of the expansions address this but may go too far.

RATING: 9
Kb. tucatnyi játék után jött csak el az a játék, amikor ráéreztem a Dominion ízére. Akkor sikerült olyan akciókombinációkat összeválogatnom a pakliépítésnél, hogy működött a paklim, nagyon jó érzés volt, kifejezetten jól esett az a játék. Ennek hatására elkezdtem sokkal nyitottabbá válni a különböző lapok iránt, nem csak mindig ugyanazt a néhány jónak tartottat felhúzni, és most úgy érzem, hogy mindenféle akciókártya iszonyú értékes és hasznos, szóval most a játék minden apró részletében a lehetőséget látom, és ettől sokkal jobban élvezem, mint valaha.
De egy dolog még mindig van benne, ami zavar: túl sokszor kell lapot húzni és paklit keverni. Két játékos esetén épp csak végzek az öt lap felhúzásával (meg esetleg a paklikeveréssel) mire ismét rám kerül a sor, azaz így nem marad időm átélni a másik játékos játékát, cselekedeteit, pedig szeretném, számomra azzal együtt lenne teljes a játék.
Mindenesetre, valószínű, hogy ehhez előbb-utóbb kiegészítő(ke)t is fogok vásárolni (de csak miután magyarul megjelennek).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[u]Comments:[/u]
I can see why this is considered a classic by most, and why it founded a whole new genre of board games. Its a well crafted design, that spawned a million impersonators. It is also terribly boring. I kind of skipped Dominion when it first came out and went straight to Thunderstone because TS had a theme that made sense to the game. When I did finally get around to playing Dominion I was shocked I didn't despise it, because lets be honest we are all pretty burnt out on Deck Building Games. But there was also nothing all that interesting about it either. Maybe it just that the DBG genre has been so overdone in the past 5 years that nothing is all that palatable anymore, other than Star Realms. Playing Dominion now for the first time is like going back and listening to a music tape. You understand why, at the time, it was considered the creme of the crop, but now you just look back and realize how far we have come from that point in time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the tension created by other players getting richer and richer, and getting more and more victory points.  Race for the Galaxy somewhat lacks this.

Memorizing the contents of each deck (including one's own) is nicely challenging.

The variety offered by the multiplicity of setups is nice.  The setup time is relatively long, though (compared to Race for the Galaxy, for instance), as you have to select the decks to be used, to remove some Victory cards (especially in 2-player games), to order the cards by cost (if wanted),...

Downtime is minimal... except when one has to wait until a deck is shuffled.  Shuffling the deck is bothersome, but also challenging, as it can divert from the game (I find it relatively hard to remain concentrated, when shuffling)!

Decisions are not as tough and varied as in Race for the Galaxy: most hands play themselves, except when it comes to choosing what to buy.  I generally buy the most expensive card I can, which limits even more the range of choices.

Decisions also do not have an immediate or obvious impact, as newly purchased cards go to the discard pile, and will appear back randomly.  This is in contrast with Race for the Galaxy, where advancing one's tableau has a strong impact, or where discarding cards means that many possibilities probably won't surface back any soon.

Understanding why the winner won is quite challenging for me, even when all players show their decks at the end of the game.

I appreciate the short playing time.  The setup is a little bit long (it's a little bit hard to find the right set of cards in the box), especially compared to Race for the Galaxy.

The gameplay experience is refreshing (i.e. original), and I'm quite addicted to it: none of my games has ever got so many plays in such a short period of time!

The deck building aspect is rooted in card frequencies (since you can get up to 10 cards of the same type, in a deck of typically 40 cards).  Card interactions also play a role.  However, the variety of the cards found in a game of Magic: the Gathering cannot be found here.

Downgraded to 9 because I find that Puzzle Strike has a few advantages over Dominion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I left my original entry from March because I hate hyperbole and I was just getting into gaming. Dominion was my third or fourth game since discovering that board games were not Monopoly and Scattergories. Seriously. I rated the game a 10, and I was sincere, I loved it, six months later I have yet to actually PLAY another hand of a 10 rated game. This is sad, and what makes me even more sad is that the video reviews on Youtube (dicetower for one)mention that they OWN every single expansion ... they haven't PLAYED them, but they OWN them. So? For me a game is not a work of art, a game is meant to be played, sometimes frequently, sometimes not. The picture above my computer was not meant to be interactive, but Dominion is. I just can't justify holding on to a base game that nearly REQUIRES expansions just because I enjoy it. I have since changed my opinions and since my girlfriend has become picky about what games that she'll play with me. I hate to drop Dominion so far down - I mean a SEVEN?! But I just don't want to play it, even when it's free online. I'm sorry Dominion, you will always have a place in my heart....

and the review that made me post that one ...

I love this game. Honestly I hate cards but this game is amazing. What really makes this game great is the amount of possibility. Really I would like some expansions, but for now Dominion gets a ten. Well rounded, small amount of luck, fun, non-combative, this game deserves every award that it has won. Grade: A+

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
We are probably in the vast minority, but unfortunately the game fell flat for us.  As has been expressed very well in a few reviews, the bulk of the game is not about [i]card play[/i] per se, but what cards you buy and deck building.  Since the card play and card combos in your hand are usually obvious, they don't give a feeling of satisfaction of accomplishment like in other games we like such as  [GAMEID=8217] or [GAMEID=12002].  One of the problems is that the cards themselves just aren't very [i]interesting[/i] (and the introductory set up is probably the worst offender in that regard)---for example, many of them are just variations of the few basic effects such as +action, +coin, or +card.  As a result, even though there are 25 kingdom cards included, many of them just don't feel very different from each other.  The actual differences are subtle and require a lot of experience to fully take advantage of.  This may be interesting from a statistical and optimization standpoint, but it just wasn't very fun and felt very dry and mechanical to us.  I also think that philosophically, the game didn't match up well with us---this game is all about flux and managing your ever changing deck.  We tend to enjoy games where you build something that has some permanence.  

One review compared this to [GAMEID=9217], particularly in the dry number-crunching sense of turning money straight into VPs.  Tellingly, we didn't really enjoy that game either.  [GAMEID=36218] is much better in that regard, and the deck building concept on the fly is novel and exciting, but it just left us wanting more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a great game with lots of tactical options. Due to the way you only get a small part of the available cards in a game it has a high replay-ability but ... something was missing .. and that's interaction between the players.
We felt like both playing a game on our own that coincidentally was played on the same board (or table that is). I hope that an expansion will fix this problem because otherwise this game might not get out of the closet to much I fear.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is kind of my favorite game because I love to play it any chance I get.  That doesn't mean I think it's the best game ever.  It's just right up my alley.  I love deckbuilders, and I love planning my whole strategy before the game even starts.  Now, other people hate that aspect of it.  And I totally understand.  That's why I don't force this game on people at all.  It's really a game for a target audience and not for other people.

Everyone complains that the theme is pasted-on.  Yes, the rulebook and the box's flavor text is goofy.  But so what.  It's just flavor text, and we shouldn't take ourselves too seriously.  Some of the later expansion's flavor texts were actually hilarious.  This one not so much.

Is the theme pasted on?  Yes and no.  I think the theme across all the expansions is consistent with itself.  You're in midevil ages up through colonial ages.  And all of the cards really explore a lot of aspects of all those times.  So I think the game did a good job of exploring its theme.

But could it have been any other theme?  Yes absolutely.  But that doesn't make it a bad game at all.

RATING: 6
Definitely not my kind of game but I do see the appeal in it. It can be quick, fast and over in 20 minutes. However with new players, it's going to be a huge snoozefest especially when they manage to hit a combo (hmm I wonder if I should play this action or that) again and again and all you can do is sit there and try not to get angry at not being able to do anything. On the first play, I thought it was totally multiplayer solitaire. It was only later did I realise that I was basing my moves on the other player's. Depending on what the other player bought, I would try to figure out a better combo or counter to their strategy or something. I've only played 2 games so far, so I think I might actually give like this if the expansions makes this game really worthwhile. But with just the base set, it is really boring and full of shuffling and automatic decisions.

RATING: 8.5
We're currently in the throes of a Dominion addiction. We have both Intrigue and Seaside expansions, and everyone we've introduced to has gone out and bought the game afterward - except for a few who are tight on funds at the moment, so they instead call us to make game dates every weekend. This is the only game we own that at an hour past our bedtimes, we can have played four times already, and still want to play "just one more game".

1/12/12 Update: no longer addicted, a little burnt out - but still great to teach new gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players: 2-4
Best: 3
Time: 30 Min
Type: Strategy

+Dominion: Intrigue  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
To start with the obvious, I like Dominion a great deal less than the overwhelming majority of the gaming public. I do like the second base set, Dominion: Intrigue, significantly more, although I won't say that I love it either. I haven't played Seaside, Alchemy, Prosperity or any other expansion or base set enough yet to have a firm opinion.

With that out of the way, on with the vivisection…

Actually, I'll begin by stating that there is some genuine genius to be found here. Building a deck in play is a marvelous idea that probably prompts a "why didn't *I* think of that!" response from a large percentage of gamers. Hopefully it will be explored in future game designs that are more amenable to my interests.

The VP cards are a cute idea, too, although one that I think is fatally flawed in the final analysis (in the absence of letting the cards do something else). While it makes the transition from income and infrastructure to scoring more difficult, having your deck spammed is less fun, and it makes the one point VP cards almost as distasteful as the -1 VP Curse cards.

Ingenuity aside, however, Dominion is gaming junk food – highly addictive in the moment, but an empty experience that leaves me dissatisfied, even a little hung over, almost immediately after I stop. In particular, I find the lack of continuity between hands really dissatisfying. There is no building of infrastructure and the deckbuilding element, which should offer some feeling of continuity, is undercut by the absence of hand management imposed by having to discard the remnants of your hand (and drawing a fresh hand) at the end of each of your turns. There is almost nothing tying one hand together to the next, and I find this makes for a hollow gaming experience. Even something as light as Lost Cities offers more in this area.

This is augmented by how the structure of the game places the only meaty decision right at the start of play. Once the array of cards is selected for the game, there is a bit of time spent analyzing what cards and combinations are available, and then picking out what you think the best available strategy is. After that, most decisions are dictated by what cards you draw, and are trivial. Some thought has to be given to when to switch form building your deck over to focusing on buying VPs, but this is mostly a matter of when you can buy Provinces with reasonable consistency.

I also find the fact that just buying money, ignoring the action cards, is a strong (and sometimes even the strongest) strategy a bit weird. While experienced players won't choose this path a lot, and the Thief decimates it, playing it is not a stupid move, but more or less destroys the middlegame for the person playing it. It also ignores the most interesting element of the game: the cool powers the cards offer.

People who (wrongly) argue that Race for the Galaxy and Princes of Florence are multiplayer solitaire really need to get a load of Dominion.

Oh, that's right. They probably love it because of all the take that cards. Unfortunately, I find take that games (Citadels or Inn-Fighting, for instance) anywhere from boring to distasteful, and Dominion is no exception. Fortunately it is possible to leave those cards out, but at that point the only effect players have on each other is depleting the card tableau, which times the end of the game.

Finally, there are games when one or more of the players get major combo engines rolling – endless streams of Villages and Festivals granting a dozen actions and a batch of purchases. In these games, one of the few real assets on Dominion's side, its pace of play, is inverted and the experience can be excruciating. These combo engines are shiny, and tend to draw in new players more than experienced players.

So, yeah. Dominion. Not my thing, really.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I eventually realized why all the card powers are so simple in Dominion. It's because your "tableau" is whatever cards you happen to hold and draw over the course of a turn. Since there's no guarantee you can connect card X to card Y, a card's combo-power has to be extremely basic or it would never be useful. So the result is that [b]the very thing which makes the game novel[/b] (i.e. the deckbuilding) is what drags it down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
really enjoyable, but strategies are a little predictable after enough plays, hopefully expansions will help
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Despite the lack of theme and that I feel there are too many turns spent buying silver (yes I know how much silver you should buy changes with the cards available, but there are too many turns spent buying silver in general), even a single card stack change can dramatically affect the gameplay, causing you to have to constantly adopt your strategy and adding a huge amount of variety. I disagree with people who consider this game being basically a solitaire experience, as you have to keep track of how fast the stacks are running out and what other people are buying in order to perform successfully, notwithstanding some (albeit small) interaction with attack cards.

EDIT: I've now played many other deckbuilders: Legendary both Marvel and Encounters, Shadowrift, Ascension, Thunderstone, Paperback, Star Realms, Magecraft, Friday, Hyperborea, Mage Knight, Trains, Xenoshyft, Automobiles, Flip City, Valley of the Kings. While the lack of theme and low level of interaction of Dominion means I think many other deck builders have a niche, I still think Dominion is the best deck builder out there. 

Firstly, this is because I think most of the other deck builders do not have as balanced cards as Dominion. There are only a couple of cards in Dominion that are very swingy (e.g Thief), and it is possible to mitigate against those cards by building your deck accordingly. Also, while there are definitely cards that are more useful in more situations, besides maybe Adventurer almost every card can be an all-star in the right situation. Meanwhile, in Thunderstone how your level 3 heroes clump together can make or break the game for you, in Xenoshyft the order of the monsters that you have very little control over can really screw you over, etc.. Also, there are cards in Trains, Thunderstone, that you never buy. There are also not of many cards that get out of hand (well quite a few in the last few expansions, but they can be diluted to weaken their combos), whilst in Legendary there are cards that at times are just terrible and other times 

Secondly, most games do not have as nuanced cards as Dominion (e.g. Library: draw back up to 7 to counter Militia: discard down to 3). Changing even one of the card stacks can totally change up your play style, whereas for most other games I feel like there are a few obviously strong cards and you try to build around those each game. I think Dominion is also helped by the one buy, one action aspect per turn. While some people may feel this is restrictive, it makes it harder to spam cards, and I feel like requires more careful deck building. While Smithy is just +3 cards, the lack of actions afterwards and need of buys to take advantage of the potentially large money hand you are about to get means you have to purchase other cards too. Meanwhile, Control Room in Trains (also +3 cards) feels like a really bland card because it just lets you do more of what you already can do.

Thirdly, for some other deck builders, the deck building aspect is kind of just pushed to the side and used as a tool, making the engine building feel much weaker (Paperback, Mage Knight, and while I haven't played it, I suspect Baseball Highlights 2045).

Fourthly, Dominion's VP mechanism makes it harder for runaway leader, or if there is one the game is almost over anyways. In contrast, the rewards for defeating enemies and not putting the monsters in your deck in Legendary means it actually promotes runaway leader, and Star Realms is so reliant on card combos that things can snowball like crazy.

Finally, Dominion is simple enough for new gamers, yet with it's different puzzle every game can keep experienced gamers engaged.

As for the base game, while some may think it is bland (and I certainly agree with the beginner setup unless you are playing with nongamers), I really like how the cards are so simple yet have all these subtle combos with each other. It creates a sort of elegance within the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.53
Comments entered on 23 Dec 2009:

Dominion was released in October 2008. This was a game that appeared on some of the hot lists for Boardgamegeek rather suddenly. I may have missed some of the initial buzz but the time from when I first heard about the game to the time when I played my first game was less than a month. This is rare as most games get months of buzz before release.

I have been able to play this on many occasions already, and it is very rare to only play one game when it does get played. I have taught probably 8-10 people how to play, and a couple of them even purchased their own copies of the game after playing. However, I taught my friend, John, who was a die-hard Magic player how to play, and he actually did not enjoy the game very much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I get the hype, now. My wife can shop, and I can hunt, perfect. Also known as 'The Shuffling Game'. I'm happy to have this game especially considering that Dale Yu is one of my favorite people on BGG.

The game for me will always lose a point because of the card backs not being a particular side up. This makes all of the shuffling that much more difficult, especially with the cards in sleeves.

I have gotten complaints regarding the card text's masculine-only gender usage. Magic The Gathering has gotten this right since 1993, I don't see why Dominion couldn't do as well in 2009. For each time I hear complaints about the strict usage of "He" and "His" on the card text... the game will never rate higher than an '8' with me.
