=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game offers a lot of what I want in a game.  It's quick while requiring some interesting decisions.  It also provides that occasional "Ah-Ha" moment when you discover a clever combination.  All of that with a simple ruleset.

Granted, I've only played three times, so my rating might go down if it lacks staying power, but right now, I'm impressed.

UPDATE:  I've lowered my rating on this, more from deck-building fatigue than anything else.  Frankly, I'm not too thrilled that the boardgame industry has moved in the direction of pumping out as many deck-building games as possible.  I'm concerned that this move is caused, in part, by a lack of ingenuity in the industry, which may not bode well for its future.  Just ten to fifteen years ago, the boardgame hobby seemed to offer a much more diverse universe of games and gaming experiences.

Dominion is not to blame for this, but I do think that the ubiquity of its deck-building mechanic is a symptom of other problems in the boardgame industry, namely euro-fatigue and the lack of design focus it brings, amateurism in design and publishing, and the economics of the industry which has curtailed the very important role of game development and other processes integral to the publication of high-quality games (proofing comes to mind).

[microbadge=13167]

Deck drafting as in-game strategy is ingenious, and the fact that it takes less than five minutes to set up and less than five minutes to teach (even to non-gamers) but still has depth and replayability abound is what sells this game.

RATING: 5
I was very excited to get and play this game.  The idea of a game with deck building being a central mechanic was intriguing.  The theme was definitely one I could get behind. 

After a few plays, Dominion has been a colossal disappointment.  I really, really wanted to love it, and I tried, but in the end, it's just not that compelling of a game.   Boring, dry, repetitive.  Virtually no interaction at all.  

I found myself calling out my plays to my opponent  (okay, playing a Village, drawing one, playing a Smithy, one action left, etc.) and realized that the only reason I was doing it was to keep us both involved in what was going on.  Otherwise, we were oblivious to what the other was doing. 

There are many games that I don't care for that are highly regarded by the BGG community, but usually I can at least appreciate why they are so esteemed.  I'm drawing a blank on this one, though.  I can not, for the life of me, understand why this is ranked #6.

Traded 6/09.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Innovative and slick game of deck building to score points.  With many cards and only 10 in each game, there is an immense replay value, though some cards do tend to dominate, leaving others by the way-side.  Set-up is a bit of a pain, but it lends itself well to multiple games at a sitting, thus easing that issue.  It does have some depth to it too, the way you see the game progress changes as your experience with it increases.  Reading the environment is key - some games will be a race to get to 8 gold and others will be more about setting yourself up for the long game.  A good game because it is satisfying without being too long.  But despite the immense replay value of so many different cards (and more and more with expansions) I don't see this as a great game, that certain cards will come to dominate a set-up.  I am happy with owning it and will play it regularly, but don't feel any great need to pursue the expansions.
UPDATE (somewhat belated): I held with that view until Prosperity and I got to try it out. Altered the dynamics so much I added it to my collection and then Seaside too. But really done with it now. Looking at the new previews, the cards are getting more and more convoluted and that is not what I want from this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really ought to play this more than I ever get a chance to. The pioneer in the deckbuilding genre does a phenomenal job of establishing the tropes that future games of its ilk would later take advantage of.

Now it feels like a very rich sort of puzzle, and the replayability is just incredible... there's a simple sort of genius at work.  Though I still don't really grasp the point of Chancellor.  Never bought it, and probably never will. --12.29.10

After I've played & logged almost 50 games and played hundreds more online, how could this not be a 10?  --4.20.13

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is more than just easy to get into and lots of fun - it also feels sort of like the "logical next step" after CCGs. If you're at all familiar with Magic, etc., playing Dominion will feel to you something like the way that Settlers or Tactics must have felt to a generation of Americans bored with endless, tedious rounds of Clue and Monopoly. 

Ultimately, it doesn't quite hit my sweet spot, because although the card art is uniformly impressive, the game is pretty themeless. After a few plays the cards really might as well just have numbers and abstract symbols on them. But that doesn't detract too much from the sheer innovative genius of the design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I think Dominion plays best on a computer. The phyiscal version is fun but takes too long to set up given the length of the game and certain card combos can get confusing. King's Courting cards can result in you cycling through your deck leading to a huge amount of book keeping. In a digital format this is done automatically and keeps play quick. The physical version, however, grinds to a halt as each player has to calculate how many actions, buys, money, price reductions etc they have at each stage of a long combo of card plays. I'd rate the computer version of Dominion an 8 or a 9 and the physical version more like a 7.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8
sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Saying that this is THE worst deck building game ever, is an understatement. What really makes me hate this game is what happens when you buy victory point cards. In a game like Ascension, when you get victory points (honor points), they just go in your pool of points. But in Dominion, they go into your discard pile, which means on subsequent turns, you will surely draw useless victory point cards. This effectively dilutes your deck, which basically goes against the whole concept of deck building. I've lost count of how many games I lost because I went on for 2-3 turns without drawing anything but victory point cards. This got old and frustrating really fast.

If you want a DBG that's well designed and leaves you with a good, positive and long lasting experience, then play Ascension. Hell, even selling your organs to buy that extra CCG booster pack to play a game like Pokémon or MTG is a better alternative to Dominion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love Dominion if only for the ease of play and variety of cards. Even the base set of the game comes with enough replay value to keep things going for a long time. Yes, it's a little bland. Yes, the artwork doesn't always match up. But what you get for your money is a neat game that spawned a generation of new deck builders for us to enjoy.

Great CHEAP storage solution:

86% of the folks polled (on a small poll) indicated that it is better to start with the basic dominion set (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/460334/which-dominion-should-i-buy). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Instant hit. Works great as a nonconfrontational couples game.

Also plays great with up to four. The extended family loves it, which is key for me.

I like that strategic play can typically win, but that in the right circumstances, luck can play a role.

Edit: The vast majority of my plays are two-player with the same opponent. We have played hundreds of times with a variety of expansions.  Games are often close, except when we use colonies (which tend to lead to more disparate scores).  Still great fun. And unless we use really action heavy card set-ups we can normally play a game in 20-30 minutes, which is a plus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
8/2008 Finally someting NEW among the masses of released games.  It's all about building a deck of cards.  You start out with 10 cards - 7 coins and 3 VPs.  Then on each turn you draw 5 cards; play action card and purchase new cards: coins, actions or VPs.  Throughout the game one has to balance the deck content and toward the end focus on having the most VP cards in your deck.  
The basic game contains 500 card, but only 25 different action cards.  This will be the games downfall quickly becoming booring and repetitive.  My initial rating will probably drop fast with further play.

2/2010 My prediction has been all wrong so far.  With the continued output of new expansions the initial 25 kingdom cards is no longer a limitation.  I'm changing the base game rating down to 8 from 9, only to give the Intrigue expansion a 9er as it is rather more interesting with added options.

5/2010 Further play haven't shown further depth.  The game consept is too solitare, and the little interaction is mostly one-way and not inter-active nor subtle enough.  Intrigue is the better box at 8 while basic Dominion is a 7 at best.

Received 16/7/2009
Sold 19/4/2011 English version


4/2011 In support of Norwegian board game initiatives I'm now left with only this edition of Dominion; awaiting the Norwegian Intrigue soon to be released.  As for my earlier game comments, see the English edition.

Bought 8/10/2010 Norwegian version

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Occasionly a frustrating or too-slow game results from a poor selection of cards. 

Other than that, a brilliant design, with huge variety from simple rules, and interesting strategy choices, which have to vary game-to-game.  Plus, it's short and light enough that you can afford to experiment with cards you haven't used before, and just have fun with it (which can't be said of the unloved buildings of PR for example).

Really very clever design indeed, with cards nicely balanced and everything flowing very smoothly.
Simple, clean, addictive fun.

Have invested in several expansions (avoiding the duffers Alchemy and Seaside) and it really does increase the variety and the options. It's more of the same, but the game is all about the available combos, and making good use of them, so this is one game where expansions work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First impression: Felt very low on interaction. Deckbuilding element appeals to an old TCGer.

Update after several plays: There is interaction after all (witch, thief, militia, spy, bureaucrat) but none of it is directed. So you can't hit the leader. You can win this game while completely ignoring what the other players do. Furthermore if you draw your copper 3-4 in the first two rounds, you are at a significant disadvantage against other players that were able to buy a 5 cost card, that is very likely to come up soon, since their deck is small. Finally the theme doesn't feel very well integrated in the game, likely a paste-on.

more updates: A thing I overlooked, that leads me to correct my rating upwards, is that Dominion is a nice filler due to the short playing time and good replayability.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Played more than 100 times]

PROs:
-) Simple basic concept that yet leads to several possible strategies. 
-) Nice blending of deckbuilding in the gameplay.
-) Good variety (and potential for expansions).
-) Short (ideal to tinker with different setups).
-) Addictive.
-) Easily expanded.

CONs:
-) Some cards seem clearly more important (powerful) than others.
-) Luck of the draw is far from negligible. 
-) Tiebreaker is not enough of a compensation for the advantage of playing first.
-) Annoying costant (re)shuffling.
-) The important info on the cards could have been printed more clearly.
-) The artwork is unimpressive, when not downright bad.
-) It'll have multiple expansions.

RATING: 8
Im Spiel geht es darum, mit Geld besondere Karten zu erwerben, die Aktionen ermöglichen, mit denen letztlich wieder Geld oder die nötigen Siegpunkte durch Ländereien zu erlangen.
Wer an der Reihe ist, spielt von seinen fünf Handkarten genau eine Aktionskarte aus. Anschließend kann der Spieler mit ausreichend Geld genau eine Karte kaufen (Geld, Aktion oder Siegpunkte). Alle genutzten oder gekauften Karten wandern auf den eigenen Ablagestapel und vom eigenen Nachziehstapel wird bis auf fünf Handkarten nachgezogen.

RATING: 8
The idea for this game is great -- very appealing. The cards see a lot of handling, so I'd suggest sleeves right off the bat. Standard Euro sleeves work fine. Playing well requires an ability to analyze the interaction between the cards. The game continues to grow on me. We have played many of the expansions to this game, but we don't like the expansions that add new rules: Alchemy & Seaside in particular. We like Dominion for it's plain and simple rules, but we like a variety of cards as well. Both of our kids own this game. Favorite expansions in order: Hinterlands Prosperity, Intrigue. That's all you really need.

Very interesting game that seems to have a lot of depth. As a long time Magic player, many of the priciples of deck construction from that game hold true while playing Dominion. Highly recommended.

Ratings update December 2010. I initially rated this game as an 8 but as Dominion and the expansions are some of the most played games I own and everyone loves them, I have to upgrade the game from 8 to 10. It is unusual to rate a game a 10 but I feel that Dominion deserves it. Dominion has opened up new design space for board games and much like Magic, my other 10, it is an absolute classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The base game of Dominion is great, but has a limited shelf life.  Add in just one expansion and it just explodes with possibilities.  

One of my favorite things about Dominion is you plot out what you plan to do in the game based on the cards available at the start.  Once the game starts, it is all about tactically managing your deck.  You have to keep in mind what you've purchased & how many of each so you can keep your deck balanced with the plan you set out to do at the start of the game.  

Once you start to add in an expansion (or more!), the game play starts to become quite deep.  Yet, the rules are simple.  Great combination!

I love combos!

RATING: 4
Great for fast games online, not sure if I would like it in person, though.  It would probably drag.  There are some strong strategies, I think players of equal skill would be highly dependent on luck.

Four players really drags, two and three is preferred.

In real life, the book keeping of +action cards is a little annoying.

Okay, approaching 200 plays and the thrill is gone.  Figuring out the combos was my favorite part, now it mostly comes down to the skill of the players and the luck of the cards.  When the skill of the players is similar, the entire game boils down to who happens to draw the bets card combos turn-to-turn, which is just not fun for me.  I will probably play this a few more times, but I'm pretty much done now. 

100+ plays, 2, 3 and 4 players

RATING: 5
Meh.  So, there's a lot of important decisions that go into optimizing a deck.  But the fact that it requires a lot of thought doesn't make it enjoyable.  It's like the Su Doku of games--you can almost mindlessly play it over and over and get really good at the strategies, with the different combos keeping it interesting for longer than the mechanic really deserves.  Top it all off with a heavy dose of randomness, and I don't see myself coming back to this.  (And on the subject of interaction, I don't think there is any.  Sure, some cards affect other plays, but in the manner of an annoying and arbitrary random event, not in a strategic manner.)  I don't see myself ever requesting this, and I'm on the verge of actively avoiding it.

RATING: 8
Absolutely brilliant game for card lovers like me. Every turn you can buy one (sometimes more) cards to go into your own private deck. There are three kinds of cards you can buy: victory points, money, and special actions. You try to build a deck that allows you to buy the victory cards faster. Fast, easy and fun, but strategy is subtle. Best with 2-4 players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
This is an amazing game.  Building a CCG-engine deck that you use throughout the game...it's just staggeringly brilliant.  

The use of only a set number of different Kingdom card types in any one game seems like it will keep the game fresh for quite awhile.  Currently, with D, D:I, D;S, D:A, D;P, D:C, D:H, D;DA, D:G, D:Adv and the (5) promo cards, there are 235 Kingdom cards to mix and match.

Wow.

-- Platinum & Colony come in if the first card drawn from the Randomizers is from Prosperity, or if at least 3 kingdom cards are from Prosperity
-- Shelters come in if the last card drawn from the Randomizers is from Dark Ages, or if at least 3 kingdom cards are from Dark Ages
-- We've finally figured out the number of cards we like best for 2p:  8 each for Victory Cards, 6 each for other Kingdom Cards, and 10 each for Curses.  Treasure supply piles stay unchanged.  This is a good balance for 2p.

[i]*Own everything Dominion that's been released so far![/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent building game with only cards in an original concept. It has money cards, building(=action=kingdom) cards and victory point cards, yet there isn't even a seperate building area! The thing you are building is your deck of cards, which you recycle continuously to buy more buildings and victory points.

The deckbuilding aspect somewhat resembles the deckbuilding in Magic(CCG). There too you have to find a delicate balance: not too much mana, not too little, not too many low-cost spells, not too many. In Dominion the trade-off is between Victory cards, which only pollute your deck, and money/building cards, which improve your deck but don't make you win by themselves.

 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Wenn Deckbuilder, dann Dominion. Allein das Basisspiel bietet schon einen enormen Wiederspielreiz.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game that's very fresh and innovative when first played, but after numerous plays, it comes down to a number crunching system. This loses the game's appeal quickly, and with a gaming group that's good in math, this becomes a quick run of maximizing your points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
This was our introduction to deck-building (one of our favorite mechanisms), and it's an excellent game. We decided to trade it because we've moved on to deck-builders that we like much better, and we were just never going to choose to play Dominion over those other games.

We had two problems with Dominion. My husband didn't like that all the cards were laid out right from the beginning. He likes the more limited options of the Ascension-style purchase row. 

I didn't love how dry the game was. In my opinion, a game can be "themeless" and still not be "dry" if the mechanisms are interesting enough. In Dominion, the cards didn't feel unique to me. It was all about making sure that you got to play as many cards on a turn as possible, while at the same time making sure you got as many extra buys as possible. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Outstanding blend of CCG offline deckbuilding with Euro game sensibilities about elegance and strategy during the game itself. I suspect your reaction to this one may have something to do with your CCG experience, but perhaps not. I was a Magic:the Gathering player, always loved the game, but didn't love the all-consuming nature of CCGs. You can "dabble" with Dominion (and buy the entire standalone game for one fair price), unlike the CCGs I remember.

RATING: 8
The first, and in my opinion, best deck-builder game I have played. All players start on an equal footing, and good decisions with the right combinations can ensure strategic success. Clever design and an elegant mechanic make this a firm favourite. Just be weary of the players who like to load up with multiple cards that have extra actions and extra card draws. You will watch them cycle through their whole deck before it's your turn! Being able to do this is great, but just remember you need that Gold too!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
11/30/08: Tentative rating of 8 after one play.  I would say that this is Fluxx on steroids, but I don't want people to get the wrong idea.  This is an excellent game, whereas Fluxx is almost as far from excellence as one can get before coming back from the other side.  Planning the buys, balancing VP cards with useful cards so you don't get hands of crap often, it's all very cool.  I look forward to more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.8
even a hit with the non-gaming wife and kids
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Why is this game number 6 on BGG?  It's a card game! Anyway, a very over rated game it would seem.  I like the general idea, and in particular the fact that, unlike CCG's such as Magic: The Gathering there is no need to buy thousands of cards to play.  However, it actually suffers all the same problems that affect MtG: any experienced player will immediately spot that from all the kingdoms played there are only a few that are any use in a given game, and it's often the same cards that are powerful in any given game.  Thus gameplay is distilled into a grab for the right cards, in the smallest decks, so players can drill through the cards and grab victory cards.  After a few games you realise there aren't enough kingdoms in the base game to keep things fresh for long and guess what, you need to be expansions to freshen things up.  It *is* in fact a collectable card game after all.  Spent far too much money on MtG to be suckered into another CCG.  Perhaps, for somebody who has never played MtG there is fun to be had, but my group of players got little from this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It gets repetitive. I'm not so obsessed with deck building. Thought it sometimes feel OK, but I prefer other games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is obviously a game that I love to play.  It plays quick and is different every time because we always play with all the expansions and promo cards available (currently we have 78 cards I think).  I expect it will be my most played game for a long time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is 75% of what I love about CCGs (deck building, taking advantage of good luck while overcoming bad luck, competition) without the 99% of what I hate about them (collectability) -- it rocks on toast with a cherry on top, and I would like more, please.

From starting on a level playing field to the pacing and overall feel of the game, Dominion is just a blast. It's easier for CCG players to grok, but also accessible to folks who've never played a CCG before. And like Pandemic, finishing a game makes me want to play again immediately.

Despite the fact that multiple plays have proven that my CCG brain doesn't mesh well with the skillset Dominion needs -- the ability to instantly assess the relative value of a set of 10 random cards and how they interact with one another (whereas I did my best at CCGs when I had a chance to hone a deck over a long period) -- I love losing at this game. When a game is fun to lose at repeatedly, it's a keeper.

I agonized over whether or not this needed to be sleeved, and decided (after much reading here) that it did. After seeing how much shuffling is involved in just one game, sleeving is a must.

---

Man, I used to love Dominion. Three things knocked it off my interest list and out of my collection.

First, I went big with it, and it collapsed under its own weight: I bundled multiple sets and expansions in a box with custom, labeled dividers, and sleeved every card. It became a production to play.

Second, my group's meta -- they were most interested in games without curses (and similar mechanics), and with an even spread of card costs, which made the game a) not essentially Dominion, and b) kind of same-y every time.

Third, it got fiddly -- especially when I contrast it with Ascension. Playing involved setup with a randomizer app, and then a discussion (see meta above), and then a fussy teardown after the game.

I'm sad to see it go, though, and I wish I'd stuck to just the base set, Seaside, and Intrigue from the outset. Re-rated from an 8 to a 7 (a long ways from its one-time height of 10!) and sold. I'd happily play it using someone else's copy, and without restrictions on the card selection.

---

After a few plays of just the core set, no expansions or fancy storage, re-rating from a 7 to an 8. I can see buying this again and not expanding it. The core gameplay is just so good.

RATING: 9
Appeals to the gamer that just loves building stuff. It's a game that just feels good; planning that perfect combination of cards and then seeing it all come together, getting ever closer to that perfect combo you strive for, "but oh, you can do better!" you think, "how about just one more of these! And these!", before suddenly your opponent is satisfied and takes off and forces you to either follow him or take the chance and build further upon your deck! The game is low on interactivity between the players, but that's because this is more like a game of building, say, a rocket that's JUST good enough to get you to the moon before the other guys do. You could build the greatest rocket ever build, but if your opponents land on the moon before you, it's all been for nothing. Get the analogy? No? Oh well, just buy it anyway!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Highly addictive with excellent replay value.

Update 3/8/13: 

I feel that I am being unfair with this rating being that Dominion was my "gateway" game. The first two strategy games I played were Carcassonne and Dominion, and out of the two, Dominion was far and way the more compelling game. That said, the excitement wore off quite fast. I will play this game if someone requests it, but I don't think I will request it myself, not with all the better games available. In fact, after multiple plays of each, I think I prefer Carcassonne (with the expansions of course).

Update 3/3/14:

I still really like this game. I added two new promo cards to try and rejuvenate it a bit. I think it helped some, but I still get burnt out on this one fast. What really bothers me is the last couple of turns, when the game is on the line, there is just too much randomness. You might draw 11 money, or you might come up empty. When you lose, it leaves you feeling cold. When you win, it leaves you feeling very fortunate.

RATING: 6

Edit 04/19/14: Dominion is overrated, and it is only the expansions which redeem this. The base game is a solid 'meh' for me.

RATING: 4
2 / 5 - Fair.

Final verdict time. This is yet another low-interaction optimization/efficiency game. It's novel, short and manages to squeeze an awful lot of game play out of some very simple rules which makes it either ideal filler for efficiency gamers, or an efficiency game for the rest of us. But it's still the same old maximise-the-efficiency-engine sort of game that's become so tediously familiar over the last few years. It'd probably be worth another point of rating played with 4 - there is a *bit* more interaction and the extra downtime gives you space in which to shuffle properly! Theme is wafer thin. After ten plays or so, I just feel ... meh. See my review for more details: http://fortressat.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=821&Itemid=318
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Even when drunk this game is fun. Played it a few times before going out and everyone's had a blast.

RATING: 7.01
I'm terrible at this game.

Despite its four pages of rules and weight rating it is far deeper than a number of games with 40+ pages of rules and vastly higher weights.

This will eventually fall into the category of something that I tip my hat at the design aspect, but the abstract nature of the game and the endlessly shifting strategies for it makes me wonder if it will ever be actually fun. I feel like I'm grasping at straws playing, ie "so wait, how many Woodcutters am I suppose to grab?"

Deck building doesn't really cure the issue of a bad draw. It merely evens out the starting point and levels the playing field in terms of what players can add to their deck. Neither does being required to discard your whole hand in order to draw up to your max hand size every turn. Maybe I actually wanted to keep a card that I wasn't able to play and now I have to wait for it to come back up again and hopefully at the right time.

Ratings potential: 7. This seems fairly set for now.

Update after 13 plays: And it is dead. Murdered not by one game, but a host of others. This is one granddaddy of a genre that didn't hold up as others came out after it. I respect the hell out of the design, but this is merely an exercise in a mechanic. A great mechanic, but other games can offer that and add to it. Might be salvageable with certain expansion combos, but that it's it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

After only two plays (with the recommended 'starting play' action cards) I'm ready to start branching out.  Pretty neat game and looking forward to playing with more people.

RATING: 6
Played 2-player game a couple times, the first two suggested games.  I'm trying to be open minded, but I don't see what the fuss is about.  It's a rush to get the province cards and that's about all.  Both times I couldn't wait for it to be over because it was getting old waiting to get 8 points so I could buy the last province card; I didn't want any more action cards because they weren't very helpful.  I like the idea though of the ever-growing deck of cards, but it didn't make it better than a repetitive exercise of playing cards that seemed largely similar to one another.  I'll still try the other setups, but what am I missing here?  Is it better with more players?  I kept looking at the action cards and thinking 'why would I want this' (e.g., chapel)?  I simply don't see why people like this game so much.

RATING: 10
Absolutely amazing game.  Very simple to teach yet it has very deep strategy.  The strategy discussions for this game remind me of many discussions from my TCG-playing days.  I love the fact that it is "collectible" but doesn't require busting open boosters or trading for singles.  I absolutely appreciate the amount of time and effort that is put into playtesting each card, which is why I love all the expansions.  This is one of my favorite board games of all time.  My only negative for this game is that the number of expansions makes this game very difficult to transport.

RATING: 6.5
Estimate about 50-100 games played, in person, on isotropic, and against Androdominion AI.

= My standard for judging deckbuilders.
+ Nostalgia for being my first deckbuilder.
+ Variety of card abilities and combos (with sufficient expansions)
- A bit lacking in player interaction. On the other hand whenever I play, I'm happier when I don't see attack cards in the set.
- Big Money strategy feels a bit too dominant.

Revised down from 8 to 6.5. These days, I'd usually rather play something else than Dominion. Main factor is the setup/teardown takes longer than I feel like tolerating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.3
Played this a few times online. Maybe it's not that representative as in playing face-to-face. It reminds me a lot of Puzzle Strike, but then another theme and a bit less interaction between players. Deckbuilding isn't my type of game: rating can go down or up, but I want to play this a few times more in 'real life' before I give my final rating.

I'd like to try out the different cards, etc. But you don't really have the time to do that (you'll be hopelessly behind in VPs), so it becomes (as in Puzzle Strike) building up credits/dollars/whatever buy-mechanism and buying the best chips/cards (VPs or cards that give you the fastest VPs)...

edit: played it with a friend: this is much better than the internet! It's a nice filler. I won't play it back to back: that makes it boring.

edit2: Dominion is not really my type of game. I have no fun in playing it. Everything you want to just 'try' (odd cards, combos, etc.) sets you up to loose... The only fun I have is the 'sitting around the table with friends' fun.

RATING: 8
A deck-building game where you start with the same cards and put together a machine that takes you to victory (or defeat).  All the cards are there for your purchase, but first you need to put together enough income generation to fund the exercise.  Once your deck is working smoothly, you should concentrate on getting VPs because (though these cards are useless for all other circumstances) that's the only thing that decides victory in the end.  A good game - very clever and quite innovative.

RATING: 8
A very neat card game which leaves you wanting more.  There has been a lot of hype for this game and it certainly doesn't disappoint.

Very few games over the past few years have left me wanting to play them back to back.  Dominion leaves you with that feeling.  Three games in and I haven't even come close to scratching the surface.  

All the talk about a million of combos is probably true, but I still wish more action cards would have been included in the base set.

I expect the expansions to cost a small fortune in comparison to the base game.  10 bucks for a single group of 10 identical cards is way too much in my opinion.

Probably the best feature of Dominion is trying to solve the puzzle in each game.  There isn't a lot of interaction unfortunately.  The second best feature is the lack of downtime.  The game plays fast even with a slow thinking bunch.

Dominion is fairly good when it last less than 90 minutes. at 2.3 hours it wears out its welcome.

RATING: 6.5
It really grates with me that, once a player's deck is expended, you then re-shuffle all the cards you've collected, including all the money you've already spent. Wait, what...? I get back the money I spent, having profited from spending it? And further, if I don't spend it, I still have to discard it. There is no incentive not to spend as much money as you can.

Other than this, it's a decent enough filler, but the illogical nature of spending cash really annoys me. I can't understand why it's so highly rated, though. I mean, as I said, it's decent, but it's not great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game that started the deck building style bonanza. 

Clever and intriguing card game where players start with identical decks used to purchase cards from common stocks to add to their own decks. Used and purchased card are placed in a personal discard pile which becomes the new draw pile when it is empty. Relatively quick games (30-60 minutes with four players), very low degree of player interaction (there are some cards which interacts with other players, but these are few and aren't very likely to be part of a game set-up), virtually a multi-player solitaire where each players tries to create an economic engine. Manages to be fun, stimulating and enthralling in spite of this. 

Update: decreased my score. After more plays the game simply isn't very fun. The card effects and themes seems arbitrarily combined, the mechanics isn't very interesting, too much time is spend shuffling cards, and you can play the game without really paying any attention at all to your co-players. Perhaps an intriguing mechanics but makes for a very dull social exchange and time. 

If you're looking for a game of the kind I much more recommend Quarriors!, which has a very similar but infinitely improved mechanics with some direct player interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very original and well designed game. Played dominon a lot a few years ago but lack of real interaction and expansions mostly full of variations of old cards has lowered my interest for the game.

RATING: 8
Fantastic card game. It was easy to explain, quick, fun, and rewarding to play.

The card draw over the first few hands can make or break a game depending on the available cards. This has greatly reduced my rating for now. I am considering a variant where each player chooses their cards for the first 2 hands to help alleviate this problem. This is a game breaker in a snowball type of game such as this when the cost of the "Good" cards is such that a bad first hand can put you multiple of the "good" cards behind.

RATING: 4
I've only ever played this on my computer. As a mindless game in the vein of whatever is your mobile "poison" of choice, this one is certainly better than most (dreck such as CandyCrush etc)! However, I'm not sure I'd ever want to play it in the physical realm... shuffling, people thinking, bah - this is not that kind of game for me - auto-shuffle, play treasures, follow whatever plan you wanted to try out this time, repeat... Win or lose, it's fine, time goes by, no frustration - only the slight "weeeee" as your malleable card-engine does what you want it to! For a physical game, Kingdom builder is my choice every time over this - the same puzzle type of game - only spatial and thus more fun for me.

Maybe expansions will change my opinion, add a bit more spice than just the base set, but meh, can't be bothered unless put in front of me by someone (at which point sure, I'd play).

A fine game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Each player attempts to snowball their own small deck of cards into a bigger one that contains the highest total victory points.

Played as: 2,3,4 player

Played with: Base game alone and mixed with Intrigue.

Pros: The rules seem pretty simple to grasp for any type of person and shouldn't take much more than five minutes to explain. I like the fast pace of the game; it seems you're always doing something whether is playing your turn, analyzing your next moves or simply shuffling in between. It all flows so well. There's a great sense of satisfaction in watching your deck grow as the game progresses. And finally, the box insert is simply the best ever.

Cons: With so many different ways to mix the decks, it's inevitable you'll have some dud games. And sure you have a selection of 10 different Action cards to choose from but it seems to me at this point you'll likely pick 3 or so to build your deck with and largely ignore the rest. With two-players, the game seems to end anti-climatically since you know how many victory cards your opponent has bought and at a certain point the results seem inevitable. All the shuffling you'll be doing is going to require card-sleeves if you want it to last.

Other: I wouldn't play this game with two unless I specifically want to have a Dominion fix and that's all the players I have available. There's just better two player experiences out there (Carc, San Juan, etc).

Best Use: An easy to grasp, high-variety card game for 3-4 people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
My penchant for all types of villages and accumulating as many actions as possible has driven by wife and the others that I play with a little batty.  Card combinations and strategy were easy to pick up on given my teenage years playing Magic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A simple, yet fun and challenging game. There is some luck with your card shuffles, however it really isn't a significant factor. I like that there really isn't a dominant strategy and one can for the most part counter another's strategy pretty effectively. Adding expansions is the way to go though because they add so many different options and variations to gameplay.

EDIT: Game's rating is a 10 instead of a 9. With the amount of variability in strategies and how light, simple, and good the game is, I feel it deserves the rating considering my non-gamer friends enjoy it (as do I a lot).

RATING: 8
I finally got a chance to play this and really like the mechanics and the way the game flows. While I had my butt handed to me, I enjoyed the interaction, the limited downtime (due to fairly fast rounds and some interactive cards) and the surprisingly intricate strategy. It is not a heavy game by any means, and you don't need to know all about the cards to play effectively. Family liked this much more than I thought they would.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating for: Base with Seaside, Adventures, Prosperity, Intrigue

Genius mechanics. Great replayability. The expansions add each interesting mechanics each. Very elegant design: Price and effect of cards just feel so balanced. The scoring mechanic is genius: Buy points, but they clutter up your deck - this already made me lose before by choosing the wrong moment to buy points. Wins are so statisfying. Prefer it with 2 or 3. Sometimes feels to solitaire, although during the game you wouldn't notice as you are always busy to think about what to buy or play next.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Night one.  "Want to play Dominion?"  "Of course, this is a really fun game."  Night two.  "Want to play Dominion?"  "Absolutely."  Night three.  "Want to play Dominion?"  "Maybe we could play something else."  "You don't like Dominion, do you?"  We've all been there.  You really like a game, but your game gaming companion likes it even more and doesn't want to play anything else.  They end up feeling hurt and betrayed if you say no and decide you must never want to play the game again.  It is a testament though to just how addictive Dominion is.  The cards have so much variety, with a never ending supply of highly rated expansions.  I enjoy exploring the different cards, because they all seem to offer an advantage if you experiment enough.  The first time I discovered trashing all your cards once you have enough gold, the game was over in a flash and was a landslide.  Try this again though and your competitor may thief you into an obsolescent hand and inescapable poverty.  Changing the cards you use completely changes the nature of the game.  Some of the hands are downright vicious.  Others give you so many victory points you feel like you are in the top 2% of the wealthiest Americans.  Another benefit is that this game is very accessible to non-gamers.  Highly recommended for your slightly less dorky friends.

Update:  Moved back into top 10 with a little help from the under one hour game bump.  That is all we play now!

RATING: 8
This is our first "boardgame" played with cards. In the beginning we played it several times a day. We never say no to a match, but we seldom choose it ourselves but every time we do we have to play several matches. Dominion is still our most well played game in our gaming evenings. We have played it with 8 persons (even if we think it is best with 3) and had a blast, even though we needed cards from an expansion.

We own every expansion and promo cards that have appeared in finnish thus far. We like this game but it gets boring if you don't get expansions. Basic game has only so much variety so expansion adds to it quite a bit. No game is the same when the action cards change. 

Every table needs to be well thought out before it is played because strategy changes with the table. Experienced gamer sees immidiately how to play to win as his experience with cards and how they interact in the game gives him the advantage in seeing how the game behaves. Sometimes the game is all about money, other times you need to keep on acguiring those action cards. 

When we first got this game, we would have given it 9,5 but we have played it for so long and it's getting boring. It is an easy game to be taught to beginners and old timers still feel the fun in this game.

We have played this with several people and only one hasn't liked it but she doesn't like any other game then Alias...

RATING: 7
[i]Includes Dominion Intrigue beginning with play #17.[/i]

[u]12-Jan-2013[/u]:  I like this game quite a bit and both of my daughters do as well.  Everyone starts with the same set of ten cards and through the course of the game builds a larger/stronger deck of cards with various actions/abilities with which to gain the ever popular victory points.  Most points wins.

It's easy to teach and play.  Play time is relatively short: 20 to 40 minutes depending on the number of players and how familiar everyone is with the game.  The variability is fantastic.  The game comes with 25 sets of main cards of which you use only 10 per game.  Familiarizing yourself with each individual card is the "hardest" part of the game.  And there are numerous expansion all adding variety and additional combinations of cards.

There are some aspects that may or may not be good depending on your perspective.  When using the base set alone, there is very little player interactivity.  Only two or three cards directly affect the other player(s).  Other expansions (see Dominion Intrigue below) offer more of this.  And the theme is fairly non-existent; it's mostly a numbers game, but not mathy.

With its low complexity, quick play time, and seemingly infinite (especially with expansions) variety, this is an easy choice to pick up and enjoy.

[u]24-01-2014[/u]:  This is another game that hasn't been hitting the table in recent months.  My daughter and I still really like it, but my collection just has too many options these days, I suppose.  I still think it's a very good game that really pioneered the deckbuilding genre.  Very light on theme but smooth playing and lots of variability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Thought about adding the base game to my collection to play with my family, but I feel the money would be better spent elsewhere.

Changed my rating to reflect my lack of enthusiasm for the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Was afraid this would be another Race to the Galaxy type game but instead I found something quite unique.  It's a deck-building game and it's quite fun.  I'm not a fan of traditional CCG deck-building but here it happens real time.  You're playing cards from your hand which give you actions, etc. then buying new cards which go to your discard pile.  When your turn is over any cards played or unplayed (from you hand) go to the discard pile.  The pile is then shuffled when your deck runs out.  Note: lots of shuffling!  

The most important decision of the game is when to stop building your engine and use it to start collecting VPs.  Often this may be decided by another player who starts the VP grab but timing is important since VP cards go into your deck too and gum-up your hand.  

There are a number of "kingdom" decks that can be used (10 of 25 used in a game) and I was pleasantly surprised how different the game felt with the various combinations that I've tried.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game isn't very complicated, but it's a blast and has a very high replay value with just the base set. Expansions increase the replay value ten fold.

*************** Update July 2010

Thunderstone probably has Dominion beat in fun factor terms, but Dominion is still a decent game.  I think I have about played this out, but will revisit from time-to-time. RATING: 10
[b]First play:[/b] Oh yeah. Very compelling; I wish I could have played six or seven more times. Very quick for an "engine" game, so there's that adjustment to be made. And there's weird tactics like throwing victory points in the trash that you don't see anywhere else. But more than that, the quickness ensures that there is not one over-arching strategy, that you really do have to adapt to the particular cards in play. This in turn entails a steeper learning curve. I'm in. [But I like Race better.]


...a year later, in which I've spent a large fraction of my gaming time playing Dominion, (and learned essentially nothing) I'm raising my rating to 10. I really feel sorry for folks who feel that they can only give one game a 10 - I think Dominion is great; if I like Race better, that doesn't change anything. Of course, the game is broken, as there is a killer strategy: don't make suboptimal moves! Oh, that's genius! Why didn't I think of that?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is bar-none an absolute classic. What I look for in a 10 game is one that I can see myself in 10, 15, 20 years breaking out and playing with my future kids. This is a game that scratches that CCG itch that I have had for years and also is incredibly diverse and easy to pick up for new players. The game plays great with 2 and scales great up to 6 (with expansion). The card drafting renaissance owes it's relevance to Dominion. Great idea. Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great fast paced game.  I normally don't like the amount of luck in card games, so when I saw the components for this was 500 cards I was put off.  Needless to say, it took me a while to finally buy it.  I really enjoyed my first play through, and after my second I was hooked.

The game starts everybody off with 10 cards, 7 treasure cards, called copper, and 3 victory point cards, called estates.  You are trying to build up your kingdom to be the winner.  You have 25 different kingdom cards, or action cards, to choose from.  Of those 25 each game will use 10.  There are a few defined sets in the rules, the first one being a beginners set that introduces you to most of the types of cards, or you can pick your favorite 10, or you can randomly pick the 10 to use, or any other mechanism you want to choose the 10 kingdom cards to play with.  You then start using your money to buy cards, hopefully you are buying cards that make your deck stronger.  The actions will help you play more actions(so you can chain actions), draw more cards, have extra money to spend, attack other players, etc.  The ultimate goal is to get a deck good enough so you can buy the big victory point cards, called provinces.  When the provinces run out, or any other 3 stacks of cards, the game ends and you count up your points.

I really enjoyed this when I first got it.  We were playing a lot though, so I kind of got burned out.  I still love to play it, but I'm not playing 5+ games a day now like I was at first.  I gave this an 8 because I think I'll be able to pick this game up about any time and play it, plus it is easy to teach, and gamers and non-gamers a like enjoy playing this.  At work on our lunch break we can easily get in 3 games and a lot of times we play 4 in the hour.  This is a classic and I can't wait for the first expansion, Intrigue.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::star::star: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::star: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 3-4

RATING: 9
Rating applies to my Dominion collection (everything but Alchemy).  

Card flow is fun.  Down time is minimal.  Thinkiness is medium-light.  Enough to think, but not so much that I'd ever feel too mentally tired to play.

Really, it's the card flow that mostly does it for me.  But of the deck building style games I've played, this feels far more polished than the others.  It can bog down with slow games, but also bogs down less than the others I've played.

This game is nearly perfect.  This is the nit-picky part where I talk about what could be changed to push this game from great to absolutely fantastically super amazing awesomeness.  It's missing interaction, and interesting decisions.  

Interaction is partially accomplished by attack and reaction cards; but more so by the race for VP feel.  It could use more interesting reactions on other peoples turns.  

There's a fair amount of decision making in the buy phase, though maybe more ways to attain victory would spice this up.  Where interesting decisions is typically lacking is the action phase.  Most of the time, there's really only one obvious best way to play your cards.  However, each expansion improved upon this, giving you multiple different choices to make, and positive rewards for building variety into your deck.  

One amazing thing about Dominion is how easy it is to add your own fan content to the game to steer in more in the direction of what makes the experience fun for you.

Dominion-Vanilla (base game) = good
Dominion-Intrigue = good
Dominion-Seaside = AMAZING!
Dominion-Prosperity = Great
Dominion-Alchemy = Overall bad (but with 1 great card)
Dominion-Cornocopia = Great
Dominion-Hinterlands = Great
Dominion-Dark Ages = Great
Dominion-Adventures = AMAZING!!

At first I liked Prosperity most, and we always played with Colony/Platinum.  But after playing more and more games, I am on the fence as to if the game is better for high level play with or without them.  I used to thing they were hands down better, but honestly they are not. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A truly innovative and inspiring game. Many people thank Dominion for its contribution but have since replaced it with his progeny. I still think it's the best. The focus is on the engine, the perfect deck, not theme or chance or tactics or monsters. The expansions offer near-infinite permutations of kingdom cards, both supplying replayability and forcing players to develop new strategies on the fly for each combination. Perhaps not everyone needs to own it, but everyone should play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dominion is a deck-building game. Players start out with an identical set of 10 cards, and draw 5 of them. They then can buy a series of Kingdom Cards (10 types per game), Currency (Copper, Silver and Gold) and finally Victory Cards (Estate, Duchy and Province). They then take turns buying, shuffling, buying, shuffling, and so on. 

Who knew a game sounding so monotonous could be so fun, but it is! What makes it fun is as the game progresses, the players begin to have more and more distinct decks. Soon you'll have cards that play (or combo) off of other cards and one turn you'll end up playing 7+ cards, often gaining multiple kingdom cards or money, or if lucky the treasured Province cards.

I recommend this game to even the most unseasoned board game player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
You won't see another game in my "Previously Owned" section with half as many plays as this sacred cow of BGG, and it even surprised me a little that I was able to cull it from my collection.  I think many games do owe this a debt of gratitude, because deckbuilding (whether it be cards, dice, or whatever) has become a favorite mechanic of many a designer.  What I realized was that I enjoyed it as one of [i]several[/i] aspects to a game, rather than the featured performer.  So off this went.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
I like this game because it is relatively short and has very simple turns (players draw five cards, get one action, and one purchase) yet still manages to be a fairly complicated strategic/tactical game.  Players all start the game with identical hands, drawing five cards from their draw pile at the start of each turn.  On each turn players choose which cards they want to buy; bought cards get added to their discard pile, which quickly gets reshuffled into their draw pile.  Thus, players get to build their own custom decks, and then use them (and continue adding cards to them) in the same game over and over.  I love the idea!

The game is customizable by having different sets of cards that can be bought; the different sets of cards drastically change the feel of the game.  I didn't like the interactive set, though, as the one game I played of that slowed to a crawl.

There is definitely an element of luck to the game, though, as especially near the end of the game the order a player's cards are drawn in will dictate what they can do.  But given the speed with which the game goes by in, that's OK.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Draft and play cards to improve your deck and collect victory cards for most points.

Plays: More than 500, counting online play against humans and AI.
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Light.
# of players: 2-4.
Playing time: 45 mins.
Player interaction: Competition for scarce resources – action and victory cards. Sometimes conflict, which always affects all opponents equally.
Randomness: Low – card draw, but you decide what cards make up your deck.

Replayability: Very high. Often everyone wants to play again immediately. There are millions of variations because the design is modular, so no game is exactly the same. There is also depth to explore.
Fun: High. Making high value hands is fun. Drawing your entire deck with action cards is even more fun. The endless shuffling is not so fun.
Memorability: High, you’ll remember the wicked combo that you managed to get off that one time to buy three Provinces and a Duchy. You’ll start remembering the less spectacular ones as well after a while, hoping for your pet cards to appear in the Kingdom next time.

Thematic integration: Strained.
Components: Not so good unfortunately. Cards are good quality, but the art is bland.
Expansions: Expansions in order of increasing complexity/fiddlyness: Hinterlands, Cornucopia, Seaside, Prosperity, Dark Ages, Alchemy. Get Hinterlands first.

Who will like this: Family gamers that want to do a bit more thinking.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A game that almost everyone in my groups loves but I abhor. It's themeless, dry work putting together the best part of most CCGs (engine building) and then never getting to turn the key to see how it runs. Most later deck-builders do it far better, in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I would consider Dominion to be another 'Gateway Game'. While it serves as a great gateway to the hobby itself, it also stands as a gateway to deckbuilders, a genre of boardgames.

Deckbuilders allow players to gain cards from communal sources, adding these new cards to their own personal deck of cards. You are effectively building your own deck. 

Dominion is immensely replayable, as a result of its almost endless combinations of cards. 

I wish there were a little more player interaction, but it's otherwise an interesting game with a wide variety of options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Less than impressed at first, [i]Dominion[/i] grew on me significantly as I played more and more games (mostly two-player). It definitely has that "let's play another" quality; it's not unusual for us to play five or six times in a row. The Action-Attack cards make the game more fun, whether or not there's a blue defensive card in play. Favorite kingdom cards from the base game: Adventurer, Bureaucrat, Chapel, Militia, Mine, Moneylender, Throne Room, Witch. [154 total plays, including many using expansion cards from [i]Intrigue, Seaside, Prosperity,[/i] and promos (own all but [i]Seaside[/i])]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An interesting game with some quirky card buy mechanics. The real strength, however, seems to come in figuring out how to build one's deck so that during one's turn, a chain-reaction of card playing is triggered. I think at one point during my first game, I played through every single card in my deck, and had somewhere around 20+ in money for card buys.

Ok. After 30 plays, the majority of which are IRL (since I get annoyed by the LACK of interaction, tabletalk, and metagaming on BSW) I have to admit I am fully and completely hooked. This is currently my preferred game and I am suggesting it above any other game - it fits the sweet spot - plays in under 30 minutes (and about half the time under fifteen), is strategic, there are plenty of difficult and interesting choices, and lots of chances to mess with others (indeed I am now at a point where I can specialize my decks specifically to mess with others and when done right, I can even still pull off a victory at the same time.)

Edit: a ratings bump after introducing it to my wife. "Hey, I actually really like this game. So there are more action cards we can play with? I totally would play this again!"

---------

This game is losing it's shine after 60+ plays. It feels rote. I have plumbed the depths of the various strategies presented by particular kingdom cards (and the combos they make available), and win about 90% of the games as a result. It's stopped being fun somewhere along the way, and I've definitely stopped thinking during game play - my choices are almost tacit.

I realize the expansion would probably infuse some new life into this situation, but why should I invest in such an expansion only for this to happen again.

It's still a good game, but it's lack of staying power keeps it from being a great game.

----------------------

Having now played the recent expansion I can say without reservation that this is essentially a ccg. As such it will only stay fresh with the expansions. Even then, I have not lost a game of it in three months because the best and fastest path to victory is always the same. It's a pity because the mechanics are genius. But in the end, I refuse to buy expansions. I REFUSE. And so the game, I suspect, will continue to fade.

-----------------------

Uh, ok. So both my mom and my dad like this. Seriously. And it wasn't me who first taught them how to play it - it was my brother-in-law (who I taught.) Go ye therefore and teach all men. Go figure.

-----------------------

Without continuing to buy expansion after expansion of this, it starts to feel really rote and uninteresting. It's basically Deck: The Shuffling.

RATING: 8
I like dominion, I genuinely do but we've found if you simply buy silver coins each round until it's starts popping up in your hand, then do the same with gold, then buy up province after province it's an easy win. The occasional thief card slows this down but it doesn't stop it. For me the option to buy game currency is a bit silly as it negates the use of a lot of the kingdom cards. A fun game let down by a very basic gaming mechanic. 

Upgraded half a point to an 8. In time after playing many other deck builders you realize just how influential Dominion is. Yes I still stand by my buy silver/gold/province claim (I avoid this tactic to make it fun) but the positives of this game far exceed the negatives. Simple, elegant (getting tired of 'fiddly' games now) and engaging from start to finish, Dominion has to be respected and admired.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After playing Dominion nearly 200 times, I was about ready to rate it a 4 (I really did have to be talked into it), but I left it at a 6 in honor of all the prior plays it had gotten. Games had gotten stale, pretty much a quick puzzle of picking one or two cards that would help get me to Gold (and then Provinces) the fastest, then waiting around while others fiddled with their decks, stringing together long chains of cards (that got increasingly insane with every expansion). I'd still win at least half the time. I really thought I was pretty much done with Dominion.

But here we are, a few years later, and I have rediscovered the game! Not only has Big Money weakened as more expansions came out, it's not even the optimal strategy on the very first game most people play. I threw down an additional 100 plays trying to build engines and work combos I'd never before considered. The game is newly challenging and even after 300 logged plays (see Intrigue), I still want more! Phenomenal.

As for the original set itself, many of these cards remain essential, if a little bland, with Chapel and Gardens probably being the most exciting. I've redistributed most of these cards into homebrew variants of the expansions, but a considerable chunk of these cards have been consigned to a special set ("Dominion: Purgatory") that will get played rarely. Even though all that averages out to ~7 in terms of my willingness to play these cards in the future, I can't deny the hours upon hours of enjoyment I've gotten from them in the past, so I'm going to leave my rating at an 8.

[i]Note: Between this and Alchemy, I've logged an even 200 plays. Hereafter, I'm recording all further plays under Intrigue. Peace out.[/i]

RATING: N/A
2013
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
From incidental comments, I expected this to be like Race for the Galaxy, but upon finally trying it, it's not. They're both card games, where each player works on an individual tableau, but if anything, Dominion's CCG-style deck building makes a lot more like a version of Saint Petersburg where only 5 of your cards are active at a time.

You use (not really spend) your money/income cards to buy new action, money, or VP cards which get shuffled into your deck. Since the cards only come up 5 at a time, it's more important that your collection of cards be efficient than large. The other interesting tradeoff is that VP cards take up space in your deck, stealing valuable hand space from income and actions if too many are acquired too early.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The game to end all games.  Dominion started the entire Deckbuilding Genre as far as I'm concerned, and it's still one of the Top3.

I've played a lot of dominion.  Alot.  I have it on my phone.  It's a great game for getting people into the hobby.  But Dominion has a flaw.

There is almost NO player interaction. None.  Each player does their own thing, building little Utopian worlds, while ignoring the other players.  Even the attacks- where the interaction should be don't really give meaningful choices.  It took me a long time to come to this conclusion... I'd say 20 game hours, at least, probably more.  But for me, unless I'm Gateway drugging people into board gaming, I probably won't play dominion of my own volition ever again.  I feel like everyone involved just plays solitaire for 10-20 minutes and then reports who won quickest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very fast play and easy to learn. I could see it getting dull after one or two plays in an evening. Very good as an intro game though because of the simple strategies and quick gameplay.

RATING: 8
Overall, I enjoy the base Dominion game.  The games go relatively quickly, it's easy enough for non-gamers to pick up, and there's enough strategic depth there to keep me interested.

My only knock against the game is that while the first 3/4 of each game -- the engine-building/optimizing part -- was always great fun, after not too many plays the end game province rush started to feel stale.  There just weren't many decisions to make at that point: if treasure > 8, buy province; if treasure > 5, buy duchy.  Prosperity fixed this for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The classic deck builder that started this genre of games and as such deserves to be as iconic as Magic: The Gathering.

Essentially players are trying to win as many VPs as they can but to reach the higher valued VP (Province) cards they will need to build there deck with higher valued gold cards and acquire other cards from the many on offer to make use of special actions and powers.

What sets Dominion apart is the variety of cards available in the game and each expansion. 

Not all card sets are used with each play so the game offer loads of re-playability and the fun is really in exploring the card sets and finding the combos.

Easy to learn, pretty thematic neutral and tends to appeal to both genders where other like titles such as Ascension and Thunderstone may not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very fun game if you dont play other collectable card game such as Magic the Gather, World of Warcraft TCG, Yugioh etc. Otherwise, this game becomes very repeatitive as experienced players know which cards to get right from the setup.. eventually it will turn into a battle to see who can get the most of those 1 or 2 piles of cards. Only recommend for people that wants a refresher on card games, but if you already are playing a TCG game.. give this one a pass.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You can custumize this game according to your preferences. It can be from very simple to quite complex. You can choose a completele random setup using all the expansions, or carefully choose the expansions and additional rules that you prefer. 
The more I play this game the more I appreciate its beuty.

RATING: 9.7
Ordered October 31st, 2008

Now that I've played this game 30+ times, I just can't get enough of it.  This game will give Race to the Galaxy a run for it's money, as it seems now the board game world is having a run of card games (i.e RttG, Dominion, Keltis)  This game is not to be compared with RttG, as it's a totally different game.  This reminds me more of St. Petersburg than anything, but with a higher replay factor.
The 25 different cards are what give this game a new experience every time.  One game you could score 49 points, the next -6.  This game is hot and is only going to continue to rise.  I see it being a top 10 in a few months time.
My fan favorite has to be the witch.  I love dealing out curses, (or in German Fluch).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm usually not a friend of deck building games, since they often boil down to who knows the different cards and combinations best. However, Dominion was a pleasant surprise for several reasons:

1. The card types used in every game are limited and known to all players.
2. The card effects are simple and clearly written.
3. The turns are quick and the games are short.
4. Yoy can play both tactically (how do I play my current hand best) and strategically (how should I build my deck to get the hand I want).
5. You do get "big" moments as you play out powerful combinations.

The less good things are still acceptable.

1. Non-existent theme, (Oh, we were playing Kings?)
2. A lot of shuffling (but between turns).
3. Enough cards for all players, limiting interaction limited to occasional card stealing.

A good filler game but nothing I would devote an entire game evening to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
主題:1
我的第一款桌遊!好玩的建立牌庫遊戲!建立自已的王國用的是手牌建構，而非一般地圖擺放圖版的方式來建立王國，令人耳目一新，分數卡、計策卡、金幣卡的設置，很有用謀略建立王國的策士精神，卡牌套用建設國家的主題恰如其分。例如行動卡就好像是執政者利用各式各樣的人士參與決策或工作，或進行重大公共設施或政策的推行。金幣簡單說就是國家的經濟力，國家經濟力越強越有能力推行重大建設或聘請有力人士。最後國家的整體實力，就是遊戲過程中購買外匯(分數卡)的表現。

美術:0.7
以卡牌遊戲還說，畫風雖稱不上精美，但還算符合遊戲風格，圖片只是陪襯。但各種行動牌的美工倒是能恰如其分展現行動卡的主題!

規則:1
規則完美，好教學，新手很快就很上手，只要告訴他三種不同種類的牌的功能，了解加錢、加行動的規則，很快就學會!是個好教學的輕中度策略遊戲!

設置:0.6
選牌庫，洗牌，收牌都會造成一些玩家的困擾，不過玩久就還能適應了，現在收牌整理速度超快的!

路線:1 
有不的打法，金錢流、抽牌流、搶分流...等等!因應桌面10份牌庫的變化做出不同的反應!暨考驗組牌策略!也考驗抽牌運氣!但基本上還是策略大於運氣，尤其是跟很愛計算的人對抗!真的讓人覺得有策略上對決的快感，又偶有運氣上的無奈!

互動:0.9 
搶牌，搶分，玩到互動強烈的牌組!真的是互相丟炸彈!但也有只能悶著頭自言自語玩牌的牌組!那就乾到不行!不過因為牌庫量的變化!每一場比賽都有不同的體驗!"原來這張牌要這樣用!"

個人:1     
超愛!我桌遊中開最多次的遊戲!

朋友:0.9    
朋友大多喜歡打!但還是有人沒被這款收服!

想玩:1      
只要時間夠!自己也會跟自己單挑!玩單人桌遊!

收藏:1      
好玩!必收! 中文版全收齊

總分:9.1

講評:
利用不同擴充來增加牌庫的變化性!真的每場打起來的感覺都不同!是個玩好幾百場也不會膩的好遊戲!缺點就是要收很多套擴充!大概就是這遊戲最大的缺點!

RATING: 8
A wonderful game, open to infinite combinations of starting cards and striking a wonderful balance of luck and skill, allowing a decent player to tip the odds in their favour while still being susceptible to the vicissitudes of fate.  Quick play is a bonus, and, with this quality, it has racked up many plays in our house.

Expanded in 2013 to include Prosperity gives the game much more scope than the slightly restricted base set.  Bigger money and more varied powers along with Colonies alter the balance of the game, and the random setup makes for a different feel each time.

Expanded in 2014 to include Intrigue.

RATING: 7.5
Dominion a vraiment réussi à devenir un incontournable des jeux que nous possédons. La rejouabilité est à la fois pratiquement illimitée et beaucoup moins dispendieuse que d'autres types de jeux "deck building" tel, bien sûr, Magic.

Longue vie à Dominion et à ses expansions!

2014-04 EDIT: L'envie d'y jouer s'est estompée depuis plus d'un an, et ma note initiale (8.2) a été revue à la baisse: 7,7 en décembre 2013, puis 7,5.

2015-06 EDIT: Beaucoup de parties jouées depuis décembre 2014, ce qui vient contredire le précédent "edit". Ayant revu plusieurs de mes ratings à la baisse, je donnerais un gros 8,5 à Dominion pour l'importance que ce jeu a pris (et continue de prendre) dans l'univers des jeux - particulièrement des decks building. 

Toutefois, il est clair à mes yeux que le seul jeu de base n'est pas suffisant pour rester un très bon jeu après quelques parties. La rejouabilité de Dominion Base est questionnable, tant Big Money a de l'importance et tant plusieurs setup donnent des parties assez drabes. On dirait que la grande majorité des parties doivent passer par quelques incontournables (Chapel, Smithy, Laboratory, Witch) et qu'un trop grand nombre de Kingdom Card ne sont pas clairement supérieures à Silver dans de nombreuses situations - d'ailleurs plusieurs cartes ont été "améliorées" dans d'autres expansions.

En fait, je conseillerais à un joueur désireux de se lancer dans l'acquisition de Dominion d'acquérir dès le départ deux expansions (Intrigue puis au choix Hinterlands, Seaside, Prosperity, Alchemy, Guilds ou Cornucopia - mais peut-être pas Dark Ages ou Adventures dès le départ). Et s'il me posait la question: "Et Dominion Base?", je ne suis pas certain de ce que je lui réponderais. 

J'attribue donc 7,75 à Dominion Base (contrairement à 8 pour la plupart des autres expansions).

2016-12 EDIT: Si l'intérêt général pour Dominion connait des hauts et quelques bas, je constate que même lorsque j'ai envie d'y jouer, je n'ai pas envie de sortir la boite de base. 7,75 -->7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The deck builder that started them all.  Innovative mechanics, lovely art, very abstract theme (possibly too abstract), and unfortunately has now been eclipsed by many other deck builders that came later.

Still a wicked, strategic filler game, and looks good to boot.

UPDATE 01/02/14

Sam properly kicked my arse at this.
I’ve still got tons of respect for it as the daddy of Deck Building Games.  But it feels like most other DBGs have improved dramatically on the design since.  This feeling might be mitigated with expansions, but why bother doing that when you can build on better DBGs already instead?  And there are so many Dominion expansions I’m not sure I’d know, or care, where to start.

That said, it’s a good, fast playing game, with occasional minor confrontation thrown in with certain cards in the random set up, like Militias and Thieves.  Again I like the card art in this game, which I’m a sucker for, though the box art is bafflingly rubbish – seems like a missed opportunity there, but certainly didn’t hurt its sales figures!  I don’t really get the feeling of building my city, but then I don’t really get much thematic satisfaction from deck builders, because everything you build or develop quickly disappears into your big stack of cards.  I think Mage Knight (or even Pathfinder) handles this deck building implementation more ‘thematically’ by making it a set of spells, items and actions you have available, instead of buildings or people that occasionally pop up, depending on what hand you’re dealt.

I’m developing this deck building mechanic as one element for my horror game Blackmoor, where your deck is a set of emotions your hero has.  Playing emotions drives the actions available to you, and as you explore the game, your more placid emotions are gradually replaced with more extreme anxieties, fears and rages, as your hero starts to gradually lose it from the events he’s witnessing.  So, for example, if you see flitting shadows in a darkened room you might get an anxiety card, but if you see a massive rearing tentacled beastie you get a terror card.  An anxiety card might help you to run away from something, but a terror card is less likely to help you, it might even drive you to do something crazy to get rid of it, like murdering an ally or stranger.  And of course if you don’t get rid of that terror card, and it’s still in your deck come the endgame, well, then really bad things are going to happen to you...  Since deck-building decks are constantly in flux I think mechanically it fits nicely with how a person’s emotions are constantly in flux, whereas more fixed game elements, like items or people will stay out in play independently of the deck building aspect of the game.

Anyway, rambling aside, Dominion am good, but not as fun as the other DBGs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The founding father of all deckbuilders. A study in mechanics above all, as the theme is essentially irrelevant and the player interaction minimal without some specific card sets (witch, etc.) Largely irrelevant at this point as many other titles have extirpated the mechanics and applied them to more sophisticated & thematically sound games. But I guess you can't get more pure deckbuilding than Dominion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this card game, one starts with a 10 card deck, consisting of seven copper cards and three 1VP cards. You always deal out five cards, perform actions, buy new cards, discard and draw five new cards. In the middle of the table are 10 different cards, with a quantity of 10, which you can buy. The game has 25 of these cards, and every game, 10 of these are in play. These cards are the heart of the game, which gives you bonuses in buying, getting more actions, etc. Also available for purchase are more copper, silver, gold,  1 VP cards, 3 VP cards and 6 VP cards. The game ends when the 6 VP cards are exhausted, or any other three stacks are depleted. 

This is a good card game with a lot of variety. There are many possibilities, different games, and they all clock in very fast.  It's also a lot of fun, though after repeated playings, it has lost a bit of the shine, though. I really enjoyed it initially, and liked the game design, but there needs to be a way to equalize player order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's good, but not great. Overhyped.
