=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominion is one of the best card games on the market. It is one of the very rare games that accomplishes simplicity of gameplay yet has some deep strategy. Games are quick, teaching new players is easy as icons and texts are very intuitive. Simply, Dominion is a deck building game. Ten variable ‘kingdom’ cards are placed out on the table, of which players use treasure cards to buy them, in order to build a deck to most effectively reach the high end victory point cards. As those ten kingdom cards change each game, there is lots of replay value and based on the theme of the cards added the game can change quite dramatically (which is where the expansions come in and shine!). 

A very fun game, being a favourite for many. Easy to learn but hard to master!

Some post thoughts:
-Would be good to see some curse markers opposed to cards. Too many curse cards in the deck ruin the fun factor of the game and make it much longer than necessary. Thus I tend to avoid curse driven games, which limits card choices.
-Some treasure cards with reactions on them, i.e. bribe the Militia? Current reaction cards could be better / useful other than the reaction component. Once again, attack cards can be annoying when you have played 500+ games. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I dislike the shuffling or dryness. I think the replayability will slow down considerably around 20 or so games with the base game, and I think I dislike how little interaction there is without attack cards.

I do however like how the deckbuilding represents an investment over time in your kingdom, how balanced the game is and how many different strategies work. I wish it came as chits and with more variation of cards though.

Plays: 10+

Replayed after a long break and liked the speed, simplicity, huge variety with expansion cards and sifferent strategies and openness to beginners. Still despise shuffling though. Its a good game otherwise though.

I think if this game came with the best two or three expansions, Id love to buy it.

Played more times and all the expansions up to Dark Ages almost minus ine or two. The strength of the game is definitely the variety and purity of the game and its expansions.its very costly and time consuming to sleeve so you can shuffle more easily but enjoyabke. Plays pretty quick and no major issues either once you getpast replay. I think I may one day get the full set, maybe, depending on how my tastes evolve. Its still just good though and not truly great imo...

EDIT: Okay, I've played the app a lot with the various expansions and REALLY like the addictiveness and variety. I think it NEEDS expansions but with them, its probably a great game that has super high replaybility and variability. Its so pure but almost always plays within an hour while being a classic deckbuilder with lots of interesting decision points, despite the lack of player interaction/attention to others. The only issue is needing SO MANY expansions since the base game itself is only decent-good ish.

RATING: 7
Too slow for what it is - a fairly luck-driven card game. I do like the deck-building aspect, moreso than MtG - and I certainly appreciate that there's not hundreds of different cards with variable powers and possible combinations to learn and remember thus alleviating the thing I disliked with Magic that you needed to dedicate yourself immensly to the game if you at all wanted to compete. Dominion is a good game, and certainly a good gateway game - yet it falls short of a great card game - there's not enough control to be a great strategy game and not enough luck to be a great push your luck card game.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
The deck building game that started it all.  The base game has great components, nice artwork and a good instruction book.  The starting kingdom card suggestions work well to get games going. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I played this yesterday with 4 players, and it really puts Ascension (the only other deckbuilder I've played) to shame. 

Having to decide when to buy victory points cards, and determining what combination of cards you need in order to build an efficient engine of cards is really nice. I like that this game doesn't give you points for actions cards like Ascension does, it makes the decision between additional actions or victory points cards somewhat difficult.

I also like the fact that the action cards remain the same throughout the entire game, again, emphasizing the fact that you need to determine what cards are best for building a good engine.

RATING: 7
I like this game as it has an almost therapeutic feel. I think it is best played with 3 players but works well with 2 or 4 as well.

I love analyzing the 10 sets of cards at the start of the game and then trying to see what combinations will be fun to use.

Your long term strategies always have to adapt if you are playing with good players as they will take advantage of the weaknesses in your deck.

This is one of the staples in my collection since I have gotten so many plays out of this and have successfully introduced it to so many people.

RATING: 7
I got a feel this game can be as addictive as Race for the Galaxy but with less variety.  It doesn't feel like any other game though, a slight comparison perhaps to some mechanics of A Game of Thrones CCG but overall it is in its own category.  Quick gameplay and the possibility of huge combos.  Very interesting mechanics, shame it only serves 2-4 people but for a game this fast that's not necessarily a bad thing.

Update 1:  The goal of the game is to make the most "broken" card combo, so the theme is irrelevant.  I much prefer other deckbuilders but to each their own.  However, Dominion is to be respected as the one that started the whole deckbuilding frenzy.

Although I enjoy it, I'm never too sure how much I like it.  It's main strengths, in my opinion, are its lightness, it's ease to teach, and the speed in which it can be played.  Has more of a feel of strategy than actual strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of only three games in my collection that deserves the perfect '10'!

In one fell swoop, Dominion created a new genre of games and threw CCGs out the window. Impressive!

The game comes with 25 sets of cards, and you use 10 each time you play. The variation is basically endless, you'll never play the same game twice! From these 10 sets, you build you deck as you play, trying to score more Victory Points than the other players.
The cards might be a tad simplistic, but it is the base game after all. However, I don't think I've ever had this much fun with only the base game with any other game before!

Ok, I'm playing this one all the time, so:
Increased the score: 9 --> 10!

RATING: 5
While I will usually play Dominion if someone wants to, and I appreciate that it started the deck building genre, I just don't like it that much.

As a deckbuilder, it maintains the old problem that, in order to win, I have to glut my deck with useless cards which often means that my hands become LESS fun as the game progresses.

Further, I don't like that the cards seem like they should be thematic, but only loosely are.  On many turns, I can't figure out exactly what it is that I did (narratively speaking), and I normally feel like I can do this in even the driest of Euros.

Finally, I feel like in the majority of the games, we set out 10 piles of cards (in addition to the 3 coin types and 3 victory point types), but only about a third of those 10 card types are used each game as experienced players quickly zero in on the best strategy and engage it.

RATING: 9.2
I am a sucker for Dominion. This is the first game after Settlers of Catan that truly grabbed me and made me feel like I should play every day. The deck building mechanic is elegant and fair, and many cards provide many exciting combinations. That said, the base set can wear out fairly quickly. There are many cards that I don't personally find interesting or useful (though I am sure some experts would disagree). Having Prosperity and Intrigue has really kept my interest strong. The only other gripe I have with the game is that there isn't a real theme here. 

Edit: Still love it! Isotropic really spoils me. When that goes down, it will effect my desire to play greatly. I hope the official app can be half as good as Isotropic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
"Reverse-Magic".

I've been recommending this game to parents whose children are interested in collectible card games but haven't actually gotten hooked on any yet: It fills the deck-construction ya-yas without forcing folks to spend billions of dollars just to keep up with the Joneses.

Also, it's crack for aspiring young game designers, as the "pick 10" rule triggers the creative spark for how games work.  I wouldn't be surprised if this game is cited by folks years from now as that game that got them to start designing.

The game has become a little more interesting now that I understand basic strategy.  It's the textbook definition of a light-weight, between-game filler and gets used as a stopgap between two game groups before the second major game of the evening happens.  Also, family.

I can't believe I'm saying this, because it goes against my principles, but it's also as true as the wheel: This game improves exponentially with expansions.  The alternatives force you out of comfortable strategies, and random draws ensure a fresh combo for you.  Yes, you'll get the inevitable "wha? really?" card in your mix.  Play anyway.  And yes, play with "attack card means at least one defense card".

RATING: 9
I think I begin to understand the love this game gets.  Easy to learn, quick to play, expandable, lots of approaches with with to experiment, plays well with 2.  If you enjoyed putting together CCG decks, you'll probably like this.  If you like creating your own luck, you'll probably like this.

If you don't mind losing, there are virtually unlimited possibilities for strategic exploration.

It is obvious to me that the creators have thoroughly tested the card cost vs. return structures.  I would not be surprised to find there are multiple equally good strategies for each combination of cards used.

Why this is not a 10:
-> I enjoy variety in my gaming.
-> After a few plays, it starts to feel the same
-> This sure is a lot of work for the amount of game!

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fantastic, elegant design which popularized a genre.  Not without its problems.

The theme is bland, and there is too much shuffling.  It feels like the game should include something to organize the cards on the table at its MSRP and given the box size.

Beyond that, the base game is not well-balanced. Your engine is either going to be straight Laboratories OR Village/Festival + card draw, or you will simply lose.  In the absence of those cards being availabe it's hard to beat straight money plus a couple +card draws.  Haven't played with expansions yet except a little bit of Intrigue, I suspect the game improves substantially with more card variety so that the metagame isn't so limited.

It may sound like I'm ragging on the game, but despite all these problems I've played it dozens of times and I think the core gameplay mechanics are nearly perfect.  The choices are so clear-cut yet so meaningful; the randomness is enough to make every game different and keep one player from always winning, but the more skilled player will still win a significant majority of games.  It's easy to teach but has plenty of depth.  Setup can be customizable through card drafting or randomly different each game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is great in that it has great variability. Each game is about determining the best set of cards to use among what's provided. All the expansions give different flavors to the game. The base game is bare bones, just the core mechanics. Intrigue gives players choices to make with each card. Seaside introduces cards that stay around and affect future turns. Prosperity brings higher value money and cards into the mix, giving players the option of trying to max out scores, or cash out quickly and end the game before others have their high price engines running. Guilds brings coins into the game, which allow you to bank some of your money for future use. All of these expansions provides something unique to the base game, and the mixture of all of them gives every game a unique feeling. I really enjoy this game and have played it with all levels of players. The core mechanics are relatively easy and approachable, and once new players have them down it's not too difficult to bring in the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely brilliant!  A customizable card game where building the deck takes place during the game.  Solid design and infinitely replayable, especially since it comes with a set of blank cards to make your own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm very impressed by the "deck building" mechanic of Dominion. The game feels very unique because of this and I like the CCG feeling of it. Trying to get working combos and therefore an edge againts other players. I really like how the deck evolves during the game. On the other hand the the way the game ends and purchasing of victory points feels "too simple" way to determine the winner. Especially because the players have hardly any interaction between them. 

The game isn't totally without interaction. Naturally you should follow how much others have invested in points and how close the game is to finish but there are only a few cards that enable any direct interaction between players. Normally this doesn't matter too much to me but in Dominion it felt almost too much of solitaire gaming. Perhaps because of this it can be annoing when you get couple of bad draws and others are luckier. Naturally you should try minimize the risk of this happening by being clever when buying cards.

I would've liked the cards more if at least those main things (actions, buyings, etc.) would have been iconized instead of text. They would've been easier to spot from the pool. When cards are in hand this doesn't matter at all. This is less of a problem once you know all the cards.

Anyway, Dominion is a good game for sure and because one game uses only a part of the cards there is plenty of replay value. Even if it is a bit of solitaire, at least it's a really good multiplayer solitaire!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Roughly played 300 games between 2010-2015. Varying numbers of players. Like it best with 2 or 3 players, and 4 is ok but takes a bit longer. Played it a few times with 6 but won't do that again, game drags then.

Like it best with at least one expansion mixed through.
Always use random selection and don't change any selected piles but play as is (as this forces you to think of new strategies).

Love that a game can last from anywhere between 10-40 minutes which means you can play and try many games on a single evening. Especially for trying out various combinations of cards it is great a game can be very quick. And even with the same kingdom each game can be completely different.

RATING: 9
The game of constant shuffling. Moves very quickly, though. Very addictive. Works for both gamers and laymen.

The card layout is not very good: Because the money cards have their value marked on the top left corner only, I find myself constantly turning my cards the right side up, in order to see how much money I have. For trashing purposes, the VP cards should also have values in their corners.

Too bad they chose to use these flimsy and narrow  cards. And the card backs are hideous, as is the box. The cards seem to be surprisingly durable anyway; After 60+ games, there are no marked cards, and all the cards look like they have seen pretty much the same amount of use.

RATING: 7.3
One of the few CCG-like games that I'll actually play.  Yes, folks, it IS a CCG, just that instead of buying cards a pack at a time, you buy expansion sets where every player gets the same card mix as everyone else.  No "rares" or whatever here.  In my opinion, this is a much more reasonable way to market a CCG.

The game itself is well-balanced and encourages some speedy play, which is nice too. Overall, I'll probably keep buying expansions for a while too, at least until the sheer number of expansions crosses from reasonable to ridiculous.

RATING: 9
It's one of those games that soon gets its hooks into you. With a plethora of cards to play with and a short playing time I can imagine saying "Just one more game" as you want to hone your strategy, but also explore new cards and combinations. Do I like it? For the most part, yes, however, I'm disappointed by the low level of interaction and I'm not sure the strategies are particularly deep. I do want to play some more so it's going to get some table time.

Update: It does get it hooks into you. There is more here that I first thought and although you spend a fair chunk of the game looking at your own hand you need to consider other peoples strategies. 

Beware - this game gets much better as you add more expansions. In fact I would say the base game is rather limited and gets stale quickly, but with two or preferably five or six expansions this is great. I'd rate it a 7 on it's own and 9 or 9.5 with all the expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dominion is a very concise adaptation of a collectable card game into a more family-friendly format. Between two and four players start with a little amount of money cards and victory point cards and have to use the money cards to slowly build a deck with action cards (that can allow them longer turns, bigger hands and better purchases), more victory point cards (to win, of course) and more money cards to keep the engine running. The game mechanics are very clean: each turn a player gets a hand of five cards and has to make the best use of it (they get more cards if the right action cards pop up). This means it's important to get a good draw at the right time (but... being able to control the quality and size of your own deck during the game, can you really call a bad draw bad luck?). Here a nice aspect of the game comes to the fore - victory point cards might bring you closer to winning, but they allow fewer options during a hand. Thus, good timing to buy the victory point cards is required.

Two issues arise when reading the rules: first, a setup (ten different sorts of cards out of twenty-five available) can be explored in a limited amount of plays; second, a strategy of buying only money cards and then buying the biggest victory point cards ("provinces") seems to be very hard to beat. These doubts vanish after a dozen of plays the latest: precisely the slight luck of the draw keeps games fresh, and even though some cards are definitely weaker than others varied strategies can be found even for one single setup (let alone the possible combinations of cards). Concerning the money strategy: relying only on money is not enough against tougher players. Without any actions in the pack hands can get trimmed without any defense or counterattack, so that buying provinces is far less easy. Two purchases in one turn or extra money (i.e. actions) always come handy, actually.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Semplice, veloce, un bel gioco!
Adatto a chi non ama regolamenti troppo complessi. Fondamentalmente è un gioco di carte (assurde le dimensioni enormi delle scatole), ma con profondità maggiore della norma. Interessante anche in partite a due giocatori; le meccaniche sono semplici e quindi un po' ripetitive, ma la possibilità di cambiare i mazzi con cui giocare lo rendono sempre diverso.
 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My rating on Dominion is dickering back and forth, but I still don't see it as a genuine Top 10 game. The mechanics are nothing we haven't seen a dozen times before, the artwork is nothing special, and there's little to be gained in the 3-player or 4-player versions except a whole bunch more downtime. It's easy to spend more time on faffy admin tasks than actually playing the damn thing, too. Holds up well because the gameplay will take violently (and surprisingly) different directions depending on which kingdom cards you use. I still maintain that Treasure decks are under-rated, though.

Further Thoughts - if nothing else, the game is becoming horrendously addictive, even with the mediocre cards in Intrigue, but it still concerns me that the whole thing seems to be a case of 'Race For The Provinces'. Bad draws after a carefully-built deck are very demoralising, too. Downgraded from an 8 to a 7.

More Further Thoughts - my God, it's easy to clock up plays with this one. It's clear that the central mechanics and the random layout work tremendously well. And I don't even mind losing. But now there are groans whenever certain cards (Chapel, Festival, Gardens) hit the layout, because we know they are going to dominate the strategy in advance. Still a 7, but for different reasons.

[i]Logging Plays - Since buying Dark Ages, we have tended to stick to 2-3 boxes per game, for richer layouts and so as not to marginalise Alchemy cards, so a play of each box is noted.[/i]

Cheap         :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Quality

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
A great game for 2-3 players.  With 4 it gets a little prolonged.  Basic rules are very simple: play an action card, buy a new card.  The most important decisions appear to be what cards to buy and when to buy them.  Deciding which card to use as your action is usually straight forward.

Depending on the choice of Kingdom Cards, this game plays a little differently everytime.  There usually isn't a lot of direct interaction between players as each is doing their own thing.  However, you do have to keep your eye on the other players carefully to gauge how soon the game is going to end and whether you want it to end sooner or later.

I rate the game highly, but only if you are playing with at least one other set of Kingdom Cards.  The cards included in this set are just a little too plain.

RATING: 8.5
After one play with a mega-set (all the expansions).  We played with Cornucopia and something else.  I liked the game.  Not sure how much I would like to keep playing it.  It has an interesting mechanic.  I won a 4p game with 2 new (myself as one) and 2 experienced players.  I went the route of cycling my deck as fast as possible to get my big cards in play.  And eschewed getting many low value cards.

For the novice player BSW is not the best.  The interface is more intuitive than other games on BSW but without the card text always available games take a while.  No shuffling but miss the shuffling and the visual cues that get from a live in-person game.

Quite addictive.  Not sure how long it will last.

RATING: 5
FIRST ENTRY 01/2010:
Indeed: This one was a good choice for 2009's Spiel des Jahres award. I'm so impressed by its speed, the innovative design, the replayability... I can hardly wait for the next sessions! 

Having known only few card games (besides traditional ones), and having had my difficulties with this kind of mechanism, I may add that I was quite a little bit sceptical about Dominion, but I'm glad I brought myself to trying it. The term may be overused on BGG, but this game is truely "elegant". It immediately found its way into my personal Top 10 games.

UPDATE 05/2010
Not as replayable as I thought. Money-buy strategy dominates in many games. There were complaints about the game being not interactive enough. I tend to agree. Dropped the rating by 2.

UPDATE 11/2010
Find it rather boring now, and even feel a little bit cheated by the poor implementation of the theme. Dropped by 1 again and decided to put it onto the for trade list. 

UPFATE 02/2013
Adjusted the rating to BGG guidelines --> -1.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an awesome game.  Although it is listed as a Board Game, it's really a card game.  As a huge fan of MtG (until the late 90's when the rules got 'dumbed down'), Dominion has all the most attractive elements of Magic.
The concept of Deck Building and Deck Tuning are an integral part of the game.
From the very beginning (with only 10 cards) you are simultaneously building and playing your deck.  As with so many of my favorite games, the resources available to 'purchase' improvements always feel like not-quite-enough.
The game is well balanced and plays EXTREMELY well with any number of players.
You have numerous alternatives for initial setup and for strategies to play during the game.  Although if you try to switch your strategy too late in the game you will fall far behind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[thing=137166][/thing]

I think Dominion is still a very good game. I think in some ways it has been surpassed by other deck builders but it still keeps a place in my collection because of its accessibility and variety. Also I've managed to get all of my Dominion cards into one box so it doesn't take up a lot of space. I did remove the base game cards because I was finding we almost always would replace them with expansion cards anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dominion is just the sort of game to appeal to an obsessive-compulsive bean counter type like myself.  Even when playing with others, you are basically in your own little world. Working away to amass victory points through the carefully balanced collection of action cards and coin is challenging and absorbing.  So many decisions to be made, and in such a short amount of time!  I also love the way that playing the right combination of cards can trigger an avalanche of branching effects.  And I almost forgot to mention--the artwork on the cards is really beautiful!  For all these reasons this game, though stressful, is also strangely soothing.   
(4+3) solo plays: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The rules are a bit bewildering at first (never quite sure with Rio Grande games whether it's the writing or the translation), but once I got going, the game does play fast and it's obvious that are innumerable paths to victory, given the sheer number and types of cards. Also, it seems to take longer to play than what I've read. 

I'm not sure what all the hub-bub is about this game. I played it solo and with my 10-year-old son, and neither of us felt the urge to keep on playing, as so many others have reported. I really wanted to like it, and he really gave it a shot, but we agreed we could both let it go, so I sold my copy. 

Also, the game seems pricey, given that it's all (of 500) cards, but the cards are high-quality and have beautiful artwork on them. 

Purchased late April 2009, swayed by all the hype, but ultimately puzzled why others are so excited about it. But, to each his or her own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Awesome game! Dominion makes me think of a highly evolved version of To Court the King! But that's not all...it's quick to play, simple rules and easy to remember, grand replayability, and interesting strategic possibilities! Begin with a starting hand of 3 estates and 7 coppers! Build your Dominion by purchasing kingdom cards to improve your property! Try not to clog your hand of cards with victory points too early in the game...but...you need them to win! Create a balance of cards to help you achieve victory! So good! 

And now with the Intrigue and Seaside expansions replay ability is vastly increased. Select your own personal card combo, pick a random selection, or play one of the suggested starter card sets...it's all good! Some complain that you can create a combo that will not work, but so far that hasn't been the case for us! In one game, everyone was reduced to zero money in our hands, but it just created a new strategy for us all!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is great. Dominion is simple but deep, and easy to learn. It is good as a long filler (typically 20-35 mins - you can vary it by which cards you put in) or it can be played back to back 2,3, maybe 4 times as it is different every time (I am normally a person who will never play the same game twice back to back if I can help it). 

There is some luck, but not too much - if you draw bad cards now, it means you are going to draw good cards later. There is also a nice mix of strategy and tactics. Some cards work better with others, and the skill is in choosing which cards to put into your deck (strategy), but also in analysing which cards to execute once they are in hand (tactics), though the tactical decisions are often automatic. 

It helps to have a good sense of pacing as this is an economic/VP engine building game that can end before you are ready. Having a good idea of what you've bought and in what ratios is helpful, so it is vital to pay attention to what you are doing. The interaction level can vary too, according to the number of attack cards available and whether or not people are buying them. If they are, then you need to pay attention as it can affect your purchasing decisions.

Dominion is elegant, deep and concise - a meaty game that plays quickly (like Puerto Rico) whilst being simple to learn (like Ticket to Ride).

Bought Jan/Feb 2009, sold to Mr.K 2010


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cull

RATING: 8
50+ plays. It doesn’t come out as much these days because it’s time-consuming to setup and pack away compared to other games in its lightweight niche. But it does provide a sense of satisfaction re determining a theory at the start of game on what the best card combos might be in the given random setup, and then coming up with and executing a plan to see how it works in practice. The limited interaction can be appealing, especially when playing with loved ones, but it therefore has the consequent sandbox downsides as well. It has the bonus of being relatively family friendly on top of being attractive to gamers as an opener or closer, so it’s no surprise it’s been so successful. Especially when you can pick and choose expansions to tailor it to your group’s preferred style.

RATING: 7
Jurds:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is the first deck-building game and arguably the only pure one.  It is one of my favourites (if not THE favourite) game and keeps making it's way back into my suggested games to play even after playing it hundreds of times.

One of my favourite thing about Dominion is the simplicity of the setup and the fairness throughout the game.  From the very beginning, all players start with the same cards and have access to the same "market" until the end of the game.  Rarely someone is able to blame losing on "bad luck", given the size and how many times you reshuffle your deck.  A bad hand is almost bound to be followed by a better one unless another player's actions interfere with this probability.

At first, I was passionate about building engines and combos and became disenchanted by the fact that they're most often inefficient.  But in the end, it was a real eye-opener to start seeing this game, as with many other pool/deck building games, as one of probability management rather than engine building.  After all, you rarely know for sure what actions will be available next turn.

Beginners and abstraction inept gamers are often intimidated or amazed at the possibilities in front of them.  That's why, unlike many others out there, I highly recommend the base game.

The base game was designed to introduce gamers to the genre, the basic mechanics and flow of the game before new expansions add to that.  Like every expansion afterwards, it contains recommended setups for introducing players to different possible deck types, card types and strategic elements.

For example, Village (+1 Card, +2 Actions) is the first of many "Village" type cards opening the possibility for engine type decks (decks focused on playing multiple actions).

Witch (+2 Cards, each other player gains a curse) in a great introduction to the burden of curses.

Chapel (You may trash up to 4 cards from your hand) is another great introduction, and one of the most famous cards, for getting rid of unwanted cards that you start with; effectively thining down your deck.

Market (+1 Card, +1 Action, +1 Buy, +1$) introduces the power cantrip (+1 Card, +1 Action) cards can have; virtually having no negative effect on draw/usage probabilities of other cards.

Moat (+2 Cards, When another player plays an attack card, you may first reveal this from your hand and be unaffected by it) introduces players to reaction cards.

Even if you're an experienced gamer, quite confident you don't need such an introduction, I still recommend getting a copy.  Cards like Chapel, Festival, Moat, Throne Room, Laboratory and Market can be appreciated when they come out during a shuffle.

Don't miss out on the simpleness and endless replay value of this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love the renaissance feel which comes through the cards and the artwork.

RATING: 7
What I like:
- Classic deck management
- Pretty easy to learn and teach
- Replayability with a variety of cards
- You *must* pay attention to your opponents to do well

What I don't like:
- Attack cards, and endless chains in a turn
- Dated deck management compared to newer games
- I dislike all the expansions I have tried
- Shuffling

I didn't expect to like it at all, but my first game was a pleasant surprise. 

However, the set of available cards really shapes how much fun it is (for me). At its worst, it's pretty miserable. Here are my ratings with some combos:
- 3 Militia/No Moat
- 4 Militia/Moat
- 4 Witch/No Moat or Trashing
- 5 Witch/Moat or Trashing
- 5 Garden

I think the voted 2.4 weight is a bit high for the base game, since those cards are not too complex and you only have to understand 10 of them at a time. I would give it a 2.2, slightly lighter than San Juan.

RATING: 5
Bleh Dominion.  Depending on the card piles used, you're basically playing a deck building game by yourself then comparing your solitaire score at the end to see who won.  many cards are dramatically more desirable than others meaning that they dictate what the games strategy will be more so than how you react to changes in the game.  When players are playing hostile cards against each other, you're not likely to even have the option to add a defensive card to your deck, making the game devolve into a lopsided arms race.  Also, the early game draws can really screw you for the rest of the game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a game where you have to create your card deck and ensure to be as efficient as possible. You start with 5 cards (bad ones) and turn by turn add more money and better actions to your deck. You need to ensure every card is used to the best of its ability since the cards keep coming back to your hand. A great game of thought and watching what your opponents are doing. There is not a lot of direct interaction, but the flow is great and if you just ignore others, you may be in for a surprise. Great game, good at two also.

RATING: 7
Finally got a chance to play this. Was decent and if it got cracked out every now and again I would not be adverse to a game but there's little appeal here for playing this game frequently. As a CCG aficionado games of Dominion's ilk appeal to me and appear far to infrequently. I like the deck construction aspect from a common and fixed pool. I think Scarab Lords is the only other game I'm familiar with that has this concept and they let people experience the best part of CCGs for far less money. The game has nowhere near the depth I could find in a game of NetRunner or Shadowfist, however, and I have little need for filler games. The upcoming Warhammer: Invasion and it's drafting system will take the part of Dominion's I enjoyed most and put in a system with some more meat on it (at least from the games I played at GenCon). Still, a decent game and I hope it's success heralds more games in this underrepresented genre.

RATING: 7
For the first 10 games it was ok and funny, since it's a totally new concept for me, who has not been playing so much.

After that, you can quite easily get to the base strategies where money matters, of course there's the "fun and not so interactive element" of building your deck huge with combined action cards, but they dont lead much to winning the game, since it's the money that matters. This is of course for the first game, and Intrique has improved that a bit, but I still get the feeling of "multiplayer solitaire in single player mode"...

If you miss the interaction and total screwage between players, full strategies and tight battle against each other till the bitter end, I suggest you check out Evolution Earth: Cataclysm.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm addicted to this one as well. Played lots of games on Board Game Arena, and still play a lot on Androminion. I haven't played live that much lately, but will usually never turn down a game of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Our favorite game. Most plays have been with 4. People complain about the game with 5 but we still like it, assuming that you don't get a wild kingdom that drags and takes forever. I particularly enjoy how larger player counts make certain cards more or less useful (pirate ship for example). My analysis of the expansions:

Intrigue: Excellent. Some fascinating cards and combos.

Seaside: Could be my favorite. I love the duration cards in this set much more than the ones in Adventures. Also contains some of my favorite attack and trashing cards.

Alchemy: Really dislike the potions. Have barely played with this one.

Prosperity: Truth be told, I dislike the platinum and colonies. On the other hand, I love the other new treasure cards and the cards that give the victory tokens. Grand Market may be one of my favorite cards.

Cornucopia: I suppose that I would consider this one good. I don't particularly like the tournament, but the cards that give more benefit for having a diverse deck are fun and often quite powerful.

Hinterlands: So many fun cards in this one. I love Fools' Gold, Tunnel, Trader, Ill Gotten Gains...maybe the only card I don't like is Oracle because it drags the game so much with more players.

Dark Ages: I need to play this one more. I didn't ease my group into it and they had a bad impression. Most of them like games with lots of easy money and powerful cards, not ones where they are scraping by or being forced to use oddball trashing or attacking strategies.

Guilds: Extremely fun. I quite enjoy the use of the coin tokens for extra one-shot money.

Adventures: My opinion is mixed on this one. The components are horrible, and I dislike the addition of all the different tokens and their associated cards. On the other hand, Events are one of my favorite additions thus far, and more duration cards are awesome!

Empires: Only played a few times, but I love Landmarks even more than Events. Castles are very cool but of questionable use in a 4+ player game. Brings back the victory tokens which I love. Still uncertain on debt and I don't really love the dual piles feature. There just doesn't seem to be any point to it.

2nd Edition: Haven't played with the new cards yet, but they look great! Most of the cards they replaced we never bought if they showed up in the kingdom.

2 players: There are better but my wife loves it so we still play frequently.
3 players: Ideal.
4 players: Great.
5 players: This is a controversial opinion, but I still like it at 5.
6 players: I'll do it but it becomes a but much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What more is there to say about Dominion that hasn't already been said?  It's the foundation upon which all other "deckbuilding" games (I don't like calling them that, but I digress) have been built, and I honestly believe it hasn't been surpassed.  Others are more thematic, or more "exciting", but none have the same delicate balance between strategy and tactics that Dominion sports.

RATING: 9
This was my favorite game for several years.  I was active on Isotropic while that was still going.  It's fallen for me just a bit because I haven't taught someone the game well enough to be super-competitive with me in my current game group.  To be fair, I haven't played a lot of the other deck builders out there, but I love the puzzle nature of looking at the ten kingdom cards and figuring out how to optimize my hand.  Add the ever shifting tactics as you watch what your opponent is doing and it hits a lot of the right buttons for me.  I like the level of interaction as well.  You can do your own thing, but you have to account for the other player otherwise you'll be left in the lurch at the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game really benefits from multiple plays. It starts out as you always trying to get the most money and winning that way [aka Big Money Strategy]. But as you play, learning how the action cards interact and how to manipulate your deck takes precedence. You can win essentially every time over new players playing that way. The base game gets stale after a while, but adding in even one or two expansions brings this game up to a 10.

Includes Black Market, Envoy, Governor, Prince, Stash and Walled Village Promos. I also have the upgrade pack which brings it up to 2nd edition. Removed the different cards.

RATING: 9
I love this game, it's fast, easy to learn, and really fun. The number of cards make each game new and you have to have different strategies for each time you play.
The deck-building mechanic is perfect, and in my group anyone can win.
I recommend that you buy sleeves to this game, you'll shuffle the cards a lot.

The game have two downsides though.
Depending on what cards you play with, there can be times where there is no interaction at all. Player A has his turn, then it's B, then it's C and then it's D. Whatever anyone did it had NO impact on someone else.
The other thing is that I find it hard to introduce this to new players, even if I want to. The reason is that someone who has played this before will kick the newbie's ass everytime, unless you play nice of course. So "casuals" (if you can call them that) might not like the game because of that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can not say enough about this game. For me personally, this is one of the greatest games I've ever played, and I've never introduced it to someone who didn't love it as well. This game has so many expansions, which add a lot of new cards and guarantee you will NEVER play the same game twice. There's multiple strategies you'll be able to do depending on which cards are in play, turns begin to go by really quick when you play with people who know how to play the game, and you can use cards that attack other players, or choose to take them out and play a game where you're just trying to earn more points than your opponents. This is my favorite card game and possibly my favorite game of all time, I can't recommend it enough.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What a cool idea for a game! It's a card game where you build your deck at the same time that you play it. 

In the early game you need money and cards that will allow you to make more actions and buy more stuff. In the end game you're trying to get rid of those cards and buy the ones that are worth points. Somewhere in the middle you have to make the shift from money to points.

It's quick, addictive and the deck building as you go mechanic really works well. It's also very suitable for online, because of all the shuffling of the decks. 

It's not thematic and doesn't score many points in the player interaction department but that's fine with me. 

After one's familiar with the mechanics and the cards, playing dominion is like driving a car: you do it without thinking and while chatting with the other players. Not thet it's bad, but it isn't a challenge, an immersive experience or a big mental exercise. It's just something pleasant and harmless to do when you need to kill some time.

Perfect for BSW!


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
 My wife is indifferent to Dominion and other deck building games, but I seem to love them for some reason.

I really enjoy the combos, variety, and euro feel to this game. Trying to build that optimal victory point engine, and doing it better than your opponent with the available resources, is something I enjoy. Of course some people are going to hate that. However Dominion seems to do it in a way that manages to hold appeal for most people. 

The balance in Dominion is such that even new players can do well. Experienced players (especially with the expansions) will win more often than not.

Interaction is low, but that changes with the expansions.

edit: Play with all the expansions with intelligent randomizing. Still greatly enjoy this game. It's a classic family game. Moved Dominion up to a 10. Many plays and many more to go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Big fan of Dominion - this was my true "gateway game." It's so simple to learn, and so adaptable. Thanks, Dice Tower.

I've played it a lot, but not enough to figure out how to use Chancellor. Even the Androminion app makes for a nice puzzle. 

A lot of complaints from pundits about this game have been that a) they played it too many times, b) other people in their gaming groups would rather play Dominion than whatever new game introduced by the podcaster, c) doubts about whether the next expansion can add as much to the game as the previous six, or d) it plays too much like multiplayer solitaire. The solitaire complaint is poor logic (the level of interaction depends on the cards that show up, with games of less interaction turning out to be very fast plays), and the other three seem to be advertisements for Dominion rather than valid criticisms. Nonetheless, a lot of these criticisms have been rather useful when I've been considering which expansions to look into. 
 
There's plenty of ways to balance the game with kids or beginners, by letting them tell you what to buy the first turn or two. That being said, I'd put it at a "medium" weight - one more than cribbage and poker, for me - due to the variety of situations and strategies contained within the base game.

As for the expansions, Prosperity has been great, and my experience with the others would seem to put Seaside and Hinterlands in a presumptive "to get" category, Cornucopia and Alchemy in the "pass" category (to say nothing for the promo cards), and Intrigue somewhere in between.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The expansions are necessary.

A brilliand concept. Add-ons are easy to include and the games vary. There is a different strategy every time a new game is played. The only downside to me is that the box is way too large for the game. Well, I just hope that it means A LOT OF new expansions coming.

To summarize: totally awesome!

RATING: 7
So far I've enjoyed this game a lot, but it's starting to feel very repetitive. Even with the variation in cards, it seems that running for gold as fast as possible is very often the best strategy. Given that one of the game's main virtues is its fast pace, it's unfortunate that all the player interaction in the game has the essential effect of slowing the game down. Still, I like how easy the game is to teach, and really like the novel game mechanic. I'm looking forward to the expansions to this game and to the next step from here.

Update: To my surprise, this recently proved to be a fantastic family game. My siblings, mom, and 8 year old nephew all loved it and were able to play well. 

Update 2: You know what, I'm starting to enjoy this one more again. Interesting.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The 8.0 rating is for Base Dominion, not for any expansions or alterations.

I really like the base set and don't enjoy playing with attack cards. I tried expansions but am not sure that the game has sufficient structure to merit turning it into a heavier game. 

The fun of the game is that it's an engine-building race, and the more "extra-move" cards you get, the more extended and crazy your moves become, but if you focus on only powers & extra-move cards, you never get enough money to do anything substantial, so you have to balance money and extra-moves acquisition to get your engine revving to critical power before your opponent so you can acquire more of the highest-point cards.

I think it would behoove the publisher to publish a list of tested game decks, because some combinations play better than others and some combinations produce slow lumpy games that struggle to build momentum. 

At its best, Dominion is fast and almost addictive. At its worst, it's a weird slog to the finish. Almost any combination of the original base-set that goes light on attack cards or avoids them entirely leads to a rockin'good time. But blending in expansions is a special kind of alchemy. I suppose if a person were really into Dominion, that the creative process of creating fun balanced game scenarios would be a rewarding part of the game. But for the casual Dominion player, guidance in game construction from expansions is almost mandatory if you don't want to have a lot of "dud" games that leave you trying to remember which cards don't fit well together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A nice easy game to learn and get into. Accessible and yet sufficiently strategic to keep more serious players engaged. Extremely customizable set up allows to to play again and again with different strategies.
The game is essentially knowing when to "change gear" between acquiring more money, turn cards and the final victory point cards. Timing, counting the card odds in your deck and a good dose of luck are the essence of the game. I have a feeling that luck is the only drawback of this game, since games tend to finish with 1-2 victory points difference at the end despite different start off strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Even players that are not seasoned with the whole set of cards can develop good deck building strategies with a few known cards. If I had to get rid of all my games but one, I would probably keep Dominion.

RATING: 8.5
A very neat little game lots of tricky interactions going on and lots of thought for the 20 minute playing tme.  As a game I really like this one as it scratches the old MtG itch without costing me the eart at the same time.  
So why only a 7?  Simply the quality of the cardstock, black borders and the daft sizing means that you have very easily damaged cards (especially if your friends can only manager a cack-handed overhand shuffle) that cannot be protected in a standard deck sleeve. Give me a 2nd edition with standard MtG sized cards or a white bordered linen finish and this is a straight 9, as I would certainly never refuse a game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In the card game Dominion, players try to acquire wealth, land, influence, and power in order to turn their modest kingdom into a fabulous dominion. Players spend the entire game building their own deck of action cards, treasure cards, and victory cards. Action cards provide a variety of bonuses such as extra actions, extra treasure, drawing more cards, and attacks against other players (although the interaction with other players is minimal). Treasure cards allow you to buy additional cards for your deck, and victory cards give you the points you need to win the game.

The rules are quite easy; each turn, you play a card, buy a card, and then draw a new hand. The strategy of the game is what you decide to add to your deck. You only have five cards in your hand each turn (usually), so you need to manage the balance between the three types of cards. Too many of any one kind can slow you down. Dominion contains 25 types of action cards, but you only use 10 of them each game. The varying combinations of action cards provide a slightly different playing experience each time.

With simple rules and mechanics, fast play, a variable supply of cards, and a reasonable balance of strategy and luck of the draw, it's easy to see why this game has been so popular. Dominion is designed for two to four players ages 8 and up. Several expansions are available to add more card variety, more choices, and more strategy. The Intrigue expansion also provides cards for more players to join in the fun. 

I was introduced to this game after a trip to the mall up north and noticed one of those board game stores in the corner by the food court.  One of the guys in there told me they were about to start a game of Dominion and that I should join.  Well I joined and must say that I really enjoyed the game.  I ended up buying it from the store and took it home and my wife loves it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Parece que precisa de umas exps para dar uma liga.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
pl
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An addictive, fast-paced, deck-building game. You and your opponent start with a deck composed of some low-value money and low-value VP cards. From this humble begginings you have to amass as much VP cards as you can. In order to do, both action cards and money cards are essential.

In fact, the touch of genius in this game is that while getting more VP cards than your opponents is  the goal of the game, VP cards are actually dead weight *during* the game. You are only allowed to have 5 cards in your hand during most of the game, meaning VP cards take up precious space - as they do nothing apart from scoring at the end of the game. So you'll have to carefully balance the composition of your deck.

As in all card games, there's a bit of luck involved. Yet, it can be tamed with a well-constructed deck. 

The theme feels a bit pasted on, but the mechanics are as simple as they are solid - and fun. A highly recommended game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Still in the "always want to play it" stage. I've been playing purely random card assortments for a bit and each combination requires a rethink of strategy to fit the mix. Excellent game. Although I will pick up expansions, I think that the current set will have a lot of replay value for quite a while.

RATING: 8
Quite a unique card game, the way you gradually choose & acquire cards to add to your deck. Plenty of scope for trying different strategies, especially given the subset of 10 card types out of 25 used in any given game.

Not too demanding on the brain. There's a fair amount of luck in the way the cards cycle into your hand, and many actual plays are obvious, but the card drafting is where the interest and replayability lies.

The card actions and variety may become stale with time - I guess this is where the exansions will come in, but if they are priced and sized similarly to the base game (and it sounds like this is to be the case) then I'm not sure they will be worth the expense or storage space.

Plays well with 2 players.

Theme is fairly irrelevant.

Card quality is fine. Sleeving is tempting especially given black borders, but probably not worthwhile given the number of cards. The box is WAY TOO BIG, even for 500 cards!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
[i]Nov. 2012 : I upgraded my rating from 1 to 2.[/i]

The [b]Tetris[/b] of card gaming : very mechanical, addictive, but void of any substance and human interaction. And therefore, a complete waste of time.

This game is dull and does not even work properly. You’re supposed to build the most efficient deck from a set of ten actions cards. Good concept, but it fails in execution. Because of randomness, you are never certain to win even if you find the best theoretical deck (in fact you could be beaten by the most basic heavy money deck). My opinion is that an abstract game for 2 players where the most basic strategy can beat the statistically most efficient is simply broken.

Designer's response for the huge impact of the luck of the draw : [q]http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2974072#2974072
“The game has a lot of luck; turn order isn't even the biggest dollop of it. And the amount of luck it has is a good amount; I don't know anyone who likes to play games where the best player always wins. Well except when they're that player”[/q]
So, a lot of luck is a good amount of luck. His game is a fest of luck and he mocks the one billion players of Xiang Qi (the chinese chess) and the players of Go who are almost as many.

RATING: 9.5
Dominion is a awesome card game. I love the interesting concept about how you create your own deck and forces you to not get mad at your deck because you are the one creating it. The combinations of cards that can be made while playing this game is practically endless in variety and makes the atmosphere exciting and intense as all the players try to reach their goal: The Provinces. The only critic that I have with this game is that sometimes with a mass amount of players, cards become short when trying to compile your deck. Other than that, (and on a personal note) my family and I are in love with this game, with me fighting against my mother for first place, while my father is lingering behind in the background. My sister is a completely different matter, with her hoarding all the Moats in order to be "protected from all the evil cards", even though she still gets caught out.Very good game.

Hogy miből vásárolhatunk? A játék elején véletlenszerűen kiválasztunk 10 félét az akciókártyák közül, így a játék újrajátszhatósága hatalmas.
Szerintem egy remek játék, mindenkinek csak ajánlani tudom!

RATING: 7
This game met my expectations, which means it is average. There was definitely a start player advantage as in one game the start player went first and last, and won by 3 points (and bought a 6pt card as his last action). Maybe I wasn't getting the card combinations but it did seem like a case where the player who got the luckiest draws won with advantage going to the start player. 

It was fun trying to work out card combos and figuring out how to improve the content of one's deck. And for a short game, a fun filler, Dominion fills the niche well. I'm not sure why it is like #27 on BGG though.

Edit: Initial reaction--this game is average. Revised impression--this game is neat. Current impression--this game sucks. There's just not enough here and there are too many setups with only one real viable strategy. The vast majority of play time is dedicated to non-decisions and shuffling. Good for passing the time with though, if Race for the Galaxy is not within reach.

RATING: 5
Pretty fun game. It's one of the original deck builders, and it needs a few expansions to be really compelling. Pretty theme-less. Game gets overwhelming with too many expansions. Many setups can be won by just buying money and ignoring actions for the most part. Also, tons of setup time and shuffling in this game.

:nostar: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:star: Good with different player counts
:star: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A pretty fun deck-building game that feels a bit incomplete. There is some interesting engine-building and it is pretty easy to jump into and grasp everything that is going on, but there is not much else to the game to support the engine-building. It feels like you just decide on a large-scale strategy when you first look over the card set, and then you often don't have many interesting decisions to make when you play the individual hands. You can play most of the game on auto-pilot, which I don't really like.

Dominion almost feels like a really cleanly built tech demo more than a full game. It's a fascinating mechanic that has been incorporated into many other games since, but some of those later games have done it better. In particular, Trains is very similar to Dominion, but the addition of the board and more player interaction means that I would always rather play Trains.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A victory point card game where the gameplay consists of building your deck by buying cards to put in it. Can be very addicting.

RATING: 7
good
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion. I succumbed to the hype and bought it one day, and, being a fan of card games, I was expecting an excellent game. Was it excellent? Nah. Don't get me wrong, it's a good game and it's well designed, but it lacks a lot of the elements that make gaming fun for me, and has a lot of the elements that make gaming dull. For example, you spend most of the game shuffling cards and watching other people take their turns, and there is very little player interaction to speak of. On the plus side, it (usually) plays quickly and there are a lot of interesting card combos that can be used, and I like the idea of building your own little deck from scratch. But the novelty wears off after a while and you spend most of your turns making sure you play the cards you just picked up in the right order... the only real decision making comes from deciding which cards you want to buy. And that's it really. A couple of my friends really enjoy the game though, so I'm quite happy to play it with them. But there are a lot of other games out there I'd much rather spend my time playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Grossly over-rated. And if you must buy expansions to 'improve' the game... then down-rated for crass marketing.

I'm not much of a fan of card combination/optimization games. It is fast and the rules easy to understand. The question is: is it worth the thought/study needed to play well? And will study actually result in a strategy that isn't mostly dominated by the card draws? And will that final strategy just be Big Money with 1 or 2 Action card buys?

There are some card deals are dull and frequently individual cards have no value. It also looks like a Deck-Thinning/Money/Province strategy could work in many cases which make the majority of the deal unused. This essentially breaks the game.

A 5 rating is GENEROUS because of the above with the POSSIBILITY that some initial deals aren't so broken. I think we are done with this game. (If buying ONLY Ag then Au then Duchy/Provinces works then this is a solid 1. With that in mind I'll take and average.. so a 3!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.25
Very good game of skill.  It is addictive and dynamic - you need to change your card buying decisions as the game progresses.

Variable playing time dependant on the Kingdom card mix and whether other players are familiar with the game, but usually quite fast.

Recommend that card sleeves are used because of the high level of card shuffling.  Also note that you only need either the original Dominion or the follow-on Dominion: Intrigue as the base game.  All expansions work with either base game.

Played a 4-player game where the winner only had 11 points, I had 6 VP and the others had 4 VP and 1 VP - this game finished with all Curses, Witches and Villages in play.

RATING: 5
Meh,
A low interaction acquire cards game. 
Not a bad game but not that interesting either. You build your efficiency engine, to get additional draws and money to be able to purchase the more valuable 
So your play is figure out what card to purchase works best given the money you have on this round. pick it, draw the next set of cards - rinse, repeat. Run out of cards shuffle new draw deck, rinse, repeat.

Fine game for online play since having opponents in the game doesn't really matter.
Yes the different sets introduce different cards, too bad it all feels the same - and to me the feeling is DULL.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fun card set-collection game where players try to earn the most points.  Throughout the game players try to decide which cards should be purchased to give them the most benefit.  Early in the game players will buy action cards and later in the game (crunch time!) players will race to purchase victory point cards.  When to make that transition is often the key to success.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We enjoy and play a lot this incredibly simple game with only cards, loads of cards.
Different strategies can be applied about what cards to buy at every moment (you are choosing all game long whether to buy action cards, money cards or VP cards)
It's got huge replayability: there are so many possible action card combinations within the basic 25 types that we don't feel the need of getting any expansion.
Our younger daughter, aged 10, loves it and she's perfectly able to go for her own combos.
And yes, frequently shuffling is needed, but it's not that hard.

RATING: 8
A must have. A good game of deck building. The rules are so simple and the card action well explained. The card graphics are superb. The game plays relatively fast. There is some strategy in trying to find the best card combinations in order not polute your deck. You also have to know when to switch from building you deck to acquiring VP cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After all the hype, I found the base set to be kind of bland. Still, this game has done a lot of the medium, and the expansions look like they have awesome cards. Without having played anything except the base set, I would recommend starting with Intrigue first. After playing with the base set, those cards feel like they'd be more interesting.

Update: I played some more and finally 'got' it. There actually is interactivity in the pacing of your deck and variance control, and while the game is still somewhat about finding the best combos, there's enough variety here to last forever. It really helped that I played with my friend's copy of the expansions though, the base game is still bland.

Edit: Sold base game to a friend starting his gaming collection. Dominion was good for me while I had it, but ultimately I had to make a decision: buy a bunch of expansions, or maintain a version of the game that people aren't talking about/devising strategies for/excited to play anymore. This game was destined for online play from the very beginning; soon, that will be the best way to play.

RATING: 9
Dominion has surprised me in many different ways. The replayability of this is outstanding because there are so many roles. This game can easily be expanded by just printing new roles. The game also appeals to CCG players as it is a drafting mechanic and trying to figure out the most optimal play. It's a fairly balanced game and none of the roles are too extreme in suckage or in overpowered. I expect this game to be in the top 50 for a long time, if not top 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I never thought I'd like this one, but I do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I'll say a few things about Dominion, none particularly insightful. The first few times I played it I liked it: it was breezy, it was simple, it was clever. But it very slowly started to feel like Pre-Game to me over time. It also just started to feel dry and unexciting: scan the market for cards that synergize, form a strategy, buy the individual parts of your engine, then see if it succeeds faster than your opponent(s). I can see the draw in how strategically-focused it is, but for me, it felt like a weird engine-building game where you're just hoping that synergizing parts of your engine get drawn into your hand each turn. 

If I want to build an engine, then I want to see if I can build an engine. I don't want to select engine parts and have them handed to me 5 at a time and hope that they can be assembled in the sequence in which I'm given them. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dominion is an excellent deck builder, it offers excellent variety of play and works very smoothly. I'm just not sure how much I really enjoy deck builders.

RATING: 4.5
Finally got around to play it and am a bit disappointed. For a boardgame, it is not very interactive and every player is kind of brewing his own soup and you can pretty much play the game while ignoring the other players. Especially with experienced players / seasoned players, the game plays very fast and more like a quick game of cards (without any bluffing/betting etc), rendering the in-game communication to a minimum. The theme is quite generic and I would have prefered a more gritty setting, dark ages instead of medieval. I quite like the idea of a new and random set up of cards each time you play, but overall. the player-player interactivity is way too limited for a boardgame.

EDIT: I had the chance to play it again with three out of four players (including me) being newbies and inexperienced and I had more fun this time. I actually noticed what was going on and at least attempted to think of something which remotely resembled a strategy. I reckon if I would play this game with a bunch of new players who play this game SLOWLY (what is it with some geeks, going for the speed record, how fast can I play the game?), I would enjoy it more. I think Dominion can be played fast, but I would rather play it with people that take longer to make their move and give me more time doing mine. Anyway, I like it better than the first time and I will play it again, but I am still not convinced it is such a great game. HX

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A dexterity game where the player who shuffles the slowest loses.  And that's only partly in jest.  It's amazing how antsy experienced players get when they have to wait for the novice to read his cards.

This is an okay game.  Players start out with a set deck of cards.  On a turn, players play what cards they can and discard the rest.  Cards provide points, money and other types of powers.  Throughout the game players use their existing cards to acquire new ones.  If properly chosen the new cards will combine to produce additional fun combinations of card play and more points.

Game play is simple to the point of being simplistic.  It's the card combos that add what spice there is to the game.  There's a few "screw your neighbor" cards, but mostly players will be racing to get the desirable cards into their deck as fast as possible.

Basically this is your standard Efficiency Engine game built around a novel deck building mechanism.  For me, a novel mechanism does not a good game make.  On one hand the game is light and fluffy and takes hardly any time at all to play.  On the other it strives for complexity in the card combos.  It goes by too fast to enjoy what complexity there is, while being too fiddly and full of pieces to justify the quick playing time.  It's sort of like listening to Beethoven's fifth sped up to twice the normal speed.

Maybe if I played it enough so that I could process the card combos and endless shuffling without thinking, thus freeing me to observe what my opponents are doing, the game would become more interesting.  But its not inspiring enough to devote that kind of time to.

It desperately needs card protectors since some cards will get worn out much faster than others.  The graphic design of the cards leave much to be desired.  The card backs are atrocious and the art, while not bad, is just generic fantasy and I'm sick of generic fantasy.

I suspect the number of expansions for this game will make its fans groan beneath the financial burden of trying to acquire them all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kind of has that awkward time slot where its between a filler and a full game. Interesting. Kind of hard to lug it around for what it feels like too. This game doesn't overstay its welcome, has good mechanics, very straightforward (with good strategy), and has little downtime between turns. The main problem I have with this is that it has very little player interaction. We find ourselves talking anyways, but it feels like a lot of the things that other people do don't affect your actions (my friends thought the same way too). The artwork is also kinda lacking. It has a great insert though!

RATING: 4
I was tempted to increase my rating after deciding to never play the game with random kingdom cards, only predetermined sets, but I decided I still need to be talked into playing it for these reasons:

1. My biggest complaint is waiting for what feels like 10 minutes or more while someone takes their turn, drawing and reshuffling and drawing and on and on with some of the combo cards.

2. I also get bored with the constant shuffling myself.

3. It never comes out when playing with regular board gamers. It's always with children and beginners. If my regular group wants to play something competitive we go with heavier games where we can plan out our moves, if we want something lighter we go for a game with less waiting between turns.

All that being said, I've played the game about 80 times, (and I finally bought a copy if you're reading this Dale). It seemed like a game that I needed in my Library now that my nephews can play it. But I still don't understand the Dominion fanboys.


  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This is not my kind of game; I don't like economic engine games. At least it's over in less than half an hour.

There are two things I don't like about economic engine games: [1] Lack of player interaction and [2] The emphasis on figuring out which combination of special powers works best.

Dominion emphasizes this combination, which most people find appealing (but unfortunately I don't). You typical economic engine/role selection game has some kind of mechanism that rewards or forces players to pick different special powers or roles. In Dominion, you can freely choose which special power you want (as long as you can afford it). So basically the key to winning Dominion is to figure out one, and only one, problem: [b]Which combination of special powers will win me the game?[/b] There are no sneaky role stealing tactics as in other economic engine games or any reason to pay attention to what your opponents are up to. If you're the first one to figure that problem out (and you're lucky enough to get lots of money early in the game), you've won.

Personally, I don't care for games that are about assembling combos of special powers. However, the majority of the board gaming world thinks the opposite, which probably explains the high ratings for the game.

=====

On an unrelated note, stay away from this game if you have carpal tunnel syndrome; the frequent shuffling will trigger its symptoms.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
This can be an enjoyable game depending on which ten (10) cards are pulled from the set to make your game.  You start by laying out on the table all the Money decks (3), Point decks (3) and the trash card (1).  The rest of the table is made up of ten (10) cards randomly drawn from the base set (and or expansions).  These ten mini decks will be used to play the game.  Players start with ten cards six (6) copper and four (4) 1 point.  Shuffle your ten (10) cards and draw five.  Your turn sequence consists of one (1) action and one (1) buy.  You buy from the mini decks on the table.  All the cards played including newly purched are put in the discard pile.  Draw five and follow sequence.  When you run out of cards shuffle your discard deck and finish drawing again.  Game ends when three piles run empty or all the Province cards are drawn.  Winner is the person with the most points.

RATING: 8.5
I could play it cool, and say that there was WAY too much hype for this game, and it isn't all that, but damn!  I can't remember being so surprised by a game as this one.  
I'd almost given up on BGG recommendations, after being disappointed by almost every game in the past couple years that has had hype, but this game is truly a revelation. How someone can come up with such a unique mechanic as shared decks but customized deck construction is brilliant.
Not only is the mechanic brand-new to gaming, it seems balanced and eminently replayable due to so many cards and combinations and gamestyles.
I will look to get in more games to try this out more.

RATING: 7
Really very fun. Build a deck of cards by "buying" them with money cards, create a deck to unleash killer card combos and buy land (victory point) cards. I like it because it is deep, highly replayable and most importantly: [i]fun[/i].

Repeated plays show just how deep Dominion really is. We play almost exclusively with just the base set and we're STILL finding new combinations or ways to approach the use of the various cards.

Also of note Dominion is the granddaddy of the deck building genre, a big claim to fame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Get it. It's perfect. With expansions it has endless replayability. Once you get tired of the pre-made sets, just randomize. You have to think of strategies on the fly. Sure there are overall strategies, but how you achieve them changes from play to play. And occasionally some set of 10 comes along where you have a stroke of genius and come up with something totally unique.

Ranking* of expansions:
1) Prosperity
2) Dark Ages
3) Guilds
4) Seaside
5) Hinterlands
6) Intrigue
7) Cornucopia
8) Alchemy

*Relative to other Dominion sets. Honestly they're all 10's (except maybe Cornucopia and Alchemy).

RATING: 8
Interesting in-game deck building mechanic.  The coolest thing about the game is the infinite replayability in that you choose 10 card types out of 25 possible to play with.  That's over 3 million different game configurations. You have a slightly better chance of playing the same game twice than you do of winning the lottery.  Some game configurations are more tense than others, but so far, it's always been fun!  

Update: the more I play it, the higher my rating goes.  After my initial two plays, I rated it a 7, three more a 7.5, three more after that an 8.  I'm getting hooked quick!  
Ok, I've upgraded to an 8.5 because I play it way more than anything else and I'm not close to getting tired of it yet.  It's an addiction.
