=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We love this game.  It takes about three run throughs to really understand how to play, but once you get your third game in, even new players can beat seasoned vets (provided you have a decent strategy).  I've always liked card games like "Magic: The gathering." but hated how expensive it was to build a deck.  Well with this brilliant little ditty, the pain of buying the cards becomes the fun part of the game. The game comes with all the cards you need to play close to a million different combinations without ever buying an expansion pack.  And it's simple enough that you can play with multi-lingual crowds without having to explain too much.

There is a bit of meta-strategy to the game.  There are pretty much three major ways to play with minor variants to each strategy depending on what's out and who's playing with you, however, these strategies counter each other quite well.  The one downside is that if your strategy is failing the game doesn't allow for the flexibility to change strategy mid-game (unless you've got the chapel) and it can be a rather slow death.  However, game-play is so fast that you can try out two or three different methods in a night and quickly figure out what you did wrong in games previous.

Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Even if I return to this game once in a while (online version), imo it has some problems:

1. Scaling - not present. If one player is better, you can tell she/he is better after 30% of the game. No fun.

2. Price - it's is overpriced comparing to other card games like Race for the Galaxy or LCGs (Arkham, LotR etc.), they have more variety of cards and strategies = and more fun.

3. Too simple, too little pieces, no variety - some cards are good, the others are not. If you choose bad ones or bad combos or have too many cards, you lose. The whole idea of the game is being able to recognize which cards/combos are good, and which are not. After 20-30 plays (which are short) you kind of know, and then the game can easily become boring (too little, too simple).

RATING: 9

*****
Update

I revised my rating from an eight to a nine after getting Seaside.  The options and interactions available in this game system are so varied and interesting that Dominion has become an indispensable game.  The expansions change the utility of the cards in the base game, which changes the way the game plays in a very positive manner.  Each card gives me something new to think about when compared to each other card.  Even with only using ten cards every game, each player will see different advantages in the available options meaning that people who often play together can shape each other's strategies.  Dominion has become a game that builds upon itself.  It's addictive because each expansion seems to offer the options of the previous game and more options that have yet to be explored!

RATING: 7.25
Awesome game.  Plays differently depending on which action cards are available.  Lots of depth and interactive feel.  Different than Race for the Galaxy, but adds depth to the genre.  The open-ended expansions add potential, but it also makes this more like MtG.  The downsize of MtG also appears in repetitive/killer combos from people who obsessively play the game too much and take the fun out of it.  Also, the game seems to suffer from nearly optimized strategies as people overplay the game.  As the game matures, it starts to feel like Magic, but with fixed (and optimized) decks.

RATING: 10
The more I play this game, the more I like it.  Kinda scratches the old Magic CCG itch without the billions of dollars Magic requires..... well.. at least until the expansions come out.

Update 3/6/10 :  I was rereading my comments and felt I did this game a slight disservice by giving it a 2 sentence review.  I like Dominion because of its speed of play, its variability between games due to the different cards, and the completeness of its rules.  If you come upon a question in the game, chances are it is answered in the index - if only all games were this water tight.

The speed of the game allows multiple plays at each session which is a big plus for me - as much as I would like to sit down and burn 5 hours playing games those days are - for the most part - gone.  Dominion is easy to get in a quick game here and there.

Looking forward to more cards over time.

RATING: 6
It's like McDonald's food: it's easy and everyone loves it, but it's bad for you and the difference is just illusion - all the food comes out of a vat at the back. I can see how recovering Magic:tG addicts might like it, but please don't share your needle with me!  I think this and many modern boardgames are inspired by a trope or mindset in net-based computer gaming where the underlying game is not really that interesting but people hang on to see what trick the next level brings (in the hope that it will make the game more interesting). The trick here is of course that each game can include a different set of cards yielding possible new killer combos.

RATING: N/A
While the game is a great intro game for new people, I find Dominion very simple and non-surprising after several plays.  Literally all you do in the game is use cards to get enough money and then use the money to buy victory point cards in order to end the game.  Nothing more strategic or cut-throat than that.

RATING: 9
This was one of the first games I experienced in the new generation of board games.  Even prior to Pandemic.  I purchased this game soon after Pandemic (a few weeks later) and have found this game to be sooooo satisfying.

The diversity in replay value is so strong because you'll quite literally never play the same game twice.  I have several expansions and it's all just amazing.  I know there are some people who think Dominion has overstayed it's welcome.  Not here.  I look forward to getting more and more expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A smooth but repetitive deckbuilder classic.

There's huge variety during set-up, especially if you have its expansions. So it's interesting deciding your strategy at the start depending on what decks are being made available.

However, after that you'll tend to be going around and around in circles doing similar actions all game. 

You'll still need to be clever to play this game well. Good judgement is key. It's just a shame that the amount of thinking is dwarfed by the hundreds of times you'll be moving cards around.

After about 40 games vs computer AI (using two of the expansions) and 2 vs real people, my concern is that it has a much less interesting 'balancing act' than deckbuilders like Star Realms or Ascension. In Dominion growth is quite linear: the endgame happens when your deck becomes rich enough to start buying good victory point cards, and it's clearly signposted when your opponent starts doing the same. In Star Realms there's a longer transition between the two stages that is more 'push your luck' and less signposted, adding fun tension. But Dominion is infinitely more interesting when you begin the game, thanks to its endless combinations of decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Edit: For awhile I resisted Dominion, because of its "multiplayer solitaire" reputation and lack of theme (along with its mediocre to horrible art). I didn't have a whole lot of fun playing this with 4 players, though I appreciated the mechanic. But, I got this in the Unity auction (and traded for Seaside and Intrigue), and we're really enjoying this as a two-player game. I haven't won yet. It's fun to do a post mortem and see what went wrong, and how you could have been more effective.

I still don't love the end game / province rush (which was a disappointing denouement with 4 players), but I'm looking forward to seeing Prosperity's effect on this. I'm also looking forward to new combinations with the other expansions I picked up.

RATING: 6.5

Oct 14 - despite being one of my most played games, and despite all the dosh I've sunk on expansions, I'm still not overly sold on Dominion, although I do seem to win more than just about any other game - buy gold and silver a lot, only buy a few actions, and race others to get the most 6 point cards.....hence can get a little tedious. The expansions no doubt add more variety so we need to explore them more to avert this problem.      
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.55
Dominion is a CCG, but a CCG with a difference. Where-as 90% of the time in most CCGs is anti-social, spent constructing your deck alone, here you build the deck as you play. Each turn you add to your deck, based on the resources drawn from your deck. If you add more resources you can do more in the future, if you add victory cards you increase your chance of winning but your deck will have less useful cards.

The game works very quickly and very elegantly, presenting enough choices to be challenging but not so many as to paralyze player. If it has a flaw it is that much strategy can probably be plotted out in advance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good entry level deck builder game. Replaced by Star Realms for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A great game for a small group of friends.  I suggest the full 4 players for the best games, though 3 is still pretty good.

Its pretty easy to learn and fast to play, though can take awhile to 'master'.  With the 500 some cards in the base set and the different possible setups, this has a LOT of replay value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fantastic, fast paced game.  It's so surprising to find a game with so much replayability and strategy, with such a short game length.  In many ways, it's almost a collectible card game, only no one has to collect anything.  The only flaws I see are that sleeves are not included (would've been nice), and that since many of the cards are similar, so the possibilities aren't quite as unlimited as they suggest.  Regardless, the replayability is fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.3
Dominion, while being a very popular game, is a
very poorly designed game.

If you simply want action Dominion will fit the bill;
however, depending upon the card decks randomly
assigned for that game, there are a number of things
which can go wrong to ruin the game:

1 The game often will end prematurely before many
Interesting strategies can come into play.

2 Because the costs of many cards were not 
competently Assigned you may get cards such as: 
Ironworks costing only 4, giving you a free 4 cost
card every turn it comes up.
These cards (and there are many of them) tend to
wipe out many of the lower card decks early and
Thus end the game prematurely, before any
Interesting strategies can be developed.

3 Conversely, there are many cards which are
Overpriced, and thus tend not to play a valuable
role in the game.

4 There are a number of cards which literally just
Ruin the game, such as Possession; where there
is no defense and repeatedly one can take turns
away from an opponent to one's side, and if he
in turn has a Possession card, a chain reaction 
can occur with one player possessing and gaining
the benefits from every other player's turn around 
the table.

If the designers had put any shred of competent
Effort into evaluating the costs of cards and assigning
Powers to cards that maintained some game balance,
Dominion could have been a solid game. They did not.

As it is, Dominion merely gives action to players in
a short game without any concern for solid or balanced
game Design nor often allowing players the possibility
of interesting development of strategies.

This is a game for the ADD crowd not for anyone with
an attention span.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The mother of all deck-building games (even though the game itself in a way pays hommage to Magic: The Gathering). The first time I played this game (Noorderspel 2010) I was fairly unimpressed. +card, +action, +buy, etc. This game didn't have a lot of depth, for sure. Well, I was definitely wrong. I gave it a second try and started liking it more and more. After having played about 50-100 games, I got into a new phase of disappointment. I had developed a clear preference for certain patterns, and games often tended to go in a similar way. When I started playing against AI, I noticed that somehow it would buy cards I hadn't even looked at twice, and with great success at that! From then on I started to check out every possible card and would try to see if I could incorporate them in a strategy. To my surprise literally every card has some use in some setups. Even a card like woodcutter, which is not much more than a silver that requires an action is something worthwhile, because it gives you a +buy, which is a GREAT help if you've got let's say 16 money to spend.
I now regularly play Dominion and must say that will all the expansions out, the base game still holds its own quite nicely. Cards like laboratory and festival are still some of my favourites.
The greatest perk of this game though is that with experienced players, you can easily play a game under 30 minutes, regardless with how many players.

RATING: 9
better than expected after all the hype it received. I like it. Very replayable, very dependent on experience with this game, but open for surprising combinations. Good for introducing people in boardgames, without frustrating them with too many rules, as you seem to learn this game while playing.
Has a pleasant chance factor that doesn't frustrate as often as you would expect in a card game.

RATING: 7
(12/08/2008) - This may make me a terrible person, but I will admit I purchased this game after only reading the description and some reviews on BGG. The concept interested me and the glowing reviews sold me on the game.

(01/16/2008) - [9] - Believe it or not, the hype is accurate for this game. I have 6 plays under my belt and I am a believer. I had never encountered the deck-building mechanic prior to this game, so perhaps some of the novelty for it artificially inflates my opinion of the game. That being said, I am giving this a solid 9 and would not be surprised for this to change to a 10 after a few more plays. In terms of raw value alone, you are getting plenty of bang for your buck with the huge pile of cards you get with the game. My only complaint is that I will need to acquire card sleeves for this before my copy gets too beat up.

(09/21/2014) - [7] - I think I've just burnt out on Dominion a bit. I went crazy with expansions and now find myself unwilling to play this a good portion of the time.

RATING: N/A
+ Can be played during a short lunch break at work easily
+ Different play styles are encouraged by changing the available cards each game which adds to the replayability 
+ Easy enough to track every player's victory points in your head by simply watching Province purchases, which adds to the strategy unlike heavy point salad games which tend to be a dice roll at the end

- Theme isn't really there but I still prefer it more than Ascension visually. 7 Wonders has more theme if that's what you're after in a light card drafting game (although I wouldn't call this a pure drafting game like 7 Wonders)

RATING: 8.5
The only thing wrong with Dominion is that I win every time we play.   :P

Also, maybe the price could go down a little by now yea? 

Third, its kinda boring after a year if you dont get the expansions. And it often feels like no one else is playing even when they attack you lol.

We wanted to play in a tournament at UCON 2012 but with all the new versions and expansions, and their super high prices, we are not familiar with the new cards and mechanics.

I guess Dominion is going the way of MTG: a constant yearly or monthly upkeep cost and if you dont pay for new games you get out of the loop.

That was one possibility, so I accept that its what happened. I was hoping for the other: that 2 or 3 versions come out and they leave it at that, and the game goes down in history and we all love it and cherish it forever.

Oh well, still a fantastic game. Dominion is not a 10, but it is great, no questions asked, period. Anyone who thinks otherwise is being stupid or is stupid.

RATING: 7
Intriguing game. We are enjoying getting to know this one. We've only played a couple of two-player games but it has been decent. Interesting mechanics allows you to build your own deck of interactive cards to gain prestige points. A bit fiddly with all of the shuffling but it kind of gives you something to do as you're waiting and thinking. Rating will probably go up.

Update - after more plays, we really don't enjoy it that much. We kept thinking we were "missing" something but really I guess it's a game that just isn't for us. For us, it seemed sort of "samey" each time and we really didn't care what the other was doing too much. More like another version of solitaire. 3-4 player games are much more interesting in our opinion but the game just hasn't had the staying power in our gaming circles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Efficiency Engine: The Game

I enjoy games that allow me to discover synergies between different cards, buildings, etc. and  Dominion is the quintessential synergy building game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game is like a bad ex. I don't really respect it, and I don't really respect myself for liking it, but I can't really help the fact that I want to play again.

Or: it's kind of like Taco Bell. Successfully engineered to push all my addiction buttons, but without any kind of the subtle, supple depth that deeply interactive games have.

I once played a game of this back-to-back with a game of Ra, after which I sort of stepped back and saw the shallowness of the Dominion experience. I mean: it's an interesting puzzle. But that thing that happens in games where you carefully try to figure out what the other people's plans are and try to become telepathic and subtly manipulate the game in your favor... it doesn't really have that very much.

BUT: it is a brilliant new mechanic, it is slick, it does act on the brain like crack, and I eagerly wait the coming of a genuinely beautiful, thoughtful, supple game built on the cold skeleton of this machine.

UPDATE: Over it. Don't want to play it again. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I am so tempted to call this FLUXX done right.  In FLUXX you start with a simple rule (Draw 1, Play 1) and the cards change all that until the goal is reached.  Here it is Play 1 Action, Buy 1 Card and the cards change all that until the goal is reached.  Of course, there are key differences, FLUXX is random with a blind draw.  Here the options are open and players manage their hands, decks, and card play to work toward the goal.  Relatively simple rules, but the key is in the interaction of the cards in hand to drive towards the goal of most VPs.  

Speedy play, some interaction makes this a fun game to add to any collection.  And having played all my games F2F - I can state, the "worry" about constant shuffling is not a bother as the next person can start playing while the previous person is "cleaning-up" without delaying the game...

 One of the few games that as soon as one play is over, folks are asking to play again.  As an added benefit, game also plays well with kids.  My 10yo daughter likes the game and has asked to play the game again and again.

A good deal of variety in the box with 25 possible decks (of which only 10 are used per game) adding to replay value, though even the basic set can be played a few times without the game getting dull.

But it goes along at a nice pace, so I'm happy to play again; but I won't be buying.

**Update** Rating down from original 6.5

RATING: 7.5
Rating likely to go up slightly after more play.  Innovative design.  Really rather unfortunate graphics throughout: small type in largely unused text boxes, ugly card backs, unbelievably useless and confusing cards to mark the end of each stack, forgettable pictures.  In spite of this, the gameplay was fun enough, though not nearly as quick as I'd been led to believe.
----------
EDIT: Rating likely to hover around here or float slightly down.  Kinda samey, and VERY little fun interaction.  Still a neat mechanism, but it's no RftG.  The poker chip version is a genius idea and will play better than shuffling thirty times a game.
----------
EDIT: As predicted, down a hair.  Just not that thrilling.
----------
EDIT: Rating down more.  Repetitive and boring.  Luckily it's also harmless and short, so I won't pitch a fit when it's brought out, but I'll always prefer a game of Race for the Galaxy, and I certainly won't want to play it more than once in a row.
----------
EDIT: Down again.  Probably as low as it can go.  I just don't find it fun enough to do the thinking about it I'd need to do to get good at it.  
----------
EDIT: No explanation for it, but I've enjoyed it well enough these last couple of times, so I bumped the rating a bit
----------
EDIT: Just added another point.  Perhaps I'm just in the mood for slightly more "autopilot" sorts of games now?

RATING: 6
Take everything that is broken about trading card games, and make a game out of it.  That's Dominion.  Good points are it can be fun and fast.  Bad points are the rich get richer and tend to run away with the game.  There are lots of expansions which can be great, but if you're unfamiliar with them, you'll spend too much time reading the cards, and you may not be able to exploit card combinations before your opponents get too far ahead.

RATING: 7
Surprisingly cool game!  The fun of deck-building without the off-putting collectible nonsense.  The central game mechanic is clever and elegant - play an action, buy a new card, discard your remaining hand, and draw 5 new cards.  The couple dozen different types of cards that come with the game are all interesting.  Play with 10 random sets of them, and every game is truly interestingly different.  It really has that "That was cool, let's play again!" quality.  (Partly that is due to the cumbersomeness of setting up and putting away, though... as long as it's out, let's play again!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As a longtime CCG player, I personally love this game and wonder why nobody ever thought of it before.  I have taught this to gamers and non-gamers with ease.  Even people who were predisposed *not* to like it have enjoyed the experience.  It is indeed addictive.

UPGRADED from 8 to 10.  Our family now plays this more than "Settlers," often 3 times in a row.  If Settlers is a "10" and we play this more often, it must also be a "10"!

RATING: 8.5
I absolutly love this game, only three games played so far but every single game was so enjoyable, great variety, great replay value.

Can't wait to buy the other expansions and play with the ones I have.

One of the biggest strengths that I like about the game is the play time, and the fact that every game it challenges you to find the best combinations with the available cards that are dealt.

And Everyone's strategy is different.

Just plain old fantastic game.  

Update:

Played with attack and curse cards tonight.  Adds some nastiness to the game.  Opponent didn't like curses too much (cost him 4 points, me 0 points) - He should have bought attack cards and payed me back =)

I loved the attack cards and curse cards, it adds the much needed interaction and flavor to the game.  Without them I don't think I would play this game as much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.45
Probably one of the three most popular card games along with Magic and Netrunner. Base game cards have a medieval village theme. Players take turns adding cards to or removing cards from their deck in order to implement a wide variety of strategies. Players then use these strategies to add victory point cards to their deck. Whoever has the most victory points at the end, wins. Simple to play but really deep with strategy. The good players know how to adjust to the other players on the fly as the game progresses which is vital. I don't think any two games will ever play out the same way. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was my "gateway" game into DBGs.  I loved it and have since become quite the DBG addict!  I love the variability this has with all the different cards.  We actually bought an app that allows to put in what versions we want to use and then randomize the game.  This is especially important because we usually play two player.  If you are teaching, picking the cards is best as it allows the most control (or use one of their suggested lists), but for experienced players, the random approach makes it more fun and harder. (JW)

RATING: 5
Artwork/Theme: blah, no personality

Gameplay: pretty mathematic and mechanical in nature

Overall Impression: Relatively unexciting for me.  It lacked in personality so much that I remember nothing about the cards, the art, the game itself.  As compared to other deck building games I own (like Tanto Cuore, Star Realms, and Ascension) this game is really unmemorable and unremarkable :(

RATING: 8.5
I've only played this twice, and greatly enjoyed it both times.  Scratches the M:tG itch, plays quickly, and appeals to my irrational love of efficiency engines (c.f. Pillars of the Earth).  It also plays at a nice, quick pace.  Main con: not enough player interaction, though -- I was interested in what other players were doing on an intellectual level, but not because it was having any significant effect on my own play.

Addendum:  I've now played several more games, and think more highly of it.  There are enough player-interaction cards to make it more than multiplayer solitaire.  And even without them, I've come to think of this more like the board-game version of a running race.  Even if I can't affect the other runners, I still feel like I'm meaningfully competing against them.

RATING: 7
A nice card game that gains plus points from its simplicity. I've played a few games online and I don't think this is the best way to do it. I see it as more something which people can do in order to get together, drink a few beers and have a chat over, rather than as an intense gaming experience. 

UPDATE: I've dropped by rating from a 7 to a 6 as more than half of my games seem to be decided about half-way through and the rest of the game seems to be just waiting to show that I or the other player has won. This is a tad dull. A few games go right down to the line--and when they do this is really quite fun--but really this is the minority. Still, when I get to play face to face again, maybe I'll put my rating back up.

UPDATE 2: Had a chance to play a little more face to face, but it just dragged on and on.... I still always felt that it was clear who had won half way through the game.

UPDATE 3: Played Dominion with my family over Christmas: it is like Settlers in that it is very easy to introduce to non-gamers and, in my experience at least, it has an equally positive response among them. Its advantage over Settlers, however, is that there is more variability, and with the addition of new expansions, more complexity. As a result, you can smoothly move your opponents on to a deeper game once they have become familiar with the basic game. In many ways, this is a game that is a lot about the people you are playing with, and how fun it is will often depend on your relationship with them. I'm putting my rating back up to 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm pretty much giving this a 9 for its *unique* CCG mechanics. Not only is drafting part of the game, but this is one of the few CCG's that doesn't use that tired over-copied, "rotate resource card to bring out other cards into play" mechanic. The additional point comes from this game being accessible to Eurogamers, Ameritrash gamers, and new players. This won't be the game that sits in your tote bag when you bring it to the game club! As a con, like other CCGs, exploring the card interactions is an important part of enjoying the game, so don't think you won't continue buying expansions. The expansions, however, are relatively inexpensive compared to Magic the Gethering and other CCGs, $35 per expansion per year online, less than a box of Magic cards.

***

[q="allenj82"]Please tell me if I am missing some grand strategy to this game, I really love the overall concept, but to me the game doesn't feel very different each time I play because you are always going for the province cards to end the game.[/q]

One "problem" about Dominion are the releases. The base set is just as much an introductory set. When no one played Dominion, this was a good idea -- a "good" game that's difficult to learn won't survive the market. (Arguably, this is why hobby boardgames will never make it beyond a small niche of players.)

However, only playing the simpler cards not surprisingly limits the variety of gameplay you can have with the game system, and that's what you're encountering. (This is not a hard and fast rule for all boardgames, as many Eurogamers will attest!) IMO, As a sweeping generality, the first sets (base, Intrigue, Seaside) can be won with the Big Money strategy, particularly the base set. It's not until Alchemy that Big Money is no longer a reliable default strategy. Prosperity will add a new Victory Point card (and Treasure card), which should further shake things up a bit.

So the new "problem" about Dominion is finding the expansions that best fit your play style. Some players do not like Big Money. Some players do not like "nasty" cards. Some players want a fast game. Some players want to make more decisions when playing a card. The Dominion expansions, IMO, require more research and work to make the right buying decision than other expansion sets from other games. While most expansions "patch" a game or add more options to the core game, the Dominion sets do neither. The Dominion sets merely have different varieties and complexities, which a certain CCG will tell you is a viable way to sell a game. In any case, you, as the consumer, certainly don't want to buy one expansion, only to find out you should have bought another. 

***


If you haven't played CCG's:
* Dominion
* Prosperity or Seaside
* Intrigue

If you have played CCG's
* Intrigue
* Prosperity or Seaside or Alchemy
* Dominion

Now start reading the reviews and looking for differences. Unlike Magic, each Dominion set has its own play style. As a CCG'er, you should be able to handle the complexity of Intrigue without playing the base game.

***

* Go bug a CCG'er how to shuffle with sleeves. I *far* prefer dealing the deck into two piles then sliding them together, than standard shuffling. But dealing the cards into three piles then a haphazard shuffle will do just fine.

* Yep, the Treasure and Victory Point cards *will* wear out faster. But you will have a second set with Intrigue, and you have to play the game quite a bit before you see wear. Still, I *have* seen worn cards at a game convention and do *not* want my cards in that condition.

* Your box can store sleeved cards, but not in the insert. Myself, I put each set of Kingdom cards in a baggie then pull out ten baggies randomly. This is *much* faster than using the Dominion randomizer cards then fishing for Kingdom cards. But not faster than using the iPod Dominion randomizer.

* You can use cheap penny sleeves, though not the cheapest ones. 

* Sleeves are not perfect. They will not prevent idiots from bending cards, and will not protect spills at the "top" of the sleeve. They will protect against idiots who insist on killing cards with a "90 degree bend" shuffle. So if you plan to play the game with strangers, you'll want to sleeve the cards.

* If the cards get worn, so what? Support the industry and buy another copy at the usual online discount. Heck, I've even seen copies at Borders, and Borders has 33% to 50% off coupons. Give the worn copy to a friend who's going off to college.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of the most over rated games om BGG according to me. Easy to learn, but too repetitive and too much down time between players. There are better games with similar mechanic (like Star Realms). A big downer is the victory point system where the most valuable victory point card you can by also determines when the game ends. This entails that the game always ends in an unsatisfactory way. Buy other games instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In it's most basic form, Dominion is a game of great promise. The central mechanic of deck-building is pretty brilliant, and I love the quick game-play and the ream of decisions that seem simple, but end up making a big impact by the end. The abstractness is a problem, but I can get past it. Less easy to get past is the repetitive nature of the game. Cards feel very similar to each other, and most of them are very basic in their function. Not only that, but about 3 or 4 key strategies emerge and are hammered into the ground by the game.

It's pretty clear that this game is meant to be expanded. Because of that, the base game is in a strange position. It's the weakest of the sets so far, but it's also essential to anyone who wants to get into the game. For neophytes, buy the base game, then pick up one of the big expansions after about 100 games. That should give as much variety as any normal person needs.

*edit* I never play Dominion anymore, but it sits on the shelf, since I've invested too much in sets and sleeves to get rid of it. Still a decent game, but I'm sort of over it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 6
Adding expansion cards made this a drag.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
I often have a feeling that this is the best game.  It doesn't seem particularly grand in any way, other than perhaps the sheer number of cards and resulting possible boards.  What it is is a game that is mechanically perfect... not in the sense of "the most ideal game imaginable; the pinnacle of all possible games", but rather in the flawlessness with which the game runs, the beauty with which new cards can be introduced and imagined and fit perfectly into this masterpiece of design.  It's the power of a simple, robust foundation; it feels as though nothing could damage this game so long as it follows the rules set out in the beginning, as though the game is immune to ambiguity so long as its few straightforward conventions are upheld.

I'm not sure why I don't rate this game a 10.  I think I am imagining that there is some game that is perfect in that first sense, the true pinnacle, the objectively ideal game, and I am reserving the 10 for that game.  Also, the game doesn't blow my mind or create bombastic experiences like some epic 6-hour game, and I have a (probably flawed) notion that a game with a true perfect score should somehow do "everything"... but this game is, I think, flawless within reason, and playable by everyone while taking hundreds or thousands of games to master.

Decided I didn't need to own a copy anymore after playing tons of Dominion on my phone. I can get the same fix much quicker now without all the pain that comes with shuffling.

RATING: 7
This game is SO much fun.  I highly recommend downloading an app to randomly select the decks for you, as it really is the most fun I've had playing the game, rather than picking good deck combos myself.

It's a great game that challenges you to come up with strategies on the fly.  Rather than studying for hours trying to come up with the best combinations, a random selection gives you a situation that you must react to.  It's all great fun, no matter how many players you have.

Update 1/1/2014: This game seriously fizzled for me.  The lack of player interaction and the fact that games always boil down to "Find a way to buy as many provinces as possible as quickly as possible" really got boring.  I still appreciate that every game is a bit different because the "engine parts" you have at your disposal are always different, but for me it just isn't interesting any more.  I probably haven't played it in about 6 months.  Will be trading it away as soon as I can.

RATING: 7
Dani
	
A mai napig legjobb... vagyizé, legismertebb pakliépítő játék! Célunk olyan kiegyensúlyozott pakli építése újabb és újabb lapok hozzáadásával, ami gyorsan pörög és eközben tempóelőnyt ad nekünk, valamint "elbírja" a győzelmi pont kártyákat, ugyanis bár a játékban ezek semmit se érnek, a végén csak ezek határozzák meg a győztes kilétét.
Három féle kártyád van: akciólap, pénz, és győzelmi pont. Minden kört öt lappal kezdesz, majd végrehajthatsz egy akciót és várásolhatsz egy lapot a kezedben lévő pénzen. A lényeg persze az akciók kombinálása, mert azok újabb akciókat, laphúzást, plusz pénzt és vásárlást jelnethetnek. Nem mellékesen a már nem kellő lapokat érdemes egy-egy akcióval kitenni, ami által "sűrűbb" lesz a pakli és nem minden 4 rossz kézre jut egy jó, hanem akár fordítva.

RATING: 9
I love the idea of a deck building card game where all players are on a level playing field.  It takes out the element of getting smashed by someone who spent five hundred dollars just buying up rare cards. The variety available is awesome as well.  If there is one particular card that your friend group that you play with doesn't like or considers to unbalance the game, you can just take it out.  Bored with the set you've been playing?  Just switch out a few more cards and you have a whole different game!  Not to mention the many expansions available to add any  number of other themes to plan around.  My only complaint is that there is not a lot of interaction between decks.  Nonetheless the game is still very enjoyable.  I highly recommend checking it out if you haven't already.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a card-driven game of economy.  Each player begins the game with the same deck of cards, and has the same option of cards to buy to add to their deck.  There are 4 kind of victory point cards (-1, 1, 3, 6), 3 currency cards, and 10 cards with varying actions.  On your turn you may play an action card from your hand, then buy a card with what currency you have in your hand, then discard your hand and re-draw.  At the end of the game the player with the most victory points wins.

The game's strategic strength is in deciding how much of which cards to buy.  The game has a built-in pacing mechanic: the game ends when any 3 stacks of cards is empty.  There are 25 different action cards in the game, and only 10 are used at a time giving it plenty of replay value, and the combination that comes out each time causes players to evaluate their strategy each game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Strategy (2.4/5.0)

RATING: 8
A great game that uses the deck-building strategy of CCG's like of Magic: the Gathering as the actual game mechanic itself.  Players try to build a deck of cards that make you build a better deck.  Land cards are VPs and do nothing more than take up space and contribute to winning.  The game is easily taught and liked by both gamers and non-gamers alike with anywhere from 10-20 second turns.

The game, however, is a trick; it claims it is not a CCG, but as expansions are being churned out, one feels helpless to not purchase another.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE 4/12:  No longer my favorite game, but still a 8 for what it was/is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Elegant and simple. You can really feel the vast playtesting time it has undergone. Amazing, Mr Vaccarino really is a great designer.  
We all know it's merit , so i just want to underline here the only flaw i think Dominion has. 
Every card game is obviously luck driven. While you can put all your effort to build a mathematic anti-luck deck you'll always have to shuffle it so you'll never be absolutely immune to absurd unlucky draws..  ATTACK cards exacerbate this. In a multiplayer game it is normal that an attack played by player X , completely destroy player Y strategy , and absolutely boost the rush to victory of player Z .  
I understand that interactions are the salt of every game but in my humble opinion  dominion's (and expansions also) interaction interfere too heavily and randomly on the game and it's overall enjoyment. Said this.. we are all free to play with the cards we like leaving aside the cards we don't, so it's not really a problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Kapsz egy pakli kártyát, véletlenszerűen kihúzzátok, hogy melyik speciális lapok vesznek részt a játékban majd elindul a játék. A körödben a húzópaklidból felveszel 5 kártyát, ezekből próbálsz újabb lapokat megszerezni, majd a felhasznált és esetleg megszerzett lapokat egy saját dobópaklit alkotva eldobod. Ha elfogyott a húzópaklid, akkor a már megnövekedett dobópaklid megkevered és egy új húzópaklit alkotsz belőle. Szép lassan megduzzad a paklid, egyre több dolgot tudsz megcsinálni a megszerzett kártyákkal. Óvatosan válaszd ki az új kártyákat, mert ha az elején túl sok győzelmi pont kártyát spájzolsz be, akkor azok visszafoghatnak hiszen játék közben a kezedben semmilyen akcióra nem lehet beváltani. Érdekes játék, több van benne mint amennyit kaptam. Többször szeretnék vele játszani.

RATING: 9
Well what do you know... Another game that's totally deserving of the hype it's received. 

This game is a lot of fun. The four of us wanted to immediately play again--something that rarely happens. So many cool mechanisms. And your strategy completely changes based on what's out--the Bureaucrat might suck in this game thanks to the Thief, but it's awesome in another game.

It's the best game I doubt I'll ever own. My family would never play this, and there are approximately 245 copies in our group.  So I'm good.

RATING: 10
Dominion really surprised me.  I wasn't expecting to enjoy it as much as I do.  It moves a long so quickly that very often it's your turn again before you've finished shuffling your deck.  My gaming group keeps coming back to it even after months of playing, which for me, is the mark of an excellent game.  We usually take turns choosing cards to determine the 10 action cards to play with, so no two games have been the same.  What I find interesting is that the different combinations of cards as well as the different ways people will play will give each game a different feel.  I really love this game.

RATING: 8
Dominion is a lot of fun as a family game.  It is easy to teach and learn, and plays quickly.  Yet, there are enough combinations to keep it interesting for adults.  My kids enjoy this, and I like having games to play with them that are interesting.  It is also a nice game to break out with non-gamers since the learning curve is so small.

I have been trying out some of the expansions.  I am surprised, but I prefer just the base game.  Prosperity extends the game a bit longer than feels right. It is ok mixing in some propsperity cards, but I really don't like the Colonies. Intrigue needs more plays but has not really wowed me yet.  I am not planning on getting any other expansions.

RATING: 7
It has a very different mechanic to it, and has a CCG like feel without having to give WotC your paycheck every month. I'm a big fan of the deckbuilding mechanic. But, I dislike the ending. I feel like I'm playing mostly by myself, while watching how other people are doing, and the ending just feels very flat. Everyone looks around and says "well, I guess that's it." and counts up their points. There's not enough tension, I guess.

So, summary: Great mechanic, crappy end-game.  Also, wish for more player interaction.

RATING: 7.5
A great game, easy to learn and jump into.  Played this recently for the first time at the FLGS game night and found that even with inexperienced players, the game moved quickly and we finished in about 1/2 hour.  

The rules are very straightforward - play an action, buy a card.  But the cards you choose to buy can allow you additional actions and buys.  From that you develop your strategy to accumulate the most victory points.

Although we played with just the basic, beginner deck it is easy to see the game has great potential for repeat plays as you have 25 decks to choose from.

As soon as the first game was done, we were ready for another.  In fact, after just two games the other players put in an order for their own copy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Received at Oasis of Fun 2009 prize table.

This seems to be a less-interactive but less-annoying Magic:The Gathering. You build your deck as you play from a common set of cards. You win by having more victory points in your deck, but the kicker is that victory point cards don't do anything else but take up space in your hand. The game comes with 25 sets of rule-bending "kingdom cards" but you only play with 10 sets at a time, giving you lots of re-playability. This is an optimizing game: each combination of 10 probably has a best strategy regardless of your opponent strategies. This suggests that at a certain point folks will get bored. :) We'll see!

UPDATE Aug-2-2009: The girlfriend likes this one. She takes particular joy in action combos centered around the Village card.

UPDATE Jun-14-2010: Dropping to a 7.5, reflecting the fact that while Dominion is highly re-playable, the repetitiveness of the shuffling mechanic can wear on me. I like to play Dominion only after getting my game on in other ways first.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2-4 players
$30
2.3 weight

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Dominion is a dry, boring exercise in analyzing the best way to get more money faster with virtually no tactical play or player interaction, uninteresting engine building, and few interesting trade offs. The victory conditions are unsatisfying, the strategies are too similar, and the card abilities tend to be bland. Money is the be all and end all of the game 95+% of the time. 

I enjoyed Dominion when I first played it, but the more I've played it, the more problems I've had with it. At this point I'd go so far as to say it's a poorly designed game with less strategy and replayability than it's proponents claim.

I much prefer Ascension, Eminent Domain, Core Worlds, Friday, Mage Knight, and Puzzle Strike. Puzzle Strike does everything right where Dominion does it wrong, and it fixed every problem I had with Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I acknowledge Dominion as the game that started the deck-building genre and it serves its place in board game history for that. It's an excellent base standard model for the deck-building mechanics which really is a brilliant in-game concept. 

The mechanics of Dominion plays solidly, but that's all there is to Dominion. There really is no game apart from continually shuffling and building your deck. I'd rather spend my time deck-building and shuffling a deck I can actually use as part of a larger game. But the simplicity of the game and light theme also makes it a very approachable gateway game to introduce to casual and non-gamers.

I've only played the base game which is what this rating reflects. I hear expansions add more depth to the game, so Dominions: Intrigue or additional expansions should be considered if you want to get into this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After having avoided this game for a few years, I was amazed at how much I liked it after just one play. The second game introduced the aspect of variation due to the deck selection, and by the third game I understood the competing impulses of wanting to try another round with the same cards, now understood, and wanting to see how a different deck selection will turn out.

As a benefit to new players, the game never induces a sense of any player doing poorly, until measured against the progress made by his competitors. The game allows a gratifying learning experience before requiring a focus on competition.

Given the design pedigree, I decided to buy Puzzle Strike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Love the concept and mechanics. Cards are fun and varied. Theme feels tacked on, but who really cares?

Few problems though. Many cards are useless/never bought, shuffling every 2 seconds, and a lot of downtime for a fast paced game. (Ever had to wait for 3 people's turns just to buy 1 card without any actions?)

Many of these problems are fixed with BSW, and in fact I kind of like playing on there more.

In NY: June 2010

RATING: 8.25
8 rating after one play. Can't wait to play again. Very fun and wondering if you need 40% treasure like 40% land in a Magic deck. Going to take me a while to make my deck building efficient. The first game I was just like ... not getting enough money ... guess I need to buy more. I was reactive and am betting pro-active is more efficient and gives me a better chance of winning. Intrigue expansion has been ordered from CSI. Which of course means I needed to get to 100$ for free shipping so sleeves for Agricola and Stone Age ordered, new Smallworld expansion and promos ordered, a Resistance expansion ordered ... Yay, I leveled up! Now level 7 and 3% off every purchase. They have me so hooked! Bastages!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fast game with allmost endless of variations. Need to play more with the expansions, but just the maingame is enough for several hours. Easy to play with non-gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
2-4 player filler-length game, that is a good embodiment of Euro design principles, so it's suitable to introduce to curious players.

It's okay. Original design, and does barely scratch the CCG itch, but gameplay is zzz dry. You barely have to care what other people are doing. The only player interaction is whether they'll end the race, and all player interaction through cards is forced. Decisions are almost completely automatic after you decide what to do at the start of the game, and everything that comes after is luck of the card draw and zzz. You just decide what to do at the start of the game, and then you become the shuffle bitch of the God of card draws and make decisions that make you feel good, but really are just automatic. At least it plays quickly enough, that it's an option for short games.

Game balance is a problem. Nearly every setup involving a Chapel only contains a single dominant strategy. The turn order is completely broken: letting players with fewer turns win the tiebreaker in no way justifies the advantage of going first and the potential to get more turns (the tiebreaker is moot, because any good start player can ensure ties are rare). 

People rave about the variability of game setups, but realistically, you get a handle on every single strategy there is after about 20-25 plays. That is way less than most other board games out there. In other board games, the way people behave differently can add almost unlimited replayability to a game, so the forced interaction in Dominion (plus obvious dominant strategies like Chapel) really hurts in this regard. In this game more so than others, sticking to a few well-learned rule-of-thumbs can guarantee victory without breaking a sweat at all (while you will get countered in other games if you always do the same thing). The learning curve is sloped gently, but very, very shallow, and once you reach its top, it's all luck.

You know a game defines mediocrity when the online implementation is actually more enjoyable than playing in real life, and when it needs cards upon expansion cards to add variability to a game that inherently has none.

Good original idea, but a work in progress.

By the way, seems like Dominion has the biggest contingent of passionate/hardcore fans, the kind who go "OMG?! YOU DON'T LIKE THIS GAME! NOZZZ WTF IS WRONG WIF YOU. YOU DON'T GET IT."

Base: 3+1
 + Intrigue: 3+2
 + Seaside: 2+3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I would rather eat my own pancreas than play this MTG rip-off.  The theme sounds cool, but is poorly implemented.  I don't feel like I'm building anything, except my tolerance for pain.  I'd rather play a really long game of Give Me a Bunch of Paper Cuts on My Eye and Pour Lemon Juice All Over My Face.

Ok,ok.  I'm going to try to give this game another chance.  I think the fact that I was still new in the gaming hobby may have colored my opinion of this.  I've upped my rating, but I still find some of the endless combos annoying and highly reminiscent of the things I disliked about Magic.  The downtime while someone is playing out their entire deck each hand is totally a drag.  I give it a 5 and that's the end of it.  One last thing - Dominion can't carry Ascension's jockstrap.

So, I've tried it yet again, and whaddya know?  I get it now.  The uber-combos still bug me, but I now enjoy it.

And now, not only do I enjoy it, but I love it.  Ridiculous, I know.

RATING: 9
This was game that really surprised me.  When it was initially released, I was not all that interested in the game.  It just didn't sound like something I would be interested in.  In fact, I didn't even plan on giving it a single play just to try it out.

Then I actually played the game and was immediately hooked.  I am not sure what it is about the game, but I find that I want to play it over and over again.  Granted, I don't have the massive number of plays that some out there have, but what I have played is a lot for me on a single game.  

I am still not all that sure what it is that I find inticing about the game.  I suppose has a little to do with the deck-building aspects of the game.  I imagine that it is the efficiency aspects that really appeal to me.  That and playing with cards, and exploring the decision space.  Well, I'm still not sure.

Still, I am happy to have the game and now am looking forward to the expansions as well. [04/07/2009] 8

RATING: 8
my wife and I are having fun with this one. The core mechanic is easy to understand, and the feel of the game evolves as you play and you deck starts to work for you. We switched out some of the cards for our last game, and it did give things a very different feel, so I think it has decent replayability value. It's fun to see your combos go off and plunge through a huge number of cards in one turn. Despite there being a few cards that affect the other players' game, it is basically a race between players who are each involved in building and running their own decks. It might be a good way to introduce people to CCGs and some of their basic concepts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
Tried it online. Didn't get it. 
4 years later - borrowed a copy, didn't get it. 
Tried Thunderstone - that one I did get. 

Problem: theme has no function whatsoever - it could for instance help you grasp the counterintuitive gameplay and card interaction (like this was accomplished in Thunderstone). I realised I just can't be bothered to play themeless games and here it's also the learning curve - I'm guessing that one must invest into a game to learn to see the subtle connection between cards, but I just don't see any reward in doing this. I play a card to play another card which lets me draw another card so I can play another card - you must be joking. Also the "auto pilot" style of playing makes no sense multiplayer (you make decisions automatically, mostly before the game). It actually lacks tactical decision process. Additional attacking (intrigue) doesn't save the game, but only hinders it - for me adding take-that elements onto a MPS is never really welcome, I want the game to be either richly interactive or solitaire (but only IF it has a theme).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Juegazo de cartas. Muy adictivo y rejugable.
Muchas variables posibles gracias a las 25 cartas diferentes que tiene (en cada partida, se usan 10) y a como interactuan entre sí. Nunca 2 partidas son iguales.
Desde Magic, que nunca me había viciado tanto a un juego de cartas. La ventaja de este, es que no tienes que estar comprando cartas cada dos por tres. Aparte que pueden jugar de 2 a 4 personas sin perder ni un ápice de diversión.

P.D: En las partidas jugadas solo apunto las que juego con el juego físico. En la BSW tengo mas de 70 partidas.

Añadidos el Dominion Intriga, Terramar y Alquimia. Todas las partidas que haré a partir de esa fecha, serán con las cartas mezcladas de todos los dominion y las apuntaré en el juego original.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[126 plays] Boy this is fun! If I get sick of this after 500 games, I don't care, because those first 499 games will have been worth the ride.

I like efficiency/economic games, and this is a clever little beast which plays quite quickly after you have a couple of games under your belt. Building your deck and getting your engine running, then converting from money to victory points at the right time reminds me of St. Pete and San Juan to some degree, but the gameplay is unique and fascinating. Some deck combinations will have more interaction, while others may have little, but you always will need to watch what other players are doing and how fast the clock is ticking.

The cards are nicely made, the artwork is pleasant, and the infinite combinations will last a long time before anyone truly needs the inevitable expansion decks. I am very pleased to own this new classic.

Most recent plays Jan '16.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
#13 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

Dominion was my first experience with deck-building, and it's still one of my favorites. I own each one of the expansions and most of the promos. I keep them all together in the Hobby Lobby wooden artists case. I admit that I don't play this one as much as I used to, but I still think highly of it and would not turn down an invitation to play. I've only played less due to my exposure to more and more amazing games- I'm a card carrying member of Cult of the New. Dominion is a classic- it's easy to learn, but a bit harder to play well. My favorite expansion is Prosperity cause I love big money!

Acquired: College
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Right. I like it.

It scratches the MtG itch, it's easier to teach and get started than RftG and it plays in 30-45 minutes.

Players start off with 10 cards and slowly use that to buy more cards in order to create a deck (engine) to generate money to buy VP cards. The 25 different cards offers much variability and strategy.

It's almost like reverse-MtG where players have access to a pool of common cards and are drafting the best decks. The 'mana' problem is fixed by having common money for everything.

Neat game that offers much replayability. Can't wait for expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Will always hold a special place in my heart as our gateway board game. The deck building is done almost perfectly in that you always have difficult decisions on what cards you want to buy because you don't want to start clogging your deck with victory cards too early, but you also can't afford to fall too far behind in the province race. After getting the game set up a two player game can be done in twenty minutes, and even when a person loses they can feel good knowing that it was just because the other person managed to build a slightly more efficient engine.

RATING: 6
The granddaddy of deck builders, Dominon has waned in popularity in our group in the face of more meaty deck builders like Core Worlds, Barbarossa, and Trains. 

The barely-there theme also fails to maintain interest in the simple deck building mechanics.  Deeper theme (Barbarossa) or tweaked mechanics (Trains, Core Worlds) are needed to keep my interest. 

When new, deck building alone was enough to sustain my interest in this game, but now, I find myself wanting to do more with the combos I build than just buy more cards.

RATING: 9
This is a fun, fast-paced, accessible game with a great deal of replay-ability.  The game is basically dynamic deck-building.  Although my least favorite aspect of collectible card games is deck-building, this game turns it into an exciting and rewarding process.  Fun for new players and addictive for the experienced.  Also, great value for money -- over 500 cards in the base set.  Definitely print out the storage label from BGG, it saves a great deal of setup/cleanup time.

RATING: 8
One has to like Dominion. The variation that the different cards give keeps the game fresh for a long, long time. The rules are easy to learn and fundamentally very simple, yet elegant. Some expansions can make Dominion more complicated and/or cumbersome though.

A really good idea was the way in which victory points hamper your deck, but are the only way to win the game. One thing I quite dislike is the possibility for the "village idiot" -strategy. Man that gets old quick.

RATING: 10
[BGCOLOR=#FFFF00][COLOR=#000000]Family.[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] 2-4p, 30m.

Card. Picked up at BGGcon on description and advanced buzz. Fantastic game - my entire group likes it quite a bit. It scratches a lot of itches, yet is mechanically simple. Mixing up the kingdom cards refreshes the feel of the game. Virtually nonexistent downtime in a 15-30 minute game that is just pure fun to play.

Update: passing 25 plays now, I've upgraded this to a full 10. I just really enjoy this game and doubt this will ever change. The forthcoming addition of new cards, and the ability to make up your own cards for kicks, will likely keep this fresh for me for a long time, too. Awesome.

Loan: Steve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After many games of Dominion with different groups of people, it's become one of those games I'd play if a group wanted to, but don't feel like I need to own a copy of. It's a neat game. You are gradually building the deck with which you are playing the game. So as the composition of your deck changes, the gameplay changes. Dominion gives players extensive feedback as to how well they are playing, and I like this about the game. What I'm not so keen on is the pride of place given to efficiency. I don't not mean to compare Dominion to Race for the Galaxy, because in most ways they aren't comparable - but imagine if Race for the Galaxy only had a single method to ending the game (victory point depletion) and only a single winning condition (most victory points earned through consumption). If this were so, I wouldn't enjoy Race nearly so much because the game would have been reduced to efficiency at this single task. And that's how Dominion feels to me. Yes, every blend of cards lends itself to slightly different strategies. But the end is always the same. Tightest deck wins. I do think it is a pretty darn good game. It's just that whenever we're talking about what to play and Dominion comes up, the feeling is always "meh".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I need to play more, but I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dominion is a game consisting of nothing more than its core deckbuilding mechanic, with a pasted on theme. With a given set of Kingdom Cards, there always seems to be a dominant strategy, so you better play with random cards all the time. However, especially with the base set alone, this quickly became boring after only a couple of plays. Sold this as I now have Mage Knight, which is a much more engaging game with a similar deckbuilding mechanic.

Don't record plays unless they are played face to face.  Games on isotropic and androminion would probably total a few thousand.

With all expansions mixed in this game could maybe be a 10 for us probably.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Many deckbuilders have come, many deckbuilders have gone, and I still find myself coming back for some Dominion. While the newer games have gone for the less deliberate, more fun approach, Dominion is the staunch defender of the strategy approach to deckbuilding. 

Is this the right time to start buying VPs? Will putting this card in my deck make it run smoother or will it be the monkey wrench in the cogs of a well-oiled machine. These are the questions you will be asking yourself during each turn of Dominion. If you don't know the game well, this can end in many wasted turns and an overall aggravating experience. But if you learn to navigate the meanders of Dominion's strategy, you will get one of the most interesting games the deckbuilding mechanics has to offer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great game, one of my top 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Deserves the praise it gets for creating the genre. As time goes by the base game loses some of it's magic, and you'd have to suggest that newer games have trumped this original set. That isn't to say that with all the expansions around Dominion isn't still incredibly relevant, but if you had to recommend a single game without expansions I'd hesitate to say Dominion.

Which all makes it quite hard to rate. It is a beautiful design, and only because others have stood on its shoulders does it start to lose some of its glamour. Seven feels too little and eight means I'd have to give others a higher score. I'll go with seven.

BGG top játék, de valahogy nálam még mindig nincs meg a hatása. A sok kártyából adódó nagyon sokfajta, különböző játék lehet ennek a társasnak a sikere. De ha valaki a Race for the Galaxy-ra azt mondja, hogy unalmas pasziánsz, akkor vajon erről miért nem ugyanaz a véleménye? Mert számomra ez a játék az unalmas pasziánsz. Egy-egy leosztás esetében valahogy mindig úgy éreztem, hogy van egy nyerő stratégia és aki azt megtalálja az mindig nyeri ezt a fajta leosztást. Valószínűleg nincs így, de mégis számomra nagyon automatikus a játék. Nem igazán éreztem egyszer sem izgalmat a játék közben. Egyértelműen jobbnak találom többen játszani mint ketten, de még így sem tudok neki 6-nál több pontot adni.

RATING: 9
So this game is super addicting and plays just great with 2-3 players. The learning curve and sometimes long turns make this not always play as well with 4+ players unless everyone kind of knows what they are doing. The rules were simple enough to also make this a pretty good "Gateway Game" to introduce people into the hobby game world with. I have noticed that currently a lot of the decks seem to be reoccurring because the set itself is pretty vanilla overall between cards. Picked up Seaside, which added a TON of depth to the game. Definitely made it more interesting. I also now have hinterlands and dark ages. It only gets better with each addition. This rating is for Dominion as a whole.

RATING: 10
Excellent presentation and components. Rules are very easy to understand and to be taught to new players. The surprisingly simple mechanics provide fluent gameplay, while the nicely illustrated cards add atmosphere. Good balance between luck and strategy, so that even first time players can win the game (if not up against hardcore gamers, of course).
Only drawback: With only the core rules interaction between the players is lacking. Therefore adding one or more of the expansions is highly recommended.

Summary: One of my all time favourites!

RATING: 6
Not enough player interaction, the card effects in the base game are too tame for my tastes, and almost zero tactical play. "Gameplay" basically consists of players testing their preset strategies against each other and seeing which one comes out on top. This is improved only slightly in expansions. Can still be a fun relaxing game to play though, but it feels more like a nice, satisfying stretch of my arms than an absorbing game. And still better than most of the copycats.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I use a reverse drafting system for setup using the blue random card setup deck.
1> Deal each player 6 of the blue cards
2> Randomly draw additional card(s) face up in the middle. 1 card for a 3 player game and 2 cards for a 4 player game.
3> Each player will look at the 6 cards and pick one to remove from the game then pass their remaining hand to the person to the left.
4> Repeat until each person has 3 cards remaining in a 3 player game or 2 cards remaining in a 4 player game.
5> Everyone reveals whats remaining and that should be the 10 card sets you should be using for the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a great & innovative design.  Appeals to my friends who were drawn to the CCG parallels.  Still light enough to play and enjoy with family.

New expansions continue to add depth with new mechanics such as Events and Landmarks that can totally change the game.  It's my all-time #1 game and nothing else comes close.)

RATING: 8
I love this game for many reasons, and hope to defend my high score here.  For one, I love deck building games.  For two, even non-gamers love this game.  For three, it isn't so serious that everyone around the table is concentrating to the point of ignoring everyone else and not talking amongst themselves.  Quite the opposite in fact.  You can hang out, have fun, and carry on conversations with people without interrupting the flow of the game.

Easy to learn, but hard to master.  Numerous card combination possibilities and personal strategies.  Very good game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not the best game ever, but certainly the one I have played the most. It's extremely replayable, has just the right amount of luck, and I can fit at least two games into a lunch hour.

Dropped 10->8. Still a great game, but substitutes obnoxious "take that" mechanics for real interaction. Attacking other players not only hurts their score (which is fine), but also makes the game more boring by robbing them of meaningful decisions (which sucks). Loses a little steam every time I play it.

Hint for people looking to make another deck-building game: instead of tacking on chrome and lame new currency types (like Thunderstone), how about improving the interaction a bit? Think of some cards that will encourage players to work together for a while before stabbing each other in the back. I'm convinced that it can be done.

Dropped again to a 7. An average game with some nice advantages and irritating disadvantages. Certainly got my money's worth out of it, but I won't be pulling it out very often.

The plummet continues, after a long session of flipping curses and waiting ten minutes for my chance to flip a few more. This game can really suck. If everyone draws 4/3 at the start and buys a militia, I'd rather be playing Monopoly. It's really that boring.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Base game only

Good things first: I like the idea of building your deck while playing and I don't mind the shuffling at all. It's a fast game too, which I like.

The bad: I think the theme is pretty weak. I never feel like i'm building a dominion. How can a bunch of Smithy's, villages, thiefs and a lot of gold constitute the strongest dominion? And buying estates, dutches and Provinces never feels like buying land, but just VP's (besides, who wants to BUY land? I want to conquer it)

I know that most games can be boiled down to getting the most VP, but a good game (in my opinion) hides this simple fact behind a great theme and storytelling. Dominion, at this point, fails to do that. 

Also, there is almost no player interaction. Just a couple of cards in the entire base-set can directly affect you opponents hand or deck, but most of the time it doesn't matter what the other players do. You just have to watch what cards are bought. Very much a solitare game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Once upon a time in the BGG forums I was told "not to listen when people water it down to a 'deck-building game'" and rather that Dominion is "really an amazing study in probability and risk-reward."

Garbage. Dominion is a game where you build a deck. You never actually get to play your deck - not in an interactive CCG sense, at least - but you have ample time to refine the snot out of it. Then the game is over.

I think it's a brilliant mechanic, but there's so much more that could've been done here. The theme, which begins and ends with some medieval-y artwork on the cards, is laughably blase and arguably nonexistant; there's nothing to disguise Dominion as anything other than a race for victory points. Moreover, there's almost no player interaction involved, and the few cards that affect other players' hands have a minimal net effect on the game. I simply can't see how people are catching the CCG vibe here as basically every CCG I've every played or read about involves sustained direct confrontation between players. Yeah, you build a deck. So what?

Come on, Dominion. You can do better than this!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty addictive and innovative card game that centers around real-time deck building.  My rating will probably go up when the inevitable expansions begin to emerge.  
My biggest issue is that there's very little player interaction--an issue that could easily be fixed with an expansion that focused solely on battle cards.  There are cards that can "harm" other players, but there's no reason not to play them.  Some elements of risk need to be introduced into the system before it can truly be considered a great game.
UPDATE:  After 40 plays, I'll amend my comments to say that this is actually a great game, but that it could be improved by better attack dynamics.  I haven't played Intrigue or Seaside, but I look forward to checking them out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Quick and fun, but deceptively deep.  Seeing how the various cards work together is far more important that seeing what they do individually, and since the available combinations can change each game, the replay potential is huge.

I bought this looking for another quick filler game, something to play in 30 mins or less.  It's not, because you always wind up playing four games in a row.

Mayday Euro Game Card Sleeves should just ship standard with this game.  They make the shuffling a breeze.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The pioneer in the deck building and drafting genre, it is unfortunately becoming dated as the field of similar games is continually refined and updated. While still fun to dust off and play occasionally, it does suffer from the fact there are a few very core strategies that will win you the game a majority of the time. 

In a group of experienced Dominion players, it largely comes down to draw luck and a race to the finish. That plus its lack of engaging player interaction really holds this title back from achieving a timeless status.

Unfortunately it has largely joined the ranks of Munchkin and Catan for our group: beloved classics and valuable introductions to the board game culture, but too tired and dated to see continual play in a modern field of game choices.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Originating deck building counts for something, but it quickly becomes bland and without interesting decisions.

RATING: 7
Fast and fun. Everyone I introduce it to enjoys it. It's less a game and more of a system, which means you'll be buying expansions. That said, the base set is the best way to learn. On its own, it's fun, but replayability increases with each expansion. Admittedly, there's not a lot of interaction, and that hurts the game somewhat, but I like it anyway. 

Puzzle Strike is the better deck-builder, but Dominion is (ironically) more of a puzzle, and that works better for people who prefer to do their own thing unimpeded by direct interference. I play with enough people like that to keep it around.

RATING: 10
Brilliant deck building card game. Simple and fast to play with considerable strategic elements to consider due to the many different cards and combinations. The transition from play building to points collection is key and it can be very easy to misjudge or have a poor choice of disparate actions, with a corresponding crash'n'burn result. Fast game and my wife likes it. Expansions keep it fresh.

RATING: 9.8
Very, very good. I like to plan, this rewards planing and good timeing. I don't like the timeing so much, I'd rather ... a set number of turn maybe. But people keep talking about Dominion 'clones' -- like they are just a re-theme of this game. NO! Noting is as good as this, this is pure. There is a trade off you see, more points in hand means fewer 'useful' cards in hand, forcing one to time the ending tightly, or loose. The close add ... junk. A board, and you can have points on the board, but then there is no strategic trade off, so the game is not as good. Dominion, very good ... but the theme is lacking, I wish there were 'clones' I'd probably like them. Though the theme doesn't really matter.

I suggest you try it yourself

Pushed the rate down to a five because this game is becoming obsolete after playing it not more than half a dozen times. Its hype doesn't make sense, the game is boring at some point. You could also play it without even looking at what you're doing and you may win!

Final edit:
And the winner is.... the player who can get 8 coins more often. It's not about building your deck or anything like it's all about getting those coins! 

This game has nice ideas but all in all it doesn't work for me. Plus I don't think that it deserves such a hype. 

PS: One of the things I hate to do is shuffling cards. A game that makes me do that all the time doesn't diserve much of my attention.
