=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
i play online and still enjoy it, though i do feel like i wasted a bunch of time afterward.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
An interesting game - it has hundreds of cards compared to other games (500 to be precise!). I purchase the "Big Box" version which included alchemy and prosperity in it as well. I was surprised excited when I opened the book due to the sheer amount of cards found in it.

The game overall is simply a deck building game without you having to go to the store and buying booster packs to build your deck. However like many card games (take Magic The Gathering for example as it was based off that game), many cards seem slightly ... ridiculous. While I do like how the game allowing you "randomize" which 10 kingdom cards that will be part of the game - it seems some cards are a bit too strong once you've figured out how to chain it with other cards.

Cards, particularly ones that let you give more actions seem to allow many players to constantly chain their actions, making them able to play a ridiculous amount of cards in one turn. While some people argue that all the cards are of equal power (call me n00b if you wish), I find some cards a bit too strong.

What I do like is the overall idea of the game, you are building your deck (kingdom) in a simple manner. The game can easily be taught almost instantaneously (explain the "ABC" rule - action, buy, and cleanup phases). The game is much easier to learn as compared to 7 Wonders in my opinion (and easier to explain!) however I still greatly prefer 7 Wonders over this.

Worst part of the game? The constant shuffling you have to do which will require you to buy plastic sleeves :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Picked this up because of how high it ranks on BGG.  Played a dozen or so hands of fake Dominion on my iPhone, and at this point I'm not sure if this game is for me.

7/23/11 - my only experience has still been limited to playing Battle of Gundabad, but I'm getting more into the game as a result.  Ascension is sort of losing my interest, and Dominion/BoG seems to offer a bit more complexity.

January 2012 -- FINALLY brought this to the table with two friends, and they both love the game.  Definitely much more fun with the "screw you" attack decks in the mix.

February 2012 -- Been playing once or twice a week for the past few weeks with the same two buddies.  We're really getting into it, going for a (mostly) random draw from the four sets I currently own.  Having a great time.

RATING: 7
Played about 50 games on BSW.  Usually I don't play board games online, I find it ruins them. This one is an exception.  It plays fast and, with my opponent in the same room, I get the social interaction without the shuffling. We found it very easy to learn. I agree that this would work as a gateway game for some new gamers.
I rate Dominion a 7.5 because although it's a good game I'm usually happy to play, I'm not as wild about it as others.  After 50 games, a play feels either samey or that I should "try a strategy for the heck of it".  Some random sets prove interesting, others not, but playing the same sets more than twice doesn't seem rewarding.
The game now feels like a filler, and doesn't rate as one of my top games - I like'em a bit meatier, like  Race for the Galaxy, or a bit more varied in activity, like Yspahan, or a bit more brain-burning, like Zertz.

RATING: 6
[i]Gameplay depth[/i] [b]7[/b]
[i]Immersiveness[/i] [b]3[/b]
[i]Elegance[/i] [b]8[/b]
[i]Aesthetics[/i] [b]7[/b]

If games were measured by how much they live up to their hype, I would hereby nominate Dominion for being the worst game in existence. I just don't understand why many people think this game is awesome. I find the deck-building concept quite interesting and appealing, but unfortunately that is all there is. Dominion feels like an idea to base a game on, rather than a complete game. It does play smooth and fast, and I don't even really mind the notorious shuffling all that much, but those traits only really matter when you actually want to play it. Which I don't. Dominion is by far the most disappointing game I've played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After several dozen plays, I'm going to adjust my rating to a 10. It's still amazingly replayable and addictive, and doesn't seem to get stale. More variety (with Intrigue) is of course better, but even with only 25 kingdom cards, I can't see myself tiring of Dominion any time soon.
------------------------

Pretty addictive, especially on BSW, where you don't need to shuffle. I prefer the random setup, where you have to find a different combo each time to win. There are lots of combos to explore, but I have the feeling that only a few are really effective. So for the long term, I fear that players of equal (high) experience will tend to make the same choices which cards to buy, so that the shuffle will to a high extent will determine the winner. But I'm happy to be proven wrong. In any case, that's not a stage I have come close to yet.

People keep comparing this with Race for the Galaxy. I can see why, but Dominion doesn't come close to Race in terms of variabilty, versatility and replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was one of the first games we got when we got into the hobby -- we loved how unique and different it was, but it wore out its welcome relatively quickly.  I've heard it described as a mechanic without a game, and I have to kind of agree.  There's zero theme (and we're pretty forgiving about lack of theme), and no player interaction (yes, there are the attack cards, but we don't like that dynamic -- they might give you a little boost in one turn, but overall I don't think they really add to the game, and are just generally nasty to play).  Trains: Rising Sun takes Dominion and turns it into a more interesting, more interactive, more thematic, fuller and therefore more fun game.

RATING: 6
As the original deck-builder, all new iterations of the genre will be compared to Dominion, and while some bring new ideas to the genre, this game still stands the test of time.  That being said, as with most builders, there is an optimal strategy for churning cards into resources, into points, and the novelty of the game eventually relies on obtaining new expansions to add the base game.  I have few enough plays of this game, so using different combinations of cards in the offer is still unique, but I don't know how often this will make it to the game table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The good: highly flexible system with many potential routes to victory and wildly variable starting cards.  The rapidity with which you go through your deck mitigates many luck of the draw issues (really the "feel" of the luck, since that luck will often make the win difference since the scores between competent players will be so close).  Every expansion builds tremendously on the possibilities.

The bad: it is mostly solitaire in that you do not play specifically to thwart the other players.  For instance if you had a better card to play to help your progress, you wouldn't choose to not play it in order to play a militia card, simply because you saw two players use their moats for card draws during the same round already.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Played this several years ago shortly after it came out. It stuck in my memory as good, but not up to the hype at the time. I got a copy through a math trade and it's about how I remember it. Glad I picked it up, but also glad I traded instead of bought.

It's shorter than most of my other games, which is good because we have an abundance of long games in the house. The fact that it's different every time you play is nice, but some of the less strategic players aren't as adaptable. I'm thinking we'll probably just use the suggested decks most of the time...

Expansions... maybe pick up one of the big expansions, but I see this going to way of Munchkin: too many expansions ruins the game.

**EDIT** I'm bumping this to an 8, based on how it has stood up over time. People still want to pull this out, even though "Joe always wins" (totally not true).

RATING: 6.5
Wow!!  I'm really very shocked on 2 accounts: this is a card game that I actually enjoy, and all the BGG hype is actually warranted!  I played this game for the first time VERY reluctantly, but after I played once I didn't want to stop!  I just hope that the enjoyment holds up to repeat plays, but judging by the nearly endless combination of cards that can be played, I don't expect this to be much of a problem.  Sure it's not perfect - the artwork on the cards is only mildly interesting, the user-created disks look much more practical than the constant shuffling, and the box seems rather huge for a card game (even if it does have 500 cards), - but it's fun game that has obviously been very extensively playtested, and my wife loves it.  All in all, my first "deck building" game was definitely a success!  Game design: 4/5  Personal enjoyment: 2.5/5  Total: 6.5/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Note that these comments refer to Dominion as a whole -- my understanding is that the cards were designed at the same time but rationed out as "expansions" for commercial reasons. There are some additional comments under specific expansions. Rating for the base game alone is perhaps 6/10 or lower. These comments also refer to Dominion as played very quickly: it is best in electronic form and best if games take less than 15 minutes. Rating for play with a physical copy at the time listed on the box is closer to 2/10.

It's a truly amazing design. It's one of those elegant games that just seems so streamlined and perfect that it deserves to be a classic -- a game that will still be played in a hundred years. It's varied and quick; luck of the draw matters, but can be mitigated by deck management. There are clear strategies. It's easily expandable and the expansions make it more interesting. 

The more I play it, the more I appreciate the way different card sets require subtly different strategies -- one strategy that is dominant with one set is ruined by a counter present in another.

It's a curious sort of design, too. In the context of recent discussions over the brokenness of A Few Acres of Snow, it struck me that Dominion is basically broken by design: many Kingdom sets have a dominant strategy; the "game" is in recognizing and executing that strategy. But while many individual games of Dominion may be grossly unbalanced, the variety makes it forgivable.

The real issue is that it strikes a very poor balance been depth and time commitment. It should be a tremendous filler, but setup time is far, far too long and fiddly. Some pathological setups (particularly involving many attack cards) are guaranteed to drag on long after the fun has worn off. Even slight AP is crippling -- if a player takes more than 2 seconds of their turn to think then they are doing it wrong.

The various electronic versions (isotropic, Androminion etc.) are far superior; even an electronic version against an AI is better than playing in person.

I want to rate it higher, but I can't, because I have no interest in playing a physical copy ever again. The ratio between decisions and the physical manipulation of components (drafting, shuffling etc.) is too skewed towards the part that feels like work.

Ratings history: 6 -> 7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Ok game, it's quick, fun and easy to grasp in a few games, although realizing the card synergies takes a while more; and it doesn't overstay its welcome. That said, I am not sure I would like to play more than once in a while because it is a bit too abstract for my liking. I am usually a sucker for expansions, but I feel for a casual approach the base game is enough for me.

Also, I prefer the more random approach of Ascension, in which you don't know in advance what cards will be available, this helps the game feel less scripted and more open.

Expansions: Black Market, Envoy

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[RGG 2009 edition] {Medieval; deck-building; scalable} There is so much hype about Dominion that I can't help getting it.  Its core mechanic is unique -- building decks during the game.  It allows both tactical and strategic plays.  Luck is not very strong.  It's more essential to manage the hand properly.  Replayability is very good due to the different combination of kingdom cards.  I am a little bit concerned about the balance of cards.  Depends on card combination, player interaction may be weak.  Keep on shuffling the cards is quite tiresome.  Nonetheless, it's a good and solid game.

The artwork of the game scares me.  It's ugly!  Why gold is not gold, silver is not silver and copper is not copper.  Using dull number on the cards is scary.

This is very great attempt for first-time designer.  Keep up the good work, Donald!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great.  Nearly endless variety of games based on combinations of cards that can be chosen for set.  On the app, this is a quick game.  In person, it can drag on quite a bit if you have some slower plays due to sequential nature of play, action stacking, and constant reshuffling.

RATING: 10
I've been lucky enough to be in on some of the later, near-final-build playtesting (read: playing and going "I really don't have any complaints except that I can't buy it yet") of this game, and I predict it will be an incredibly hot item toward the end of the year.  If you take attempting to build a really good deck for a CCG, and make an awesome game around that feeling, you get Dominion.  I've only played three-player games of it, but I assume that two and four work just as well.  Plays in about 20-30 minutes, generally, except that you can never play just one game of it.  Not quite a 10 in my book yet, I'm reserving final judgment for when I've played the final build, but for right now I'm incredibly impressed with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The first deck builder i know of, and probably the first ever.

Even if it isn't i'm sure that it has set the trend and paved the road for all others.

This base game only, has some unbalanced cards, but with only 1 ban (smithy) the game is pretty enjoyable.

I really love the fact that you need to balance every little thing in the deck you build, that being:
1. how much cards you have
2. how many actions you are left in each hand
3. how much gold you have
4. how many victory cards you have
5. 1-4 at approximate time of finishing the game :D

That all makes your head explode, and you can always blame it on the luck :D so all in all it is very interesting
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Geniale e innovativo gioco di carte, rigorosamente non collezionabili a differenza di altri prodotti, che ha saputo rivoluzionare il genere. E il meglio è che il gioco si impara in 5 minuti! Dominion, un gioco che non annoia mai e che riesce a catturare grandi e piccoli giocatori.

Contenuti:
500 carte

RATING: 6.5
I have played a fair amount of the Dominion base set and less of the various expansions, so my rating is for the base game only (my friends who love the game insist it's much better as you add in more expansion cards). I'll give this game a ton of credit for the deckbuilding mechanic which I love, but the base set has a ton of problems once you start to get better at it. Certain cards are too good for their costs and certain kingdoms have fairly degenerate strategies.

I don't really want to spend $200 to get all the expansions and everything that allegedly improve on my complaints so I wish somebody would put together a "greatest hits" version of the game or something that results in the best experience for a reasonable price.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The deckbuilding game.

I've marked it down because there are certain cards (village and chapel for example) that are just too strong for what they cost and you should get as many in your deck as you can.  

In addition to this the cost of cards is very important, which forces you to never have too many 5 and 6 cost cards avaialbe each game.  This basically means that the replayability isn't as high as it would seem.

It's a good game and I've played it a lot.

RATING: 7
Ideally, a game should strive for players to describe it as "easy to learn, lifetime to master". Dominion's brilliantly streamlined deck-building and plentiful expansions bring it as close to embodying that description as any game ever designed.

Having said that, I wouldn't start with the base game. I would advise new players to get Intrigue first, and expand from there.

RATING: 8
Over a year ago I tried to introduce my 8 year old son to Thunderstone because I thought he would like the theme.  I tried to explain what the game was about and he wasn't interested in trying a card game.  He wanted a game with mini's!

My wife wanted to play Dominion and even though it is the most popular game at our meet up's, she couldn't get into a game.  I played it and after the game I wasn't sure what the big deal was.  I felt that if I never played Dominion again I wouldn't miss it.

I was able to trade for a copy of the game for my wife to try.  It's short and I will play just about any game if my wife likes it.  

Surprise, surprise,  not only did my wife like it but my Zombicide loving son really liked it.  It appeals to his capitalist nature.  After a few more plays I  like it too.  It is fun to look at all of the cards and try to create a strategy to get your engine going.  

After about 10 plays I was kind of bored but Dominion does have a lot of expansion to increase variety.

RATING: 8.5
The basic mechanic is innovative and promising. While luck can be a big factor, victory is usually achieved by the player who came up with the best idea of what to do with the available kingdom cards.
Sometimes the set of kingdom cards (randomly) chosen for a game can be rather one-sided. Some card combinations are obvious strategies while others are hardly good in combination with the other available cards.
It's a great game overall though!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A good strategy game with excellent depth. It has a few flaws: you need the expansions to make the game really shine, and a lot of the cards in the base set could have been made stronger. Despite that, Dominion is an excellent expandable game that I could play over and over again. It's really most of the fun of a CCG, squeezed into a eurogame box. 

Note: Rating is for the entire system, not the base game. I find that Intrigue and Seaside have more interesting cards overall - you can actually skip the base game.

RATING: 6
I used to rate Dominion an 8, but I've been forced to drop that because the game now bores me to tears.  There is almost nothing to do when it's not your turn unless there are a lot of attacks in play.  When those are in play, they make the game unnecessarily long.  Add that up and it just ruins the game for me.  Don't even get me started on curses.  It's just too long for what it is.

RATING: 9
father of deck building games

RATING: 10
I love this game.  It has cards you can hold in your hand.  It moves quickly and you can talk lots of shit while you play.  It has infinite combinations.  I win a lot.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The granddaddy of the deck builders! This game is easy to pick up. Play one action, buy one card. Until you buy a card that gives you another action, or a buy, or lets you draw another card, which might give you another action, or another coin (you see where this is going.) The rotating cards in the base set alone allow for amazing replayability. Start adding expansions and you will never play the same game twice unless you choose to do so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
You will need an expansion or two, but it will be worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is a game for a game collector really.
I cant see why some people are so entusiastic about this game. The mechanic is pretty dull, and the special cards dont add much to make the mechanic any more interesting.
It suits those who like to feel they are surreptiously stabbing opponents in the back.
I'm not saying there is not a game to be played, but one doesn't seem to have been on a Gaming Journey after playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A well thought out game. It offers the player numerous decisions and there are several strategies that can be adopted. There's also a lot of variety here due mainly to the different card combinations that the game offers (this will increase greatly with future expansions providing the game with a huge amount of replay value) and virtualy every game is different. I personally don't feel as though I interact with this game quite as much as other similar games (i.e. card based) but there's a real simplicity to the gameplay, which means that it can be used as an excellent gateway game for novice gamers. The one problem I have with it however is the amount of randomness generated by continually having to discard your hand and re-draw cards. Personally I prefer games it which you have a little more control over the decisions you're faced with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Laura's Rank (3/15) – 4.5 out of 5. Unique mechanic. Easy to teach. Tons of replayability because of the different combinations. Light enough to allow table talk without really drastically affecting strategy.

Ryan's Rank (3/15) – 4.5 out of 5. This is such an easy game to get to the table. It's fun, it's quick, it can have some strategic depth with the different cards. I just really like it.

Overall Rank (3/15) – 9 out of 10

It plays quickly, and I really enjoy the experience.  The deck construction plan, slow execution and tweaking, as well as watching it play out hand to hand is just delicious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Maybe there is too little player interaction, but once you get the hang of the strategy it's interesting to see how you can curve statistics in your favor.

I play this 2-player only and a turn takes about 20 seconds if you really think it over.
Compared to many other games out there there is very little tendency for analysis paralysis, because you usually make a plan to begin with and stick to it.

It's a good game, although a little light compared to Race for the Galaxy and Call of Cthulhu, but its ease of play is a big plus when you can't muster the mental resources for an hour of brain burning and just want a game where you slap some cards on the table.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Owned by Trevor and Al
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This quickly became one of my favorite games.  The base set is pretty vanilla, but the expansions are fantastic.  

The game is mostly strategical with just the right amount of luck tossed in.  It scales great from 2 to 4 players, but more than that and the game can take too long.  Most games I play finish within 30 mins, which means it makes several appearances each game night.

RATING: 8
Huge crush on Dominion right now. Admittedly, if I sat down with just one set of 10 cards, I'd complain that this game was boring after about three plays. But since the possible cards are always changing, this is never a problem.

In fact, the joy of the game is that you're constantly learning something new, not really that the game itself is brilliant. It's like cracking open a new box every single time and playing a brand new game. Love it.

This rating could go down to 7ish if I lose that constant new game feel, but up to 10 if it sticks around for 15 or so more plays.

RATING: 6
Fantastic, innovative (original?) deck building mechanic. The rest of the choices made in developing this game are just bad. The theme what is it? I dunno something vaguely medieval. Victory pts? Blech! Even worse having this tableau of cards face up, so everyone knows what you're doing and its a race to do it. Not enuf cards at the start; shuffling 10 cards is lame. The worst is the default strategy of buying Province when possible, then Gold when possible, then silver. On the good side; does not overstay it's welcome, provides a nice social setting, it's fun. I hate this game mainly for it's poor development choices; on the creative side it has one Great mechanic. So I am torn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
tl;dr: holds up

I've never been one to go all in on Dominion. I like the concept, but I also felt like it was something that would be enjoyed best when not played to death. I also never got any other boxes but the base set. I don't play it a lot, but I recently got to play it again after a 7 year period of not playing it. And it still holds up. The base mechanism is just so rock solid it's not surprising it has been copied so many times. With all the variety of cards in the base set, there is already a lot of play value there, and I don't need to own every single card available.
I'm personally not a fan of the attack cards, I feel like most of them just make the game longer and this game is best when it takes about 30 to 45 minutes.
I will be enjoying this game for years to come, just very sparingly :)

Rating: 7.5/10
BGG scale: 7/10

RATING: 8
I played collectible card games before and therefore am familiar with the concept of deck-building. Finding the deck-building process turned into a game on its own was a nice idea - and actually a wonder nobody thought of that before.
The game works very well and I enjoy playing it relatively regularly - but for a higher rating, it needs far more player interaction.
Player interaction is an important component in collectible card games, and it's a shame you don't see that much of it in Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't think I'm quite as enamored with this as some people around me are.  Mostly to me, it seems like a race to the province cards.  Build an engine that lets you usually buy one of those a turn, and repeat until they are gone, see if you won.  More plays would probably flesh this out, but most strategies basically seem to be variants as to the best way to get 8 gold in your hand a turn.

I agree with Marshall, I thought my group needed a copy, so I got it, but I really wish "someone else" owned it.

Edit: In the end, I got rid of it.  Not because everyone in the group started to not like it, but because I didn't want to play the game, and if it was on the shelf, people would suggest it.  Now, if they want to play it, they can get a copy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.8
I somehow just don't like it.

- bad artworks and card design, odd theme/tropes
- combo/engine/deck builder isn't my thing (It's odd for board games and reminds too much of MTG while looking bad in comparison.)
- not much player interaction
- heavily card-based (sleeves necessary)
- repetitive gameplay
- theme absent
- expensive (for just cards)

If you ask me, it's just shuffling cards.

update:Most már elég sokat(?) játszottam vele (alap és intrika)  és csalódtam benne:( Egész egyszerűen az akció lapoknak alig van lényeges szerepe. RATING: 8.5
A fun and easy-to-learn kingdom building game. Everyone starts off with the same amount of money, but each kingdom can progress differently. There are many cards to buy and ways to achieve the winning goal. Each game will use 10 Kingdom decks, and the base game has 25 Kingdom decks to use. So each game will require a different approach to winning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When I first played Dominion, I intensely hated it. I felt like the other players were not helping me learn the game, and were using that against me to win.  Years later from that experience, I am SO happy I went back to this game.  It is likely my favorite all time game.  

Dominion is a 'deck-building' game. Your goal is to buy cards to put into your deck that allow you to more effectively buy point cards.  The game mechanics are remarkably basic, and can be taught in seconds.  The depth of play has to do with how different cards augment the basic things you can do with your cards.  The rules are so wildly varied and dynamic that it is possible to play this game hundreds of times without playing with the same set of 10 action cards.  There is some player interaction with cards that do things to other players, but for the most part it is a race to the highest score.  If you like very high player interaction, this game is not the best.  That being said.........

Play this game!  As a base set, the cards in this box are simple and straightforward.  They are great to start playing with, and don't take a lot to figure out.  The expansions add that depth once you are used to the mechanics and basic interactions of the game.  Things never feel old and you can fit 2-3 rounds of Dominion comfortably in an evening of play.  In my opinion, the game itself plays best with 3 players, but plays refreshingly fast with 2 players and has more opportunity with interaction with 4 players.  

Why did I give this a 9 and other Dominion sets 10?  Simply put, the expansion sets make this game.  The card interactions are simply mind boggling and endlessly entertaining.  This set is a simple starter kit to get you ready for the delicious variety that comes with the greater scope of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A uniquie card drafting game with a well working deck building mechanism
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2015 20x5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
19-Nov-08: Can see why this appeals to Magic players who are into Deck Construction. It took a while for the card actions to sink in, and I still find it hard to find synergies with the cards, apart from the simple 'Get cards that give you more Gold and Actions'. So far, I feel it's a game where you try to better your chances to draw 8+ gold with 5 cards. Provinces cost 8 Gold, so if you're the first to get to the point where you can buy at least 1 Province per turn, you've effectively won the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Still need more plays before I can give a definitive review. I only have the base set, but I've enjoyed it when I play it. I don't usually like to suggest it, though, because it seems like it takes a long while to set up and tear down. Would rather play something quicker like Ascension or Hero/Star Realms.

One thing that I really appreciate is the victory point mechanic, wherein victory points are added to the player deck, thus diluting it with important but inert cards. It's a clever way to slow down the first place player, and discourages one person from snapping up all of the cheap VPs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great, easy-to-play game. Shows, in contrast to Race for the Galaxy, that complexity doesn't have to be accompanied by confusion. Vaguely reminds me of Goa, due to the advantage of multiple actions. Very replayable.

It seems like a majority of games need the same tactic. Buy a province, gold, or silver if you can. Rinse, repeat. Some cards make you change that tactic, but not that many in the basic set--many in the expansions.

An absolutely [b]superb[/b] box tray! A place for every deck of cards, stored vertically so they're easy to grab and can't slid out with the box top on. (Still, once you get a couple expansions, you're looking for something more compact. Best solution I've seen: every deck in a bag.)

But why in the world aren't gold cards gold, silver cards silver, and copper cards copper????
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of the original deck builders, good, innovative, and fun.  Building a deck and having a magic like ccg feel in a living card game style really is a winning combo for this game.  The theme is alright, perhaps dry and generic, but this game has always been more about the mechanics of deck building anyhow.  The number of decisions and yet simplicity of rules make for a very dense amount of strategy in a simple to explain game.

One thing I would mention is to not play this with experienced players or play it with lots of players, both are extremely painful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was starting to worry some of my regular gamers were going to start grinding up the cards and shooting them up intravenously.  It's a unique take on deck building, which is oddly the actual mechanic of the game.  Dominion's play is a unique look at constructing a deck of cards that actually works quite well and inspires some nostalgia of CCG days in my youth.  I love the design and system as well as the choice making nature of it.  I'm also quite fond of the the replayability through various selections of card types and the fact that it seems well balanced.

RATING: 6

It offers a surprising amount of variety, and I've gotten non-gamers to enjoy this. It doesn't, however, have real long-term staying power. I played it lots and with lots of different groups for about three years off-and-on. Less after that. Almost never now (haven't in at least three years). I would play it again (I'll have forgotten enough that it won't be obvious from the setup what everyone will do), but it will never be a weekly thing like it could have been in 2008/2009. I probably won't get rid of it, though. Well, not yet.

RATING: 7.5
SEPT 2014 - NOTE: My rating is for the BASE game ONLY. I have ALL the expansions and a custom wood box. It needs it when you have everything. My rating for Dominion overall with ALL expansions together is probably 8.5 - I still haven't gotten tired of it with all the possible combinations of different cards. I'm guessing I *still* haven't played EVERY card available, but I'm not sure.

My son has been very active in wanting to play Dominion lately and I haven't balked at all!
-----------------------------
APR 2009 - Played the Black Market and Envoy promo cards. I like both cards. Black Market adds the ability to get a card that the other person won't be able to get which is great. Envoy lets you draw 4 more cards into your hand. Both are powerful to a point, but not overwhelmingly so as I first thought they would be. 
------------------------------
APR 2009 - Played with my 8 yr old daughter and she really liked it. However, she didn't quite get the idea of chaining cards together initially. After explaining it a couple of times I think she'll really get it soon. I still enjoyed playing and am looking forward to trying some of the other Kingdoms.
------------------------------------------------
JAN 2009 - First time playing this I really had a great time. The person I played with wasn't initially confrontational with the basic setup kingdom cards. So, when I started playing Militia and he didn't have any moats, it really started hurting his hands. He still was initially successful at getting many VP cards including Province cards, but I made a strong comeback and nearly won.

I love the ability to chain cards together - this is a feature similar to what you can do in Pillars of the Earth which I also really liked.

RATING: 7
The game is fun, but in any one game between two similarly skilled players, luck will determine who wins in a big way.

You know what really turns me off this game?  I really like games that have lots of cards which give you interesting powers, which this has, but too often the optimal strategy in a given setup is to buy 1 or 2 action cards.  Combos are fun, but rarely do they win against a streamlined strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Really an interesting and unique system. Multiple sets of cards which players will slowly "draft" - incorporating into their individual decks. Each deck evolves until the player is able to use their deck for scoring. Quick playing (though slow to setup and pickup). A good variety of cards makes each game unique and each has a slightly different flavor.

UPDATE: After playing the "successor" to this style of game - Thunderstone - I'm dropping my rating of Dominion. Yes, the mechanic is unique, but ultimately this game is pretty boring. It is a build an economic engine game - the choices each turn are fairly limited and repetitive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Solid game of deck building that I still find clever. A bit too solitaire-ish for my tastes overall, and the "just grab money" strategy is a bit too inviting with the basic set. On the other hand, with the expansions, I have a problem with the elaborate, often beautiful combinations that experienced players string together. As with many recent games that offer a lot of different cards (or tiles, or buildings, or powers, etc.), I have the suspicion that I'd be better off studying everything ahead of time -- but the game nonetheless forces me to search for combinations on the fly. This is the nature of deck building games, but it's not an experience that will ever appeal to me in more than a passing way. Compare to Magic, for example, where everyone constructs a deck ahead of time, and has the opportunity to complete most of the "work" ahead of time. Play then becomes mostly about creative use of cards. That said, I still find the basic Dominion set an enjoyable game from time to time, especially with more casual players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Whole family loves this one.

The way the victory points clog up your deck is excellent.  The game has billions of starting combinations, so this one looks to be pretty replayable.

RATING: 6
The mechanism is great. However, the base game leaves me cold. If Seaside and Intrigue are use, I would rate it a 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
I question the dedication of those who love this game yet 'humbly admit' that the theme is lacking. No, I say. Dominion has one of the best themes of any game I've ever played. The idea that we, as players, are recruiting agents of dominance into our repertoire whether it be militia, certain types of buildings and establishments, members of the occult, even simply money, all of which we are using as a selection of cronies to do our bidding and win dominance over the land oozes forth through the gameplay. The game moves quickly, the mechanics are brilliantly strategic and luck can be fairly well mitigated as you streamline your deck (engine). It is a closed system, making gameplay fair. There is a minor balancing issue in terms of advantage for first player, and possibly the game should be split into rounds (and therefore the game only ends at the end of a round once conditions have been met) but still, it can be pretty tight. A marvel to study strategically, much like Chess in it's variation yet tightness as a closed system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Too much of an engine builder and players generally use the same strategy. Prefer Puzzle Strike as it has so much more player interaction.

RATING: 9
After playing so many different games these past years, I was surprised that some game can really make an impression with a new and clever mechanism. Dominion did that. Really good. There's quite a bit of luck in the draws, do the 3's and 2's you bought come up at same time so that you can buy one of the bigger value cards or money card or points. It's deck-building, yeah, and you should optimize your deck to the best you can - but there's still luck, say what you will. Still, Dominion is enjoyable little romp I can play whenever suggested.

RATING: 10
I was first introduced to Dominion a year ago by my college fairing younger brother. Since then, Dominion and its expansions have been a family favorite and go to game. My children (ages 8 and 9) love playing and my wife is always in a competitive mood to play.

We now own the base game and 2 expansions (Alchemy and Seaside) and we play them often (usually 3-4 times a month). As far as re-playability, this game has kept our interest for a year.

This is also a great game for anyone wanting to get into deck builders.

RATING: 8.9
This game seemed to divide our group, with opinions ranging from "it's too random which cards you draw when", through "it's not bad, but I don't get what all the hype is about", right up to "this is awesome". I fall into the latter camp, though I haven't played it nearly enough to judge it properly, especially given the fact that every play is completely different.

Edit: Finally got another game of this in after a long absence, and it seems to be catching on a bit more with our group now. I love the way that every game of it is different. This recent play was rather dominated by the Militia card, with rarely a round played that we weren't mostly down to three cards.

Edit: This has become a firm favourite now, even eclipsing 7 Wonders as our lunchtime game of choice. We've played several games of it in the last few weeks, and I'm beginning to get more of an idea of strategy. I love the game so much, I've even ordered one of the expansions, and our group has bought another. I look forward to finding out how all the new cards affect play.

Edit: Having played this extensively on Isotropic, and subsequently on Goko since Isotropic's untimely demise, this has become more of an addiction than a game to me. The online versions, while lacking some of the fun of handling the real physical cards, have the advantage of removing one of the few downsides of this game - the amount of time it takes to set up and pack away all the cards. The ability to play a deeply skilful and strategic game in something like 10-15 minutes makes this one of my favourite games ever.

RATING: 10
Great game. Instantly went on my short list of top favorites. Long-term replayability? Time will tell, but it looks promising.

If you like lighter euro games, this is a must-have. If you like multi-player solitaire or non-confrontational games, this game works well that way too; just don't play using Attack cards.

At first glance, the game appears way overpriced, if you look only at what you get for components. $30 street price for a little stack of cards? But if you consider enjoyment per dollar, this game is a great buy.

[Updated] After several more plays, my rating goes from 9 to 10. Amazingly good game. Every game is different - even changing out just one of the 10 action cards gives it a different dynamic. The expansions add even more great variety into the mix.

RATING: 6
Interesting and addictive game.  I think one thing about it that I don't like is that all players don't get the same number of turns, giving players earlier in the round a significant advantage, esp near the end of the game when decks are more powerful.

This game is pretty good, but I'm starting to get a little burned out on it.  Then again, 23 plays in one week is still an impressive number of plays!

(Later)Yeah, I'm not that interested in playing much more.  The variability of the cards plus the fact that the game is so short means that there is very little meaningful long-term strategy planning in the game (beyond the randomness of the cards, of course).  Maybe if we played with the same 10 cards repeatedly this wouldn't be an issue, but with switching cards out all of the time, I can't say that I'm all that interested in playing much more.

(Even later)  Played for the first time on BSW yesterday, and I have to say that that's the best way to play the game.  The constant shuffling is avoided, and the game is just smoother that way.  Like it much better on BSW than F2F, though I admit that it's making me interested in playing more F2F, too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:thumbsup: There are great games out there that use deck building to good effect, but if you focus just on the mechanic itself, no other game I know does it better than Dominion. Dominion distills deck building to its purest form and takes it very seriously.
:thumbsup: Fantastic with 2 players. There's little to no downtime with another experienced player.
:thumbsup: The essence of the game is the random setup. Before the game starts, you will evaluate the 10 kingdom cards that players will be able to buy this game, look for synergies, and make a plan how to build the best deck with these cards. It takes the best parts from CCG/LCG deck construction (creativity, variety, card synergy) and condenses it to a much smaller card pool and time frame.
:thumbsup: You get a sense of achievement from building your deck and seeing how you can have progressively stronger turns.
:thumbsup: There's a turning point where you need to decide to stop primarily improving your deck and focus on buying victory point cards. It usually depends on both the strength of your deck and your opponent's deck. It's a fine line, and if you go for victory points too early, you might clog up your deck and be unable to finish the game quickly.
:thumbsup: I love how every additional expansion exponentially increases the overall replayability of the game.
:thumbsup: The variety of different card effects across the expansions is tremendous, and yet everything fits into the gameplay nicely.
:thumbsup: One of the less obvious advantages of Dominion over a CCG/LCG is that as you card pool and options grow, the amount of time and effort required to play the game stays low. You don't need to know and analyze 500 different cards you own to be able to build a deck. You only ever need to consider 10 cards in isolation, and what combination of these particular cards can win you the game.
[b][color=green]------------------------------[/color][/b]
:?block: Artwork style varies and can be a little inconsistent. And although some artwork is really not that great, I think I came to appreciate the scope and variety of different illustrations – there are professions, landscapes, structures, buildings, rooms, people and places. There's also some card art that I like a lot!
:?block: The theme of the game is rather abstracted, but I do like how many cards have names and artwork that capture thematically what the card does in the game.
:?block: There's a lot of shuffling in Dominion, and there's just too many cards for me to be willing to sleeve the entire game and use a faster mash shuffle.
:!block: It can be hard for new players to figure out how to play well, or what playing well even means. It may also take many plays with some expansions to start to fully appreciate Dominion.
[b][color=red]------------------------------[/color][/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played a lot of dominion. Probably a lot more than I have recorded. I really like the deck building. It's also a good gateway game. I've turned non-gamers into gamers with this game.

RATING: 5
Downtime is high. Playing with slower people can be frustrating. Some combos run on forever. When running a combo, decisions won't be placed until you actually draw your cards from the combo. Shuffling takes forever and it's too hard to regulate everyone to shuffle completely. At some point, there's no turning back from a dead strategy and you're milling around till the game ends. Despite all this, I still like it. I have a history of being a MtG deckbuilder. I would build all kinds of funky decks to see how they would come out working. A game based on variably building an efficient deck with a goal to morph it to a totally inefficient slab of points by the time the game ends (which is variable) still has me coming back for more despite the downtime.

Update: Downtime wins. I lose. Not enough thinking past initial setup w/ planned branching. Ends up being a select a strategy then see what happens game. Would rather play many other games at this point.

RATING: 8.5
It's a beautifully designed game.  The custom deck-building from a common pool of cards is my favorite part.  Everyone starts with the same options and has more-or-less, equal access to them, which makes thing competitively balanced.  It also has a well-balanced luck/skill ratio, especially with the discarding options, which let you really specialize your deck, and make it very predictable if you want.  It definitely works best with 2-3 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Deck building and combining card effects much like CCGs, without all the time and money. Not extremely thematic, but it has all the fun of coming up with a deck concept and trying it out (the thing that drew me to Magic) without the same expense and competitive environment.

I'm beginning to think that most of the expansions aren't necessary. After several years, we only play with the base game, Prosperity, and Seaside.

Plays include all owned expansions at the time of the play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I figured that this would be a decent enough game, and one that might wife might like.  She loves it.  Which translates into a sure keeper.

Though I can see how the game might grow a little too mechanical and programmed over many playings, I don't figure to have that problem, as I don't figure to play the game over and over hundreds of times.  I am drifting into the "Hates any game that involves castles" category, as I have just played too many games that involve castles.  And though this game is marginally about castles and kingdom building, it is thoroughly engaging.  

Sleeving the game is another problem.  The cards are OK, though they don't have the longer lasting linen finish.  $45 retail for 500 cards seems a little steep, but I suppose that when you compare that to what it'd cost to really get into a CCG, it's not bad.  Still, I guess I would've liked to have seen a bit more put into the finish on the cards, at least to protect from a bit of wear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The first deck-builder I've ever played, quite by accident, as it turns out. Ran across this game on Amazon and after a quick look, put it low on my Christmas list based mostly on theme. Was sorely disappointed upon going through the box to discover there was no game board and that this was more of card game, along the lines of Magic. Read up on the rules and decided to give it a try with my wife, though I had low expectations. The first game or two were just okay. However, once my wife and I played through all of the recommended sets of cards in the base game and read up on some basic strategies, the game really came alive for us. 

The strategic depth is fantastic, mainly because there are so many various paths to victory in any given game. It's also quite entertaining to observe players adopt various approaches to building their decks and countering the decks of others. The number of completely unique decks which can be built from the same 10 action cards in any given game is quite surprising. The replayability is extremely high, as the number of unique combinations of 10 action cards available per game is simply incredible, and that's just within the base game. I have not played any of the myriad expansions available but they can only serve to increase the appeal and replayability of this game by adding more cards to the, er, shuffle. This game plays fantastically well with 2P, with games lasting about 30 minutes, perfect for an after-supper game or two between my wife and I. I've played several 4P games and they are just as fun, though they can last close to an hour.

The one criticism of the game which I have heard is that players can sometimes feel as if they are simply playing solitaire. My wife and I haven't found this to be a major issue, as the choices one makes when building one's deck often hinge upon the choices of other players. For example, if one or more of my opponents are pursuing a big money strategy and are filling their decks with Silvers and Golds, I would be well served to pick up a Thief or two to take advantage. There are many, many scenarios like this present in the game, to the extent that I have never felt as if I was simply playing solitaire. The one criticism of the game that I do agree with is that there is a lot of shuffling involved, especially early in the game. I would imagine this is true of all DBG's, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Solid and fun.  Easy to teach and play fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Since none of us had played this before, it took a couple of minutes to get how it all worked together.  What suprised us was just how solitaire this game was.  When someone was cleaning up, the others were getting started, or meking decisions.  Only when attack cards come out, or Provinces bought, was much attention payed to the current player.

Overall we all really enjoyed it and are looking forward to playing it again.

RATING: 10
Logging all Dominion plays under this entry.

It's great, and the expansions add an incredible amount of variety.

Update: I would rate the base game about an 8, but as a whole, Dominion is a 10. I've now played most of the major deck-building contenders (DC, Marvel, Ascension, Thunderstone, Trains) and Dominion is still easily the best. Dominion has explored almost every conceivable facet of the deckbuilding genre at this point and I don't see many ways it could be improved. I like that some of those other games let you play all of your cards on a turn, but it's usually easy enough to get extra action in Dominion. Great game, still the best in class.

RATING: 8
For the past year, I've struggled to get my family into my new gaming hobby. For me Dominion has been the answer for several of my most stubborn siblings. A few things make it a spectacular gateway game: 

1. No large, intimidating board or components. 
2. You can sell it as "just a card game." 
3. The "click." For learners, there's usually a moment when it all "clicks" for them. This is a great moment for non-gamers. They'll love it and want it again when you approach them about another game.

Thanks, Dominion. Because of you, I have successfully hooked several members of my stubborn family.
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: gateway, euro, card game, deck building, fast, 2-4 players, engine building, classic[/COLOR]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I own the Zombinion version from the files section and the 9.5 rating is for that version.

For the original Dominion I give a 7.  I am a fan of zombies and zombie games, but that is not the biggest reason why I have rated Zombinion so much higher. (I think the Galaxy Trucker theme posted in the files also works MUCH better than the original).

Dominion's theme is very, very tired.  I am no longer enthused by medieval or renaissance-aged themes set in Europe.  It...has...been...done...to...death.

Update:  Zombinion is still a 9.5 and I still would not want to play Dominion. 

I don't mind the card shuffleing half as much as the setup and take-down. I swear I would play this twice as much if it wasn't such a hassle.   

But even worse, that theme doesn't even work well in the Dominion system.  The game does feel amazingly interactive even though it does have a large solitaire component to it.  And it certainly is dynamic.  The theme should reflect this.  In my opinion the zombie theme does, the kingdom building theme doesn't.

I would much rather play a "Quick Escape" card than a "Bureaucrat" (QE and B are the same action) card.  "Hide" is actually an action and much more visceral than "Library" (same card).

The Dominion system is unique, engaging and fun, but the theme greatly detracts from the gameplay.  

Update: Downgraded to a 9.  I just dislike the setup so much.



Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 2
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 1.25

RATING: 6
This game really is one of my personal gateways -- as a former magic junkie, it got me that MTG fix while showing me what modern board game designs were capable of. That said, it's largely gotten old for me... while I appreciate the variety of decks, I actually dislike that. I'd rather have a game that carefully thought through its interactions and mechanics rather than throwing things in a blender and seeing what comes out (even if what comes out is sometimes really cool in dominion). I'd rather play other things, but appreciate the brilliance of this design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Disappointment definitely played a role in my perception of this game. After hearing so much about Dominion, its great depth and replayability, I finally got it. When I think of depth and replayability in a card game, R4tG is what comes to mind. Dominion's depth is, well, not very deep. So, if you like the "depth" and "replayability" of Lost Cities (blech!), then maybe this is for you. Don't get me wrong, I don't hate this game. I see some value in it and I will play it more in the future, but it just manages a 6 for me (I had originally rated it at 5.5. Perhaps this will go up a little more). 

I feel like most of the strategy is decided in the beginning and there aren't very many meaningful decisions during the game. I do see a lot of potential. The expansions could add a great deal. But for now, this is a good pick for non-gamers, a filler, or if you want something to play while you're watching TV. There's a little hyperbole in this, but not much.

UPDATE: OK. 12 plays now. This is very easy to teach and a game to which my brothers warmed right up. Due to the likelihood of playing semi-frequently with them and not hating it, I'm bumping this up to a 6.5. I don't think I will be needing to update this again. There's just not enough here for me.

UPDATE: I was wrong. I do need to update this. So, I've played 36 times now and I just can't shake the feeling that this game is pointless. There are several combinations of cards that are going allow you to get 4 Provinces in about 10 turns. Does that make the Chapel better than the Bureaucrat or the Smithy better than the Chapel? Unfortunately, it doesn't matter. Chance is going to take care of that, but since it's so quick, even if you lose you can just play another game! Um, how about you play for me and let me know who won?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I've enjoyed my games of Dominion and it certainly has its addictive qualities, but was not as enamored of it as some in my gaming group.  The variety of the card setup is definitely a plus, as is the quick playing time, but initially it felt like some card combos lead a player to one strategy.  That seems disappointing, when two (or three) cards showing up together means either taking the pre-ordained path or performing suboptimally.

I don't know if it's my change in playing partners or what, but I've been really enjoying the game recently.  Maybe it is the expansions that make other combos more viable or just that I'm understanding the game better after 25 plays and seeing more depth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominion is pretty much the one game that got me into modern board games, so it's responsible for a lot of spent time and money, but brought me lots of fun times through the several years I've been doing this stuff.

:star: neat, simple ruleset makes this an easy game to teach even to completely new players
:star: keeping all cards available for purchase at all times is a much better system than the central row in games like Ascension or Legendary - it allows for far more strategy
:star: hardly any troublesome card wordings and effects to be seen, and any potential problems are excellently solved by the detailed rulebook
:star: no two games are ever the same
:star: deckbuilding is a super awesome thing, and this game lets you just deckbuild, without getting other things in the way

:nostar: I would've preferred a card layout that let me see more of the art
:nostar: some of the cards are simply unfun (fortunately, second editions are clearing that up!)

RATING: 10
A Classic; and utterly amazing.  The franchise face of deckbuilding.

It does basically everything right, but most importantly it nails the 2 most important stat categories: Great Balance and Insane replay value.  It can be played over and over and it can be played competitively.

Min Expansions Recommended (at least 2 of): Intigue, seaside, prosperity, hinterlands, cornucopia
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As I become exposed to more games, I find myself returning to Dominion less and less. What I enjoy about Dominion is the huge selection of unique cards. This makes each new game an exploration for me. I enjoy trying to find the ideal combos and/or the ideal hand strategy within each 10 card selection. What I don't like about Dominion is that having played with the cards in advance will put you at an extreme advantage over players unfamiliar with them. There are lines and combos that, once encountered, become obvious plays (or obvious things to avoid) - much like chess. Then the game becomes one of study and memorization while the hand plays itself. I have found that card drafting games are particularly prone to this (MTG being the biggest offender). 

I still have several cards I've not played with in my two expansions, so the game isn't dead just yet. I am likely to pick up further expansions to keep the game fresh, but I do not see this returning to my list of favorites without a significant change in taste on my part.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Considered the first of the "deck building" genre this game is alright. The general theme is pretty bland but the concept is fun and it works as a good starting point to teach people about deck builders since it doesn't add much complexity to the concept even though I'd rather play other deck building games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's like Magic lite, you get to build card combos from a random selection of card types (10 per game).

This game is great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've quickly been falling in love with this game.  As a long time CCGer who hasn't played in years because the games just got to expensive and time consuming despite my enjoyment, I really feel this game feeds my love of CCGs without the same sort of continual cost of play.  It also impresses me how they made card drafting a game mechanic, when I'm accustomed to it as a meta-game aspect. Very cool!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Grade: B [05-12-009].  The deck-building is effective and fun.  The variety of cards will help keep the interactions fresh, while also making the core system plenty expandable.  This game seems to be an evolution in design, but only because it game-izes deck-building, a feature of CCGs or CCG-style games that has otherwise been part of the metagame.  It does this well, but I think in a few years other games will have absorbed the Dominion deck-building mechanic.  Will "Vanilla Dominion" still be fun at that point?  Time will tell. 

Score: 8 [5-12-09].  I appreciate Dominion.  Deck-building in CCGs has been an important part of the game, but it's more like doing sprints than playing the game; it gets you in shape to finish the game effectively, but it isn't the game itself.  With Dominion Vaccarino has turned this optimization process into a part of the game itself.  It's a weird sort of backwards innovation.  It ultimately succeeds because it is quick, accessible, has virtually no downtime, includes an astronomical (and sure-to-be-ever-expanding) variety of fairly clever card combinations--all of which make it very replayable.  Optimization is such a feature of Euros that you could, perhaps, say that he has euro-ized the CCG experience (rather than just the CCG).  It works, but I'm cautious about giving it a super high score because I want to see how well it will hold up over time.  I think there's some iteration of this type of game that could be a 10 for me--I'm just not sure someone's designed it yet. For now, though, I'll surely be happy to play the game several more times.

It is themeless however, and that is a big minus for me. After 200+ plays, after the mechanics (finally) get a bit repetitive, the lack of theme becomes ever more significant.

RATING: 7
Highly addictive card game.  The variability introduced by the different cards and the short play time combine to make either a great filler or, more frequently, invite a series of games.  I did find, however that the base game alone got a bit tired after a while (albeit maybe a hundred plays between face-to-face and BrettSpielWelt).  Despite all the cards there are only three or four viable strategies, two of which (Chapel, Gardens) are based on a single card.  The others (big money, draw as much of your deck as possible) have some variations depending on the available cards, but tend to feel the same after a while.  I have returned with renewed interest, however, after Intrigue and Seaside.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.75
Notable in that it is the first deck builder. I found it very unforgiving for new players who don't grab key cards before they run out. Theme is nonexistent and gameplay is not really funner than other deck builders.

It is also a game that I cannot get my head around. I did worse in my best play of Dominion than I did in my worst play of any other deck builder. For whatever reason, I am doomed to end up in far last no matter what I do. I know that the game is about finding a core combo and riding it for buckets of points, but I just cannot do it.

When I tried to build an all around solid deck that has a nice point engine and support cards around it, my engine never came together, my support cards all clumped up and never fired, and I get beaten by an opponent who, more or less, focused on a single card.

When I tried to focus on a single card, my deck ended up an unbalanced mess.

I know that this game is about building a perfect engine and I have seen other players do it, but for whatever reason, I have a mental block around it and don't even understand what I don't understand.

The only reason that I would ever play this game again is out of shear stubbornness about the fact that I cannot be this bad at a pure deck builder.

RATING: 9.1
[u]Kids[/u]

RATING: 8
All the fun of a CCG without the empty wallet. Great strategy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
200 plays.  Not my favorite game, but a game I love which can't help but find it way onto the table. 

My comments and ranking assume at least 2 expansions: Gaming crack.  Addicting, quick, and combos!  I am obsessed with this game currently.  Always thinking what else to do.  Play 15 on, really starting to maximize my strategy.  I have been playing back to back games with identical card sets.  This has allowed to hone strategies and realize "dead end" strategies.  It also helps mitigate the luck in the game, and I think I will be using the back to back game for future sessions.  Love it love it love it.  I have played this with hardcore gamers, family, its been a gateway.  Dominion is a good game to get played in any and all gaming situations.  Its incredible the wide appeal it has.

The base game alone would probably merit a 7, but with at least 2 expansions its an easy 10.

Based upon the card set up available, one must choose the strategy to pursue which means which actions to buy and which percentage of the deck should be actions.   It's just a fun puzzle.  There is quite a bit of luck on turns 3,4,5 which affects the rest of the game.  It is so much fun, it is easy to overlook.  

It has some ridiculous combos which I applaud.  I dislike games which have such neutered powers that they are of little benefit, so it can't be overpowering.  Dominion takes the chance that it can make balanced overpowering combos and it makes the game a lot more fun.  

I create random sets of cards for no reason other than to daydream what my strategy would be.  I need help, but this game is so addicting.

Simplicity, Elegance, Variety, enough luck to keep it interesting, enough depth to keep it interesting, expansions to keep it interesting, really everything i want to keep it interesting is here.  Each box holds 30-35 must play right now and nothing else for me, until it becomes merely a favorite.

I refuse to bring this out, unless time permits to play twice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

OK this is a f'ing good game with lots of potential (via expansion cards) to keep on being good. 2 to 4 works great for player numbers, now bring on intrigue and let's get up to 8 and see how it holds.

With the expansions it's harder to just plan a deck on a subset of cards knowing the others won't interfere too much, and it makes it a much more interesting game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the very first games we bought due to the Spiel des Jahres award and general good reviews on BGG. The rules are simple and concise so you should not need to refer to them much as instructions are printed on the action cards. Seeing all the cards in front of you means you can plan out strategies in advance and knows what's in your deck but chance is added by the necessity of needing to shuffle your deck when you get to the end. With the amount of combinations on offer there is a ton of variety and different ways to win; indeed if you end up enjoying Dominion buying the expansions becomes very addictive; all of them can be combined with each other to produce a dizzying amount of possible card combinations. One of the more interactive card games I have played, the attack cards allow you to irritate the opposition. Only negative is in the downtime created between people's turns; this builds with more players therefore I find this game is best with two players.

Must have!!!

RATING: N/A
Easy to teach card game.  You build your deck as you play, so it's a REALLY interesting gameplay mechanic.  You use the cards in your deck to by more cards, and you discard as you play your hand.  Then when your draw pile is empty.. you shuffle the discard pile and start drawing from that.  Lots of variety of game types too!  Cheap!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
(Rating remains the same as of 72 plays of my physical copy and a bunch on BSW.)

I never thought I'd decide on one favorite game, but this game has become the one.

I am loving this game - it's fun to just keep playing and playing. It's enjoyable to do what you can with the set of cards offered each time. This is a very clever design, like MTG summarized into a short complete package. I like games with lots of options and multiple ways to aim for the goal. I also like the card format. The only downside is having to sleeve nearly 500 cards and being forced to use overhand or hindu shuffle. But I've found that penny sleeves allow for easily sliding one half of your deck into the other for a smooth mix-up.

Best of all, the game is short and easy. I love games like this, and they really fit my current schedule which doesn't have windows of time to play long games.

The decisions are fun, but quick. Downtime is negligible. You shuffle and plan, and it's your turn again.

I like how close the scores can be. I had 4 2P ties in 2 days. The guys in my gaming group are always willing to play. This game has been a delight.

On top of it all, the design is very expansion-ready. I'm looking forward to the new batches of kingdom cards.

UPDATE: While I still rank this a 10 at this point, I have found that what I first loved about Dominion (simplicity, short turns) has been compromised by two things. 

First, many players have become fond of power combos (play 10 cards, shuffle, play more cards, buy 3 Provinces, etc.). This really slows down the game and spoils the fun for me.

Second, Alchemy and Prosperity have introduced layers of complexity that take away from the sweet simplicity of the original Dominion model.

As long as I only use Base + Intrigue + Seaside, and play with quick thinkers, this game is excellent!

UPDATE 5-26-2016:

I never play this game now. Ever since I discovered Star Realms, Dominion has had no place in my life. Star Realms does everything better. The whole package is more satisfying. I would play Dominion if someone really wanted to, but I never choose it now.

I still stick with only the first 3 sets. Lowered my rating from 10 to 7.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
(from my Xmas 2010 post) 
From my kids and wife, Daddy got Dominion. I had tried it a few months back and was really not impressed - seemed to programmed, and the drain-3-piles endgame with 2 players bothered me (why not have fewer cards per pile in 2 player games). But i wanted to try more. So i borrowed the game from the owners of the local toy/game store (Big Smiles - very nice folks), and we tried a few more games. Lo and behold, it grabbed me and i had to have it. Luckily my boy and wife were paying attention. My opinion on the programmed nature of the play boils down basically to: don't be a dolt. (my same basic reaction to Puerto Rico.) If you are playing as an optimizer i think you are missing something in the "playing" part of the game. Have fun, try different strategies and its a blast.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The millions of different combinations thing was always clearly a red herring. Once you develop the heuristics for analysing a set-up (considering how many terminal vs. non-terminal action cards there are, how many cards offer extra buys, etc), rumination over the selected kingdom cards, originally so exciting, becomes the selection of one (or more) of four(ish) paradigms (big money, action chaining, deck thinning, attacking). This applies equally whether there are previously unseen kingdom cards in a set-up or not.

Still. There are games, and there are moments. Buying a couple of curses to end the game. Remodelling a Province into another Province as a tempo play. Many such things. Tricks which haven't occurred to me yet. These sort of things don't come every game. But they feel genuinely skillful when they do.

The diminishing return in buying new Dominion expansions is in more than the ever smaller consequence of a new card in terms of the overall card pool: I've learnt too much about this game, so broadly figuring out the impact of new mechanisms takes less time and gives less pleasure with each new set. I won't buy any more.

RATING: 10
2-4p

downside - don't always care what your opponents do

This game gives me the same feeling as playing MTG but we don't need each player to spend a large sum of money to build a deck beforehand. You can build a unique deck every time and you will because you need to adapt your strategy to what your opponents are doing as well as what is going on with the cards in random play.  The playing field is leveled and you can play with anyone.  Amazing game.  Great, deep strategy.  It's like a Magic the Gathering cube draft but faster and streamlined.

The theme is kind of pasted on and the title of a card doesn't always make sense with what the card does.  It can be humorous a lot of the time.

RATING: 9
I once played Dominion base game with a few mates for 18 hours straight. Yes I agreed that 7-8 hours into everything sort of became automatic. With every set we could immediately identify the best strategy and counter strategy. Even with this we kept playing. Once you add expansions if it takes you 50-100+ hours to figure out a game back to front I don't think that's a bad thing. I still have many long Dominion sessions now because we haven't figured everything out and it's too easy to go round after round after round.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This one's a 10.  Rated for 2 player, primarily; probably a 10 with 3 and 9 with 4 due to downtime between turns.

This rating is slightly biased in that it accounts for expansions.  The rating is for the idea behind the game, how it plays, and so on.  However, be mindful that without expansions the longevity of the game will be much shorter and will have you wanting more. 

Each expansion exponentially boosts the value of this game and the other expansions that you buy.  Very unique concepts in this game and truly a gem.   

The only con I can really say about this game is that the boxes (with expansions) are pretty large and it can be a pain to pull them out if you want to truly randomize your games.  Then switching between cards from one game to the next can be tiring as well.

*Note, I can't at all agree with the criticisms that the game plays like solitaire.  This game so very heavily relies on you knowing what your opponents are doing and playing around it that.. it's just not true.

*UPDATE 3/6/17: Still love the game, always will.  Starting to feel that the time to set up (take cards out, put old ones away) each game is too cumbersome and preferring alternatives. Changed to a 9.  Great game, just not perfect.

RATING: 7.5
This game has grown on me, largely because of the ease of play on BSW.  It started off as a curiosity, and, with additional plays (now at 154), has become a compelling game with deep strategy. 

I think of this game as an unique game with strategy but without tactics.

Technically, my 11yo daughter owns this, not me.  I've told her, though, that when she goes away to college, she can't take it. ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good:
-Cool card interactions
-Amazing diversity
-So many cards
-Amazing inlay
-Quick game play
-Great expansions

Bad:
-I am a robot (must do X, Y, & Z)
-Follow the leader (Players mimics each other for the first few turns)
-Highly competitive
-Terrible theme
-The winner is too often established in the first couple of turns

Overall:
Another game that is aging poorly.  My biggest grip is that I often feel pigeonholed into certain strategies.  Experimenting typically means losing.  If you are late to the decking building bandwagon you probably want to look elsewhere as there are other deck builders that offer more interaction and/or freedom.  If you already a fan, buy some expansions as they drastically improve the base game.

RATING: 9
I really enjoy this game.  I like that turns are quick.  You are doing plenty while others take their turns.  You should be checking out your hand as well as watching what the other players are buying.  I feel like I have a lot of control over what happens in the game.  I have introduced this game to non-gamers many times and it always goes over well.  Most always ask, 'What else you got?'  The strategies change from game to game although there will always be strong combos, the existence of other cards add that necessary bit of flavor.  Its also fairly quick to play, at least it feels that way.
