=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
04/2009:6.5
I am generally not a fan of card-driven games, with the exception of Citadels. So, I am straddling the fence on Dominion. It is a good design, fast paced and short. However, I can see the game getting stale, even with expansion cards. The actions are quite repetitive. Buy cards, use cards, buy cards, use cards...etc. The saving grace for this game is that it is short. Each game can be a short as 20 min depending on the skill levels of the player. Also, the current set of cards doesn't really promote much player interaction other than messing up the hand of cards. Which is why I do like games like citadels. Lots of player interaction. Still, after several plays, I give it an above average score, but I fully expect that rating to drop with more plays.
One note: I feel like this game WAS designed for online play. The computer takes care of all the card shuffling and also the book keeping. THAT is huge especially when 8-10 cards are played in each round. It will get annoying having to shuffle every other time or to keep try of how many actions/buys/money.

After a couple more plays, I am beginning to lose some interest in Dominion. In most cases, I can see that the solitare-esque nature of the game bugs people. There are a couple of really dominant strategies in the mix of the deck and after encountering a couple of those plays, I can see why this game can get boring against novices (the chapel/laboratory combo comes to mind).

0.5 notch downwards.

12/29/08 : Finally played the actual board game version of this game and my thoughts remained the same. This game is best played online. The shuffling of the deck and keeping track of the number of actions/buys is cumbersome. The computer easily takes care of both issues. Played a 2 and 3 player rounds. I have to say this game is slowly losing its luster for me because of its repetitive nature. Giving it another 0.5 notch downward
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Star Realms fired this game for me. 

The beginning setup and the ending count of VPs all take a little too long for me to really enjoy this. 

Star Realms has none of that, and it's just a lot faster to start and play again. I give this game props for taking the combo elements in Magic the Gathering and turning it into a game. Mind you, the amount that this takes from Magic is not minor.

It still is better than the vast majority of deck builders out there, but I've had my fill and moved on. It's important to note that I'm talking about the base game only. I've never played with the expansion cards so can't say whether the experience improves or not with the expansions. I'm assuming it does.

Update 01/03/15 - Updated from a 3 to a 4 and then back down to a 3 again. I've been playing the expansions online and it's been fun! The fact that the setup is done for you makes it even better. Unfortunately there's still issues.

- Warning: Minor strategy talk ahead - 





I find big money in the base game really boring. Base game dominion is probably a 2 or 3 for me if players just play big money strategies. If all players are running the big money strategy then we might as well flip a coin and call it right there and then.

After playing with the expansions, while big money is less prevalent, it's still a big enough part of the game that I'm not fond of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In the 4 years since Dominion was published, it's established itself as one of the benchmark games of the hobby, and with good reason. The compact playing time and excellent accommodation of 2-4 players make this an easy pick for many occasions. But what I especially admire is how accessible the strategy of the game is, even to casual gamers. I've taught Dominion to a wide range of people, and they all "get it" within 5 minutes of sitting down. That doesn't mean they can instantly pick the optimal strategy, of course. But they know what they're supposed to be thinking about, and a lot of Euros take at least a full game to get to that point. Dominion may well be the game best suited to showing off "what the hobby is about" to the uninitiated.

That being said, I find the base game by itself to be a little dull. That's not to say that it's always easy to find the best strategy, only that the cards start feeling ho-hum after a dozen plays or so. The game becomes a lot more interesting and flavorful with the expansion sets, even if you play with only one at a time. By itself, I rate the base game an 8. Throw in an expansion or two that appeals to you and it's a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
My wife and I are new to gaming, so I may have been overly ambitious when I made the immediate jump from Lost Cities to Dominion. I was pleasantly surprised to see her pick up this game so easily. Very easy to explain, one drawback is the setup. While an individual game with 2 people can take 20-30 minutes, the initial setup with new treasury cards can take half that time. Android apps that randomly determine treasury cards are helpful. People will say, "just use the same setup multiple times." However, what I like most about the game is the initial random drawing of treasury cards, as I like thinking out the new strategies that come about with the new setup. Playing the game, I find that we use maybe 2/3 to 3/4 of the available cards, only going for cards that we find to be the most effective. This makes me think that the variety of cards don't actually equate to a variety of paths to victory. In 2 player dominion, I find the race for provinces to be dull and I believe it takes away from playing the different action cards, which I find to be the most fun aspect of the game. The artwork is very nice, the card quality is great, and the card text is very clear which requires basically no explanation. The game pretty much teaches itself. Overall, this is a fun game to play with my wife, which is really what matters most. Not overly confrontational, lots of different, fun cards to choose from (which unfortunately are not chosen because we usually find it better to invest in gold), but the initial setup takes too long, and while I could go down the road of just buying expansion after expansion, I would rather just play a game that focuses more on what satisfies me (the randomness of drawing cards from a pre-shuffled stack is more fun to me than choosing cards already laid out in front of me). I will never turn down a game if my wife wants to play, but something about the game makes me want to find a game that is more completely satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A very capable deck building game. One of the modern card/board games that brought me back to physical games but since playing Dominion, I have come across many more games and can safely say, although Dominion is a good game, it is no longer the sharpest tool in the shed. 

What I really like with the game is the calculated risk and even playing field. After a few pilot rounds, you can readily have a decent game strategy put together. Other than the few new mechanics put into the game, such as curses and new victory tokens, there really isn't a very big twist in any of the other expansions.

After several dozen games, I felt that the lustre of the franchise start to wear off. Strategies begin to find it's most effective and efficient form and variation slowly fades into the background. The solution? Randomize what is played, but there is no guarantee there. On occasion, some of the randomization makes for a refreshing new take on the game, but more often than not, there are no synergies and the game could just drag itself out.

In summary, this is a good game to have handy and a great way to introduce someone into the hobby. The Intrigue and Prosperity expansions are a must have in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros: original deckbuilding game, highly variable initial set-up, limited card market accessible to each player equally, variable strategies, high replayability, easy-to-learn mechanics

Cons: limited player interaction depending on set-up & card availability in the market, little tactical decision-making, harsh strategic imbalances, barely thematic, steep learning curve when encountering new cards

One of my favorites for a very long time and really the game that got me hooked on the hobby. My friends and I spent hours playing this and Settlers of Catan. I own most of the expansions, and have found that the expansions both immensely increase replayability & correct imbalances in the original first edition. There can be a steep learning curve for newbies, especially as more complex cards are introduced. I've recently "grown out" of Dominion (not near as obsessed as I was), but it is still a top contender for bringing to the table on game nights.

Plays listed include any and/or all expansions plus 2nd edition cards.

RATING: 5
Run a medieval dominion by shuffling cards. Alot. Interesting and novel game mechanism with respect to card drafting, but the game as a whole left me cold. Some of the poorest theme integration I've seen. Player interaction is minimal. While I see that the deck construction element plays on  edging your probabilities, something I usually like, the part of the game where you play through your deck felt robotic. A few strategies also appeared dominant - I can see how altering the cards would change that dominance, but then you delve in the realm of CCGs of old, where each expansion leads to *new* dominant strategies - but dominant strategies nevertheless exist. Some may argue the game's depth due to the different possibilities of cards being used from game-to-game, but I see that as more of the same - i.e. shuffling different cards. Clearly, this is not for me. Dominion, to me, is an average quick filler that I would never suggest but could play once in a blue moon if in the right mood. Dominion is in a class of recent CCG-like games with deck acrobatic mechanisms, along with San Juan & Race For The Galaxy, that appears to simply not be my thing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic strategy game for kids 8+, and my favorite adult strategy game -- but you'll soon want to invest in at least 3 expansions: Intrigue, Seaside, and Prosperity, so it will get pricy. 

Dominion is a strategic deck-building strategy game that may be my favorite all-time board game, even though I tend to not play deck-building games. There are now several other similar games that have come out since Dominion, but I love this one and think this is the one to get; and it really builds cognitive and reasoning skills. This one's actually worth spending money on and getting all the expansions.

You choose 10 piles of cards out of over 100 (if you have all the expansions) and so no two games are ever quite the same. Some cards work more efficiently than others, and figuring out the most efficient strategy is a central part of the game. 

Get this if you want your kid to grow up to be a computer programmer or engineer: it has such emergent strategies and makes you calculate and choose among differing scenarios every game that I find it amazing. You're either going to love this game with a passion, or not like it, but give it a few tries, as I had to play a few games before I fell in love with it, unlike many other games where I'm sold on it after playing once.

Again, if you love the game, you want to get all the expansions, but to start, there are two critical expansions to get besides the base game: get Prosperity and Intrigue. Plus get the 6 stand-alone promo cards: Black Market, Envoy, Walled Village, Governor, Stash, and Prince; hopefully you can find them bundled together or at the BGG online store. Those three sets (base-game-plus-Prosperity-plus-Intrigue) and the promos will get you familiar with the game and keep you happy learning the game for months before you're ready for the rest. 

The other expansions you probably want to get in the order they were release, because the makers purposely held back the more complex cards, as the expansions increase in complexity, with Dark Ages being the most complex and confusing in that it alters the game the most. The one exception is Alchemy: avoid getting this one until dead last: don't get it unless or until you have all the other expansions, as it's my least favorite and many players exclude it, or, as I do, just add to their collection the handful of cards that don't use the extra "potion" currency unique to Alchemy. 


 If you buy that first, you may get too confused and give up on the game before you've realized how enchanting it is. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominion is a fast paced game that plays quickly but still requires thoughtful strategy. With just the base set I'd rate this a 7. It's a good game, but it tends to be a bit simple.

It's not the cards that make the game though. While a variety of cards is essential to the format, individual sets of cards can be optimized and almost "solved" but the format is brilliant. The deck building structure can house a potentially infinite number of strategies and systems within it. Potentially a game like magic could be restructured to fit the format.

The only thing wrong with the game at this point is the copyright protection. Because of the strange card size there is no easy way to make your own cards. It makes sense, but it does put a damper on the replay value since eventually there will stop being official expansions.

With:

RATING: N/A
In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players strive for the most efficient path to victory points.

2-4 (best 3)

Card game, deck building

RATING: 10
This game should be the #1 game of all time, in my opinion.  Almost every game I play of this is filled with interesting decisions.  

There's a lot of other games that excel with replayability, but none of them to the extent of this game.  It really feels like an entirely new game almost every time I play it.   

Even though the game doesn't boast balance, it is very clear that an enormous amount of work went into planning and tweaking the cards.  I wouldn't be surprised if more hours have been spent playtesting this game than any other game.

I have 275+ recorded plays for this game and its expansions.  I highly doubt that I'll ever have half as many plays of any other game as I do on Dominion.  I'm finally increasing my rating from 9 to 10 based on the quality of the the Prosperity expansion, and my continued eagerness to play the game after 275 plays.

only played base game a few times, very underwhelming experience. I can see how it would have been a great new game when it came out, but having played a ton of ascension on iOs and a ton of Legendary Marvel, Dominion felt very outdated.

[+] very streamlined deck-builder, variety of the setup, good sense of progression (have to find the right time to switch from engine to point building)
[-] it's slow paced (turns can take a long time for not much achieved), don't like the VP card mechanic, keeping track of how many actions/buys/gold you have is boring

RATING: 4
I am not nearly as enthused about the game as others are, but I have made my peace with Dominion.  I acknowledge that it has a function... but that function is fairly restrictive, as it's filler for hardcore gamers.  I can't play this with people who aren't hardcore gamers, as the rules and strategy are too much, with not enough payoff.  As for playing with gamers as a real game, it's so short that it almost ends just as it gets going, and my group wants something with more depth and involvement.  Dominion is sorta like gamer junk food.  Even when I can find the right situation, I'm just as likely to ask for something else.  How about [gameid=172] or [gameid=11]?

I've played more than enough Dominion to not care if I ever try it again.  Any freshness was gone after the fifth play or so, and even the deck building mechanic that it pioneered is more satisfying in games like [gameid=69789].  At this point, it is akin to overdeveloped mush, with bland variations on the same pattern, and no amount of nicely threaded turns is going to rehabilitate it for me.  What's more, most of the game is evaluating the tableau at the beginning, and thus the "gameplay" almost feels akin to a gigantic resolution phase.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Deckbuilding is my favorite in-game mechanic, and I appreciate and respect Dominion for what it is and how much it added to hobby gaming. That said, it really does bore the heck out of me. The father of the "pure" deckbuilders (along with Ascension, Legendary, Cryptozoic's Cerberus engine games, and Thunderstone), it stops short of actually doing something with the creative mechanic: gathering estates and provinces just pales in comparison to fighting monsters and superhero/villains.

RATING: 5

Luca Iennaco say:


PROs:
-) Simple basic concept that yet leads to several possible strategies. 
-) Nice blending of deckbuilding in the gameplay.
-) Good variety (and potential for expansions).
-) Short (ideal to tinker with different setups).
-) Addictive.
-) Easily expanded.

CONs:
-) Some cards seem clearly more important (powerful) than others.
-) Luck of the draw is far from negligible. 
-) Tiebreaker is not enough of a compensation for the advantage of playing first.
-) Annoying costant (re)shuffling.
-) The important info on the cards could have been printed more clearly.
-) The artwork is unimpressive, when not downright bad.
-) It'll have multiple expansions. 

2011-07-25

My rating went up to a 9! Great game.

RATING: 7
A mai napig legjobb... vagyizé, legismertebb pakliépítő játék! Célunk olyan kiegyensúlyozott pakli építése újabb és újabb lapok hozzáadásával, ami gyorsan pörög és eközben tempóelőnyt ad nekünk, valamint "elbírja" a győzelmi pont kártyákat, ugyanis bár a játékban ezek semmit se érnek, a végén csak ezek határozzák meg a győztes kilétét.
Három féle kártyád van: akciólap, pénz, és győzelmi pont. Minden kört öt lappal kezdesz, majd végrehajthatsz egy akciót és várásolhatsz egy lapot a kezedben lévő pénzen. A lényeg persze az akciók kombinálása, mert azok újabb akciókat, laphúzást, plusz pénzt és vásárlást jelnethetnek. Nem mellékesen a már nem kellő lapokat érdemes egy-egy akcióval kitenni, ami által "sűrűbb" lesz a pakli és nem minden 4 rossz kézre jut egy jó, hanem akár fordítva.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Filler, but only if rampaging wildebeest have eaten every other card game..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating is given after 50 games, and with over 20 wins the game is getting better. :)

By the rules, it is quite simple game, but each card breaking the rules, makes it more challenging and harder. The aim is to collect points and you need to build your deck in the meanwhile. Actions, money and points are all cards, you need a good combination of all in order to make your deck work and have the most points in the end. Changing the setup (and expansions) greatly affects the re-playability, which is nice. Feels like a good, balanced game.

Playable with 2, 3 or 4, so it is very flexible in that sense. With Intrigue it is possible to have 5-8 players, but the downtime gets quite high even with 5.

I have now played couple of times with the cards from the expansion mixed into this game. Really hard to say anything hard of them, but at least they give something new to the base game, extend it's life, but still don't break the feeling too much.

Updated after the 57th play (1st with Adventures): The elegance of the original Dominion gets quite lost with expansion like Adventures, but happily it is possible to choose the expansions you like. Still a good game.

Updated after 5 duels with just the base game. First two plays were a bit longer, but last three were played in 15 minutes each once the opponent learnt the rules.

Two duels with random setup, the plays are no longer because of new cards and different setups.

Three duels with random setup (same for each three), this time the setup was fast, so 15-20 minutes each. Good.

Add 10 more duels, and I decided to update the rating from 8 to 9. I was surprised how easy this was to teach to newbie and how fast she learned to properly play. The game is very fast, 10-15 minutes a play nowadays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This box was so cheap. I paid only 6 € for it. (Plus 15 € for the sleeves.)

When I found Dominion from a local online second hand forum I had never played it before. I knew nothing of it other than that according to the internet it was a good game. I had not even bought any proper boardgame sleeves before.

Thus Dominion is one of the first 'adult' gateway boardgames I've bought myself. ("Myself" since my family had already gifted me for instance 'Carcassonne' and Rainer Knizia's 'Ingenius'.)

That year I played Dominion a lot. I took it on the vacations with me and made custom card separators for it. I still play it but nowadays I don't take it to the trips. It's too big to carry in a backbag on the train even though I store the cards in a smallish cardboard box that once belonged to 'Carcassonne: The Princess & the Dragon'.

Dominion has a place on my shelf because it's an easy game to intruduce to all kinds of people. : )

RATING: 9
This is basically MTG where your hand size is 5 instead of 7 and you buy cards to fill up your deck instead of summoning monsters and..... anyway, I like it! I'm giving it a 9 for now as I've only played the basic setup. *update 12/31/08* I've played 4 of the 5 setups (all but Size Distortion) from the back of the manual. The game plays great with any number but I'm liking the two-player the best so far. I'm updating my rating to a 10. The game sets up quickly, plays fairly quickly and I like shuffling cards. *4/2/09 I'm lowering my rating to a 9. The base 25 actions is starting to grow old. The shuffling is tedious. I'm making a chip-set Dominion and the expansion is coming soon so these factors may just raise it back up to a 10.

RATING: 7
Вобщем я не могу назвать достоинства этой игры. А недостатки - пожалуйста:

1. Много раз надо тасовать карты (я не люблю)
2. Сложно следить что делают другие. Наверное это лечиться если хорошо изучить все карты (т.е. привыкнуть к ним)
3. Сам процесс игры основанный на построении колоды я не нахожу чем-либо занимательным.
4. Новичку плохо, т.к. надо изучать карты, которые обладают не самыми простыми свойствами, и еще сложно научиться сочетать их в колоде.

RATING: N/A
#2 #3 #4 #5 #6 (#7) (#8)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION

Needs expansions to be good. The base game has three winning strategies and they're obvious on second play. Once you've discovered them, the game gets tired very quickly. It's very strategic and, thus, dull once you understand the best strategies in the set.

With expansions, this game is a 9. It's simple and quick-to-play with huge strategic depth. The card combinations and complexity increases exponentially, but the rules remain simple and elegant. A brilliant game design.

Don't buy it if you use theme to learn to play. I enjoy playing Dominion, but am learning the expanded game through teaching matches against my husband (who plays online). The game is very mechanical and the theme has no relationship to the cards. 

That said, the artwork is very pretty and the card stock is the best I've seen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Why this game is special for me: this is the first game which makes me want to explore further, both inside the scope of this game as well as flickering my game designer mind. The system which uses several cards from easily expandable number of selections for each game really intrigues me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The granddaddy of the deck building genre, Dominion is a solid game and with a few expansions, definitely has a ton of replayability. I only have 2 gripes with it which are: it is more or less themeless and isn't as interactive as I would like compared to some of the newer deck builders out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great game!  I suck at it, but it is a very well rounded game.  All of the strategy is in what cards you buy and WHEN you buy them.  It is smart to break up your strategy into 3 parts: Early game, mid-game and End-game.  It is also good to find cards that will combine well with others (i.e. modifiers and special cards).  The suggested sets are a good way to go.  The "randomizer deck" can make the game slower and less interesting and some cards don't work well with others.  This game is great for 2 players, it can also range up to 6 players, but the most I've played was 4.  Turns can get long, but I think this game is great.  Another thing is that the more you know the cards, the better off you will be.  Also, if you can't get into medival theme stuff, this is not for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's multiplayer solitaire. Maybe I wasn't playing with the right expansions, but I find this game kind of dull. The game comes down to building the best engine, with little interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, this is one crazy-addictive game.  Remember that first time you played Fairy Tale, and you got that itch to play it again and again because of the drafting mechanism?  You know, where you wanted to play it again right away?  Well, say goodbye to Fairy Tale and hello to Dominion, because you may never come back to the former once you've played the latter.

Aside from being cardboard cocaine, the game also shows the multiple playtests and the amount of development put into it, so it's going to be a finely tuned machine.  There's something very satisfying about building your own deck and timing when to make the shift from money and action cards to VPs.  This game is challenging, versatile, and requires a different approach depending on what cards are in play.  It's also nicely balanced to be "just" a card game, and the number of cards and the method for choosing the cards in each game will guarantee that the game will have a long shelf life.  

I've heard complaints that the game can feel deterministic, since with each hand you draw, you'll have a single best way to play the hand, but for me, getting to the point where you can have your deck doing what you want it to do is pretty fun.  If you're not a fan of deck-building, then it won't be for you; otherwise, just get on and enjoy the ride.

19 plays: 2 players
12 plays: 3 players
37 plays: 4 players
5 plays: 5 players

I will not be buying any more of the boxed expansions. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a way to acquire stacks of individual cards. Ordering promo cards is the closest thing to buying singles in Dominion. 

Decided against [gameid=125403] - looks like it encourages engine building. Alchemy, Guilds, Seaside, and (especially) Prosperity seem to over-complicate the game. I also don't like the flavour of several of their cards (e.g. Colony and Native Village). Adding tokens spoils the base game elegance of only needing cards. There are similar games, with better gameplay. However Dominion has wider appeal, especially amongst my friends who don't play games.

RATING: 9
In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.
\13\\13\
Note:
\13\
Stored with the base game are the following expansions:\13\

  Prosperity\13\
  Seaside\13\

  Envoy promo card\13\

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's addictive, and like Magic, relies on expansions to ensure its continued depth. The pattern is pretty much the same each time a new expansion is released: play some exploratory rounds, figure out which cards are viable, then degenerate into playing the same few overpowered cards each time. The game is obviously most fun in the exploratory stages, and can get pretty stale after the luster of new cards has worn off. Still, the game is amazingly fun while it "lasts," and not too bad even when you have "solved" the game. 

Unfortunately, after burning through a bunch of expansions, I'm kind of burned out on the whole thing. I'd much prefer it if the dev had spent a long time making one really good set of kingdom cards rather than a an endless array of crappy ones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played once with my group. Would like to play more with other expansions

RATING: 7
Dominion takes the deck building aspect of collectible card games and makes a game out of it. Initially, I was underwhelmed. I thought the concept was an absolute homerun, but the actual gameplay was a little dull. It almost felt like I was playing half of a game. I've built a deck...now shouldn't I do something with it? My initial lackluster feelings have improved quite a bit though, and I feel a little better with each new release of the game's fantastic expansions. They've added a lot of interactivity and many of the new cards are far more interesting than the simple +1 action, +1 gold type cards of the base set. To make a long story short, Dominion has grown into one of my favorite games and I can't wait to see how it continues to evolve.

RATING: 9

When teaching the game 3 times in 2 days recently (using the First Game suggested setup) I used 3 totally different strategies - and won all 3 games. The short playtime is also a plus. The biggest downside for me is the setup time if you're only going to be playing one game or with mass market-type gamers, but overall this is one of my favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/4p/user/Vroenis]4 players[/url].
Teaching: 55 - 65 minutes (strictly using selected core cards).
Mastery: 40 - 60+ minutes depending on cards used.
Retails in a square box but you can pack two full decks into a box of roughly 2 x small box dimensions.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geektag.php?tags=embassy_%26_outpost&username=Vroenis&action=usertags]Embassy_&_Outpost[/url]

Also available: Prosperity.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/outpost_mobile/user/Vroenis]Outpost mobile[/url].

The quintessential [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/deck_builder/user/Vroenis]Deck builder[/url].
Hand management.
Medium weight for beginners, light with mastery.
Low level interaction (The Intrigue expansion increases it).
Low theme application for the most part.

One of the most fluid deck builders created. Core cards are great for new groups with fewer complex cards.
Those with mastery will have to take it easy on those just learning for at least a few turns, as veterans will maximise efficiency much quicker. Still, it's an easy game to get the hang of and develop good deck management skills.

Sometimes you'll draw five useless cards which won't be fun - it's rare, but it does happen a time or two. The good thing is the game cycles quickly so before you know it, it's your turn again. Then you may have an epic 9 card combo with two buys and score a high VP card plus something else useful. Little direct interaction can mean little banter, but you do pay attention to what everyone else is doing, their card distros (as best you can) and charismatic players will always be able to amp things as there's plenty of opportunity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update:  I'll fess up that I've played over 500 games of Dominion online with a couple of friends.  A friend has purchased all available cards and we play with random decks.  I won't play anywhere other than online since setup is instantaneous and card rules are baked into the interface (no mistakes, no mulligans).  With experience the game has become much more cut-throat and also more varied as new approaches are regularly tried.  I really enjoy the challenge of the on-the-fly deck-building and deck-culling (if there are cards that allow it) to create snowballing combinations.  My rating is for online play.

8/14/2013:  [bgcolor=#9999FF][s][color=#9999FF]-[/color][/s][b]6[/b][s][color=#9999FF]-[/color][/s][/bgcolor] Too dang many cards to learn.  And my eyes no longer enjoy closely reading small print.  The interactions of the cards are also reminiscent of Magic the Gathering which kinda turns me off as I have totally burned out the MtG torch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Hate building a deck in front of my opponent.

[q]I don't like how it implements the theme. I mean, you pay gold to hire these heroes and they don't show up! You get a Militia man with three torches, and a sword he can't even lift. This is a fantasy game if Dilbert's pointy-haired boss invented it.[/q]

Thanks for the review of Thunderstone, Sam and Max.

However, with Dominion, there is ZERO theme here. Nothing. Nada. Zilch. Zippo. Nothing. It is the blandest of the bland. Blank cards would be a better game than this.

Then, just as you say in TS "they don't show up." In Dominion, they don't show up either. If You get gold and victory point cards only, you can only buy stuff and end your turn. most victory points wins.. What?


[b]You literally assemble a deck and the game ends... So, you built a deck to.. Build a deck??? You don't do anything with the completed deck?? What? I have a complete deck now and you want to count victory points?

WORST GAME EVER!!![/b]

RATING: 9.1
I have the "Black Market", "Envoy", and "Stash" promo cards.

A unique mechanic -- building a deck of cards but being only able to use 5 of them at a time. Good mix of strategy and some luck. A relatively quick game. The interaction aspect isn't huge, but the existence of attack cards makes others pay attention to your deck.

RATING: 3
Though Dominion introduced the idea of deckbuilding games, the vanilla set relies on that system alone, and as far as I know includes no cards that require you to acknowledge the other players. Though I may change my mind if I ever play using other sets, I feel that Dominion itself has a backbone, but no heart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As a former [i]Magic[/i] player, I love the combo-licious appeal of [i]Dominion[/i]. Not only are you looking at each hand to see what to make of it, but just as you make control, aggressive or combo decks in [i]Magic[/i], you can create a deck in [i]Dominion[/i] that has a particular playing style.

For the first few games, you’ll be buying willy-nilly, trying things out to see what happens when you draw card X, Y or Z, but with experience you get a sense for which cards work well together, which cards to buy when, what percentage of your deck should be Treasure and which kinds, when to transition into buying Victory cards, and so on. Cards that initially seem stupid, weak or useless become must buys in later games once you realize how powerful they can be in the right circumstances – a term which is shorthand for you being on the wrong end of a thrashing.

For my [url=http://www.boardgamenews.com/index.php/boardgamenews/comments/game_preview_review_dominion/]complete review[/url], which includes several thousand words on the game's design and development from designer Donald X. Vaccarino, head to Boardgame News. Full disclosure: I playtested [i]Dominion[/i] and received a copy of the game as payment. All games played have been face-to-face.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game. Captures the essence of a CCG without the collectibility. I LOVE CCGs but will not spend the money on them any longer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.46
Well lets get this straight, this is in nowhere the same league, hell not in the same universe as MTG. But neither is it probably meant to be. Bizarrely for a game with a gazillions different combinations the variety really isn't there as all the cards are of very similar ilk and do a limited number of the same things. Having said all of that its still a very good game and one I'm always happy to play just isn't the killer game it seems to be made out to be though fair kudos must be given for it inventing its own genre

Alone with just the base game it gets dull very quickly though so a few expansions are a must. I just wish all the expansions fit nicely into the game and expanded it rather than having little extra bits that kind of sit to the side without really 100% gelling with the whole

A flawed masterpiece

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
CCGish in ways that I dislike: fussing over exact deck proportions, finding power cards and perfect combos, and (thus) hyper-tuning a subset of an already small subset of cards. Also adds a new annoyance: crazy amounts of shuffling. And missing are some things I love about CCGs: highlander-ish making the best of bad sets, hand-management and in-play dilemmas (vs. all focus on deckbuilding), and the possibility of surprise. It really is like turning Asperger-esque Magic deck tuning into a competition.

So I should hate it, but I don't. I do wish all the above were different, but it's not fair to judge the game for what it isn't. What it is is a fairly solitaire-ish, front-loaded, programming exercise, with some hard choices around what to include and when to time the switch from building an engine to collecting points.

The base set is the worst. Several expansions open the game up more, and broader is better for this one.

Also, Big Money is annoying. Buying a couple of action cards + money is just too strong a default strategy. Even experts note that it has a non-trivial win rate, even against competent players. Also, each expansion has chipped away at BM, sometimes blatantly, which I really doubt is a coincidence (and is great for the game, but I do think it points to even the designer tacitly acknowledging that BM was a bit too strong out of the gate).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Dominion was my introduction to deck-building, one of my favorite mechanisms, but even the first time I felt something was lacking. Then I played a lot against the computer and now I tried it again IRL.
Here's why I never want to play it again IRL:
- Some cards just make it very fiddly and have a long downtime while offering no interesting choices.
- Deckbuilding provides escalation and fast gameplay. Dominion sometimes does that, but not reliably. (see next point)
- Random setup in theory means infinite replayabity, but in practice means lots of horrible or at least boring setups and most of the cards are pretty similar and the ones that aren't are usually incredibly fiddly or not efficient.
- While Dominion is strategic in terms of what's available to buy, it has an insane luck of the draw aspect. Lot of the cards only work well if drawn with other cards. At some setups if your starting 2 draws are 5 and 2 money, you essentially lose a turn, and you can easily lose the game because of this disadvantage.
- But in the end buying VP cards is just such a letdown. It's fundamentally uninteresting. The part of the game I like is pulling off combo chains, but that is insanely luck-dependant and sometimes isn't even as good as just buying money cards.
- It might seem like it, but you don't really have to have some kind of balance beetween engine building and buying points. At some point you just start buying points and that's it. It's not even really a dramatic or interesting choice when to start doing that, you just start when other players do, and you'll effectively see that way whose deck is better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There are some very interesting self-balancing game play elements that appeal, but the decisions are simple.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You are a monarch, that wants a bigger and more pleasant kingdom,  you want more, you want a Dominion! Each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can buy. 
When you use a card it goes back into your desc, so you have to construct  your deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to victory points by end game. You select 10 of the many card types to include in any given play, making each game very different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[i]Rating for the whole Dominion system:[/i]

If I were to limit my collection to just one game - this would be it. I can't express how much I love it. It's infinitely replayable, extremely addictive and you can tailor its complexity level to just about any type of player you happen to play with. 

I love the dynamic, fast-paced gameplay and the clean, elegant deck-building mechanism. Finding the perfect combination of cards and creating the most efficient deck is a fantastic puzzle, there's a whole world of strategies only waiting to be discovered. I could play Dominion all the time.

[i]I own the following expansions: Intrigue, Seaside, Prosperity, Cornucopia, Empires + promo cards: Envoy, Prince, Black Market, Sauna/Avanto, Governor, Walled Village.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shine has pretty much come off - it's a relaxing, "autopilot"-style game.  The ability to do deck-building in-game is deceptive - once you get past initial play,  it's probably better to plan your deck-building beforehand...so really heading back to offline deckbuilding.  Not a mechanic I'm enamoured with,  but I can't deny that it is an innovative design. Can sometimes go too long for what it is (in my mind it should be a 5-10 minute filler), especially when it ends 3 card stacks being empty.

Simple rules that leads to a quick strategic game.  Pretty straightforward increasing economy/switch to VPs mechanism.  Game can drag if you end up in a situation where getting 8 gold is tough/impossible,  and you have to exhaust piles.  The shuffling is only a bit annoying in real life,  although the setup before/sorting afterwards is a bit more annoying.  

It's a little irritating to play someone who's trying a similar strategy to your own (when they're buying the same cards as you) - starts to feel that luck of the draw is more important than skill.

Actually,  it feels a bit like tuning a computer program on the fly - those "battling robots" kinds of competitions,  but with the ability to add in parts as the competition goes on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.94
What I Love- 
meaningful choices, building efficiency, the feel of progression as you shape your deck into a well oiled machine. Quick play time. Big turns. Near infinite variety of kingdoms and replay value now that I own all sets and expansions.Simple to teach and play, but still strategic. Skill testing, manageable luck. 

What I Dislike- 
depending on the kingdom, some waiting on other players big turns. Getting buried in curses or ruins,(you almost always have to fight fire with fire in these cases). Limited ability to change strategies mid game.(but that's always your fault when it happens)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
To my mind, one of the essential modern tabletop games, and certainly the most ingenious response to CCGs. Burnout is real -- in midlevel play it's an analytically demanding game, and early/midgame plays can seem rote -- but you can play a hundred great games without repeating yourself, which is (1) great value for $$$ and (2) an impressive feat of design.

Bonus: For a time, Dominion was one of the only games that consistently brought our *entire* friend group to the table, not just the gents. Vital!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is the one that really got me into boardgaming as a hobby. I'd gone to Gencon for years playing collectible card games (WWE Raw Deal in particular, also a little L5R) but in 2009 I was looking for something new to refresh my faith in gaming. Dominion was it.

I had heard in hushed whispers about the game and every other vendor booth had sleeves FOR Dominion in particular so I decided to seek out a demo. Played it and bought it and Intrigue on the spot.

Since then other deck builders have come up through the ranks (Ascension in particular) and even though Dominion has lost a bit of its luster, I still respect it for what it is: Solid game with an innovative mechanic that I can easily teach and enjoy playing for hours. Great game.

RATING: 5
This game is not a good as some people say it is! The reason being that you collect cards to build your deck, but you don't feel that you're building a city/ civilization, which I believe is the theme here? The theme is not coming through for me. I feel like I'm collection cards with a goal, to win, I'm not collect card to have a great city or civilization.
There are much better deck builders out there! 
But all in all this is a fine light game, I think it would be great for new board gamers just to understand the deck building mechanic.

RATING: 7.5

Turns are quick and the game doesn't take too too long, which is a big plus.  And the large number of Action cards to mix and match makes for a different experience each game.  I haven't played the expansions, but I can see how they would really add to this game.  I do feel it can get a little old after repeated play, but it's great for new gamers and a good one to pull out if you're short on time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Build a kingdom by building a deck of cards.  This game is entirely a card game, where players all start with a weak identical little deck of 10 cards and try to build it into the best deck, Cards to buy include victory point cards, money cards, and action cards.  Some action cards attack other players or steal from time, but most just give bonuses during a players turn.  The neat feature is that victory point cards give no benefit during the game, only at the end, so picking them up early is actually to a player's disadvantage. Great game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I have not played many recent games, but Dominion is by far my favourite.  Can't recommend enough.  I like this game better every time I play it.  Well integrated theme, re-playability, fast pace, easy to teach, great artwork, expansions, storage system integrated into the packaging, custom community rules...  This game has it all.  It's at the point now where I really don't even want to play other games.

I can't wait to play 8 players when intrigue comes out.  I'm just way too excited about that expansion.  I'm also waiting anxiously for my Black Market and Envoy cards to arrive in the mail.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Dominion is an undeniably clever card game in which players use action (“kingdom”) and money (“treasure”) cards to buy additional action cards, additional money cards, and victory point cards.  The basic idea is that newly purchased action/money/VP cards are eventually re-shuffled back into the deck; as a result, each player’s deck steadily increases in size and becomes increasingly more powerful. When the game ends, the winner is the player who has the greatest sum total of VP cards in his/her deck.

Innovations notwithstanding, my rating of Dominion is uncharitably low due to (1) the game’s reliance on a criminally insane amount of card shuffling, (2) the extremely minor extent to which players can exert any direct influence over other players’ strategies/actions, and (3) the chaotic, indiscriminate nature of the few direct-interaction cards that exist in the game. (Caveat: I haven’t seen the entire span of Dominion's game cards.)

Regardless, gamers who enjoy "parallel play" efficiency/engine games (Agricola, Race for the Galaxy) will find a lot to like in Dominion.  I have no doubt that many people will enjoy playing Dominion countless times.  For me, a couple of times was enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a great design. You have to build your hand from the available cards on the table. First you try to increase your deck and later try to switch from building the deck to adding victory points. With 25 decks to start with and only using 10 per game there is a lot of replay here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Had you asked me to rate this in 2010, I would have given it a 10.  This was my gateway drug and the reason why I'm into hobby board gaming today.  It taught me that one person could spend 40 bucks and play a card game with up to four people an infinite number of times, and have as much fun, if not more, than if that same  person had dumped their life savings into an ever-expanding CCG. Its deck building concept was novel then, and still holds up to this day.

The only reason I rate this a 8 these days is because I'm not always in the mood to play it.  I've expanded my horizons, and while Dominion still holds up and deserves a steady place on the shelf as a classic, I have moved on to graze in other pastures.  I will say this:  I have yet to encounter a mechanically better deck-builder.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
https://www.playdominion.com/

Deckbuilding is a really interesting idea, but it feels a little pointless in this game I guess. You get cards that let you use more cards that let you draw more cards that let you use more cards (repeat a thousand times) then reshuffle every 30 seconds. Well... it felt too mechanical for me.

As a former MTG player, I miss creatures, combat and spells. Plus the fact that your only objective in the game is to put a lot of useless cards in your deck makes this game the opposite of fun for me.

If I ever want to play a deckbuilding game, I'll be happy to play Ascension or even Friday... Not Dominion.

PS: Ohhh, and for the love of god, WTF is wrong with the art of the back of the cards? Geez that's probably the worse card back art I've ever seen!

RATING: 9
Definitely in love with this game! I love the variation in setups that are possible and even created my own setup-generation app for Android specifically for this game (even though there are others out there).

This box has basic cards but creates a firm base to work from and to learn the game. The game is not hard to learn, but there is a noticeable skill disparity between those that have played this game a lot and those that have not. People with experience in this game can regularly crush new player without breaking a sweat.

The game has almost no direct player interaction, except for the occasional attack card or what not. I have not problems with that, but I know people who don't like playing 'multiplayer solitair', as they would describe it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Deckbuilding is a fine idea, and I suspect the success of Dominion has more to do with this process as opposed to enthusiasm for a game that actually works. The static board is a huge problem; all the combinations and possibilities don't mean anything when there's a best strategy on the table and it's available to everyone. When you purchase Chapel and pass the turn, the next guy has exactly the same options; nothing has actually changed about the board. And if players are pretty much in agreement on the best strategy, turns tend to look very much alike. With any given pool of ten cards, once you determine the optimum build, players start the same and have the same options so is it any wonder they all do the same thing? Thus, turn order and luck of the draw becomes integral to winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first of the deckbuilding games, and I love it. Great introduction game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I don't know about this game. I like the idea, love the concept, but somehow it doesn't click with me like with others. There are a few problems with it:
1) Setup: isn't in 5 minutes 
2) Game flow: beginning goes quick, then usually becomes a drag because the game takes too long and it lacks some sort of climax at the end. It just ends, player count their points, the end.
3) It feels a bit linear to me. It suggests to be a simple game with loads of depth and variation once you play it, but it isn't. It's exactly what it is. Combo's and interaction are limited and not very interesting.

Played it quite a few times now with 3 people. I did get to like it more, but it doesn't get nowhere near the level it is on BGG :)

So i guess this is not my kind of game. Still ok and somewhat interesting to play though.

RATING: 7
One of the originals of the deck-building genre and one the original games in my collection that I have played to death. The variety, quickness of play, and the ability to interact with other players or play your own game makes this a lot of fun. While I wouldn't say that I have a strong desire to pull this game out all of the time, its not a game that I would necessarily turn down either.

Not that an expansion is necessary given the potential combinations that come in the base game, I could see myself buying an expansion down the road just to add a little more life back in to the game. I could also see this being a potentially fun family game when the kids get older as well.

As it currently stands, and the fact that my wife also really enjoys this, it is a great game and one that I'll hold on to for the foreseeable future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game have a lot of things I love, constructing decks, different strategies to win, victory points, limited interaction with other players, and, of course, the most important reason, everyone have the same cards. It's not the more you pay the more you win, like Magic the Gathering, here it's only your own ability to make a winning deck. In this game you have also the luck, like in Magic, but it's a more limited factor. And you don't need to buy the expansions if you have the basic game. The not so good aspect of the game are the irregular illustrations, some are good and another ones are creepy and horrible. 

Este juego tiene un montón de cosas que adoro, construir mazos, diferentes estrategias para ganar, puntos de victoria, interacción limitada con otros jugadores, y, por supuesto, la razón más importante, todo el mundo tiene las mismas cartas. No es eso de que cuanto más te gastas más ganas, como en Magic el encuentro, aquí sólo cuenta tu propia habilidad para hacer un mazo ganador. En este juego también entra la suerte, pero es un factor más limitado que en Magic. Y no necesitas comprarte las expansiones si tienes el básico. Lo malo del juego son las irregulares ilustraciones, que van de las buenas a las más horribles y extrañas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first of the deck building games. Terrific concept, loved it at first play. 

Each player starts with the same 10 cards and from that must build a victory point machine. There are 10 different cards as well as higher denominations of coins and three levels of victory points. You use the coins in your starting hand (initially all low value) to buy higher valued denominations of coins, victory points or cards from the center. Those extra cards give you extra buy actions, extra options to play cards or draw cards thus allowing you to do more during your turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Very impressed after first several games. Making the meta-game of deck-building into the game experience itself is both novel and incredibly compelling. So far all the games have been very close (if not score-wise, then turn-wise, such as "with one more turn, I could have done XXX for the win!").

RATING: 9
Medieval strategy game without the board, cubes or knight pieces. Card driven deck building game, very clever and a lot of variety, use to he card randomiser to make sure no two games the same-great value for money in my opinion.
If you love Magic the Gathering or Pokemon the game play should be second nature to you. Its a must have in any collection, I never get bored of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I found the base set was great at its time of release, a very innovative, and exciting game, even approachable as a family game with casual players. That quickly went out the window with each expansion adding more to the game, but still leaving it a mechanical, and strictly theme-less game. Now there are so many extra boards, of various sizes, and shapes, along with a variety of silly tokens. The graphic design, and art direction has always been poor: the logo is horrible, the card back doubly so, the art style is so divergent from card to card that it ruins any attempt at a theme, and it features an overall just boring look. The gameplay feels bland, very mechanical, like a test of concept, and not a finished product. It has definitely been surpassed by many newer games since, where deckbuilding is used in more thematic ways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's Dominion... not super grounded in theme, but it's the original deckbuilder.  Fabulous mechanics and tons of variety when (like I have) you invest in lots of the expansions.   It's not always the best for player interaction, but I think it's not as solitaire an experience as many people claim.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]BREATHTAKING![/b]

Superior to Race for the Galaxy or any other deck churning, engine building game I can think of. Amazingly good.

Would rate this game a "10" if there was more player interaction. That said, I'm not overly happy with the interaction there is at present. I certainly don't enjoy the game as much when the set-up includes "screw you" cards, and no Moats or moat-clones "counterspells" to deny that bitch-slap strategy. What I mean to say, is that I like cards that poke your friends in the eye, ONLY if their is a counter tactic available, and not just one that optimises your own deck hoping not to get walloped.

If the trend for this in our games continues, may rating will plummet.

UPDATE: Dominion has earned its place in the throne-room. Played with alarming regularity at our gaming meets.

[i]Dominion will be remembered as the Father of the greatest card game ever designed. Whatever that game may turn out to be![/i]

RATING: 8.5
This is a great, basic card deck building game where one accumulates coins (treasures) and actions. You can rush people by starting the race for points or for longer games really develop your deck. This is a great 2 player game. That said, it can play well 3-4 people as well. A good starter for anyone interested in card deck building games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Playtest (provisional) rating: My recommendation is to avoid the hype unless you are keen on being underwhelmed by this at first.  Game has a subtle depth if you are willing to allow the time to explore all that it has to offer.  I enjoyed my plays thus far, but do have some reservation in terms of its polish and the interaction between some of the cards.

Update #1: Raised my initial score by 0.5.  There have been some real nice combinations that I've tried which really make the game a lot more interesting.  There are still a handful of cards which seem to be lacking.  Plays quick, even faster than Race for the Galaxy and that is definitely not a bad thing.  Setup and tear down is a pain though.

Update #2: Due to the specific cards involved in the last couple of sessions, the gameplay has evolved from racking up as many points as possible to giving out as many negative ones and ending the game soon after.  I've found this dynamic to be a lot more fun and if Dominion continues to allow different objectives to win, I think it will be an even greater success.

Update #3: Honestly, I just don't have any real desire to play Dominion these days.  Keeping track of all of the actions and buys you've accumulated each time is such a burdensome task to do.  I also don't find it enjoyable to try to determine the ultimate card combo.  Much like how Magic over the time devolved into merely a deckbuilding exercise instead of playing the game for fun.  Except it took Dominion less than a year to become a bore for me to participate in.  The only good thing I can say is that it's relatively easy to pick back up, so the familiarity is still there, for the moment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played the prototype at Origins.  Pretty non-existent in the player interaction department, but still some interesting things going on.  I think people are so enamoured with Dominion because it's unlike anything currently out there.  But why not just play a dead CCG?  Then you can do all the deckbuilding you want without it actually being the main mechanic of the game.  All the shuffling gets annoying, too.  I'm not sure it's worth the effort... UPDATE: Played 2 more times, once with a different setup.  I like it now better than after my first play, but this is still not a top tier game for me (unless there are cards I haven't seen which make the actual gameplay a whole lot more interesting than what's there now).  Update #2: The more I play it (especially with random setups) the more I like it.  It's addictive and multiple games in a row can be common (especially playing it on BSW...in fact, I prefer playing it there, as it eliminates setup and shuffling ;)).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dominion is... not terrible. I think, by this point, this game is one of those deck builders where it founded the genre, but has been slightly left behind for other deck builders with more notable mechanics. Look at games like Eminent Domain and the Alien and Predator deck building games! Look at Friday! Each of these games presents something fresh and interesting to the genre, and lasting. Dominion just sort of feels old at this point, a lot like Magic. Yeah, it founded the genre but I feel at this point, it's been done and done again, and done better elsewhere. It's not terrible, but just not terribly exciting.

RATING: 9.75
Great game.  I know that there are better deck-builder games out there.  But this one just has a great level of simplicity that makes for a very enjoyable game. Best with 2 or 3 players though... with 4 you can sometimes feel like there is too much down time (with certain players who can't decide on their card purchases...).  the .25 I took off a perfect score was due to the lack of interactivity between players in the base game.  But, similar to other LCGs, [some of] the expansions add some fun interactions that fix the lack of interaction.  To a point.  
Like playing a great game of solitaire.  But against people who can screw you over :)

RATING: 8.5
When it was a prototype under playtesting and development:  Can't say too much yet, but constructing a deck for maximal efficiency as you play is challenging and addicting.  It's easy to find yourself playing this several times in a row.

Now:  This game provides interesting choices and balance as you build a CCG-style deck on the fly, with victory points acting as dead weight in the deck.  Brilliant!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I was browsing for new games and found that year's Spiel des Jahres which happened to be Keltis.
Reading descriptions and reviews on Amazon I quickly figured I didn't like it. But one review hinted towards Dominion being a far better game.
I got it and was fascinated while reading the rule book. The deck-drafting mechanic was a great idea (you can see it counting new games that have implemented it).
What should I say? I've never had any issues in 3+ players games. There might be balance problems but all cards are available to all players.
1vs1 was a bit too much on the luck-reliant side for my taste.
The game is not perfect (low player interaction) but it sure is fun.

In addition, the box is awesome: It can hold all sets of cards individually and they won't mingle with each other even when turning the box upside-down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
So, after one play, I think I know why a lot of first games take so long.  Both my wife and I had no cohesive strategy, so we were just buying whichever cards sounded good.  I think planning ahead on how you are going to create your deck will help eliminate a lot of the extra cards that don't really help.  This in turn will help you buy more valuable cards quicker as you can actually have a hand with a decent amount of money.

Update:  I've played this a few times with my buddies at work and am undefeated so far.  :)  I really enjoy picking a strategy and running with it.  Of course, I'm always tempted to deviate as we play...

A couple things that annoy me:  The spare cards need to have a background that is easier to pick out from the rest of the cards.  Why are there spare VP cards?  The treasure cards need to be colored differently (i.e. Gold, Silver, and Bronze).

Update: Taught this to the in-laws and it has quickly become a favorite.  While it took me this long to figure out some good basic strategies, My mother-in-law has picked it right up.  I think that is one of the appealing things to me.  It is easy to pick up, but you can really dig into it.

Update:  Playing with the Witch especially is not a good idea with people who don't like nastiness.

SDJ-2009

DSP-2009

GG: Game of the Year-2009

GG: Best Card Game-2009

MC-2008

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent concept and totally absorbing when played on the PC. Bought the base set because of that, but the real thing played on a table hasn't satisfied me nor any other friend I've played with: too strategy without game (most decisions should be taken once the kingdom is decided) and too "solitaire" (doesn't benefit much from having your opponents in front of you).

I may have a problem with deckbuilding games in general, as I don't actually enjoy building my deck as much as I enjoy building a tableau, for instance... probably it's because I can't visualize well the evolution in the state of play with dbgs (cards are drawn, used, and discarded).

Update: after trying Nightfall now I know that my problem is not with deckbuilding, but with games that only offer deckbuilding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Nehéz a pontozás. Egyáltalán nem volt rossz, de vhogy nem az én világom. Lehet, h fogok még vele játszani, hiszen gyors és pörgős, kellőképp izgalmas is, de nekem ez a deckbuilding nem az esetem, még ilyen kezdő szinten sem. Ettől függetlenül megértem az iránta való rajongást.
---
Melóban nyomtam vagy online 20 partit egyik délután és teljesen rákattantam. Emelek is egy fél pontot rajta :D
5 -> 5.5
---
Vicces, újabb 30 online parti után konkrétan ott tartok, hogy rá akarom beszélni a feleségem a megvételre.
5.5 -> 6.5
---
Na, megkaptuk kölcsönbe, így asszonyt is be tudtam vezetni a játékba. Ennek örömére meg is vesszük hamarosan. ;)
6.5 -> 7.5
---
Megvettük, hálistennek rákattant ő is. :D
---

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After 20+ Plays: After my first play, I was in love with this game and had to have it right away.  After about 20 games, though, my love has begun to wane.  The games are feeling a little same-ish, despite the variability of the setup.  It seems that though there are ten cards, the best style of deck is determined by the best couple of cards available, so there are actually fewer significantly different combinations of cards.

My other problem is that while building your deck is fun and gives you several strategic options, there seems to be a real void of tactical decisions.  While you to decide what to buy, the actual functioning of the deck is generally obvious and follows the same script.  This is probably why it is a good gateway into ccg type games, but it lacks the depth of games like Race for the Galaxy, which offer multiple strategic paths as well and interesting, and often agonizing, tactical decisions. 

After 50+ Plays: I think the expansions really improve this game.  More than the diversity of set-ups they make possible, the cards are just more interesting.  There are fewer set-ups that can be beaten by a simple silver then gold then province buy progression, there are more incentives to diversify your deck, and there are more interesting decisions to be made during the rest of your turn.  I'm keeping my rating for the base set at 6, but my rating for the game system as a whole would be about an 8. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
POSSIBLY BEST COMPETITIVE BOARD GAME OF ALL TIME. OK, maybe not really. But, maybe. 

Can be tough for new people to play with experienced players if the experienced people are like, in it to win it. Competition can be ruthless. 

However, also easy to learn and super fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dominion is a fun card drafting/ deck and hand management game. 
It has a solid 6 for the time being as it is sorely out classed by newer games. 
The open market card pools lead to samey decks from everyone at the table and can lead to snow balling for whoever calmed the optimal strategy first.
the reliance on +action +buy and draw cards in this game is harsh, leading to some long games with bloated decks no matter what you do. 

All in all there are cards that are musts from the base set so it still gets its score but many of its cards are out classed in the expansions.

chances are that you have a friend who has most of this game and you'll need at least 2 more people to play so I would advise against buying any of the sets and going for a cheaper more fulfilling drafting game like Star Realms.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.7
When it comes to Dominion, I had never played a deckbuilding game before. I had my doubts, and couldn't find myself enjoying a card game. Dominion erased all doubt after the first play. I didn't play once that night, I played three times. It's a blast. Every decision is rewarding but strategy is deep, as well. There are multiple ways to win, but as the games goes on, there is a time where you better adjust or make it work. What a fantastic mechanic. The theme gets better the more you play and understand the game, as well.

RATING: 7
An interesting card game that seems like it would feel very limiting (only 10 different action cards?) but plays out nicely. It has a quick rhythm to it.

What keeps it from a higher score: The game has massive amounts of shuffling and has a tendency to draw out.

Own the Intrigue, Seaside, Alchemy, Prosperity expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The grand-daddy of deck building games. Players start with a small deck of currency and must buy cards from the central supply to add to their deck. Cards include Actions, which do stuff, Treasures, which buy stuff, and Victory cards, which are useless apart from their points at the end of the game. Hundreds of cards available across the expansions, easy to learn with an ocean of depth and nuance.

Theme: Medieval/low-fantasy 
Mechanic: Deck building
Ideal players: 2-3
Length: Medium

RATING: 8.5
I really like Dominion and it's expansions.  It's easy to teach and is fast enough to get several more games in once everyone understands what is going on.  Random setup seems to be the most fun as you never know what combos are going to hit the table.  It also means that each set will have a different flow and tempo, making each game feel unique.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game doesn't have any staying power with me, unfortunately.    

The people who introduced it to me had 100+ games of Dominion under their belt, and I lost by only one point in the first game, and thoroughly beat them in the second.  That never happens with me, as my win:lose ratio is usually fairly evenly split, or on the side of losing.  I believe it's because I quickly picked up on the probability manipulation intrinsic to deck-building, and, without any more to the game, I found that that was all there was to it.  Thus, since I *do* like the deck-building mechanic, I've found that Thunderstone: Advance (and retroactively adding the earlier expansions) is a much better fit for me.  There's more to do, and I enjoy the dungeon-delving adventure.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
DBG卡牌构筑类游戏的鼻祖了，上市多年扩充不断，如今依然像个常青树，fans数量也节节高升。撇开各种扩充，就基础游戏来说卡牌内容设计非常简洁明了，洗牌，抽牌，一个行动，一个购买，计算金币量买新卡牌，这些几乎就是游戏的全部了。游戏中行动牌构成了游戏的灵魂，每次游戏随机的十张行动牌（目前所有扩加起来达上百种）可以将游戏变换成N多种不同体验，不管是桌游新手还是老手，都能乐在其中，耐玩性没得说。。。
【关键词】洗牌，抽牌，诅咒，金币，行动，进攻/防御，无穷的扩充性，不同的卡牌组合，毫无他用的分数牌

【推荐度】极高 【DBG始祖，轻中度德式爱好者

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As already-mentioned in the Ascension comments box, I have very limited play experience with Dominion, but right from the get-go, I was kind of fascinated and disgusted by some of the possibilities the kingdom card assortments can offer... 

Some of the cards seem like almost "auto-includes", and once everyone's decks become pretty tuned, turns seem to go on forever with all the card drawing/replacing/manipulation and multiple actions.

I still think I will enjoy playing the game several times, since it should take many games before even the most basic combinations and strategies become too obvious and the game starts feeling like auto-piloting your way to victory (or a very cool version of solitaire)...

EDIT:
Having played it quite a bit more, I've come to the conclusion that it's basically a solitaire game where you compete against other players' scores. Basically no interaction whatsover, symmetric decks, unbalanced cards...

The concept is amazing, I just think there are better deckbuilding games out there, now.
